401 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York Public Interest Research Group, Inc. v. Steingut


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


40 N.Y.2d 250; 353 N.E.2d 558; 386 N.Y.S.2d 646; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2883


June 2, 1976, Argued  
June 17, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department, New York, affirmed an order and judgment that declared 1975 N.Y. Laws 460 unconstitutional, requiring respondent lawmakers to make restitution of allowances and to pay plaintiff public interest group in a declaratory judgment action. Parties on both sides appealed.


OVERVIEW: A special interest group brought suit against the New York Senate, Assembly, and Comptroller, alleging that the enactment of 1975 N.Y. Laws 460 was unconstitutional. The court found that the new law provided lawmakers who performed additional services an increased allowance. The court held that N.Y. Const. art. III, § 6 prohibited the lawmakers from increasing an allowance during the term for which the officers were elected. The court found that the legislature, after the expiration of the express exception, continued regularly to alter allowances through annual appropriations and was a clear and explicit constitutional prohibition. The court held that lawmakers did not have to make restitution of money already received because they had a long-standing practice of passing such increases and had done so in good faith.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment and then affirmed it. The modifications eliminated the payment of attorneys' fees to the special interest group and rescinded the order that lawmakers make restitution of allowances that were already received.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional law -- legislative allowances -- allowances to members of Legislature for particular and additional services under chapter 460 of Laws of 1975 are proper under section 6 of article III of State Constitution to extent that they do not exceed amounts "fixed by law" in prior term of Legislature, and, although prior appropriation had expired as predicate for claim on public funds, it set effective level for allowances, which may not be increased or decreased; accordingly, current practice of providing allowances by annual appropriation without prospective general law is constitutional, if allowances are maintaned at prior effective level, in view of judicial respect for distribution of governmental powers, restraint in intervention in internal legislative affairs and great weight which must be given to Legislature's contemporaneous construction of constitutional provision -- to extent that allowances exceed 1974 appropriations for like offices or are for offices for which there was no 1974 appropriation, they are unconstitutional -- comparison should not be only between total, gross annual appropriations, since changes in individual allowances would then be permitted, with accompanying possibility of misuse to influence legislative action -- payments of unauthorized allowances should not be restored by reimbursement or withholding, since funds were not for unconstitutional purpose and fairness and justice mandate no reimbursement from those who relied on payment in good faith -- there should be no award of attorney fees from fund established under section 123-g of State Finance Law; such awards may only be made from that fund and it has not been shown that such fund in fact exists or contains any money; in any event, such allowance is discretionary.

1. Allowances to members of the Legislature for particular and additional services under chapter 460 of the Laws of 1975 are proper under section 6 of article III of the State Constitution to the extent that the amounts thereof do not exceed the amounts "fixed by law" for such allowances in a prior term of the Legislature, and, notwithstanding that allowances have been annually appropriated and paid, thereupon expiring as a predicate for a claim against public funds, they retain a continuing vitality as establishing a level of appropriation for a particular office, which may not be increased or decreased. Every legislative enactment is deemed constitutional until the contrary is shown, and the courts should show respect for the distribution of governmental powers and restraint in intervening in internal legislative affairs. The constitutional restrictions were intended to forestall vote manipulation through financial coercion and to avoid conflicts of interest by removing the authority from legislators to vote themselves financial benefits. After the constitutional enactment, the Legislature continued its prior practice of granting allowances through annual appropriations, and great weight must be given to such contemporaneous construction. Accordingly, the Legislature may constitutionally provide current allowances by annual appropriation without a prospective general law, as is its present practice, if such allowances are maintained at prior effective levels.

2. To the extent that the allowances provided in chapter 460 of the Laws of 1975 exceed 1974 appropriations for like offices or are for offices for which there was no 1974 appropriation, they are unconstitutional, and such violation cannot be validated by the regular annual alteration of allowances in the past.

3. The Legislature must attend to the correlations between allowances in different years free from judicial interference, but the public good and the prohibition against alterations preclude comparison between total, gross appropriations only, since changes in individual allowances would then be permitted, with an accompanying possibility of misuse to influence legislative action.

4. Payments of those allowances which were unauthorized should not be restored either by reimbursement or withholding, since the funds were not for an unconstitutional purpose, but were merely improperly authorized, and fairness and justice mandate that no reimbursement be demanded from those who relied in good faith, supported by long practice, upon such disbursements.

5. There should be no award of attorney fees from the fund established under section 123-g of the State Finance Law for citizen-taxpayer actions; such awards may only be made from that fund and it has not been shown that such fund in fact exists or contains any money; in any event, such allowance is discretionary.

 

402 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Abrahams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


40 N.Y.2d 277; 353 N.E.2d 574; 386 N.Y.S.2d 661; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2887


March 31, 1976, Argued  
June 17, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed and the information dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Informations charging defendants with violations of the Sabbath Laws, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law §§ 2-12, were dismissed. The Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) reversed the order that dismissed the informations and reinstated the informations. One defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was an employee in a local pharmacy that was charged with Sabbath breaking for selling a ceramic bank. The merchandise was not specifically exempted from N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 9. Sections 9 and 12 dealt with the prohibition against public sales and forfeiture. The court dismissed the information and held that both sections were constitutionally defective. The court held that the collection of exceptions created to the Sunday sales under § 9 ranged from thoroughbreds to soda water. The court held that the large amount of exceptions created to § 9 obliterated any nexus between it and the purpose of the Sabbath Laws. The court held that the proper solution was to declare all of § 9 unconstitutional because, if only the offending exceptions were declared void, the general closing mandate would still have remained. The court held that § 12, the forfeiture provision, was unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The order reinstating the information against defendant was reversed, and the information was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sunday Sales Law -- irrationality -- vagueness -- prohibitions against public sales on Sunday (General Business Law, § 9) are unconstitutional, since many exceptions thereto have eliminated rational nexus with statutory purpose and, although judiciary must defer to enactments rationally related to intended purpose, statute encompassing haphazard exceptions unconnected to such purpose cannot be condoned -- entire section should be invalidated, since voiding of exceptions alone would cause general closing mandate to remain and court should not assume legislative function of choosing those exceptions which are proper -- forfeiture provisions regarding goods illegally offered for sale (General Business Law, § 12) are unconstitutionally vague; proceeds of sales of goods forfeited are payable to nonexistent "overseers of the poor" and recipients thereof are unspecified.

1. The prohibitions against public sales on Sunday provided in section 9 of the General Business Law are unconstitutional, since the many exceptions thereto have eliminated any rational nexus between the statute and its purpose. Although arbitrary distinctions may be part of a rational pattern and the judiciary must defer to enactments rationally related to the intended purpose, a statute encompassing haphazard and anachronistic exceptions unconnected to such purpose cannot be condoned. Section 9 contains exceptions devoid of reason and erosive of respect for the law.

2. The exceptions may not alone be declared unconstitutional, since the general closing mandate would remain, and the court should not assume the legislative function of selecting those exceptions which are proper. Accordingly, the entire section should be invalidated.

3. The forfeiture provisions of section 12 of the General Business Law, applying to foods illegally offered for sale, are unconstitutionally vague. While the proceeds of sales of forfeited goods are to be paid to the "overseers of the poor", no municipality appears to have such an office, and how the recipients would be selected is not specified in the statute.

4. Accordingly, the information charging defendant pharmacy employee with sale of a ceramic bank should be dismissed.

 

403 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Brown


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


40 N.Y.2d 381; 353 N.E.2d 811; 386 N.Y.S.2d 848; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2897


May 6, 1976, Argued  
June 17, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) which dismissed an appeal from an order granting defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged in a one-count indictment of bribery. At the conclusion of the People's case in chief, defendant moved for a trial order of dismissal on the ground that a prima facie case of his guilt of bribery had not been made. He argued that the People failed to sufficiently prove an element of the crime. The court granted his motion and entered a trial order of dismissal. The People appealed to the intermediate court, and it unanimously dismissed the appeal. The appellate court affirmed the order of the intermediate court. Relying on a recent trilogy of U.S. Supreme Court cases, the court concluded that the double jeopardy clause precluded the People from appealing a trial court's order dismissing an indictment where retrial of defendant, or indeed any supplemental fact finding, might result from appellate reversal of the order sought to be appealed.


OUTCOME: The order of the Appellate Division, which dismissed the People's appeal of an order granting defendant's motion to dismiss an indictment, was affirmed because double jeopardy precluded the People from appealing a trial court's order dismissing an indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- former jeopardy -- trial order of dismissal -- where, at conclusion of People's case-in-chief on indictment charging crime of bribery, court granted defendant's motion to dismiss indictment on ground that prima facie case had not been made out, People may not appeal; CPL 450.20 (subd 2), which provides that People may appeal trial order of dismissal entered pursuant to CPL 290.10, is unconstitutional as violative of right not to be placed twice in jeopardy for same offense if further proceedings of some sort devoted to resolution of factual issues going to elements of offense charged would have been required upon reversal and remand.

Where, at the conclusion of the People's case-in-chief on an indictment charging the crime of bribery, the trial court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that a prima facie case had not been made out, the People may not appeal from the trial order of dismissal. CPL 450.20 (subd 2), which provides that the People may appeal such an order entered pursuant to CPL 290.10, is unconstitutional as violative of the right not to be placed twice in jeopardy for the same offense (NY Const, art I, § 6; US Const, 5th Amdt) if further proceedings of some sort devoted to the resolution of factual issues going to the elements of the offense charged would have been required upon reversal and remand. Supreme Court cases in United States v Wilson (420 U.S. 332), United States v Jenkins (420 U.S. 358) and Serfass v United States (420 U.S. 377) mandate this result, and the holding to the contrary in People v Fellman (35 NY2d 158) is overruled. The Supreme Court has held that under the Federal double joepardy clause only where there has been a jury verdict of guilty or findings by the court in a nonjury trial to support a verdict of guilty, but the trial court in either case then finds in the defendant's favor on a question of law, will appeal be permitted. In such case the double joepardy clause does not bar an appeal because errors of law may be corrected and the guilty verdict reinstated without another trial.

 

404 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Tenants' Union of West Side, Inc. v. Beame


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


40 N.Y.2d 133; 351 N.E.2d 731; 386 N.Y.S.2d 83; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2790


April 29, 1976, Argued  
June 15, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, tenants and organizations representing tenants of accommodations subject to rent control, appealed a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), dismissing a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding against respondents, Mayor of New York and city rent agency, relating to the Rent and Rehabilitation Law of the City of New York, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § Y51-5.0(a)(3), (4).


OVERVIEW: Petitioners complained that the city rent agency was doing a poor job of issuing Maximum Base Rent (MBR) orders that controlled just how much landlords could increase the rents in rent-controlled units. In affirming the judgment the court acknowledged that the Rent Control Law was inadequate, that the rental housing situation in the city was in desperate straits, and so held that under the circumstances the respondents were in substantial compliance with the law. Respondents were entitled to resort to statistical averaging in lieu of the individual determinations required by § Y51-5.0(a)(3). And the city rent agency actually did not have to audit the books that § Y51-5.0(a)(4) required the landlords to submit for inspection - it lacked the resources to do so in any event. Finally, the delegation of the actual calculation of the new "average" MBR and the corresponding rent increase to the landlords was not impermissible, because this was a ministerial task.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that dismissed the petitioners' proceeding against the mayor and the city rent agency.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and tenant -- rent regulation -- use by New York City rent agency of average experience of small fraction of buildings involved to arrive at 8 1/2% standardized increase factor as determinant of percentage by which all Maximum Base Rents (MBR) were to be increased was proper; while statute requires building-by-building basis, judicial intervention will be withheld against substitution of average in face of hopelessly bogged-down system -- petitioners have not carried burden of showing that average fell short of accepted standards -- statutory provision that rent agency require each owner to make available its books for audit does not require that agency make such audit; exercise of right to audit is matter of administrative discretion -- procedure under which actual calculation of average MBR and corresponding rent increase is left to landlords is not impermissible delegation of power.

1. The use by the New York City rent agency of the average experience of a small fraction of the approximately 74,000 buildings involved to arrive at an 8 1/2% standardized increase factor as the determinant of the percentage by which all Maximum Base Rents (MBR) were to be increased was proper. While the statute (Administrative Code, § Y51-5.0, subd a, par [3]) appears to require that the computation must be made on a building-by-building basis, judicial intervention will be withheld against the substitution of the statistical average to avoid a disaster for the people of the city whether landlords or tenants. The rent agency is hopelessly bogged down and it might be years before the statutorily required MBR adjustments to economic change could be put into effect.

2. The sampling techniques and statistical methods by which the average was obtained must be sound, fair, representative and designed to produce an accurate result, and petitioners, tenants and organizations representing tenants, have not carried the burden of showing that the average fell short of those standards. It cannot be said that there was a violation of equal protection because the average was not used in the 9,000 cases already individually computed.

3. The provision in the city Rent Control Law (§ Y51-5.0, subd a, par [4]) that the rent agency require each owner to make available its books for audit at least once every three years does not require, as a precondition to the issuance of an MBR, that the agency make the audit. The extent to which it exercises the right to audit is a matter of administrative discretion.

4. The agency's procedure under which the actual calculation of the average MBR and the corresponding rent increase is left to the landlords does not constitute an impermissible delegation of power and a violation of the tenants' due process rights. Although the delegation leaves much to be desired as an administrative device, no statute or regulation forbids it. Furthermore, the landlords' functions are sufficiently ministerial so that it cannot be said that the delegation was unconstitutional.

 

405 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Jewish Reconstructionist Synagogue, Inc. v. Roslyn Harbor


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


40 N.Y.2d 158; 352 N.E.2d 115; 386 N.Y.S.2d 198; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2822


March 25, 1976, Argued  
June 15, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff religious corporation and defendants, a village and its board of zoning appeals, appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), affirming the trial court's order, which declared the village's zoning ordinance invalid only to the extent it required a variance applicant to pay the board's legal fees and the cost of transcribing minutes of hearings before the board.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance required an applicant for a variance, other than a variance in connection with a single-family residence, to pay the actual costs incurred by the board of zoning appeals in passing on the matter. There were no limits set on these costs. The court held the lower courts had properly struck down those provisions of the ordinance relating to the board's legal fees and the costs of transcription. N.Y. Village Law § 7-712(1), under which villages set up boards of zoning appeals, did not specify how their expenses were to be paid. While the power to enact fees could be implied, the fees charged were required to be reasonably necessary to the accomplishment of the statutory command. The charges for the necessary engineering and inspection reports and the costs of publishing the statutory notice were not in excess of what was necessary in order to carry out the statutory mandate. Such charges were fairly uniform and predictable. However, the charges for legal fees and for transcribing the record of the proceedings did not represent necessary expenditures, but rather conveniences to the board. Further, such fees were not limited or assessed in reference to other similar cases.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- zoning -- costs of board of zoning appeals -- defendant village could not, pursuant to local ordinance, require applicants for variances and special use permits to pay costs of legal fees, meeting hall rentals and costs of transcription and copying of minutes incurred by board of zoning appeals, and levy of such charges against plaintiff was properly disallowed; delegation of power to localitites is impliedly limited to enactment of provisions reasonably necessary, such that fees should be based upon average costs to prevent oppressive and unnecessary costs to individual; there was no basis to determine average costs and no attempt to examine charges in comparable villages or to determine if charges would discourage appeals; fees charged were not necessary, but were conveniences to board in discharging its function, and amounts were not limited by definite standard -- charges for cost of publishing notice and for technical reports were proper, despite absence of guidelines therefor, since wide range of instances in which such services are employed provides assurance of uniform, predictable assessment.

1. The defendant village could not, pursuant to local ordinance, require applicants for variances and special use permits to pay the costs of legal fees, meeting hall rentals and the costs of transcription and copying of minutes incurred by its board of zoning appeals in reaching its determination, and Special Term properly disallowed the levy of such charges against the plaintiff. Fee structures are usually based upon an assessment of costs of special services against the party deriving a benefit therefrom, whereas the plaintiff was seeking relief from hardship, rather than a benefit. By failing to specify how expenses of zoning appeal boards should be paid, the Legislature has impliedly delegated to local governments the limited power to enact provisions reasonably necessary to carry out the legislative plan. Fees should be based upon average costs to prevent a board from incurring costs in an individual case which exceed what is necessary and would be oppressive to an applicant or class of applicants. There was no basis from which the village could determine average costs and no attempt was made to examine charges in comparable villages or to determine whether the charges would discourage appeals. The fees charged were not necessary, but were conveniences to the board in discharging its function, and the amounts were not limited by any definite standard.

2. Charges for the cost of publishing the notice required by statute and for technical reports were necessary and supportable, notwithstanding that the local ordinance does not set a guideline for the items, since the wide range of instances in which such services are employed provides assurance of a uniform, predictable assessment.

 

406 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. De Bour


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


40 N.Y.2d 210; 352 N.E.2d 562; 386 N.Y.S.2d 375; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2873


April 1, 1976, Argued; May 7, 1976, Argued  
June 15, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: In People v De Bour: Order affirmed.

In People v La Pene: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In cases consolidated for review, defendants challenged orders of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirming their convictions for attempted possession of weapons.


OVERVIEW: Two cases involving similar issues were consolidated for review. In the first case, defendant one was stopped by police officers while walking on the street in the middle of the night. The officer noticed a slight waist-high bulge in defendant one's jacket. The officer asked defendant one to unzip his coat and discovered a weapon. Defendant one was arrested for possession of the gun. His motion to suppress was denied. Defendant one pleaded guilty and the appellate division affirmed. The court affirmed holding that the police could approach a citizen on the street for the purpose of requesting information so long as there was a reason sufficient to justify the police action. In the second case, the police had an anonymous phone tip that led them to defendant two in a bar. The police ordered defendant two to freeze, raise his hands, and they discovered a loaded pistol. Defendant two was arrested for possession of a weapon, and after his motion to suppress was denied, he pleaded guilty. The appellate division affirmed. The court reversed and dismissed the indictment holding that the circumstances of the confrontation did not supply the requisite degree of belief to sustain a frisk.


OUTCOME: In the first case, the court of appeals affirmed defendant one's conviction for attempted possession of a weapon where the stop was lawful and the subsequent frisk was reasonably limited in scope and intensity. In the second case, the court reversed defendant two's conviction for attempted possession of a weapon because the anonymous tip alone was insufficient cause to sustain a frisk.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- police inquiry -- police officers, in absence of any concrete indication of criminal activity, could approach defendant on street for inquiry, based upon articulable reason that he conspicuously crossed to opposite side of street in area known for drug activity when approached by police officers; although encounter was supported by less than reasonable suspicion and would not have justified seizure of person, there was no constitutional violation, absent arbitrary intrusion -- minimal intrusion occasioned by request to open jacket, after police noticed bulge at defendant's waistband, was reasonably limited in scope and intensity in view of context of late night encounter and apparently evasive crossing of street; accordingly, court properly denied motion to suppress weapon seized -- although police had suitable predicate to make inquiry of second defendant, based upon radio bulletin reporting anonymous telephone call that Black male in red shirt had gun in certain bar, there was no reasonable suspicion justifying precipitate frisk, since information was unverified, no attempt was made to ascertain if others met description and defendant did not act suspiciously or appear to be armed; radio bulletin did not prima facie establish reasonable suspicion, since it was anonymous, not personally communicated, and not specific or detailed; accordingly, weapon seized should have been suppressed and indictment for felonious possession of weapon dismissed.

1. Two police officers, in the absence of any concrete indication of criminality, could approach the defendant on the street for the purpose of requesting information. The police action must be justified by some sufficient, articulable reason, and the fact that the defendant conspicuously crossed to the opposite side of the street after midnight in an area known for its high incidence of drug activity when the police officers approached from 30 to 40 feet away constitutes such a reason. The encounter was supported by less than reasonable suspicion and would not have justified a stop involving restraint or seizure of the person, defined as a significant interruption with liberty of movement. The defendant, however, was merely approached and questioned, and, absent an arbitrary intrusion, based upon whim, curiosity or caprice or with an intent to harass, there is no constitutional violation. More than one half of police work is noncriminally related and the police must be given wide latitude and not be unrealistically restricted in approaching individuals for information in the course of such work.

2. The extremely minimal intrusion to which the defendant was subjected when the police asked him to open his jacket upon having noticed a bulge at the waistband was reasonably limited in scope and intensity in view of the context of the late night encounter coupled with the defendant's apparently evasive crossing of the street. Accordingly, a weapon taken from the person of the defendant was properly seized and the court properly denied a motion to suppress.

3. Although the police had a suitable predicate to approach and make inquiry of a second defendant, based upon a police radio bulletin reporting an anonymous telephone call that a Black male, wearing a red shirt, had a gun and was in a certain bar, neither that predicate nor ensuing events constituted reasonable suspicion which would justify a precipitate frisk of that defendant. The information was unverified and no attempt was made to ascertain if others meeting the description were in the bar. The defendant's conduct was not suspicious, and there was no sign that he was armed. The radio bulletin was not prima facie sufficient to establish reasonable suspicion that the defendant possessed a gun, since the source was anonymous and the information was not personally communicated, specific or detailed. A report of possession of a gun, alone, without any urgency to act or indication of dangerous or criminal use or potential, will not authorize a frisk unless information gained from a prior inquiry supports it. Accordingly, a weapon seized from the defendant should have been suppressed; and the indictment for felonious possession of a weapon dismissed.

 

407 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


American Bible Soc. v. Lewisohn


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


40 N.Y.2d 78; 351 N.E.2d 697; 386 N.Y.S.2d 49; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2782


May 3, 1976, Argued  
June 10, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a corporation that published and distributed the Bible, brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding against defendants, the city finance administrator and others (city). The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) reversed a judgment of the trial court that ordered certain real property of the corporation to be removed from the tax rolls of the city. The city appealed.


OVERVIEW: The trial court determined that the corporation's real property had to be removed from the tax rolls, having found that the four organizations occupying the real property in question were organized exclusively for religious and/or charitable and/or educational purposes. The appellate court reversed, concluding that the corporation was organized exclusively for Bible purposes and that any religious or educational purposes, or benefits were merely incidental and thus insufficient to secure for the corporation the unqualified exemption of N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 421(1)(a). The court agreed and affirmed on appeal. The court held that a corporation organized and conducted exclusively for the purpose of publishing and distributing the Bible, when neither the corporation nor its corporate activity was directly associated with an organized religious denomination or with an organization having as its avowed purpose the furthering of a recognized religion, was entitled only to a qualified exemption from real property taxation under § 421(1)(b). Because the qualified exemption had been withdrawn, the corporation was subject to taxation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court that reversed the trial court's determination that the corporation's property was exempt from taxation.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- exemptions -- Bible societies -- petitioner, corporation organized exclusively for purpose of publishing and distributing Bible and which has no direct religious affiliation or activities, is entitled only to qualified real property tax exemption (Real Property Tax Law, § 421, subd 1, par [b]), and, since such exemption has been withdrawn for corporations organized exclusively for Bible purposes (Local Laws, 1971, No. 46 of City of New York), petitioner is subject to taxation; petitioner's charter precludes any doctrinal or denominational position or finding that it is organized for religious or educational purposes; legislative purpose was to reduce local tax burden and distinction between religious and Bible purposes was intentional -- withdrawal of tax exempt status does not violate due process or equal protection, since there is rational basis therefor and no irrational or impermissible vague classification -- res judicata and stare decisis are inapplicable, since earlier decision was based upon significantly different statute and did not determine petitioner's entitlement to tax exempt status.

1. Petitioner, a corporation organized exclusively for the purpose of publishing and distributing the Bible and which has no direct religious affiliation or activities, is entitled only to a qualified exemption from real property taxation under the Real Property Tax Law ( § 421, subd 1, par [b]), and, since the City of New York has withdrawn such exemption for corporations organized exclusively for Bible purposes (Local Laws, 1971, No. 46 of City of New York), petitioner is subject to taxation. The term "exclusively" should be interpreted to mean "primarily". While petitioner's activities inevitably further the advancement of religion, its charter limits it to publication without note or comment, precluding any doctrinal or denominational position or a finding that it is organized for religious or educational purposes. The purpose of the qualified exemption was to allow localities to reduce an increasing tax burden by withdrawing exempt status, and the Legislature intentionally distinguished between religious and Bible purposes.

2. The withdrawal of unqualified tax exempt status does not violate due process or equal protection, since there is a rational basis for the legislation and no irrational or impermissibly vague classification is drawn.

3. The principle of res judicata is inapplicable, since a prior decision involving petitioner ( People ex rel. American Bible Soc. v Commissioners of Taxes & Assessments, 76 Hun 491) was based upon the statute prior to substantial amendment, and the statute herein is significantly different. The doctrine of stare decisis is inapplicable, since the entitlement of petitioner to tax exemption was not considered.

 

408 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Swedenborg Foundation, Inc. v. Lewisohn


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


40 N.Y.2d 87; 351 N.E.2d 702; 386 N.Y.S.2d 54; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2783


May 3, 1976, Argued  
June 10, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant nonprofit corporation challenged the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which reversed a lower court's judgment that directed respondent city finance administrator to remove certain property of the corporations from the tax rolls of the city. The court found that the corporation's real property was not exempt from real property taxation.


OVERVIEW: The nonprofit corporation's activities included a wide public dissemination of the religious and philosophical writings and teachings of an eighteenth century Swedish theologian, philosopher, and scientist. The corporation's financial support came without active solicitation, from gifts, bequests and investment income. The corporation purchased a three-story building. It leased the second and third floors to a commercial tenant and used the basement and ground floor for its headquarters, offices, library, and reading room. The city asserted that the corporation's real property was no longer exempt under a new local law and the property was restored to the tax rolls at its full assessment. The court affirmed the judgment and held that the corporation was not entitled to exemption from taxation under N.Y. Real. Prop. Tax Law § 421. The court held that the primary purpose of the corporation was not religious within the contemplation of § 421. The court held that neither the corporation nor any corporate activity was directly associated with an organized religious denomination or with an organization having as its avowed purpose the furthering of a recognized religion.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the nonprofit corporation's petition for tax exemption.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- exemptions -- religious, educational and charitable corporations -- petitioner, nonprofit corporation organized to publish, distribute theological and philosophical works of and to further teachings of eighteenth century theologian, is not entitled to unqualified real property tax exemption under section 421 of Real Property Tax Law as religious corporation, since petitioner's primary purpose is not religious and petitioner is not directly associated with religious denomination or furtherance thereof -- petitioner is not educational corporation entitled to unqualified exemption, since education under  section 421 means development of faculties and powers and expansion of knowledge by teaching, as distinguished from broader process of communication of ideas and facts -- primary purpose of petitioner is not charitable -- tax exempt status for other purposes does not affect determination under section 421.

1. Petitioner, a nonprofit corporation organized for the purpose of publishing and distributing the theological and philosophical works of and furthering the teachings of an eighteenth century theologian, is not entitled to an unqualified exemption from real property taxation under section 421 of the Real Property Tax Law as a religious corporation, since the primary purpose of petitioner is not religious and neither the corporation nor any of its activity is directly associated with an organized religious denomination or with an organization having the purpose of furthering a religion. While most of petitioner's members are members of a church espousing the teachings which petitioner disseminates, the two organizations are legally unrelated, and a significant portion of the writings published by petitioner are nontheological, precluding a finding of a primary religious purpose.

2. Petitioner is not an educational corporation entitled to an unqualified exemption under section 421. Education, within the meaning of section 421, means the development of faculties and powers and the expansion of knowledge by teaching, as distinguished from the broader process of communication of ideas and facts. While the Department of Education consented to a 1928 amendment of petitioner's corporate certificate, petitioner is not chartered by the Board of Regents or classified as an educational institution by the Department of Education. The dissemination of ideas and facts does not entitle petitioner to an unqualified exemption.

3. The principal purpose of petitioner is not charitable.

4. Tax exempt status for other purposes does not affect the determination under section 421.

 

409 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Goldswer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 656; 350 N.E.2d 604; 385 N.Y.S.2d 274; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2725


April 30, 1976, Argued  
June 8, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the lower court, upon a verdict convicting defendant of official misconduct.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, the former Sheriff of Schoharie County, was indicted in Schoharie County for various offenses relating to the performance of his official duties. Upon application by the prosecution for a change of venue, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 230.20(2), on the ground that there was reasonable cause to believe that a fair and impartial trial could not be had in Schoharie County, the motion was granted. The case was removed to Warren County where, after a jury trial, defendant was found guilty of official misconduct. On appeal, the court affirmed the conviction, finding that defendant did not have the constitutional right under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 2 to be tried by a jury of the county where the offense was committed, and therefore, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 230.20(2) was not unconstitutional, nor did the statute offend the U.S. Const. amend VI. Prior to the adoption of the state constitution, it was recognized that the legislature could alter an accused's common law right to be tried by a jury of the county where the crime was committed, and the constitutional guarantee embodied the law as it was when the state bill of rights was adopted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the intermediate court upholding defendant's conviction because he was not deprived of his right to be tried by an impartial jury of the district in which the crimes were alleged to have been committed by the lower court's granting of the prosecution's application for a change of venue.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- venue -- transfer to different county -- where defendant, former Sheriff of Schoharie County, was indicted in Schoharie County, prosecutor's motion for change of venue pursuant to CPL 230.20 (subd 2) was properly granted and case transferred to Warren County wherein defendant was found guilty of official misconduct; defendant does not have right to be tried by jury of county where offense was committed -- CPL 230.20 (subd 2) does not violate either section 2 of article I of State Constitution or Sixth Amendment of Federal Constitution -- statute is designed to insure neutral forum; there must be reasonable belief that trial in county in which indictment is pending would not be impartial, and community to which trial is transferred should reflect character of county where crime was committed.

1. Defendant, the former Sheriff of Schoharie County, was indicted in Schoharie County for various offenses relating to the performance of his official duties. Upon application by the Special Prosecutor to the Appellate Division, Third Department, for a change of venue pursuant to CPL 230.20 (subd 2) on the ground that there was "reasonable cause to believe that a fair and impartial trial" could not be had in Schoharie County, the motion was properly granted and the case removed to Warren County where, after a jury trial, defendant was found guilty of official misconduct. Defendant does not have the constitutional right under section 2 of article I of the State Constitution to be tried by a jury of the county where the offense was committed and, therefore, CPL 230.20 (subd 2) is not unconstitutional. Prior to the adoption of the Constitution it was recognized that the Legislature could alter the accused's common-law right to be tried by a jury of the county where the crime was committed, and the constitutional guarantee embodies the law as it was when the Bill of Rights was adopted.

2. Nor does the statute offend the Sixth Amendment to the Federal Constitution, which guarantees the accused the right to a trial by "an impartial jury of the State and district wherein the crime shall have been committed", by permitting the Appellate Division to transfer a criminal case for trial in a county other than the county of the offense. The Sixth Amendment represents a compromise of competing interests and is intended to be restrictive enough to protect the individual from being tried by an alien body, and yet not so restrictive as to deny the Government a forum when a trial is impractical in the county where the crime was committed. The Legislature is given the power to define or designate "districts" and, while "district" means Federal judicial districts in Federal prosecutions, it is not entirely clear what this means in State prosecutions, or whether it imposes any obligations on the State to create or designate subdivisions limiting venue and vicinage within the State.

3. CPL 230.20 (subd 2) is designed to insure a neutral forum and should not be construed so as to permit the prosecutor to obtain a more favorable tribunal. There must be at least a reasonable basis for belief that a trial in the county in which the indictment is pending would not be a fair and impartial determination on the merits, and within reasonable limits, the community to which the trial is transferred should reflect the character of the county where the crime was committed.

 

410 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Jones


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 694; 350 N.E.2d 913; 385 N.Y.S.2d 525; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2796


March 24, 1976, Argued  
June 8, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant criminal defendant challenged the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) rejecting her claims that the 15-years-to-life sentence she received for drug possession was unconstitutionally cruel and violated her rights to equal protection of the laws.


OVERVIEW: Appellant criminal defendant was tried for and convicted of first-degree drug possession and, pursuant to mandatory sentencing laws, was sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 15 years. She appealed her sentence, arguing it constituted unconstitutionally cruel punishment due to its severity and violated equal protection since a dozen others were permitted to pled to lesser crimes and, thus, received lesser sentences. After a state appellate court upheld her sentence, she sought and was granted a further appeal by the state's highest court. That court also affirmed, ruling that the sentence was not unconstitutionally severe since it was within the limits of a valid sentencing statute and, further, that her equal protection rights were not violated since all who were convicted of the crime for which she was convicted were subject to the identical punishment. Court noted in passing that she had declined a lesser offense offer.


OUTCOME: Judgment sentencing the appellant was affirmed; sentence imposed was not unconstitutionally cruel under the circumstances, given that it was imposed pursuant to a valid statute, and appellant was not denied equal protection of the law since all who were convicted of the crime for which she was convicted were subject to the same punishment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence -- cruel and unusual punishment -- although other persons arrested in connection with heroin operation were permitted to plead to lesser crimes and were given lighter sentences, mandatory sentence of defendant of 15 years to life after conviction following jury trial of criminal possession of dangerous drug in first degree, class A felony, was not violative of equal protection clauses of State and United States Constitutions; circumstances were not same since defendant was convicted of crime different than that of her codefendants -- sentence of defendant was not so disproportionate to offense as to amount to cruel and unusual punishment -- no inference that defendant was punished because she insisted on right to trial; she received minimum punishment prescribed by law -- defendant was offered three-year sentence in exchange for guilty plea and, accordingly, there was no discrimination practiced against her.

1. Defendant, a "millhand" in a large scale heroin operation, was convicted after a jury trial of criminal possession of a dangerous drug in the first degree, a class A felony at the time of the offense, and was sentenced under the mandatory provisions of section 70.00 of the Penal Law to a term of from 15 years to life. Other persons arrested in connection with the same operation were permitted to plead to lesser charges of attempted criminal possession of a dangerous drug in the first degree, criminal possession of a dangerous drug in the third degree and attempted criminal possession of a dangerous drug in the fourth degree and were sentenced to 8 1/3 to 25 years, 5 years and 3 years, depending on the crime to which they pleaded guilty. On the facts the statutes have not been unconstitutionally applied under the equal protection clauses of the State and United States Constitutions. The circumstances were not the same since defendant was convicted of a crime different than that of her codefendants for which there was a mandatory minimum sentence not applicable to them.

2. Regardless of its severity, a sentence within the limits of a valid statute ordinarily is not a cruel and unusual punishment in the constitutional sense and there were no exceptional circumstances justifying a variance from that rule. The sentence of defendant was not so grossly disproportionate to the offense as to amount to cruel and unusual punishment. Furthermore, the facts, convictions for different crimes and the mandatory statute, justified an inequality of sentences.

3. It cannot be inferred that defendant was punished because she pleaded not guilty and insisted on her right to a trial. She received the minimum punishment prescribed by law.

4. Defendant was offered a three-year sentence in exchange for a guilty plea and, accordingly, there was no discrimination practiced against defendant in that regard.

 

411 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York State School Bus Operators Asso. v. County of Nassau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 638; 350 N.E.2d 593; 385 N.Y.S.2d 263; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2722


May 3, 1976, Argued  
June 3, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action for a judgment declaring the bus transportation operation by defendants, county and others, unconstitutional, plaintiffs, association and others, appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the trial court's order denying plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, granting defendants' cross motions for summary judgment, and dismissing the complaint.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs brought an action for a judgment declaring the operation of charter bus and school bus transportation by defendants unconstitutional and illegal. The trial court denied plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, granted defendants' cross motions for summary judgment, and dismissed the complaint. The appellate court affirmed. The court affirmed the judgments below. The court held that defendants, pursuant to N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(c)(7) and N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(1)(ii)(a)(7), were given the power to acquire transit facilities including acquisition by eminent domain. The court additionally held that the public need or desirability, without more, was not subject to judicial review. Plaintiffs' attack on appeal did not go to establish lack of power and therefore was not reviewable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which affirmed the trial court's order denying plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, granting defendants' cross motions for summary judgment, and dismissing the complaint in an action for a judgment declaring the bus transportation operation by defendants unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- transit facilities -- transportation of school children -- County of Nassau and Suburban Bus Authority have constitutional and statutory power to acquire transit facilities, including acquisition by eminent domain, and restrictive language may not be imported to limit term "transit facilities" as used in context -- requisite public purpose of taking of transit facilities in eminent domain for school pupil transportation is not negated by any lack of wisdom in public, rather than private, provision thereof, and public need or desirability alone is not, in any event, subject to judicial review.

1. The County of Nassau and the Suburban Bus Authority have the power to acquire transit facilities, including acquisition by eminent domain, under the unrestricted language of the State Constitution (art IX, § 2, subd [c], par 7) and the Municipal Home Rule Law ( § 10, subd 1, par [ii], cl a, subcl [7]). The term "transit facilities" covers any tangible means of moving people and things, and more restrictive language elsewhere may not be imported to interpret the term as used in context.

2. The requisite public purpose of the taking of transit facilities in eminent domain is not negated by any lack of wisdom in the public, rather than private, provision of school pupil transportation, since such transportation is a public purpose, notwithstanding which method best fulfills the need, and, in any event, public need or desirability, without more, is not subject to judicial review.

 

412 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Wayburn v. Schupf


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 682; 350 N.E.2d 906; 385 N.Y.S.2d 518; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2795


March 22, 1976, Argued  
May 13, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, without costs, and the petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent appealed, on constitutional grounds, from a judgment of the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York) sustaining a writ of habeas corpus, releasing respondent pending a hearing, and adjudging that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 739 (b) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: After respondent allegedly committed criminal acts, respondent was ordered detained pending a hearing. Respondent brought a habeas corpus proceeding. The lower court ordered his release pending the hearing concluding that the statute authorizing detention was violative of the equal protection clause because it authorized pretrial detention of juveniles with no comparable authority for pretrial detention of adults similarly charged. Respondent appealed. Meanwhile, respondent was adjudicated a juvenile delinquent and placed in a training school. However, the court declined to dismiss the case on the ground of mootness. The court reversed the judgment and dismissed the petition for a writ of habeas corpus holding there was a compelling state interest to be served in differentiating between juveniles charged with delinquency and adults charged with crime with respect to preventive detention, and in the very nature of the process there was no less offensive means to achieve the desired objective.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment releasing respondent and adjudging the statute unconstitutional and dismissed the petition for a writ of habeas corpus holding the statute furthered a compelling state interest and there was no less offensive means to achieve the state's desired objective.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- juvenile delinquents -- pretrial detention -- constitutionality of section 739 of Family Court Act, which authorizes pretrial detention of youths charged as juvenile delinquents when serious risk exists of commission of criminal act before return date of petition, should be subject to strict scrutiny, since fundamental right of liberty is impinged upon -- there is compelling State interest in differentiating between youths charged as juvenile delinquents and adults charged with crime, since State is fundamentally concerned with protection of society from crime and protection of children, and immature juveniles may found to be more likely than adults to commit another criminal act -- no less burdensome means than detention is advanced to prevent further criminal acts -- due process is not violated by speculative element in prediction of probability of further crime and Family Court must exercise substitute parental control over children who are without effective control of parents or guardians -- accordingly, pretrial detention based upon serious risk of further crime does not violate due process or equal protection provisions of State or Federal Constitutions -- since probable cause existed to believe that relator strangled pedestrian during mugging and upon finding of serious risk of further crime, relator's constitutional rights were not violated by pretrial detention.

1. A determination of the constitutionality of section 739 of the Family Court Act, which authorizes pretrial detention of a youth charged as a juvenile delinquent when there is a serious risk that he may commit a criminal act before the return date of the petition, must be under the strict scrutiny test, since the fundamental right to liberty is impinged upon.

2. There is a compelling State interest in differentiating between juveniles charged with delinquency and adults charged with crime. The State is fundamentally concerned with the protection of society from crime and the protection of children in need of special treatment and care. It may be concluded that juveniles, in their earlier stages of intellectual and emotional growth, are more likely to commit another criminal act than are adults, who are subject to greater self-restraint and the deterrents of second-offender sentencing and the absence of juvenile delinquency treatment.

3. No less burdensome means than detention is advanced to prevent the commission of further criminal acts.

4. Due process is not violated by the element of speculation involved in predicting the probability of repetition of criminal behavior and, many children being without the effective control of parents or guardians, the Family Court must exercise substitute parental control. While more children may be detained than are ultimately placed in training schools, the determination of placement is based upon the vastly different data available after the dispositional hearing.

5. Accordingly, pretrial detention based upon serious risk of further criminal activity does not violate the due process or equal protection provisions of the Federal or State Constitutions.

6. Since there was probable cause to believe that the 15-year-old relator had strangled a pedestrian during a mugging and, upon a finding of serious risk that if released the relator would commit another crime, his constitutional rights were not violated by pretrial detention.

 

413 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Levine v. Whalen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 510; 349 N.E.2d 820; 384 N.Y.S.2d 721; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2677


March 30, 1976, Argued  
May 11, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, with costs to petitioner-respondent, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the State Commissioner of Health (Commissioner), sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which annulled a determination of the Commissioner that revoked respondent convalescent home's hospital operating certificate and declared N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2800 unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The Commissioner revoked the hospital operating certificate of a convalescent home for violations of N.Y. Pub. Health Law art. 28. The convalescent home filed suit to annul the determination. The trial court held that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2800 was unconstitutional and granted the annulment. On appeal, the court held that § 2800 was not unconstitutionally vague, that it was not an improper delegation of the legislature's authority to the department of health without adequate standards, and that its stated policy, "to provide for the protection and promotion of the health of the inhabitants of the state," was sufficiently specific and clear. The court explained that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2806(1) provided that a hospital operating certificate of a nursing home could be revoked on proof that the hospital failed to comply with the provisions of art. 28 or rules promulgated thereunder. The administrative regulations, set forth in N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, § 711 et seq., would have been upheld if they had a rational basis; however, the court found that §§ 711.5, 711.1(c)(1), and the three methods for compliance set forth in § 711.1 were impermissibly vague.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed as modified. The court found that the statute was constitutional but that certain regulations promulgated under it were invalid.


HEADNOTES

Hospitals and asylums -- nursing homes -- section 2800 of Public Health Law, which declares, as policy of State, that hospital and related services be of highest quality, efficiently provided, and properly utilized at reasonable cost, and, in order to provide for protection and promotion of health of inhabitants of State, gives to Department of Health responsibility for development and administration of State's policy, is constitutional -- Legislature has established sufficient guidelines for department regarding structural requirements for nursing homes -- however, regulations promulgated by Commissioner of Health provided three possible methods for compliance with State Hospital Code by nursing homes, of which two lacked objectivity, and those invalid methods were so interwoven with valid method that none can stand.

1. Section 2800 of the Public Health Law, which declares, as the policy of the State, that hospital and related services be of the highest quality, efficiently provided, and properly utilized at a reasonable cost, and, in order to provide for the protection and promotion of the health of the inhabitants of the State, gives to the Department of Health the central, comprehensive responsibility for the development and administration of the State's policy with respect to hospital and related services, is constitutional. It outlines a policy, sets forth a standard which is sufficiently specific and clear, and establishes an easily understood principle in a field where a substantial degree of flexibility is required.

2. The Legislature has established sufficient guidelines for the Department of Health regarding structural requirements for nursing homes. Other sections of article 28 of the Public Health Law provide that a hospital operating certificate may be revoked on proof that the hospital failed to comply with the provisions of the article or rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, and that a hospital operating certificate shall not be issued unless the department finds that the premises and equipment are fit and adequate.

3. Regulations promulgated by the Commissioner of Health provided three possible methods for compliance with the State Hospital Code by nursing homes, the first being compliance by such a facility with specific standards of construction, and this method was unobjectionable. However, the second and third methods, under which the commissioner could modify the applicability of the construction standards or grant an exception to their applicability, lacked objectivity, and were invalid. They were so interwoven with the valid method that none can stand.

 

414 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Broidrick v. Lindsay


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 641; 350 N.E.2d 595; 385 N.Y.S.2d 265; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2723; 14 Fair Empl. Prac. Cas. (BNA) 38; 12 Empl. Prac. Dec. (CCH) P11,171


March 29, 1976, Argued  
May 11, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff trades filed an action against defendant city pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 seeking relief from regulations issued by defendant deputy mayor. The supreme court (New York) entered judgment granting the trades' motion to convert the action into one for declaratory judgment, granting their motion for summary judgment and adjudging the regulations invalid. The appellate division entered an order of affirmance, and the city appealed.


OVERVIEW: The deputy mayor was charged with issuing rules and regulations implementing New York City, N.Y. Exec. Order No. 71 issued by defendant mayor in 1968. About four years later, the deputy mayor issued rules and regulations in part requiring building trades' unions or organizations to accept new minority apprentices at the rate of no less than one minority apprentice to every three non-minority apprentices. The trades objected and filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78. After the supreme court and the appellate division found in the trades' favor, the city argued the actions taken were valid exercises of authority. The court held the deputy mayor's action went far beyond merely implementing existing state and local law to effectuate equal employment opportunity and in effect mandated percentage employment. Because the regulations exceeded the limits of state or local legislation, if not constitutional limitations, they were beyond the executive power and were thus invalid.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Civil rights -- discrimination in employment -- percentage employment requirement -- although there is strong public policy against minority discrimination and, while Mayor or Deputy Mayor of City of New York may require compliance with statutory prohibitions against employment discrimination by city contractors, regulations requiring affirmative action in form of minority employment percentages are in excess of executive authority under State and local statute; mayoral policy displaces legislative policy of employment based upon merit and equal employment opportunity -- minority employment percentages are not rationally related to cost considerations, and instead attempt to promote extrinsic social policy -- State law requires that apprentices be selected upon objective qualifications and such requirements invalidate regulation mandating acceptance of apprentices by percentage -- affirmative executive action would be permissible if limited to policy of increasing pool of eligibles for employment.

1. Although there is a strong public policy against minority discrimination and, while the Mayor or Deputy Mayor of the City of New York may be empowered to require compliance with section 343-8.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which prohibits discrimination in employment by city contractors, regulations under Executive Order No. 71 requiring affirmative action in the form of prescribed minority employment percentages are in excess of executive authority under State and local statute. Within the bounds of legislative policy, the executive is accorded flexibility in determining enforcement methods, and the nature of discrimination requires a broad policy declaration. Nevertheless, the mayoral policy mandating employment percentages displaces the legislative policy of employment based upon individual merit and equal employment opportunity.

2. The minority employment percentages are not rationally related to cost considerations in government projects, a proper executive consideration, and instead constitute an attempt to promote an extrinsic social policy without legislative authority.

3. New York State law requires that apprentices shall be selected solely upon objective qualifications without reference to minority status (Labor Law, § 815, subd 5; Executive Law, § 296, subd 1-a, par [a]), and such requirements invalidate the regulation which mandates acceptance of minority apprentices by percentage.

4. Affirmative executive action would be permissible if limited to a policy of increasing the pool of eligibles for employment by including previously excluded minority workers.

 

415 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bush


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 529; 349 N.E.2d 832; 384 N.Y.S.2d 733; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2679; 92 L.R.R.M. 3268; 80 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P53,901


February 19, 1976, Argued  
May 4, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, who were union members, appealed a judgment from the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed their convictions for criminal trespass, N.Y. Penal Law § 140.05, for picketing on private property in front of stores that sold the products of their employer, even after the managers of the stores asked defendants to remove their picketing to an area away from store entrances.


OVERVIEW: During a labor dispute with their employer, defendants began picketing stores that sold their employer's products. The union had not, prior to this action, applied to the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) for an order indicating its members had a right to picket on particular private property. When defendants refused to move their picket line away from store entrances, as requested by store managers, they were charged with criminal trespass, N.Y. Penal Law § 140.05. Defendants were convicted, and their convictions upheld by the appellate division. Defendants appealed. In affirming, the court ruled that their free speech rights under U.S. Const. amend. I were superseded by the private property rights of the stores' owners and that the owners could regulate picketing. Moreover, because the union had not obtained an order from the NLRB authorizing the picketing, defendants did not have rights under the National Labor Relations Act, 29 U.S.C.S. § 151 et seq. that overrode those private property rights.


OUTCOME: The judgment upholding the convictions was affirmed because defendants did not have a First Amendment right to picket on private property that overrode the property rights of the stores' owners and their rights under the National Labor Relations Act were similarly limited since the union had not obtained a prior order from the National Labor Relations Board authorizing such conduct.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- trespass -- labor unions -- defendants are not protected by First Amendment from consequences of failure to co-operate with reasonable regulation of picketing outside private supermarkets, since trespassory conduct, not speech, was sought to be regulated -- National Labor Relations Act does not pre-empt enforcement of State criminal trespass statute against picketers upon private property -- union is not without remedy, since access to private property may be gained if National Labor Relations Board finds it justified upon advance application -- section 140.05 of Penal Law is not void for vagueness -- accordingly, Appellate Term properly upheld convictions of defendants for criminal trespass.

1. The defendants are not protected by the First Amendment against the consequences of their failure to co-operate with a reasonable regulation of their picketing outside private supermarkets. First Amendment rights under the Federal Constitution in the area of labor picketing are subordinate to private property rights, except where the employer and property owner has a totality of control, as in the instance of a company town, and, whatever State free speech protections continue to apply, trespassory conduct on public or private property may be regulated. The defendant picketers were asked to move their lines because of their conduct, rather than their speech and were not even requested to leave the area entirely.

2. The National Labor Relations Act (US Code, tit 29, § 151 et seq.) does not pre-empt enforcement of the State criminal trespass statute against picketers upon private property of an employer related to a Federally governed labor dispute. Except as to trespass, where a dispute is arguably within the ambit of the act, a ruling of the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), that particular conduct sought to be regulated is neither protected nor prohibited by Federal law, is required precedent to State court action.

3. Access to private property is nevertheless available if the NLRB finds it justified upon application in advance of union action, and the union is therefore not without a remedy.

4. Section 140.05 of the Penal Law is not void for vagueness.

5. Accordingly, the Appellate Term properly upheld the convictions of the defendants for criminal trespass.

 

416 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Drayton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 580; 350 N.E.2d 377; 385 N.Y.S.2d 1; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2710


March 24, 1976, Argued  
May 4, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed the denial of his motion for resentencing and his claim that permitting superior courts discretion to afford youthful offender treatment, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §720.20, while such treatment was mandatory in local criminal courts, violated his equal protection rights under U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted, at the age of 16, for robbery and felonious assault. The trial court, a superior court having exclusive jurisdiction over felonies pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §10.20, accepted his guilty plea to misdemeanor assault. Although he was found to be an eligible youth, defendant was denied youthful offender treatment under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §720.20. Defendant moved for resentencing, claiming that § 720.20 violated his equal protection rights, U.S. Const. amend. XIV, because it allowed superior courts discretion in granting youthful offender treatment, whereas such treatment was mandatory in local criminal courts. His motion was denied and the appellate division affirmed. The defendant filed this appeal. In affirming, the court ruled that the difference in treatment provided by § 720.20 was not invidiously discriminatory and did not violate equal protection. The difference in treatment between courts was based upon the difference in the seriousness of the offenses over which those courts had jurisdiction and the seriousness of the crime committed by a defendant was a rational basis for youthful offender treatment being discretionary rather than mandatory.


OUTCOME: The judgment affirming the denial of defendant's conviction and denying his motion for resentencing was affirmed because there was a rational basis for the difference in treatment allowed in the youthful offender statutes, such differences were not arbitrary and did not constitute invidious discrimination; superior courts had jurisdiction over more serious offenses and the seriousness of the crime justified the different treatment.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- youthful offenders -- subdivision 1 of CPL 720.20, which provides that court in its discretion may find eligible youth who has been convicted of crime is youthful offender and that, where conviction is had in local criminal court, court must find that eligible youth is youthful offender, does not violate equal protection guarantees; distinction between youths charged in superior courts, which are vested with jurisdiction of felonies, as opposed to local courts which are given jurisdiction of misdemeanors, is not arbitrary; there is rational basis therefor -- accordingly, defendant, who was indicted for robbery in second degree and assault in second degree, felonies, and who entered plea in Supreme Court to assault in third degree, misdemeanor, was properly denied youthful offender treatment on basis of unfavorable probation report.

1. Subdivision 1 of CPL 720.20, which provides that a court in its discretion may find that an eligible youth who has been convicted of a crime is a youthful offender and that, where a conviction is had in a local criminal court, the court must find that an eligible youth is a youthful offender, does not violate the equal protection guarantees of the United States and New York State Constitutions. The distinction between youths charged in superior as opposed to local courts is not arbitrary. Superior courts, the Supreme Court and the County Court, are vested with exclusive jurisdiction of the trial of felonies while local criminal courts are given jurisdiction of the trial of offenses other than felonies. The classification in CPL 720.20 is based on the gravity of the crime with which the youth is charged and there is a rational basis for distinguishing between a youth accused of a felony and one charged with a misdemeanor. There is no invidious discrimination in a legislative decision that youths believed to have committed felonies should not automatically be endowed with youthful offender status. Furthermore, it was proper for the Legislature to decide that, in the interests of judicial economy, it was not necessary to require a time-consuming investigation to determine youthful offender eligibility in misdemeanor cases.

2. The rationality of the classification in CPL 720.20 is especially compelling in the instant case. Defendant, 17 years of age at the time of the commission of the crimes, who was indicted for robbery in the second degree and assault in the second degree, class D felonies, and who entered a plea of guilty in Supreme Court to assault in the third degree, a class A misdemeanor, was properly denied youthful offender treatment on the basis of an unfavorable probation report. Defendant may not reap a double benefit from the congestion in the criminal courts by not only securing a plea to a lesser charge but also by obtaining automatic youthful offender treatment.

 

417 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


L. v. New York State Dep't of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 434; 348 N.E.2d 867; 384 N.Y.S.2d 392; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2664


February 19, 1976, Argued  
April 8, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of L.: Order affirmed, without costs.

In Matter of K.: Order reversed, without costs, and the petitions dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner child appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirming a family court order directing respondents, New York State Department of Education and others (agencies), to reimburse tuition. Appellant city challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirming orders to reimburse respondent second child.


OVERVIEW: The child suffered from severe emotional problems and required private schooling. The parents of the child paid tuition for his special education during three school years and the family court only ordered reimbursement by the agencies for one year. The court affirmed the contested appellate division order. The court concluded that the payments for the two years were correctly denied because the claims for reimbursement were not timely presented. The second child suffered from a functional brain disorder and a personality disorder requiring private schooling. The parents of the second child paid tuition for his special education tuition during two years and the family court ordered reimbursement from the city for two years. The court reversed the contested order of the appellate division.
