The court concluded that the payments for the two years were improperly granted because the claims for reimbursement were not timely presented. The court ruled that, according to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 8, § 200.8(b),(c), for the parents to recover they had to seek reimbursement from the chargeable locality in the school year for which the private school tuition was paid.


OUTCOME: The court reversed without costs the order of the appellate division challenged by the child that sustained the family court orders requiring the agencies to reimburse the special education tuition of the child. The court reversed without costs the order of the appellate division contested by the city that sustained the orders to reimburse the special education tuition of the second child. The court dismissed the city's petitions.


HEADNOTES

 Schools -- education of handicapped children -- parents of handicapped children who require special educational facilities must seek reimbursement for tuition at private school from locality chargeable therewith within school year for which tuition was paid; under section 232 of Family Court Act, court must review condition of children as well as state of available public facilities on annual basis and determine whether previous order should be amended -- statute requires filing of claim promptly while sufficient time remains in school year for any change in placement -- aside from statute, Legislature intended orderly procedure for payment of tuition -- regulation as to State approval of reimbursement to locality supports view claims must be promptly made.

1. The parents of handicapped children who require special facilities for their education must seek reimbursement for tuition at a private school in which such children are enrolled from the locality chargeable therewith within the school year for which the tuition was paid. Under section 232 of the Family Court Act, the court must continually review the condition of the children as well as the state of available public facilities. The condition of a handicapped child may improve to the point that the child may attend public school, may change so that the child may be more appropriately treated in a different private school, or additional facilities may have been added to the public school system. Accordingly, the court under section 232 must review each case on an annual basis and determine whether its previous order should be amended. By not presenting claims for reimbursement within the current school year, parents deprive the court of the opportunity for such a periodic review. Later consideration would preclude an opportunity to make necessary changes.

2. Section 232 of the Family Court Act requires that a claim be filed promptly while sufficient time remains in the school year for any change in placement to be effectuated. A review proceeding must occur while there is time to prevent further unnecessary expenditure of public funds.

3. Aside from the requirement of the statute, it is clear that the Legislature intended to provide an orderly procedure for the payment of tuition for, without a limitation of time to make application, local governments and school districts would face budgetary chaos.

4. A regulation of the State Commissioner of Education (8 NYCRR 200.8) with respect to State approval of reimbursement to a locality for special educational services supports the view that claims must be promptly made. Since the claim triggers the payment for which the locality will be reimbursed, the locality cannot receive its reimbursement from the State unless the claim of the parents is promptly filed.

 

418 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Burke


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 729; 349 N.E.2d 870; 384 N.Y.S.2d 770; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2690


February 13, 1976, Argued  
April 6, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- sentence -- defendant was convicted of robbery, assault and possession of weapon, and was sentenced to indeterminate term of not less than 6 nor more than 18 years on robbery count, to run concurrently with term of not more than 6 years on assault count, and conditional discharge on weapon count -- contention by him that sentencing court failed to comply with requirement of section 70.00 (subd 3, par [b]) of Penal Law that, when minimum period of imprisonment was fixed, "court shall set forth in the record the reasons for its action" -- judgment of conviction was properly affirmed -- at sentencing Assistant District Attorney gave his reasons for recommending minimum sentence, and court imposed minimum sentence within seconds after statement by him -- it is inferable from its more conclusory recital that court was incorporating Assistant District Attorney's references -- there was, therefore, substantial compliance with statute and its salutary purposes. 

 

419 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Siwek v. Mahoney


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 159; 347 N.E.2d 599; 383 N.Y.S.2d 238; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2391


March 22, 1976, Argued  
April 1, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, without costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, Erie County, for the entry of judgment in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner voter filed a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 against respondent election commissioners, challenging the validity of N.Y. Elec. law § 153 under N.Y. Const. art. II, § 5. The Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) entered judgment declaring N.Y. Elec. Law § 153 unconstitutional and enjoining the election commissioners from accepting applications for voter registration by mail. The election commissioners appealed.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Elec. Law § 153, enacted in 1975, provided a state-wide form of mail registration to the personal registration procedures already available. In response, the voter filed suit against the election commissioners. The supreme court treated the action as one for declaratory judgment, declared that § 153 violated N.Y. Const. art. II, § 5, and enjoined the election commissioners from accepting applications for voter registration and enrollment by mail unless proof was shown that applicants qualified pursuant to specific exemptions as defined in § 5. On appeal, the court held that it was § 6, and not § 5, by which N.Y. Elec. Law § 153 had to be tested. The court then held that § 153 was valid because all citizens of the state were treated in the same manner, and the mail registration system created by § 153 was a personal application within the limitations of N.Y. Const. art. II, § 6.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment granting the voter's prayers for relief and directed the entry of a judgment containing a declaration as to the constitutionality of the challenged provision and denying the voter's prayers for relief.


HEADNOTES

Elections -- voter registration by mail -- constitutional law -- provision under section 153 of Election Law for applications for voter registration to be made by mail violates neither section 5 nor section 6 of article II of State Constitution; annual registration system of section 5 has been rendered inoperative by utilization of section 6, which allows Legislature to establish by statute system of permanent registration requiring "personal application" rather than previous requirement that voter "appear personally"; wording of section 6 may be interpreted to mean that voter must himself perform application procedures; since section 6 was intended to increase voter participation among voters who are unable or for whom it is inconvenient to register in person, requirement under section 153 of Election Law of personal completion of application prior to mailing, having identical purpose, constitutes "personal application" -- since no geographical distinction is made under section 153 of Election Law, all voters are treated equally and there is no denial of equal protection.

1. Section 153 of the Election Law, which provides for applications for registration to vote to be made by mail, violates neither section 5 nor section 6 of article II of the State Constitution. Section 5, which establishes a system of annual voter registration requiring in-person application in villages and cities with populations exceeding 5,000, has been rendered inoperative by the Legislature's utilization of section 6, which allows the establishment by statute of a permanent registration system. Unlike section 5, which requires that an applicant "appear personally", section 6 mandates only "personal application", which may be interpreted to mean that the voter must himself perform the necessary application procedures. Section 6 of article II of the Constitution was intended to increase voter participation by avoiding the loss of voters who are unable or for whom it is inconvenient to register in person, and the requirement under section 153 of the Election Law that a voter personally complete an application before mailing, having an identical purpose, constitutes a "personal application".

2. Since there is no geographical distinction made under section 153 of the Election Law, all voters are accorded equal treatment and there is no denial of equal protection.

 

420 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rallo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 217; 347 N.E.2d 633; 383 N.Y.S.2d 271; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2399


January 8, 1976, Argued  
April 1, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Orders affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which reversed a decision of the trial court and reinstated indictments against them, which charged them with a multi-county misappropriation offense.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with misappropriations in connection with a housing project, which misappropriations occurred in one county. However, the construction loan to finance the housing projects was made in another county. The trial court dismissed defendants' indictments because the deputy attorney general in charge of the Organized Task Force appeared before the grand jury. The court affirmed the reinstatement of the indictments because such appearance was proper under N.Y. Exec. Law § 70-a(7). Specifically, it was not required that the conduct occurring in the second county, the loan, have been that of an eventually indicted defendant or have constituted the requisite offense with which the grand jury was concerned. Rather, the conduct in the second county was only required to relate to the misappropriation offense. The court further held that proof of organized crime was not a prerequisite to the deputy attorney general's appearance before the grand jury.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the reinstatement of the indictments against defendants, which charged them with a multi-county misappropriation offense.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Organized Crime Task Force -- Deputy Attorney-General in charge of Organized Crime Task Force is authorized to appear before Grand Jury if three conditions prescribed in subdivision 7 of section 70-a of Executive Law are met, i.e., Governor must give his approval, appropriate District Attorney must request or approve such appearance, and Grand Jury proceeding must be concerned with multicounty or interstate conduct -- showing that presentments laid before Grand Jury involve "organized crime activities" is not prerequisite to his authority to appear before it -- in order to meet condition as to multicounty conduct, conduct occurring in second county need not be that of eventually indicted defendant, nor need it constitute or be requisite to offense with which Grand Jury is concerned, but it is enough that it is related thereto "in any manner."

1. The Deputy Attorney-General in charge of the Organized Crime Task Force is authorized to appear before a Grand Jury if the three conditions prescribed in subdivision 7 of section 70-a of the Executive Law are met, i.e., the Governor must give his approval, the appropriate District Attorney must request or approve such appearance, and the Grand Jury proceeding must be concerned with multicounty or interstate conduct. A showing that the presentments laid before the Grand Jury involve "organized crime activities" is not a prerequisite to his authority to appear before it. (Cf. Matter of Sussman v New York State Organized Crime Task Force, 39 NY2d 227.)

2. In order to meet the condition as to multicounty conduct, the statute requires only that "any conduct * * * in any * * * manner related to [the] offense occurred * * * in two or more counties of this state". The conduct occurring in the second county need not be that of an eventually indicted defendant, nor need it constitute or be requisite to the offense with which the Grand Jury is concerned. It is enough that it is related thereto "in any manner".

 

421 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sussman v. New York State Organized Crime Task Force


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 227; 347 N.E.2d 638; 383 N.Y.S.2d 276; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2400


January 8, 1976, Argued  
April 1, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state task force challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) which affirmed a lower court order quashing subpoenas duces tecum served upon appellees pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 70-a. The task force argued that it should not be required to show that criminal activity under review is "organized" criminal activity in order to sustain the issuance of a nonjudicial subpoena duces tecum pursuant to § 70-a.


OVERVIEW: Appellant state task force served subpoenas duces tecum upon appellees pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 70-a. Appellees filed motions to quash the subpoenas, arguing that the task force did not offer any facts showing that its investigation was of organized crime activities that crossed state or county lines. Appellees also argued that investigation of the validity of a nonjudicial subpoena duces tecum issued under § 70-a should be conducted openly in an adversary forum and not in camera. The trial court granted the motions to quash. On review, the task force argued that it should not be required to show that criminal activity under review is "organized" criminal activity in order to sustain the issuance of a nonjudicial subpoena duces tecum pursuant to § 70-a. The appeals court ruled that the resolution in each case must be left to the sound determination of the court before which the issue is raised, subject to appropriate appellate review. The proof must establish that the attorney-general is proceeding in good faith and that the testimony and documents he seeks bear a reasonable relationship to matters properly under the task force's investigatory jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The reviewing court affirmed the appeals court order because the task force made no preliminary showing of either multicounty crime or of organized crime.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Organized Crime Task Force -- showing by Deputy Attorney-General in charge of Organized Crime Task Force that purpose of his investigation is inquiry into "organized crime activities", and, more particularly, organized crime activities which are also either multicounty or interstate, is prerequisite to issuance of office subpoenas by him in exercise of investigatory authority granted by subdivision 4 of section 70-a of Executive Law -- resolution of precise quantum of proof which will be required must be left to sound determination of court or Judge before which or whom issue is raised -- proof must establish that Deputy Attorney-General is proceeding in good faith and that testimony and documents he seeks bear reasonable relationship to organized crime activities which are multicounty or interstate -- while there may be instances where it may be appropriate to employ specially limited, in camera, or even ex parte, procedures, full record should be preserved for appellate review -- that phrase "organized crime activities" is not susceptible of precise definition does not render subdivision 4 of section 70-a unconstitutional.

1. A showing by the Deputy Attorney-General in charge of the Organized Crime Task Force that the purpose of his investigation is inquiry into "organized crime activities", and, more particularly, organized crime activities which are also either multicounty or interstate, is a prerequisite to the issuance of office subpoenas by him in the exercise of the investigatory authority granted to his office by subdivision 4 of section 70-a of the Executive Law. (Cf. People v Rallo, 39 NY2d 217.)

2. The resolution of the precise quantum of proof which will be required must be left to the sound determination of the court or Judge before which or whom the issue is raised, subject to appropriate appellate relief. The proof must establish that the Deputy Attorney-General is proceeding in good faith and that the testimony and documents he seeks bear a reasonable relationship to organized crime activities which are also either multicounty or interstate. While there may be instances in which the delicacy of the particular investigation or the risk of and consequence attendant on premature disclosure may be such that it will be appropriate to employ specially limited, in camera, or even ex parte, procedures in which to receive the Deputy Attorney-General's proof and to make the necessary judicial determination, a full record, perhaps sealed, should be preserved to permit informed appellate review.

3. That the phrase "organized crime activities" is not susceptible of precise definition does not render subdivision 4 of section 70-a unconstitutional. Where vagueness as to the authority for the issuance of an office subpoena is asserted, that issue can be tested by an appropriate proceeding to quash the subpoena or in resisting a proceeding to compel compliance with it, and thus a target or a witness may avoid being placed in jeopardy and obliged to dishonor the subpoena at his peril. And if, after investigation by the Organized Crime Task Force, a presentment is made to a Grand Jury, such presentment and any subsequent charges will be concerned with specified substantive crimes, each of which may be tested under the constitutional void-for-vagueness test, and the concept of "organized crime activities" will then be irrelevant.

 

422 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Patterson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 288; 347 N.E.2d 898; 383 N.Y.S.2d 573; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2409


January 15, 1976, Argued  
April 1, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the judgment of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed his conviction for murder, N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25, in a trial where the burden of persuasion had been placed on defendant with respect to whether he had been acting under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance, so as to reduce a murder charge to manslaughter.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with murder, N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25, after he shot his estranged wife's boyfriend. At his trial he raised the affirmative defense that he was acting under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance at the time of the incident, which would reduce the offense from murder to manslaughter. Without objection, the jury was instructed that, while the burden of proof as to intent was on the prosecution, the burden of persuasion was on defendant with respect to his defense of extreme emotional disturbance. Defendant was convicted of murder and he appealed. In affirming, the court ruled that, although he had not objected at trial, defendant could raise the issue of whether placing the burden on him to show extreme emotional disturbance violated his due process rights under U.S. Const. amend. XIV, because the recently decided case of Mullaney v. Wilbur had retroactive application. Nevertheless, putting the burden on defendant did not violate due process since extreme emotional disturbance was merely a mitigating circumstance that did not alter the prosecution's burden to prove intent, which was not negated by such disturbance.


OUTCOME: The judgment affirming a murder conviction was affirmed because placing the burden of persuasion on defendant to show the existence of extreme emotional disturbance did not violate his due process rights; allowing defendant to establish the existence of mitigating circumstances did not detract from the requirement that the prosecution prove intent beyond a reasonable doubt since extreme emotional disturbance did not negate intent.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- affirmative defense -- burden of proof -- defendant is not deprived of due process by placing upon him burden of persuasion on defense of acting under influence of extreme emotional disturbance to reduce homicide to manslaughter in first degree; unlike New York statutory scheme, State of Maine homicide statute, held unconstitutional by United States Supreme Court, has single category of homicide, which implies malice from act of killing and allows mitigation, in punishment only, for killing in heat of passion; New York requires prosecution to prove intent and allows defendant to prove mitigating circumstances, notwithstanding intent, whereas Maine makes intent relevant only to punishment and requires defendant to negate presumption thereof; statutes differ significantly and, accordingly, holding of unconstitutionality of Maine statute does not mandate like holding with respect to New York affirmative defense -- jury finding that defendant did not act under extreme mental trauma, affirmed by intermediate appellate court, is not reviewable -- there is jurisdiction over claim of improper distribution of burden of persuasion, although defendant failed to object at trial, since issue goes to essential validity of trial and, if claim were meritorious, trial would not have been conducted according to mandatory State procedures; defendant cannot be deprived of right to have arguments heard despite failure to object, since practice he attacks had not yet been called into question by United States Supreme Court at time of trial and intermediate appeal -- United States Supreme Court decision declaring Maine statute unconstitutional should be given retroactive effect, as was earlier case upon which it was based.

1. Due process limitations are not invaded by placing upon the defendant the burden of persuasion as to the defense of acting under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance in order to reduce the crime of homicide to manslaughter in the first degree. Unlike New York's statutory scheme, the homicide statute of the State of Maine, found unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court ( Mullaney v Wilbur, 421 U.S. 684), has only a single category of homicide, which implies premeditation or malice from the act of killing and allows mitigation, in punishment only, for killing in the heat of passion. New York requires that the prosecution prove the element of intent beyond a reasonable doubt, but permits the defendant to prove mitigating circumstances, whereas the Maine statute makes intent relevant only to punishment and unconstitutionally requires the defendant to negate a presumption thereof. Extreme emotional disturbance under the New York statute does not negate intent, while heat of passion under the Maine statute does. The statutes differ significantly and Mullaney, accordingly, does not mandate a holding that the New York affirmative defense is unconstitutional.

2. The finding by the jury that the defendant did not act under extreme mental trauma, affirmed by an intermediate appellate court, is not reviewable.

3. There is jurisdiction over the claim by the defendant of deprivation of due process in placing upon him the burden of proving extreme emotional disturbance, although he failed to object at the time of trial. The distribution of the burden of persuasion goes to the essential validity of a trial, such that the trial would not have been conducted according to procedures mandated by State law if the claim of error were meritorious. Moreover, the practice which the defendant attacks had not yet been called into question by the United States Supreme Court at the time of trial and intermediate appeal, and he cannot, accordingly, be deprived of the right to have his arguments heard for failure to object to such practice.

4. The United States Supreme Court decision in Mullaney v Wilbur should be given retroactive effect, as was the earlier case upon which it was based.

 

423 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wein v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 136; 347 N.E.2d 586; 383 N.Y.S.2d 225; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2390


January 13, 1976, Argued  
March 23, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff state taxpayer appealed from the order of the Supreme Court (New York), which declared constitutional a financial emergency statute providing for short-term borrowing to fund appropriations for the purpose of ameliorating the dire financial situation of New York City.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer alleged that the appropriation of $ 750 million to the city of New York and its municipal assistance corporation, to be funded by short-term state borrowing in the form of revenue anticipation notes, was an unconstitutional gift or loan of the state's credit in violation of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 8(1). The court held that the state constitution did not prohibit the state from giving or lending its money, as distinguished from its credit, to assist a municipal or other public corporation for a public purpose. The court also noted that the state constitution allowed short-term borrowing in advance of anticipated taxes and revenues to fund appropriations previously made. The court noted that the historical impetus for the constitutional prohibitions on gifts and lending of credit derived from the extensive and highly speculative subsidization of private railroad and canal companies with long-term debt obligations. The court held that the only constitutional restriction on the debt obligations was that they be issued in anticipation of revenues and that they be paid off in the next fiscal year, and that the state did not incur further debt in order to pay them off.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

State -- loan of credit -- revenue anticipation notes issued to fund appropriations for reimbursable advances to City of New York and Municipal Assistance Corporation do not violate constitutional proscription against giving or lending of credit of State to public corporations, since cash in hand may be given or loaned, and, where appropriation therefor has been made under balanced budget, funds may be obtained through short-term notes secured by committed revenues authentically anticipated within one year.

The issuance of revenue anticipation notes to fund appropriations of $ 250 million and $ 500 million for reimbursable advances to the City of New York and the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York respectively, while reaching the limits of valid constitutional practice, does not violate the proscription against the giving or lending of the credit of the State to public corporations (NY Const, art VII, § 8, subd 1). The Constitution does not prohibit the giving or lending of money to a municipal or other public corporation, such that cash in hand may be given or loaned, and, where the appropriation for a gift or loan has been made under a balanced budget, the transaction involves cash in hand, regardless of whether the funds are temporarily financed by borrowings. The required funds may be obtained through short-term notes, which are secured by committed tax, Federal grant and bond revenues authentically anticipated within one year and which may not be rolled over into long-term obligations or a new short-term issue. Such temporary obligations, properly administered, will not burden future taxpayers by the direct or indirect creation of a deficit in the year of repayment, in contrast to the constitutionally prohibited use of long-term borrowing to finance State gifts. Historically, the constitutional prohibition against gifts or loans of the State's credit was intended to protect posterity from the consequences of future contingent liabilities profligately incurred. The instant transactions present no such abuse, so long as the fiscal prospects are tenable.

 

424 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Horodner v. Fisher


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 680; 345 N.E.2d 571; 382 N.Y.S.2d 28; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2307


January 9, 1976, Submitted  
February 26, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) that dismissed a petition for a judgment setting aside the revocation of petitioner's license to operate a motor vehicle.


OVERVIEW: Within an 18-month period, petitioner was thrice convicted of speeding, which convictions served as the basis for the revocation of his driver's license. He was charged with a misdemeanor for driving while his license was revoked. His guilty plea resulted in a judgment of conviction, the appeal from which was dismissed for lack of prosecution. Petitioner brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7803 proceeding to set aside the revocation as well as to stay sentence on the misdemeanor conviction. Petitioner alleged that prior to revocation, the due process requirements of notice and hearing were not met and that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 510 was unconstitutional. The court affirmed the order and found the law to be constitutional. The court determined that petitioner, having been convicted for speeding on three occasions within a period of 18 months, had been entitled on each conviction to notice and hearing. The Legislature intended by such revocation to remove from the roads drivers who, by their conduct, had been found to have repeatedly placed their own personal interests above those of the rest of the citizenry. The due process protection of a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7803 proceeding was sufficient.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed and the law was declared constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Motor vehicles -- revocation of licenses -- section 510 of Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides for mandatory revocation, without notice or hearing, of license of driver convicted of three speeding violations within 18-month period, is constitutional -- driver has been entitled, on each conviction, to notice and hearing, and to warning as to effect of conviction, and, on notice of revocation, he may seek stay and, by way of article 78 proceeding, challenge action taken -- in view of purpose of statute, which was enacted to deal with emergency situation, due process of article 78 proceeding suffices.

 Section 510 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, which provides for mandatory revocation, without notice or a hearing, of the license of a driver who has been convicted of three speeding violations within an 18-month period, and which provides that such act of revocation shall be deemed administrative for purposes of judicial review, is constitutional. The driver has been entitled, on each conviction, to notice and hearing, and to a warning as to the effect of a conviction upon revocation or suspension of his license, and, on notice of revocation, he may seek a stay and, by way of an article 78 proceeding, challenge the action taken on such grounds as misidentification of the person subject to one or more of the convictions, reversal or dismissal on appeal of one or more of them, and miscalculation of the time within which they occurred. In view of the purpose of the statute, which was enacted to deal with an emergency situation, and remove from the roads of the State those drivers who, by their conduct, have been found to have repeatedly placed their own personal interests above those of the rest of the citizenry, the due process of an article 78 proceeding suffices.

 

425 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. McCartney


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 618; 345 N.E.2d 326; 381 N.Y.S.2d 855; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2276


January 16, 1976, Submitted  
February 24, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), denying defendant's request to compel an out-of-state witness to appear under the Uniform Act To Secure Attendance Of Witnesses From Without The State In Criminal Cases, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 640.10(3).


OVERVIEW: Defendant pleaded guilty to robbery in the second degree. At the pretrial suppression hearing, defendant sought to compel the attendance of a Maryland state trooper under the Uniform Act To Secure Attendance Of Witnesses From Without The State In Criminal Cases, N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 640.10(3). The trial court judge denied the request to issue the certificate requiring trooper's attendance because his testimony would not be of any determinative value since he did not participate in defendant's questioning. The appellate court affirmed. Defendant appealed. The court affirmed because the trial judge neither acted arbitrarily and capriciously, nor abused his discretion in denying defendant's request since defendant did not meet his burden to prove that trooper's attendance was both material and necessary.


OUTCOME: The intermediate court's affirmation of denial of defendant's request to compel trooper's attendance was affirmed because, since defendant did not meet his burden to prove that trooper's attendance was both material and necessary, and the trial judge neither acted arbitrarily and capriciously, nor abused his discretion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- compelling attendance of out-of-State witness -- to be entitled to issuance of process to compel attendance of out-of-State witness ( CPL 640.10), court of requesting State must determine materiality of witness; burden of showing such materiality is on party seeking to compel attendance of witness and it must be demonstrated that testimony of witness is relevant, admissible and of significance -- in instant case, defendant has not met burden of proof of materiality as to his attempt to secure attendance of Maryland State trooper at hearing to suppress statements made by defendant to New York police officials; Trial Judge did not act arbitrarily in denying defendant's request.

1. In order to be entitled to the issuance of process to compel the attendance of an out-of-State witness in a criminal case pursuant to CPL 640.10, the "Uniform Act To Secure The Attendance Of Witnesses From Without A State In Criminal Cases", the court of the requesting State must determine whether the witness sought is material. Unsupported statements that the witness is material or necessary are not sufficient. The party seeking the presence of the out-of-State witness should present evidence in the form of an affidavit of the witness or otherwise show that his testimony is material and necessary. The burden of showing materiality is on the party seeking to compel such attendance and it must be demonstrated by that party that the testimony of the witness is relevant, admissible and of significance.

2. In the instant case, defendant has not met his burden of proof of materiality with respect to his attempt to secure the attendance of a Maryland State trooper at a hearing to suppress statements made by defendant to New York police officials in Maryland. He has made only an unsupported statement that there were discrepancies between the testimony of two police investigators, but has made no attempt to point out the discrepancies and no effort to call one of the investigators to testify at the suppression hearing. A request for the issuance of a certificate to compel attendance of an out-of-State witness is addressed to the discretion of the Trial Judge and in the circumstances of the present case, it cannot be said that the Trial Judge acted arbitrarily and capriciously in denying defendant's request. In the absence of an abuse of discretion, the Court of Appeals may not overturn the determination of nonmateriality.

 

426 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bender v. New York City Health & Hospitals Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 662; 345 N.E.2d 561; 382 N.Y.S.2d 18; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2305


January 12, 1976, Argued  
February 19, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Bender v New York City Health & Hosps. Corp .: Order reversed and case remitted to Supreme Court, Queens County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein, with costs to plaintiffs to abide the event.

In Matter of Economou v New York City Health & Hosps. Corp.: Order modified and matter remitted to the Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed, with costs to petitioners to abide the event.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant injured individuals filed personal injury actions against appellee municipal medical facilities corporation (corporation) and filed notices of claim with the city rather than the corporation. The Appellate Divisions of the Supreme Court in the Second and First Judicial Departments (New York) denied in matter one and granted in matter two leave to serve a late notice of claim upon the corporation. Review was sought.


OVERVIEW: The appeals stemmed from the creation of a corporation to operate the municipal medical facilities in New York City. Along with changing the operating responsibility, the notice of claim procedure was changed, requiring filing of a verified notice of claim with the corporation, not the city, prior to the commencement of a lawsuit under § 20 of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation Act, codified at N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e.The injured individuals sought leave to file notices of claim on the corporation, nunc pro tunc. The appellate division concluded that failure to serve notice of claim was a fatal defect. The court adopted a doctrine of estoppel in the notice of claim area, holding that where a governmental subdivision acted wrongfully, inducing reliance by a party who was entitled to rely and who changed his position to his detriment, that subdivision should have been estopped from asserting a right that it otherwise could have raised. To cure the defect, the court held that a motion to file a notice of claim nunc pro tunc was proper. The issue could then be litigated prior to proceeding to trial on evidentiary facts.


OUTCOME: The orders of the appellate division were reversed in matter one and modified in matter two and the matters were remitted to special term for a consideration of evidentiary facts as to whether or not there should be an estoppel against the corporation.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- notice of claim -- estoppel -- doctrine of estoppel should apply in area of notice of claim to insure that filing statutes are not traps for unwary where governmental subdivision has wrongfully induced detrimental reliance by party failing to file notice -- estoppel may best be asserted by motion to file notice of claim nunc pro tunc, since matter could then be litigated prior to trial -- record does not present facts sufficient to determine if filing nunc pro tunc should be accorded to plaintiffs, who filed timely notices of tort claims against municipal hospitals with City of New York instead of New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and were not informed of statute transferring functions from city to corporation; Special Term should consider evidentiary facts relative to allegations that there was delay in applying statute, that date of transfer was not publicly discoverable, that autonomy of corporation was not indicated in such manner as that of other autonomous agencies, and that inaction of city and its Corporation Counsel is attributable to corporation.

1. The doctrine of estoppel should be operative in the area of notice of claim. Where a governmental subdivision negligently or wrongfully induces reliance by a party who changes his position to his detriment, that subdivision should be estopped from asserting a right or defense otherwise available, and the application of such estoppel to the failure to file a notice of claim may insure that statutes like section 50-e of the General Municipal Law are not traps for the unwary.

2. Estoppel may best be asserted by motion to file a notice of claim nunc pro tunc, since the matter could then be litigated prior to trial, in contrast to proceeding by way of service of an amended complaint setting forth facts sufficient to excuse filing.

3. The record does not present facts sufficient to determine if a filing nunc pro tunc should be accorded to the plaintiffs, who filed timely notices of malpractice and negligence claims against municipal hospitals with the City of New York instead of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and were not informed of the statute transferring operating responsibility for municipal hospitals from the city to the corporation. Special Term should consider the evidentiary facts relative to the allegations that the corporation and city refrained for a time from applying the statute, that the date of transfer of responsibilities was not publicly discoverable, that the autonomy of the corporation was not indicated in such manner as that of other autonomous city agencies, and that the inaction of the city and its Corporation Counsel is attributable to the corporation.

 

427 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Schacht v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


39 N.Y.2d 28; 346 N.E.2d 518; 382 N.Y.S.2d 717; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2372; 91 L.R.R.M. 2774


January 8, 1976, Argued  
February 19, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant retiree challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department which modified and affirmed an order and judgment of the supreme court granting respondent city's motion for summary judgment in an action to collect benefits from a previous retirement plan that she was removed from by negotiations between the union and the city.


OVERVIEW: Prior to her retirement, the retiree held a position with the city. Her potential retirement and pension benefits were governed by regulations known as the "Career and Salary Plan" and the benefits for persons with her title were removed from that plan and became governed by the "Managerial Pay Plan." Contending that she had vested rights in the "Career and Salary Plan" and that through this plan she would have been entitled to greater pension and retirement benefits, the retiree brought an action to recover additional benefits. The court affirmed the summary judgment, holding that any claim that she may have had for the benefits under the "Career and Salary Plan" had been effectively waived by an agreement made by her collective bargaining representative and by her own actions. The court held that the retiree, having designated the union to be her agent for collective bargaining purposes, was bound by agreements made by that union on her behalf and further held that she was not entitled reject certain acts of her bargaining representative and accept others.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed, holding that the retiree designated the union to be her agent for collective bargaining purposes and was bound by agreements made by that union on her behalf.


HEADNOTES

Civil service -- retirement -- retirement and pension benefits of plaintiff had been governed by "Career and Salary Plan" until January 1, 1971 when her benefits became governed by "Managerial Pay Plan"; any claim plaintiff may have had for greater benefits under "Career and Salary Plan" was waived by agreement made by her collective bargaining representative and by her own actions; plaintiff is bound by agreement made on her behalf -- waiver not against public policy.

1. Until January 1, 1971 the potential retirement and pension benefits of plaintiff, who held the position of Assistant Director, Child Welfare, in the Department of Social Services of the City of New York, were governed by regulations known as the "Career and Salary Plan". As of that date such benefits for persons with her title became governed by the "Managerial Pay Plan". Any claim plaintiff may have had for the greater benefits under the "Career and Salary Plan" was waived by an agreement made by her collective bargaining representative and by her own actions. Plaintiff, having designated the representative to be her agent, is bound by that agreement made on her behalf and she may not reject certain acts of her representative and accept others.

2. The waiver is not against public policy.

 

428 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Levy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 653; 345 N.E.2d 556; 382 N.Y.S.2d 13; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2304


January 7, 1976, Argued  
February 17, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parents sought review of orders of the Family Court, Queens County (New York) and the Family Court, New York County (New York), which granted the parents' applications for payment of full tuition for special residential educational training for their handicapped children as well as of all related transportation expenses, but denied their applications for maintenance payments and directed them to pay maintenance expenses.


OVERVIEW: The parents' children were in need of special residential educational training. The parents challenged Fam. Ct. Act § 234, which authorized family court to direct parents of handicapped children, other than children who were blind or deaf, to contribute to the maintenance of such children in connection with their education. The parents contended that § 234 was unconstitutional because it denied them equal protection of the law. The court affirmed the order below, holding that a rational basis existed for the distinction made in relieving the parents of blind and deaf children from any financial responsibility in connection with their children's education while at the same time requiring parents whose children were otherwise handicapped to contribute to the maintenance component of educational expenses. History and tradition accorded special recognition to the blind and to the deaf in the field of education. In addition, there was no difference in the authority of the courts within and without New York City to direct a parent financially able to do so to contribute to the maintenance component of the expense of education of his handicapped child.


OUTCOME: The orders requiring the parents to make maintenance payments for their handicapped children were affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- education of handicapped children -- Family Court Act ( § 234), which authorizes Family Court in New York City to direct parents of handicapped children, other than children who are blind or deaf, to contribute to maintenance of such children in connection with their education, not unconstitutional -- rational basis exists for distinction between parents of blind and deaf children and parents of children otherwise handicapped -- historically, special recognition accorded to blind and deaf -- no difference in authority of courts within and without New York City to direct parents to contribute to maintenance.

1. Section 234 of the Family Court Act which authorizes the Family Court in New York City to direct parents of handicapped children, other than children who are blind or deaf, to contribute to the maintenance of such children in connection with their education, which is free (NY Const, art XI, § 1; Education Law, § 3202, subd 1; § 4403; Family Ct Act, § 231 et seq.), is not unconstitutional.

2. A rational basis does exist for the distinction made in relieving the parents of blind and deaf children from any financial responsibility in connection with their children's education while at the same time requiring parents whose children are otherwise handicapped to contribute to maintenance.

3. As a matter of history and tradition our society has accorded special recognition to the blind and to the deaf. The Federal Government has also long accorded privileges and benefits to the blind which are not available to other handicapped persons. The Legislature acted rationally when it took into account historical distinctions. The State government is not required to withdraw the benefits conferred on blind and deaf if it is unable to provide totally comprehensive programs.

4. There is no difference in the authority of the courts within and without New York City to direct a parent financially able to do so to contribute to maintenance. The Family Court Act ( § 234) expressly grants the authority within the city. Exercise of a comparable authority outside the city has been upheld as implicit in the power of the court to enter a "suitable order" under the Family Court Act ( §§ 232, 413, 414, 416).

 

429 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dutchess County Pharmaceutical Soc. v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 887; 346 N.E.2d 548; 382 N.Y.S.2d 746; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2331


January 13, 1976, Argued  
February 12, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Drugs and druggists -- constitutionality of statute requiring posting of selling prices -- section 6826 of Education Law, which provides access to information about cost of prescription drugs by requiring pharmacies to post their current selling prices of 150 such drugs which are most frequently prescribed, together with their usual dossages, as set out on list required to be prepared by State Board of Pharmacy, is within permissible scope of State's power to regulate  [***2] drug stores, nor is it unconstitutional either for vagueness or for delegation of power to board to draw up list in accordance with standards set out by statute. 

 

430 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Judiz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 529; 344 N.E.2d 399; 381 N.Y.S.2d 467; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2260


January 5, 1976, Argued  
February 10, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the order of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed defendant's conviction for possession of an imitation pistol in violation of the Administrative Code of the City of New York § 436-5.0(g).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted under a local ordinance for possessing a toy pistol which resembled a real gun. Defendant appealed the conviction and alleged that the ordinance was unconstitutional because it permitted a finding of criminality without a finding of specific intent to use the toy in an illegal manner. Defendant also alleged that N.Y. Penal Law § 265.00 preempted the ordinance because the state statute required proof of defendant's intent to use the toy gun and that intent was not inferred from possession. Defendant's conviction was affirmed. On further review, the court also affirmed the conviction and held that the local ordinance was a valid exercise of police powers delegated to the municipality. The court found that there was a reasonable relationship between the ordinance and the public welfare. Plaintiff state delegated the exercise of police powers to the municipality and, therefore, the ordinance was entitled to a presumption of constitutionality. The state statute did not preempt the ordinance because the ordinance and the state statute were not at odds with one another and plaintiff did not evidence an intent to occupy the entire field.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction under an ordinance for possessing an imitation pistol and held that the ordinance was a valid exercise of the police powers and that a state statute did not preempt the ordinance.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- possession of toy pistol -- section 436-5.0 (subd g) of Administrative Code of City of New York, providing it shall be unlawful to possess toy pistol resembling real gun, is valid exercise of police powers delegated to city -- State law, which is neither at odds with nor exclusive of city statute, does not pre-empt field of legislation -- accordingly, conviction of defendant, apprehended while in possession of toy pistol resembling Luger, was proper.

1. Subdivision g of section 436-5.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which provides it shall be unlawful to possess a toy pistol resembling a real gun in certain particulars, is constitutional. The statute is a valid exercise of the police powers delegated to the city (NY Const, art IX, § 2; Municipal Home Rule Law, § 10). There is a reasonable relationship between the public welfare and the act proscribed.

2. The State law (Penal Law, §§ 265.01, 265.15) does not pre-empt the field of legislation. It evinces an intent to cover most of the possible categories of weapons for which it deems some sanction necessary when these are used with illegal intent while the city statute is aimed at the prevention of a particular type of abuse. The one does not depend on the other and they are not inconsistent with one another. Therefore, the State statute is neither at odds with nor exclusive of the city statute.

3. Accordingly, the conviction of defendant, who was apprehended while in possession of a toy pistol resembling a gun known as a Luger, was proper.

 

431 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Carey Transp. v. Triborough Bridge & Tunnel Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 545; 345 N.E.2d 281; 381 N.Y.S.2d 811; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2264


November 20, 1975, Argued  
January 15, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs in all courts to appellant, the orders and judgments of Supreme Court, New York County, vacated, and judgment granted in favor of appellant Authority in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant bridge and tunnel authority challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the trial court's judgment declaring that the franchise bus rate applicable to general transportation buses was applicable to plaintiff airport bus company's franchise buses, enjoined authority from collecting tolls from franchise buses, and granted judgment to bus company.


OVERVIEW: The court found that the tolls and charges set and collected by authority for bus company were valid. Authority was a governmental enterprise whose purpose was to operate its tunnels and bridges on economic principles, just as any entrepreneur might. Its charges and tolls were not regulated by statute, or by regulatory authority. The legislature lawfully empowered authority to fix rates, without limitation, assuming that economic and political forces would control the exercise of the toll-charging function, subject always to legislative correction if the power were abused. It therefore could charge higher tolls to differentially classified tunnel and bridge users. Authority had this power so long as there was not involved any of the invidious discriminations condemned by statute or constitution, or some utterly arbitrary discrimination not related to economic considerations or some accepted public goal. Bus company's claims of an improper delegation of power had to be left to the legislature. Assuming that authority's power to set and collect rates had to be exercised on a uniform basis within classes of users of its facilitates, it did not violate any classification principles.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the orders and judgments and granted judgment in favor of authority.


HEADNOTES

Public authorities -- toll rates -- Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority may fix such tolls and charges for use of its facilities as, in its judgment, will best serve its economic and public policy goals, and may set higher tolls and charges for some users of its facilities than for others, so long as invidious illicit discriminations are not practiced and differentials are not utterly arbitrary and unrelated to economic considerations or some accepted public goal -- it could properly distinguish between what it defined as general purpose buses, those engaged in general transportation of public, and special purpose buses, which include those which travel between fixed stations to and from airports, beaches, raceways and sports stadiums, and, based on that distinction, charge higher tolls for special purpose buses -- assuming its power to set rates must be exercised on some uniform basis within classes of users of its facilities, it has not violated any principles of classification -- to differentiate toll charges according to purpose of most of passengers is permissible basis.

1. The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which is empowered by statute to fix tolls and charges for the use of its bridge and tunnel facilities, and which has had no limitation placed upon its rate-fixing power by statute or by any regulatory authority, may fix such tolls and charges as, in its judgment, will best serve its economic and public policy goals, and may set higher tolls and charges for some users of its facilities than it sets for other users thereof, so long as invidious illicit discriminations are not practiced and differentials are not utterly arbitrary and unrelated to economic considerations or some accepted public goal. It could properly distinguish between what it defined as general purpose buses, those franchised buses, whether publicly or privately owned, which are engaged in the general transportation of the public, and special purpose buses, which include those franchised buses which travel between fixed stations to and from the airports, beaches, raceways and sports stadiums, and, based on that distinction, charge higher tolls for the special purpose buses.

2. Assuming that the Authority's power to set rates must be exercised on some uniform basis within classes of users of its facilities, it has not violated any principles of classification. Special purpose buses are distinguishable from general purpose buses, in that the former are associated with recreational travel or with high cost means of interurban, national or international travel, and are used for the special purpose of the passengers, most often without periodicity and at separated irregular time intervals, while the latter are forms of mass transportation from place to place in the course of daily life, usually regardless of the purpose of the passengers. To differentiate toll charges according to the purpose of most of the passengers is a permissible basis.

 

432 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lane v. Mt. Vernon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 344; 342 N.E.2d 571; 379 N.Y.S.2d 798; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2245


November 26, 1975, Submitted  
January 8, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owner challenged the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which modified the order of the trial court in plaintiff's action to have defendant city's ordinance declared illegal, void and unconstitutional by declaring Mount Vernon, N.Y., City Building Code § 21.04(h) constitutional and valid and, as modified, affirmed the trial court's order and judgment.


OVERVIEW: The property owner argued that the assessment of charges against his property amounted to a private law passed to levy a tax upon his land and that, as such, it was unconstitutional. He contended that he received no notice and that as a matter of due process the assessment could not bind him. The court affirmed the intermediate appellate court's order. It concluded that the assessment was not a tax levy but was enacted pursuant to the police power of the State, delegated to local governments. The court observed that when a local government, in the proper exercise of its delegated powers, summarily abated a public nuisance, it could compel the property owner to bear the cost of abatement. It held that the exercise of police power in issue was not only statutorily authorized but was consonant as well with common-law principles and was constitutional. The court found that it was unnecessary for the city to serve the property owner because at the time when service was appropriate, the city did serve the owner of record. It reasoned that the city was entitled to rely on publication to bind those parties who were not, at that time, discoverable with a reasonable amount of effort.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's order, which modified the trial court's order by declaring a city ordinance constitutional and valid and, as modified, affirmed the trial court's order and judgment in the property owner's action against the city.


HEADNOTES

Municipal corporations -- assessment -- defendant city had power to assess cost of clearing plaintiff's land, where building thereon was unsound and in danger of collapse, against property -- assessment not tax but enacted pursuant to police power of State -- service by city sufficient -- moreover, plaintiff is chargeable with constructive notice of proceeding.

1. Because, as the result of a fire, the plaintiff's building was unsound and in imminent danger of collapse, the building commissioner of defendant city had the land cleared. The assessment of the cost of this clearance against the property does not amount to a private law passed to levy a tax upon plaintiff's land and is not unconstitutional. The assessment was not a tax levy but was enacted pursuant to the police power of the State, delegated, under the State Constitution, to local governments. (NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [c], par [ii], cl [10]; General City Law, § 20, subd 35; Mount Vernon City Building Code, § 21.01, subd [d]; § 21.03; § 21.04, subds [d], [h].)

2. The language of the constitutional delegation of the police power is broad enough to permit the enabling legislation and the local ordinances enacted under it.

3. The power of the Legislature to enlarge the category of public nuisances is not limited to those known at common law.

4. The exercise of the police power here involved is not only statutorily authorized but is in accord also with common-law principles.

5. Although plaintiff bought the property after it had been cleared, it was unnecessary for the city to serve plaintiff. The city did serve the owner of record. Although due process requires personal service upon owners who are known or who can be readily ascertained, the city was entitled to rely on publication, a form of substituted service, to bind those parties who were not discoverable with a reasonable amount of effort.

6. Moreover, plaintiff is chargeable with constructive notice of this proceeding. The records of the violations which culminated in the assessment are available for examination at the department of buildings and are public records. They state expressly that failure to remedy the violations will subject an owner to the penalties outlined in the building code, which, in turn, outlines the assessment procedure followed here.

 

433 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dalton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


38 N.Y.2d 222; 342 N.E.2d 493; 379 N.Y.S.2d 691; 1976 N.Y. LEXIS 2243


November 18, 1975, Argued  
January 6, 1976, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified and case remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed by permission from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment convicting defendant of possession and of sale of narcotics and related offenses. Defendant claimed that the trial court improperly excluded the testimony of an alibi witness.


OVERVIEW: The trial court excluded one of defendant's alibi witnesses because he had not listed the witness in accordance with N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.20. The court noted that a similar notice-of-alibi statute had been declared unconstitutional and the decision applied retroactively. Although the exclusion was error, the People argued that it was harmless error and that the evidence was merely cumulative because defendant's relatives and a friend had also supplied alibi testimony. The court held that an error that involved defendant's constitutional rights could not be considered harmless unless there was no reasonable possibility that it might have contributed to the conviction. Furthermore, the evidence was not cumulative because the excluded witness was more disinterested than the others were and therefore less susceptible to impeachment for personal bias. A new trial was ordered on the drug sale charge only, because the possession charges were based on the result of a search that occurred on a different day, which was not implicated by the alleged alibi.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment by reversing the conviction for selling narcotics and remanding for a new trial on that charge only. The convictions were affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- alibi -- on trial of defendant for sale of dangerous drug to police officer, erroneous exclusion of alibi testimony by trial court for failure to comply with notice statute, later held unconstitutional which holding was to be applied retroactively, was not harmless beyond reasonable doubt; although witness whose testimony was excluded may not have been completely disinterested, she was less susceptible to impeachment for personal bias than other alibi witnesses and, therefore, her testimony could not be considered cumulative; in addition, exclusion left gap in alibi defense which prosecutor exploited; new trial ordered.

On the trial of defendant under an indictment charging him, inter alia, with the sale of a dangerous drug to a plain-clothes police officer, the court held that certain alibi testimony of a defense witness should be excluded for failure to comply with the notice-of-alibi provisions of CPL 250.20. Several months after a verdict of guilty, the United States Supreme Court held a notice-of-alibi statute unconstitutional ( Wardius v Oregon, 412 U.S. 470). Thereafter the Court of Appeals held a similar New York statute unconstitutional ( People v Bush, 33 NY2d 921) and later decided that the decision should be applied retroactively ( People v Morales, 37 NY2d 262). Accordingly, the trial court's ruling was erroneous and, on the record, the erroneous exclusion of the alibi testimony was not harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. Because of that ruling, the alibi defense rested on the testimony of two of defendant's relatives and a close family friend. Although the witness whose testimony was excluded may not have been completely disinterested, she was less susceptible to impeachment for personal bias and, therefore, her testimony could not be considered merely cumulative. In addition, the exclusion left a gap in the alibi defense which the prosecutor exploited. In these circumstances, the conviction must be reversed and a new trial ordered on that count of the indictment.

 

434 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Goldberg v. Corcoran


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


153 A.D.2d 113; 549 N.Y.S.2d 503; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 16555



December 29, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order and judgment is modified by deleting the provision thereof which granted that branch of the defendant's motion which was to dismiss those claims alleged on behalf of the plaintiff Donald D. Goldberg, and substituting therefor a provision denying that branch of the motion and declaring that Insurance Law § 5108 is constitutional; as so modified the order and judgment is affirmed, with costs to the respondent.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff surgeon brought a declaratory judgment action that challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Ins. Law § 5108. The Supreme Court, Queens County (New York) dismissed the complaint for failure to state a cause of action and the surgeon appealed.


OVERVIEW: The physician challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Ins. Law § 5108 insofar as it limited the amount that a provider of health services may demand in payment for services rendered under the New York "no-fault" law. On appeal, the court held that § 5108 is constitutional and that the adoption of fee schedules under § 5108 did not contravene the Due Process Clauses of the United States or the New York Constitutions. The court found the legislature was acting in pursuit of permissible state objectives in enacting § 5108 and that the means adopted by the statute were reasonably related to the accomplishment of those objectives. The court found § 5108 was not unconstitutionally vague and that a person of average intelligence would understand § 5108 to constitute a prohibition against accepting any payments in excess of the fee schedule, including payments voluntarily made by patients. The court found § 5108 did not deny equal protection under the law because there was a reasonable relationship between the stated legislative objective and the means employed to realize it. The court found that § 5108 did not violate the physician's right to privacy.


OUTCOME: The court modified the dismissal of the action by declaring the insurance law constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Constitutionality of Medical Fee Schedule -- Due Process

1. Insurance Law § 5108, insofar as it limits the amount that a provider of health services may demand or request in payment for services rendered under the no-fault insurance law, is constitutional; the adoption of fee schedules pursuant to the statute does not contravene the due process clauses of either the Federal or State Constitution. The purpose of the statute and the fee schedules promulgated thereunder is to significantly reduce the amount paid by insurers for medical services and, thereby, help contain the no-fault premium; the Legislature was acting in pursuit of permissible State objectives in enacting the statute and the means adopted by the statute are reasonably related to the accomplishment of those objectives.

Parties -- Fictitious Plaintiff -- Class Representative

2. In an action challenging the constitutionality of Insurance Law § 5108, which limits the amount that a provider of health services may demand or request in payment for services rendered under the no-fault insurance law, the lower court correctly dismissed all claims asserted on behalf of a fictitious plaintiff, who supposedly represented the interests of those patients whom the real plaintiff, a physician, refused to treat under the no-fault fee schedules promulgated pursuant to the statute, since no valid lawsuit may be brought by a person who does not exist. Moreover, plaintiff physician may not serve as the representative of his patients as a class, since their pecuniary interests are in conflict with his own.

Declaratory Judgments -- Form of Relief -- Constitutional Challenge

3. In an action challenging the constitutionality of Insurance Law § 5108, which limits the amount that a provider of health services may demand or request in payment for services rendered under the no-fault insurance law, the lower court should not have dismissed the entire complaint for failure to state a cause of action where plaintiff presented a justiciable issue, but should have made a declaration as to the constitutionality of the statute.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Constitutionality of Fee Schedule -- Right to Contract

4. Insurance Law § 5108, which limits the amount that a provider of health services may demand or request in payment for services rendered under the no-fault insurance law, does not unreasonably impair the right of physicians to contract, since the right to make contracts is not absolute, but is subject to regulation where, as here, the public need requires.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Constitutionality of Fee Schedule -- Vagueness

5. Insurance Law § 5108, which limits the amount that a provider of health services may request or demand in payment for services rendered under the no-fault insurance law, is not unconstitutionally vague; subdivision (c) thereof states that "no provider * * * may demand or request any payment in addition to the charges authorized pursuant to this section", and a person of average intelligence would understand that to constitute a prohibition against accepting any payments in excess of the fee schedule promulgated pursuant to the statute, including payments "voluntarily" made by patients.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Constitutionality of Fee Schedule -- Equal Protection

6. Insurance Law § 5108, which limits the amount that a provider of health services may request or demand in payment for services rendered under the no-fault insurance law, does not deny plaintiff physician equal protection under the law; unless a suspect classification is involved or a fundamental right is affected, neither of which is true here, the challenged classification will survive if there is any rational relationship between it and the legislative goal to be achieved, and inasmuch as there is a reasonable affinity between the stated legislative objective, viz., to lower premiums, and the means employed to realize it, viz., a fee schedule for medical providers, the statute is not violative of the Equal Protection Clause.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Constitutionality of Fee Schedule -- Right to Privacy

7. Insurance Law § 5108, which limits the amount that a provider of health services may request or demand in payment for services rendered under the no-fault insurance law, does not violate the right to privacy of plaintiff physician since the physician/patient relationship is not entitled to the same protection as is afforded in matters of procreation; notwithstanding the importance of a patient's decision in choosing a no-fault physician, such a choice simply does not have such an intimate or sensitive character as to warrant protection under the constitutional doctrine of right to privacy.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Constitutionality of Fee Schedule -- Police Power

8. Insurance Law § 5108, which limits the amount that a provider of health services may request or demand in payment for services rendered under the no-fault insurance law, is not unconstitutional since the provisions designed to control the amounts to be awarded for medical services, i.e., fee schedules for medical providers, are warranted as police regulations.

 

435 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ohrenstein


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


153 A.D.2d 342; 549 N.Y.S.2d 962; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 15886



December 21, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on or about June 15, 1988, affirmed; and application for a writ of prohibition, granted, to the extent that respondents are prohibited from prosecuting the petitioners under indictment No. 10173/87 as to those counts that relate to Category 3 employees, and otherwise denied, without costs and without disbursements, as indicated in this court's order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After a New York County Supreme Court (New York) dismissed several counts in an indictment brought against petitioners, three state senators, the state senate minority leader, and the minority leader's chief of staff (collectively, the senators), the senators sought mandamus and prohibition to prevent respondent district attorney from prosecuting them for remaining counts claiming conspiracy, grand larceny, and offering false instruments.


OVERVIEW: The state claimed, among other things, that the senators' utilization of legislative aides in state senatorial campaigns prior to 1987 constituted an impermissible use of state employees and that payments of salaries out of the legislative budget for their services constituted violations of general penal laws. The senators challenged the applicability of the penal statutes to legislative campaigning, arguing that the prosecution impermissibly intruded into constitutionally protected areas affecting the separation of powers and responsibilities and violated their constitutional privileges under the Speech or Debate Clause. The court held that (1) during the period covered by the indictment, there were no legislative standards, rules, or guidelines regarding the proper duties of "category 3" legislative employees, (2) the assignment of employees to campaign work only was a legislative personnel judgment in an area wholly within the legislature's purview and not subject to judicial or prosecutorial oversight, (3) prosecution would violate the senator's due process rights, and (4) the conspiracy count was also rendered meaningless based on the court's determinations.


OUTCOME: The court granted the application for a writ of prohibition to the extent that the state was prohibited from prosecuting the senators for counts related to category 3 employees, and otherwise it was denied.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition -- When Remedy Available -- Prevention of Criminal Prosecution

1. CPLR article 78 relief in the nature of prohibition is available to the Minority Leader of the State Senate, his chief of staff, and two State Senators to prevent their criminal prosecution under an indictment charging them with conspiracy, grand larceny and offering false instruments for filing arising out of allegations that they paid political campaign workers out of the State treasury by claiming that the workers were legislative employees, since prohibition is allowed when a court acts without jurisdiction in a matter over which it has no power over the subject matter or where it exceeds its authorized powers in a proceeding over which it has jurisdiction; where one branch of government oversteps another coordinate branch's functions, a writ of prohibition may issue. Moreover, an article 78 proceeding is generally proper to determine whether a statute has been applied in an unconstitutional manner, and the instant case presents issues of separation of powers and constitutional violations in the application of various criminal statutes.

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Speech or Debate Clause -- Hiring Legislative Employees to Work on Election Campaigns

2.
