In a proceeding in the nature of prohibition in which petitioners, the Minority Leader of the State Senate, his chief of staff, and two State Senators, seek to prevent their criminal prosecution on charges of conspiracy, larceny and offering false instruments for filing arising out of allegations that they paid political campaign workers out the State treasury by claiming that the workers were legislative employees, the Speech or Debate Clause (NY Const, art III, § 11), which confers immunity on legislators for their remarks in the Legislature, is of limited application since the provision is not intended to confer a general exemption upon legislators from liability or process in criminal cases, but is, rather, directed to matters which must be an integral part of the deliberative and communicative process of legislators. The indictment cannot be legally sufficient if it is based on testimony which may require inquiry into legislative acts or the motivation for such acts, and although Grand Jury evidence is usually viewed in the light most favorable to the People, that rule does not apply where the constitutional rights protected by the Speech or Debate Clause are affected. The obligation is on the prosecutor to show that no privileged legislative act would be implicated, and the People herein failed to meet their obligation with respect to the activities of three individuals who did prepare reports and arranged hearings on noncampaign matters.

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Separation of Powers -- Speech or Debate Clause -- Hiring Legislative Employees to Work on Election Campaigns

3. In a proceeding in the nature of prohibition in which petitioners, the Minority Leader of the State Senate, his chief of staff, and two State Senators, seek to prevent their criminal prosecution on charges of conspiracy, larceny and offering false instruments for filing arising out of allegations that they arranged to have political campaign workers paid out of the State treasury on the premise that they were legislative employees, the Speech or Debate Clause (NY Const, art III, § 11) does not meet all of the separation of powers concerns implicated by a prosecution against a legislator since the separation of powers doctrine is not contiguous with the Speech or Debate Clause, but has a far broader reach. There must be restraint on the part of the judiciary in responding to invitations to intervene in the internal affairs of the Legislature as a coordinate branch of government, and there are many activities of legislators, concededly not covered by the Speech or Debate Clause, which fall within the ambit of a legislator's work and are nonjusticiable. The relevant considerations concerning nonjusticiable political questions addressed in Baker v Carr (369 US 186) are implicated and inextricably entwined with the facts herein to the extent that they relate to the issue of whether the assignment of legislative employees to work on senatorial campaigns falls within the proper duties of legislative employment.

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Separation of Powers -- Nonjusticiable Controversy -- Hiring Legislative Employees to Work on Election Campaigns

4. In a proceeding in the nature of prohibition in which petitioners, the Minority Leader of the State Senate, his chief of staff, and two State Senators, seek to prevent their criminal prosecution on charges of conspiracy, larceny and offering false instruments for filing arising out of allegations that they arranged to have political campaign workers paid out of the State treasury on the premise that the workers were legislative employees, such prosecution is prohibited since the propriety of work assignments of legislative employees is a matter which is singularly within the Legislature's own purview, involving as it does the internal procedures and administration of the functions and peculiar duties of that body, which should be free from interference from another branch of government, particularly where the payments herein were authorized pursuant to a broadly worded appropriations bill which has never been directly challenged; moreover, the Minority Leader is given broad power by statute to appoint such employees to assist him in the performance of his duties (see, Legislative Law §§ 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10).

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution for Legislative Acts -- Separation of Powers -- Nonjusticiable Controversy -- Hiring of Legislative Employees to Work on Election Campaigns -- Lack of Penal Standard

5. In a proceeding in the nature of prohibition in which petitioners, the Minority Leader of the State Senate, his chief of staff, and two State Senators, seek to prevent their criminal prosecution on charges of conspiracy, larceny and offering false instruments for filing arising out of allegations that they paid political campaign workers out of the State treasury by asserting that the workers were legislative employees, the provision of the State Constitution prohibiting gifts of State money (NY Const, art VII, § 8) does not, standing alone, provide the kind of clear and unambiguous guidance necessary to enable appropriate judicial resolution of the instant nonjusticiable controversy, which involves not an individual case determination but, rather, a wide-scale particularization of the propriety of the specific activities and terms and conditions of employment of numerous employees working in a broad range of categories. It is not the court's function to engage in such "itemization", and the failure of the Legislature to act in promulgating appropriate standards governing the duties and assignments of its employees, a matter within its sphere of authority,

 

436 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


American Motors Sales Corp. v. Brown


[No number in original]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


152 A.D.2d 343; 548 N.Y.S.2d 791; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 15832



December 13, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed, without costs or disbursements; and it is further,

Ordered that Renewed Motion No. 3703 by the petitioner American Motors Sales Corporation to dismiss the appeal of the Attorney-General is granted; and it is further,

Ordered that Cross Motion No. 3705 by the Attorney-General for leave to file an amicus curiae brief on the appeal of Leon W. Brown is granted; and it is further,

Ordered that Cross Motion No. 3704 by Leon W. Brown for leave to adopt the note of issue, brief and record on appeal filed by the Attorney-General as his own, is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant purchaser challenged the decision of the Supreme Court (New York), which granted respondent auto dealer's petition to vacate an arbitration award in favor of the purchaser. The arbitrator held that an automobile purchased for personal use from an automobile dealer, was protected by the provisions of the New Car Lemon Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198-a.


OVERVIEW: The dealer argued that the vehicle at issue was not a new motor vehicle and thus the purchaser was not entitled to seek compulsory arbitration of his claim under § 198-a(k). The dealer further contended that the vehicle constituted a used motor vehicle within the meaning of the Used Car Lemon Law, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198-b(a)(2), which did not contain a compulsory arbitration provision at the time of purchaser's complaint. The court held that a literal reading of the relevant provisions of the New and Used Car Lemon Laws led to the logical conclusion that while the purchaser fit within the term consumer as defined by the New Car Lemon Law, the vehicle which he purchased fell within the definition of a used motor vehicle. The court also stated that a subsequent amendment to N.Y. Gen. Oblig. Law § 198-b extending the right to compulsory arbitration used motor vehicle owners reflected a legislative recognition that the New Car Lemon Law did not encompass used motor vehicles. Therefore the court held that it agreed with the trial court's determination that the arbitrator exceeded his authority in rendering an award in the purchaser's favor.


OUTCOME: The decision was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Used Car

1. An automobile purchased by a consumer for personal use from an automobile dealer, which at the time of its purchase had an odometer reading of approximately 5,600 miles, was less than two years old, and was covered by a manufacturer's warranty, is not protected by the provisions of the New Car Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a) and, hence, the consumer may not avail himself of the compulsory arbitration provisions of said law. The vehicle purchased by the consumer fell within the description of a "used motor vehicle" under the Used Car Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-b [a] [2]) which specifically defines such vehicles as those "which ha[ve] been driven more than the limited use necessary in moving or road testing a new vehicle prior to delivery". In determining legislative intent, courts should look to the specific statute in question and all statutes relating to the general subject matter, and although the consumer herein is a "consumer" within the definition of the New Car Lemon Law, the vehicle which he purchased was clearly not a "new" car for the purpose of that statute; the vehicle does not qualify as a "new motor vehicle" pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 462 (11) and the invoice stated that the car was "used". Inasmuch as statutes should be harmoniously interpreted, a reading of the New and Used Car Lemon Laws indicates that the former applies only to individuals who fit within its statutory definition of "consumer" and who purchase a "new motor vehicle". Accordingly, the arbitrator's conclusion that the car in question was "new" was not supported by the evidence or other basis in reason, and the resulting award is vacated.

Appeal -- Parties Aggrieved -- Attorney-General

2. In a proceeding to vacate an arbitration award rendered pursuant to the New Car Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a) in which petitioner manufacturer alleged that the statute was unconstitutional but the Supreme Court did not reach that issue, the Attorney-General was not aggrieved by the order vacating the award and his appeal is dismissed.

 

437 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Savastano v. Nurnberg


[No number in original]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


152 A.D.2d 290; 548 N.Y.S.2d 555; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 15798



December 11, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is reversed, insofar as appealed from, on the law, without costs or disbursements, it is declared that Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11 and 14 NYCRR 517.4, are constitutional on their face to the extent they permit the transfers of involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients, over objection, from municipal facilities to psychiatric facilities operated by the New York State Office of Mental Health, without a prior judicial hearing as to the need for such transfers, and the complaint is otherwise dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent legal services brought an action against appellant hospital on behalf of involuntary patients who objected to their proposed transfers from municipal to state mental facilities. The Supreme Court of Queens County (New York) held that N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 29.11 and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 14, § 517.4 were unconstitutional and that the transfer procedures violated the patients' due process rights. The hospital appealed.


OVERVIEW: The legal services argued that the patients had a liberty interest not to be transferred and that involuntary transfer violated their constitutional rights. On appeal, the court held that N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 29.11 and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 14, § 517.4 were constitutional on their face. There was no basis for requiring a judicial hearing prior to the transfer of the objecting patients from municipal facilities to state facilities. The patients had no constitutional right to be treated at any particular facility. There was no evidence that the transfers further restricted their liberty or that their confinement was unnecessarily prolonged. The statutes had not created a constitutionally protected liberty interest or explicitly required any specific substantive predicates. The transfer decisions were not made in bad faith, out of pique, or on irrational grounds. The veto power of the receiving facility created an independent, nonbiased review of whether a transfer was in the patient's best interest, and no evidence had been presented to the contrary. The patients' allegations that the hospital had not complied with the regulatory scheme were unsupported by any evidence.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment, which had held that the statutory provisions permitting the transfer of involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients, over their objection, from municipal facilities to state psychiatric facilities with prior judicial hearings were unconstitutionality.


HEADNOTES

Mental Health -- Transfer of Patients -- Involuntary Transfer from Municipal to State Facilities

1. The statutory and regulatory scheme (see, Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11; 14 NYCRR 517.4) which permits the transfer of involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients, without their consent or a prior judicial hearing, from municipal facilities to psychiatric facilities operated by the State Office of Mental Health, does not violate the Due Process Clause of either the State or Federal Constitution; although such patients have liberty interests subject to constitutional requirements of due process, no evidence was submitted that the transfers in question would further restrict their liberty since the receiving facility may only retain the patient for the balance of the period for which the sending facility was authorized to retain the patient without further court order. Moreover, no evidence was presented that patients in municipal facilities were further stigmatized by their transfer to State facilities or that such a transfer resulted in the labeling of an individual as a "chronic mental patient". The statute does not use any mandatory language prohibiting transfers unless certain substantive criteria are met, and the regulation does not create a constitutionally protected liberty interest.

Appeal -- Academic and Moot Questions -- Transfer of Mental Patients -- Release of Patients

2. In an action challenging the statutory and regulatory scheme (see, Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11; 14 NYCRR 517.4) which permits the transfer of involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients, without their consent or a prior judicial hearing, from municipal facilities to psychiatric facilities operated by the State Office of Mental Health, although all the named patient plaintiffs had been discharged prior to their proposed transfers, it is appropriate to determine the issues rather than dismiss the appeal as academic since the issues raised are significant, and there is a likelihood of their repetition and a need to clarify the law for the participants.

Mental Health -- Transfer of Patients -- Involuntary Transfer from Municipal to State Facilities

3. The statutory and regulatory scheme (see, Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11; 14 NYCRR 517.4) which permits the transfer of involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients, without their consent or a prior judicial hearing, from municipal facilities to psychiatric facilities operated by the State Office of Mental Health, does not violate the Due Process Clause of either the State or Federal Constitution, and the State Constitution does not accord greater protection to such patients with respect to the issue of a pretransfer judicial hearing; the authority of the Commissioner of the Office of Mental Health to transfer involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients without court intervention has existed since 1933 in virtually its current form. Moreover, the predecessor regulation to 14 NYCRR 517.4 did not provide for any pretransfer judicial hearing where no court proceedings were pending involving the patients.

Mental Health -- Transfer of Patients -- Involuntary Transfer from Municipal to State Facilities

4. In an action challenging the statutory and regulatory scheme (see, Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11; 14 NYCRR 517.4) which permits the transfer of involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients, without their consent or a prior judicial hearing, from municipal facilities to psychiatric facilities operated by the State Office of Mental Health, the determination that the challenged provisions did not satisfy the requirements of due process was erroneous, even assuming that the scheme created a liberty interest to be protected, since there was no evidence that the transfers in question imposed additional restrictions or stigma upon the patients or that the transfers will unduly delay the release of such patients; the regulatory scheme poses only a small risk of erroneous deprivation and that risk would not be significantly reduced by superimposing the requirements of a pretransfer judicial hearing. The shortcomings of specialists cannot always be avoided by shifting the decision to an untrained Judge and the record does not support a finding that the challenged transfers were made in bad faith, out of pique, or on irrational grounds.

Mental Health -- Transfer of Patients -- Involuntary Transfer from Municipal to State Facilities

5. In an action challenging the statutory and regulatory scheme (see, Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11; 14 NYCRR 517.4) which permits the transfer of involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients, without their consent or a prior judicial hearing, from municipal facilities to psychiatric facilities operated by the State Office of Mental Health, the regulation does not preclude the director of the transferring facility from deciding the issue of transfer in an unbiased and impartial manner owing to the fact that his decision may be motivated by the desire or necessity to alleviate overcrowding in the facility, with the director thereafter being called upon to review his decision to transfer a patient should an objection be raised, since overcrowding is only one of many factors to be considered in determining the transfer issue, and in any event, the receiving facility is to ascertain whether the patient would benefit from its services and can reject a patient even after a transfer; that veto power creates an independent, nonbiased review of whether the transfer is in the patient's best interest and no evidence has been presented to the contrary.

Mental Health -- Transfer of Patients -- Involuntary Transfer from Municipal to State Facilities

6. In an action challenging the statutory and regulatory scheme (see, Mental Hygiene Law § 29.11; 14 NYCRR 517.4) which permits the transfer of involuntarily admitted mentally ill patients, without their consent or a prior judicial hearing, from municipal facilities to State psychiatric facilities, the appeal procedure set forth in 14 NYCRR 517.4 (c) is not constitutionally inadequate notwithstanding the fact that it does not provide for the full panoply of procedural safeguards, since those procedures are not required by the Due Process Clause; in light of the fact that the transfer decision involves the proper treatment to be afforded the patient, the value of cross-examination to discredit a professional medical opinion is at best limited, and the accuracy of the transfer decision would not be significantly enhanced by adherence to the rules of evidence or by the imposition of a legal standard of proof by clear and convincing evidence. A written application for a transfer order must be prepared, indicating the reasons for the application and including a summary of the appeal procedure, and such documentation would be sufficient to permit review in a CPLR article 78 proceeding.

 

438 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Scalza


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


152 A.D.2d 235; 548 N.Y.S.2d 349; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 15419



December 4, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed, and the matter is remitted to the County Court, Nassau County, for further proceedings pursuant to CPL 460.509 (5).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Nassau County Court (New York), which convicted defendant of six counts of criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested after the police discovered a quantity of weapons in his residence and automobile. The trial court directed that a hearing be conducted with regard to defendant's motion to suppress physical evidence and his statements to law enforcement authorities. Pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 255.20(4), the trial court assigned the pretrial hearing to a judicial hearing officer, who found no impropriety in the conduct of the police. Defendant contended that § 255.20(4) was unconstitutional in that it allegedly authorized the transfer of court powers from constitutionally elected judges to nonjudicial, unelected court employees. The court found no merit in that argument, observing that although judicial hearing officers were empowered to make recommendations, they could not issue binding determinations with respect to pretrial criminal matters pending before them. Rather, § 255.20(4) unqualifiedly vested in the assigning judge the authority to render decisions resolving the issues litigated before a judicial hearing officer.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the conviction and remanded for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Crimes-- Jurisdiction of County Court -- References to Judicial Hearing Officers

 CPL 255.20 (4), which authorizes references to Judicial Hearing Officers (i.e., retired Judges) in pretrial criminal matters, does not constitute an impermissible delegation of the County Court's jurisdiction to unelected, nonjudicial State employees (see, NY Const, art VI, §§ 10, 11) since the statute provides that upon review of the hearing transcript, the Hearing Officer's report, and other relevant documents and submissions, the court shall render the ultimate determination with regard to the matter. Defendant has failed to discharge his heavy burden of establishing the unconstitutionality of the statute: there is no evidence that the court's adoption of the Hearing Officer's recommendations constitutes a ministerial formality by which the court surrendered jurisdiction or that the court abandoned its statutory duty to fully and independently review the Officer's report. Although the Hearing Officer may assess credibility, an issue of constitutional import is not raised because such an assessment or finding of fact is made. The Hearing Officers possess no power to issue binding determinations, and the court surrendered jurisdiction or that the court Legislature broad powers to prescribe procedural rules for the courts. The use of retired Judges to ease calendar congestion in the criminal courts is not an unconstitutional method to streamline the judicial process.

 

439 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Timber Point Homes v. County of Suffolk


No. 4479E


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


155 A.D.2d 671; 548 N.Y.S.2d 250; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 15114


Argued - June 26, 1989  
November 27, 1989 



DISPOSITION: ORDERED that that branch of the petition which challenges the constitutionality of Suffolk County Sanitary Code former § 607(1) (renumbered § 609) is converted into an action for a declaratory judgment, with that branch of the petition deemed a complaint; and it is further,

ADJUDGED that it is declared that Suffolk County Sanitary Code former § 607(1) (renumbered § 609) is unconstitutional, the determinations are annulled, on the law, without costs or disbursements, and the matter is remitted to the Suffolk County Department of Health Services for promulgation of a new provision of the Suffolk County Sanitary Code [**2] which complies with the Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution within 60 days after service upon it of a copy of this decision and order, with notice of entry, after which the Board of Review of the Suffolk County Department of Health Services shall reconsider the petitioner's application in accordance with the new provision.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner corporation sought review of a determination by respondent Board of Review (board), which denied the corporation's application for a variance from Suffolk, N.Y., County Sanitary Code § 605(1)(c) and (2)(a), and (2) and denied an application for a rehearing.


OVERVIEW: Following the denial of its variance application, the corporation retained a professional engineer to render an opinion as to the density and ground water conditions of the subject parcel. The expert concluded that approval of the petitioner's proposed subdivision would not have an adverse effect on the quality of the groundwater. The court remitted the mater to the Department of Heath for promulgation of a new provision which complied with the Due Process Clause of the U.S. Constitution, after which the board was ordered to consider the application in accordance with the new provision. The court held that the standard was impermissibly vague and allowed the commissioner and the board unfettered discretion to grant or deny a variance. Thus, the variance provision of the Suffolk County Sanitary Code was fatally flawed and the determinations under review had to be annulled.


OUTCOME: The court remitted the matter at issue to the Department of Health for promulgation of a new provision in the corporation's challenge of the board's decision to deny the corporation a variance.

 

440 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York Public Interest Research Group, Inc. v. New York State Thruway Authority


No. 58935


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


155 A.D.2d 861; 548 N.Y.S.2d 116; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 14346



November 22, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner public interest group sought review of the decision of Supreme Court in Albany County (New York), which dismissed the group's application to review a determination of respondent New York State Thruway Authority raising tolls on the thruway.


OVERVIEW: The Authority determined that an increase in the amount of the tolls on the thruway was warranted. The Authority submitted appropriate information about the proposal to the Comptroller for review, and a public report. The Comptroller refused to examine the proposal, finding that any proposed toll increase by a public corporation such as the Authority was not dependent upon Comptroller review and report. The group commenced a proceeding to challenge the Authority's action. The group alleged that the toll increase was null and void as illegal because it was adopted without the Comptroller's participation as required by N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 2804(2), (3). The lower court concluded that there was substantial compliance with the statute and dismissed the petition. The group appealed. The court found that § 2804(2), (3) unconstitutionally mandated that the comptroller perform certain acts with regard to a proposed toll increase by a public corporation. The court found that the Comptroller's refusal to perform these acts was permissible and did not undermine the legality of the toll increase. The court found that the petition was properly dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court, which dismissed the group's application to review a toll increase determination of the Authority.

 

441 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Coconato v. Esopus


[No number in original]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


152 A.D.2d 39; 547 N.Y.S.2d 953; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 14365



November 22, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant town appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court in Ulster County (New York), which granted plaintiff developers' motion for summary judgment and declared a local law invalid.


OVERVIEW: The town enacted a local law that required payment of a hook-up fee for new entries into the water district. The developers received an extensive bill for hook-up fees and filed an action seeking a declaration that the local law was unconstitutional. The trial court granted the developers' motion for summary judgment and declared the local law an unconstitutional exercise of the town's authority, and the town appealed the decision. The court noted that local governments did not have inherent power to adopt local laws, and were only able to exercise those powers expressly granted to them by the state constitution or the legislature. If the local government acted beyond the scope of authority granted to it, its act was considered unconstitutional. Finding that neither the state constitution nor the legislature had granted the authority to the town to collect a hook-up fee, the court held that the local law was an improper exercise of the town's authority, and it was properly declared unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court granting the developers' motion for summary judgment and declaring a local law unconstitutional was affirmed, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Water Districts -- Authorization to Impose Hook-Up Fee

1. A local law which required all new customers of a water district to pay an initial hook-up fee, fixed at $ 1,000 per dwelling unit and $ 1 per square foot of nonresidential space, and which provided that the fees so collected be deposited into a special account to be used solely for capital developments in the district, is invalid; Town Law § 198 (3) (a), which refers to "that portion of a supply pipe within the bounds of a public highway" and provides for "a uniform service charge for the installation of such portion of a supply pipe", but only if the town performs the installation, does not authorize the local law where the plans submitted by plaintiff developers provided that plaintiffs install, construct and retain ownership of all water supply pipes and roads within the project and that plaintiffs make all connections to district mains, thereby rendering the statute inapplicable to the project. Moreover, the Town Board failed to adopt a resolution governing the installation of plaintiffs' supply pipe, as required by the statute. 

Municipal Corporations -- Water Districts -- Authorization to Impose Hook-Up Fee

2. A local law which required all new customers of a water district to pay an initial hook-up fee, fixed at $ 1,000 per dwelling unit and $ 1 per square foot of nonresidential space, and which provided that the fees so collected be deposited into a special account to be used solely for capital developments in the district, is not authorized pursuant to NY Constitution, article IX, § 2 and Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 since the means by which revenues are raised and expended for the purpose of acquiring or constructing capital improvements or additional facilities in a town water district is already the subject of considerable regulation and there is no authority for a town's adoption or amendment of a local law amending or superseding a State statute relating to a special or improvement district or an improvement area (see, Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [ii] [d] [3]). Articles 12 and 12-A of the Town Law establish a comprehensive scheme for financing water district improvements, manifesting the Legislature's intent to preempt the area of financing capital improvements to water districts; Town Law § 202-b, governing the financing of improvements or additions to water district facilities, provides that any cost or expense incurred in the acquisition of additional facilities or improvements to existing facilities shall be a charge against the entire district and assessed, levied and collected in the same manner as other charges against the particular district.

Municipal Corporations -- Water Districts -- Authorization to Impose Hook-Up Fee

3. A local law which required all new customers of a water district to pay an initial hook-up fee, fixed at $ 1,000 per dwelling unit and $ 1 per square foot of nonresidential space, and which provided that the fees so collected be deposited into a special account to be used solely for capital developments in the district, is invalid; inasmuch as the expenses of construction and maintenance of the facilities of the district have always been assessed pursuant to Town Law § 202 (3) on an ad valorem basis, all future assessments must be levied on the same basis. There is no provision in the Town Law which allows a town to change the basis of assessment following the establishment of a water district (see, Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [ii] [d]), and the feecannot be justified as an entrance fee since a license fee, imposed pursuant to the power to regulate, cannot be greater than a sum reasonably necessary to cover the costs of issuance, inspection and enforcement.

Municipal Corporations -- Water Districts -- Authorization to Impose Hook-Up Fee

4. A local law which required all new customers of a water district to pay an initial hook-up fee, fixed at $ 1,000 per dwelling unit and $ 1 per square foot of nonresidential space, and which provided that the fees so collected be deposited into a special account to be used solely for capital developments in the district is not authorized by NY Constitution, article IX, § 1 (f) (1), which grants municipal water systems the right to make a fair return over and above the costs of operation and maintenance and necessary and proper reserves; although Town Law § 198 (3) (d) authorizes a town board to set and raise water rates, a charge for hooking up to a town water system is not within its purview.

Municipal Corporations -- Water Districts -- Authorization to Impose Hook-Up Fee

5. A local law which required all new customers of a water district to pay an initial hook-up fee, fixed at $ 1,000 per dwelling unit and $ 1 per square foot of nonresidential space, and which provided that the fees so collected be deposited into a special account to be used solely for capital developments, is invalid; the use of funds collected for capital reserves would be unlawful and improvements to the district may not be financed by a capital reserve fund. The provision of the local law that the initial hook-up fees shall be deposited in a "special account" violates the proscription against a town's establishment of capital reserve funds to finance all or part of the cost of improvements to be constructed, reconstructed or acquired or equipment to be acquired, on behalf of an improvement district within such town (General Municipal Law § 6-c [3] [a]).

Municipal Corporations -- Water Districts -- Authorization to Impose Hook-Up Fee -- Constitutionality of Fee as Applied

6. A local law which required all new customers of a water district to pay an initial hook-up fee, fixed at $ 1,000 per dwelling unit and $ 1 per square foot of nonresidential space, and which provided that the fees so collected be deposited into a special account to be used solely for capital developments is unconstitutional as applied to plaintiff developers since it imposes a uniform fee on all new dwelling units without regard to whether the development has necessitated an expansion of existing facilities or whether plaintiffs will be primarily and proportionately benefited by any such expansion; as such, the fee constitutes a tax, prohibited by the Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 (1) (ii) (d) (3), the Fourteenth Amendment, and NY Constitution, article I, § 11.

 

442 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ehinger


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


152 A.D.2d 97; 547 N.Y.S.2d 302; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 14314



November 21, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgments, Supreme Court, New York County, rendered on May 24, 1988, unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed from the judgment of the New York County Supreme Court (New York) convicting them, upon a jury verdict, of kidnapping and grand larceny after they held their roommate captive in his apartment for five days.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of kidnapping after they held their roommate captive in his apartment for five days and tortured him. On appeal, defendants contended that their convictions should be vacated because the statutory reference in N.Y. Penal Law § 135.00(2) to a place where the victim was "not likely to be found" was either constitutionally void for vagueness or, in the alternative, the victim's apartment fell outside the statutory definition as a matter of law. The appellate court affirmed the convictions. The standard by which the sufficiency of a statute was measured when attacked for vagueness was that it must not be so drawn that men of common intelligence must necessarily guess at what conduct was prohibited. The court held that the statutory reference attacked by defendants passed constitutional muster under this test. Additionally, the degree of likelihood or unlikelihood of discovery of the victim's hiding place presented a factual question for the jury to resolve in light of all the circumstances of the abduction and restraint and was not susceptible to disposition as a matter of law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendants' convictions for kidnapping as the statutory reference to a place where the victim was "not likely to be found" was not void for vagueness and the degree of likelihood of discovery of the victim's hiding place presented a factual question for the jury and was not susceptible to disposition as a matter of law.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review -- Error of Asserted Constitutional Dimension

1. In a prosecution for kidnapping in the first degree in which defendants assert on appeal that their convictions should be vacated because the statutory reference to a place where the victim "is not likely to be found" (see, Penal Law § 135.00 [2] defining "abduct") is either constitutionally void for vagueness or because the place where the victim was kept, his apartment, fell outside the statutory definition as a matter of law, defendant never raised those claims either by motion addressed to the indictment or any objection made to the trial court, and, therefore, they have not been preserved for appellate review; because an alleged error is assertedly of constitutional dimension does not create an exception to the rule.

Crimes -- Kidnapping -- Secreting Victim "In a Place Where He Is Not Likely to Be Found" -- Constitutionality of Locational Language -- Void for Vagueness

2. In a prosecution for kidnapping in the first degree (Penal Law § 135.25), the statutory language defining "abduct", viz., "holding [the victim] in a place where he is not likely to be found" (Penal Law § 135.00 [2]), is not constitutionally void for vagueness since the proscribed conduct, in order to constitute the crime, must be coupled with restraint of the victim for over a 12-hour period; a vagueness challenge must be addressed to the facts before the court, and the void-for-vagueness doctrine embodies a rough idea of fairness. Accordingly, the statutory reference to a place where a victim is not likely to be found passes constitutional muster where the victim herein was bound and restrained in his apartment for five days while defendants attempted to force him to reveal the access code to his automatic teller card.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review -- Hiding Place of Kidnapping Victim

3. In a prosecution for kidnapping in the first degree, the contention of defendants that the apartment of the victim falls outside the statutory definition of "abduct" as a matter of law (see, Penal Law § 135.00 [2] which requires that the victim be held "in a place where he is not likely to be found"), since the apartment of an urban dweller is a place where he is most likely to be found, has not been preserved for review by any motion to dismiss or request to charge which might have focused the jury's attention upon that particular element of the offense, which in fact was charged by the court without objection by the defense as to form or substance. Moreover, the contention is unpersuasive since the degree of likelihood or unlikelihood of discovery of the victim's hiding place simply presented a factual question for the jury to resolve in light of all the circumstances of the abduction and restraint, and is not susceptible to disposition as a matter of law on the instant record.

 

443 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Akpan v. Koch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


152 A.D.2d 113; 547 N.Y.S.2d 852; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 14337



November 21, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on May 16, 1988, unanimously affirmed, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant coalition of residents challenged an order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which granted a motion by respondents, city officials and agencies and a developer, for summary judgment and dismissed a complaint alleging that approval of a downtown renewal project violated the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA), N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 8-0101 et seq.


OVERVIEW: A coalition of residents who lived near the site of a proposed downtown renewal project filed an action against various city officials and agencies and a developer seeking to annul the city's approval of the project. The coalition argued that the SEQRA was violated because the needs of the low-income residents of the area were not properly considered. The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the city and developer, and the coalition appealed. The court affirmed the judgment because the officials and agencies had not abused their discretion or acted arbitrarily or capriciously in approving a well-considered plan that took many factors into consideration, including the secondary displacement effects of the project on surrounding areas. There was no affirmative obligation to provide for the housing needs of low-income residents because not every conceivable environmental impact, mitigating measure or alternative had to be identified and addressed before a final environmental impact statement satisfied SEQRA's substantive requirements.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the grant of summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Consideration of Secondary Displacement Effect of Urban Development Project on Low-Income Housing

1. A complaint alleging that a municipality violated the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) (ECL art 8) by, inter alia failing to consider the secondary displacement effect of a large urban development project on nearby low-income residents was properly dismissed where defendant municipal officials and agencies approved the project after taking many factors into consideration, including the housing needs of low-income residents in surrounding areas; there is no affirmative obligation imposed upon municipal authorities to provide for the housing needs of low-income residents, and judicial review of administrative actions is strictly limited to a determination as to whether such action is arbitrary and capricious or an abuse of discretion. The municipal agency which finally approved the project has wide latitude in concluding which alternative plans to accept, and mere disagreement with the plan promulgated does not make its action arbitrary, capricious, unsupported by substantial evidence or irrational; the action of defendant agency, under SEQRA, must be viewed in light of a rule of reason, and, accordingly, was not an abuse of discretion.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Consideration of Secondary Displacement Effect of Urban Development Project on Low-Income Housing

2. A complaint alleging that a municipality violated the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) (ECL art 8) by, inter alia, failing to consider the secondary displacement effect of a large urban development project on nearby low-income residents was properly dismissed where defendant municipal authorities reviewed the draft environmental impact statement, determined that additional information on secondary displacement was required, conducted a survey of the area, introduced new computer-generated data, and concluded that 80% of the residents in the affected area were protected by either rent control or rent stabilization and, thus, would not be threatened with displocement as a result of the project, and that the remainder of the residents were likely to be living in owner-occupied homes. The fact that defendants concluded that the significance of the secondary displacement was minimal does not mean that they did not consider secondary, long-term effects of the project and the potential impact on the surrounding community. SEQRA does not require an agency to impose every conceivable mitigation measure or any particular one; the municipal agencies took the required "hard look" at the possibility of secondary displacement.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Lead Agency

3. A complaint alleging that a municipality violated the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) (ECL art 8) by, inter alia, failing to consider the secondary displacement effect of a large urban development project on nearby low-income residents was properly dismissed; there was nothing wrong with the use by the New York City Board of Estimate and the City Planning Commission, which were the ultimate decision-makers concerning the approval of the prRoject, of the lead agencies, the City Department of Environmental Protection and the Department of City Planning, as investigative arms during the review process, since those agencies had the technical expertise necessary to prepare the draft and final environmental impact statements. The environmental impact statements were ultimately reviewed by the relevant decision-making authorities, and the municipal departments merely functioned as experts for the Board, which did make the final determination, as required by statutory and case law.

 

444 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Ajay Glass & Mirror Co. v. County of Erie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


155 A.D.2d 988; 547 N.Y.S.2d 790; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 14879



November 15, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court of Erie County (New York) which annulled its determination awarding a construction contract to appellant corporation and that ordered the county to award the contract to respondent corporation on the ground that the Minority Business Enterprise (MBE) affirmative action goals sought to be enforced by the county were invalid under the state and federal constitutions.


OVERVIEW: The trial court annulled the county's determination awarding a contract to install security windows at a county holding center to appellant corporation, and ordered the county to award the contract to respondent, holding that the MBE affirmative action goals sought to be enforced were invalid under the state and federal constitutions because they were in conflict with the competitive bidding statute, N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 103(1), and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The county determined that appellant corporation, unlike respondent, complied with the bid requirement of the contractor that they set forth their qualifications and prior experience. The court reversed the judgment, stating that the trial court erred in annulling the county's determination on constitutional grounds because no constitutional claim was raise in respondent's petition, and the lack of notice deprived the county of an opportunity to submit evidence in support of the validity of the local law. Further, the trial court erred in reaching the constitutional issue unnecessarily as respondent failed to comply with the bid requirement, justifying the rejection of its bid.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment annulling the county's determination awarding a construction contract to appellant corporation and ordering the county to award the contract to respondent.

 

445 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Davis v. State Tax Comm'n


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


155 A.D.2d 743; 548 N.Y.S.2d 1005; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 16848



November 9, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.

 

446 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Litod Paper Stock Corp. v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


154 A.D.2d 280; 546 N.Y.S.2d 361; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13332



October 24, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff waste carters appealed from the judgment of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which declared that defendants, city and Commissioner of Sanitation, were entitled to retroactively collect increased dump fees for the use of the city's waste-disposal facilities.


OVERVIEW: The waste carters began proceedings challenging the rate increase of dump fees for use of the city's waste-disposal facilities. The carters were granted a stay of the implementation date for the increased dump fees. After the trial court decided in favor of the city, the waste carters sought declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting defendants from collecting the increased dumping fees for the period when the stay was in effect. The trial court declared that defendants were entitled to collect retroactively the fees for use of the waste-disposal facilities during the period when the stay was in effect. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding that the collection of increased fees, properly promulgated, and imposed prospectively, for the period that a judicially imposed stay of such collection was in effect, was not a denial of due process. The court further held that the city should not be equitably estopped from collecting the fee increases.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of defendants in the waste carters' action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting defendants from collecting increased dumping fees.

 

447 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Axelrod v. New York State Teachers' Retirement System


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


154 A.D.2d 827; 546 N.Y.S.2d 489; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12689



October 19, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, excluded members of a retirement system, sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York) that granted the motion of defendants, a retirement system and others, for summary judgment based on the failure to state a cause of action, the bar of the statute of limitations, and laches.


OVERVIEW: Members of the system prior to July 1, 1973, who were full-time teachers and residents of New York upon entry into and discharge from World War II military service could purchase up to three years of credit toward their retirement for their military service. The residence requirement was perceived as constitutional in case law that was specifically overruled. The members filed an action for a judgment declaring that the residency requirement of N.Y. Educ. Law § 503(10) was unconstitutional and for an order allowing them to purchase the credit. Defendants filed a motion to dismiss. The trial court granted the motion. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that, even if it declared the residency requirement of § 503(10) unconstitutional, the members would have had no right to the credit sought because they never applied for it within the statutorily permitted time period. As a result, the court concluded that the members were not personally injured by the challenged statute and, therefore, lacked standing to complain about any alleged deficiencies in the law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the grant of summary judgment to defendants for the members' failure to state a cause of action.

 

448 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Vaccaro v. Jorling


Proceeding Nos. 1, 2


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


151 A.D.2d 34; 546 N.Y.S.2d 470; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12718; 21 ELR 20642



October 19, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed, without costs, and petitions dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowners appealed the judgment by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed the determination of respondent Commissioner of Environmental Protection (commissioner) authorizing the acquisition of real property by eminent domain.


OVERVIEW: The landowners' property was completely surrounded by state owned forest land. The state offered to purchase the property, but the landowners refused. The state then instituted eminent domain proceedings. The commissioner ordered appropriation of the land, after determining that the property was completely surrounded by state owned land and that the appropriation would accomplish state objectives. The landowners appealed. The appellate court affirmed. The landowners appealed the appellate court's judgment. The court affirmed. The court held that the landowners who had only a life estate had no standing to object because the appropriation was made subject to their life estates. The court held that the state was not required to show that the appropriated land was unique or threatened. The court held that the acquisition of the land to consolidate the state owned forest and protect from further development was a proper purpose for appropriation. The court held that the enlargement to the Adirondack forest was a public use of the appropriated land.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment, which affirmed the commissioner's determination that the landowners' property should be appropriated by eminent domain.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Proper Parties -- Aggrieved Persons -- Eminent Domain Proceeding -- Holders of Life Estate

1. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation authorizing the acquisition of certain real property by eminent domain, petitioners, the owners of a life estate in the property, are not aggrieved persons under EDPL 207 (A) because the appropriation was expressly made subject to their interest. Petitioners' exclusive right to use and possess approximately eight acres of the land in question will be honored, and their nonexclusive rights in the remaining 1,055 acres are, in essence, in the nature of an easement over the property for the duration of their life estate interests; as such, petitioners lack the legal power to prohibit general use or enjoyment of the property by the owner in fee. Petitioners' nonexclusive rights are subject to the fee owner's right to use the land in any manner that does not unreasonably interfere with the rights of the owner of the easement; accordingly, the proposed use by the State as owner in fee, to allow the public access to the remaining property for recreational purposes, does not deprive petitioners of any legal right or unreasonably interfere with their interests in that portion of the property. Consequently, their petition should be dismissed.

Eminent Domain -- Adirondack Forest Preserve -- Unique or Threatened Lands

2. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation authorizing the acquisition of certain real property in the Adirondack Park by eminent domain, the Commissioner did not exceed his authority since the word "acquire" used in ECL 3-0305 authorizes the condemnation of land for the establishment of fish and wildlife areas as set forth in ECL 11-2103, and eminent domain may be applied to lands within the Adirondack forest preserve which are not unique or threatened. Moreover, the absence of a specific reference to eminent domain in ECL 9-0105 (7) does not preclude the Commissioner from appropriating land to accomplish the objectives of the Department of Environmental Conservation of enlarging and protecting the forest preserve, and the term "acquire" as used in section 9-0105 (7) includes the power of eminent domain to achieve the objectives stated therein.

Eminent Domain -- Adirondack Forest Preserve -- Environmental Quality Bond Act

3. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation authorizing the acquisition of certain real property in the Adirondack Park, petitioner's argument that the power of eminent domain was improperly exercised because the 1972 Environmental Quality Bond Act (see, ECL art 51) envisions the appropriation of land which is unique and threatened, and that there is not an adequate basis to make such a finding, is without merit since the implementing legislation of the Bond Act allocated funds for both forest preserve projects in the Adirondack Park and unique area preservation projects, with the funds appropriated for unique areas being, by definition, for land outside the Park (see, ECL 51-0703 [4]). By contrast, the "Forest Preserve Project" is a project directed expressly for the acquisition of lands as additions to the forest preserve within the Park.

Eminent Domain -- Adirondack Forest Preserve -- Constitutionality of Taking -- Increased Recreational Opportunities

4. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation authorizing the acquisition of certain real property in the Adirondack Park, the constitutional requirement that a taking by eminent domain be for a public purpose has been satisfied since enlargement of the Adirondack forest preserve is a public use expressly authorized by ECL 3-0305 (1) and 9-0105, and legislatively funded by ECL 51-0701 (1); several public purposes, such as consolidating State-owned forest preserve lands, providing additional recreational opportunities for the public, eliminating administrative and environmental problems associated with increased usage of an access road, and protecting the natural resources of the property from further development, are accomplished by the appropriation in question. Moreover, the appropriation in fee, instead of some less restrictive means, was necessary to effectuate the objectives enumerated in ECL 9-0105 (7), and the appropriation was supported by an adequate basis and has not been shown to be unreasonable or arbitrary.

 

449 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


TOH REALTY CORP. v. CITY OF NEW YORK


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


154 A.D.2d 267; 546 N.Y.S.2d 357; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12641



October 17, 1989 

 

450 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Schneider v. Sobol


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


150 A.D.2d 135; 546 N.Y.S.2d 221; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12388



October 12, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment modified, on the law, with costs to plaintiffs, by directing that the declaration of invalidity of 8 NYCRR 175.35 (e) (1) (i) shall be effective upon service of the order to be entered upon this court's decision with notice of entry, and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Commissioner of Education and plaintiff organizations of school principals and other educational professionals who taught classes and/or provided other nonsupervisory services to pupils appealed an order of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which granted summary judgment to the organizations, declared N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 8, § 175.35(e)(1)(i) unconstitutional, and limited its judgment to prospective effect only.


OVERVIEW: The organizations challenged the Commissioner's regulation implementing the excellence in teaching (EIT) set-aside grants. The organizations brought an action seeking a declaratory judgment that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 8, § 175.35(e)(1)(i), as amended, violated the Equal Protection Clauses of the U.S. and N.Y. Constitutions. The lower court granted the organizations' motion for summary judgment, declaring § 175.35(e)(1)(i) invalid, but limiting its judgment to prospective effect only. The parties cross appealed. The court held that: (1) the challenged regulation violated equal protection because similarly situated educators were treated differently with regard to EIT set-aside fund eligibility based on how their salary was characterized, which was directly related to the collective bargaining process, a factor that was an unwarranted basis for classification; and (2) because of the demonstrated hardship and fiscal confusion that would result from retroactive application of the declaration of invalidity, the judgment would be prospective only. The judgment was modified and affirmed as modified.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment declaring the Commissioner's regulation implementing the excellence in teaching set-aside grants invalid, modifying the judgment only to ensure prospective application of the declaration of invalidity.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- Teachers -- Excellence in Teaching Funds -- Equal Protection

A regulation of the Commissioner of Education (8 NYCRR 175.35 [e] [1] [i]), which attempted to implement the excellence in teaching (EIT) program, whereby funds would be provided to augment the salaries of deserving teachers, is unconstitutional as violative of equal protection, where the regulation provides that mentor teachers and others providing educational services under a nonadministrative teaching certificate who are compensated under a teachers' salary schedule are eligible for EIT funds, but those compensated under an administrative or supervisory salary or salary schedule are not eligible. However, the fact that administrators and supervisors generally are paid higher salaries than teachers does not alter the fact that similarly situated educators are not subject to similar EIT fund eligibility for any logical reason; rather, the distinctions are based on the fortuities of how a person's salary is characterized, which is directly related to the collective bargaining process, a factor previously held to be an unwarranted basis for classification for EIT fund eligibility. Moreover, although some professional educators paid under an administrator's salary schedule will be eligible for EIT funds despite the language of the regulation to the contrary, other professional educators who provide comparable educational services but are paid an administrator's salary will not be eligible; such distinctions defy logic and are not constitutionally permissible.

 

451 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. McGourty


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


153 A.D.2d 991; 545 N.Y.S.2d 434; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11707



September 21, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

452 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Trudo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


153 A.D.2d 993; 545 N.Y.S.2d 437; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11709



September 21, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order of the County Court of Albany County sentencing defendant as a persistent felon. Defendant claimed his antecedent federal possession of firearms conviction under 18 U.S.C.S app. former § 1202 could not be used to support a finding that defendant was a persistent felon where the federal statute more broadly defined the term firearm than state law and did not constitute a felony under N.Y. Penal Law § 26.02(1).


OVERVIEW: Defendant's sentence as a persistent felon was vacated where finding that defendant was a persistent felon was based on a federal firearm possession conviction and federal statute's definition of firearm was broader than state's statute. Defendant was convicted of robbery, burglary, and grand larceny. The trial court sentenced defendant as a persistent felon where defendant was convicted under federal law for transportation of firearms in interstate commerce. Defendant brought a motion to set aside the sentence, claiming the conviction under 18 U.S.C.S. app. former § 1202(c)(3) did not constitute a felony under N.Y. Penal Law § 26.02(1). The trial court denied the motion. Defendant appealed. The reviewing court affirmed, holding where state law gave a more limited meaning to the term firearm than that used under federal law, and where evidence did not indicate the type of firearm defendant possessed under the federal law, vacation of the sentence was warranted.


OUTCOME: The reviewing court vacated the trial court's sentencing of defendant as a persistent felon, holding where the federal statute defined firearms more broadly than the state statute, defendant's federal conviction could not serve as a basis to find defendant a persistent felon.

 

453 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Executive Land Corp. v. Chu


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


150 A.D.2d 7; 545 N.Y.S.2d 354; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11545



September 11, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order is affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners appealed from an order of the Supreme Court (New York), which granted defendant tax commissioner's motion to dismiss the complaints in the property owners' consolidated actions for judgments declaring that the partial and successive transfers of properties owned by plaintiffs were not subject to aggregation for taxation purposes pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law §1440(7).


OVERVIEW: The property owners owned two large tracts of land that they were developing as industrial parks. They had sold separate portions of the tracts for various prices which, in the aggregate, amount to more than $ 1 million for each property owner. The tax commission assessed the transfers in the aggregate under N.Y. Tax Law § 1440(7) as transfers pursuant to a plan or agreement and subject to the gains tax. The property owners paid the gains taxes and filed an action seeking a declaratory judgment. The trial court dismissed their complaints. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court found that the property owners had the burden of proof to overcome the tax assessments, and that the tax commission's determination that the sales were in pursuit of a plan to develop industrial parks was a reasonable interpretation of the statutes and regulations. The court concluded that the property owners' statements that their sales were not in pursuit of plans were insufficient. The court found that the heavy tax burden placed on the property owners as opposed to residential property owners was justified by the substantial burdens placed on the governments by the development of the industrial parks.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court, which dismissed the property owners' complaints protesting the aggregation for tax purposes of their real estate transfers.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Gains Tax -- Aggregation of Partial and Successive Transfers

The partial and successive transfers of certain real property owned by plaintiffs are subject to aggregation for taxation purposes pursuant to the real property transfer gains tax (see, Tax Law § 1440 [7]) where the parcels are zoned for industrial use, each plaintiff is preparing the land for use as industrial parks, portions of the parcels have been sold to separate unrelated purchasers for various prices under $ 1,000,000, and the aggregate of the consideration of the transfers was in excess of $ 1,000,000, since the determination of the State Tax Commission that a common purpose was the operative factor in all of the transfers and that tax avoidance was the ultimate goal was supported by substantial evidence; plaintiffs are admittedly engaged in developing industrial parks and the Commission found that their assertion that they have no "plan" to effectuate transfers in avoidance of the tax because their transfers were to separate and unrelated transferees lacked credibility. The tax may not be avoided merely by filing a statement that the transferor is not acting pursuant to a plan to avoid the tax since interpreting the statute in that manner would not further the legislative purpose of taxing large real estate transactions. Plaintiffs have failed to sustain their heavy burden of showing that the gains tax statute is arbitrary or that it invidiously discriminates against them since every property owner in their situation is treated similarly, and the fact that residential and industrial properties are treated differently is justifiable given the substantial burdens placed upon local and State governments by the development of large industrial complexes.

 

454 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Raquel Marie X.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


150 A.D.2d 23; 545 N.Y.S.2d 379; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11570



September 11, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order is reversed insofar as appealed from, on the law, and the matter is remitted to the Family Court, Westchester County, for further proceedings on the petition for adoption in accordance herewith, before a different Judge.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant proposed adoptive parents appealed the order from the Family Court, Westchester County (New York), which denied their petition for adoption of an infant on the ground that respondent natural father's consent was required because the natural father had sufficiently met the requirements of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111(1)(e).


OVERVIEW: The natural father and respondent natural mother were unmarried and not cohabitating when the infant was born. Three days before the natural mother executed the consent to adoption, the natural father began a custody proceeding. A filiation order was entered a month later. The natural parents married, and the natural mother joined in the custody action. The natural parents opposed the adoption on the grounds that the natural father's consent to the adoption was required and the natural mother's consent was invalid. The trial court bifurcated the hearing and limited the evidence to the issue of whether the natural father's consent was required. The court reversed the order denying the adoption and remanded for determination of the validity of the natural mother's consent. The court held that the criteria set forth in N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 111(1)(e) were mandatory, that the consent of the natural father was not required because he failed to satisfy those criteria, that § 111(1)(e) satisfied the constitutional test for a gender-based classification, and that the natural parents' subsequent marriage did not operate retroactively so as to require the natural father's consent.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order denying the petition for adoption and remitted the matter to another judge of the trial court for a prompt hearing regarding the validity of the natural mother's consent to the adoption and resolution of any remaining issues.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Consent -- Natural Father -- Failure to Meet Statutory Criteria

1. The consent of a natural father to the proposed adoption of his infant daughter is not required pursuant to Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e) where the father did not marry the child's mother until more than five months after the child's birth and more than three months after her placement for adoption, since the father failed to satisfy the statutory criterion that he openly lived with the child or the child's mother for a continuous period of six months immediately preceding the placement of the child for adoption; inasmuch as the subject child was placed for adoption before she was six months old, section 111 (1) (e) applies and its criteria setting forth the conditions which an unmarried natural father must satisfy are mandatory. The statute has been held to be constitutional for it provides logical, objective and eminently sound indicia by which to determine whether an unmarried father has manifested the intent to establish a substantial familial relationship with an infant born out of wedlock, thereby justifying the gender-based classification. Moreover, given the lack of evidence that the natural father herein took meaningful steps to establish a family unit, it need not be decided if something less than total compliance with the three criteria listed in the statute may satisfy the law and require an unmarried father's consent to an adoption; the record overwhelmingly demonstrates that even under a relaxed interpretation of the statute, the natural father's efforts to establish a substantial family relationship were woefully inadequate.

Adoption -- Consent -- Natural Father -- Subsequent Marriage to Natural Mother

2. The consent of a natural father to the proposed adoption of his infant daughter is not required where the father failed to satisfy the criteria listed in Domestic Relations Law § 111 (1) (e), and the fact that the father married the natural mother some five months after the child's birth and three months after her placement for adoption does not operate to require that the consent of the natural father be given for the adoption to proceed; to require consents from later-married natural fathers would render the statutory provisions meaningless and create uncertainty in adoption proceedings by permitting unwed parents to marry at any point prior to an adoption being finalized and thereby acquire the power to veto the proposed adoption.

Adoption -- Consent -- Bifurcated Hearing

3. In an adoption proceeding, Family Court improvidently exercised its discretion in ordering a bifurcated hearing to determine whether the natural father's consent to the adoption was required before receiving evidence on the question of the validity of the natural mother's consent, which was also in issue.

 

455 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Ware v. Valley Stream High School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


150 A.D.2d 14; 545 N.Y.S.2d 316; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11235



September 5, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order and judgment is modified, on the law, by adding a provision thereto declaring that 8 NYCRR 135.3 (b) (2) and (c) (2) are not unconstitutional as applied to the appellants; as so modified, the order and judgment is affirmed, without costs or disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parents sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court (New York), which granted respondent school district summary judgment in the parents' cause of action to prevent the mandatory attendance of their children in AIDS and alcohol and drug abuse instructional classes as violative of their rights under U.S. Const. amend. I.


OVERVIEW: The parents sought a total exemption from the school's curriculum on the grounds that it violated their right to a free exercise of their religion under U.S. Const. amend. I, and their implied right of privacy to raise their children in accordance with their religious beliefs. The school district argued that the mere exposure of the children to the contested material did not constitute a violation of the parents' free exercise rights, and even if it did, the state had a compelling interest in educating citizens in ways to protect themselves from the dangers of AIDS and alcohol and drug abuse. The court modified the judgment, but only to append a declaration that the statute was not unconstitutional. The court determined that the compulsory education material could place a limited burden on the parents' free exercise rights because even fundamental rights such as those under the First Amendment could be impinged upon through the least restrictive means if the state posited a compelling state interest. In light of the numerous compelling state interests in this case, the court ruled that the parents' religious freedom was not impermissibly infringed upon by the contested curriculum.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order and judgment in favor of the state by declaring that the relevant statute was not unconstitutional as applied to the parents, and otherwise affirmed the order and judgment.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- Curriculum -- Mandatory AIDS Education -- Exemption from Exposing Children to AIDS Education on Religious Grounds

Regulations promulgated by the Commissioner of Education requiring all primary and secondary school students to receive instruction with regard to AIDS, and alcohol and drug abuse (8 NYCRR 135.3 [b] [2]; [c] [2]) do not impermissibly infringe on the First Amendment rights of petitioners to freely exercise their religious beliefs; although petitioners' religious beliefs require them to remain "simple as to evil" and distance themselves from all perceived evil, and although the compulsory education in issue may violate their First Amendment rights, even fundamental rights may be impinged upon through the least restrictive means when, in so doing, the State is advancing a compelling interest which is essential to the accomplishment of an overriding governmental purpose, and the compulsory health education curriculum clearly meets the test of advancing several compelling State interests, viz., the education of its citizens and the protection of the public health from the very real and dangerous AIDS crisis. Petitioners' invocation of their implied fundamental right of privacy is unavailing since uncontradicted religious indoctrination which denies the existence of undeniable health crises does not provide a suitable alternative to education where there is a very real likelihood that disaffected members of petitioners' sect will either leave or be cast out into society ignorant of AIDS and its methods of transmission and prevention, thereby becoming a risk to the public health.

 

456 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Russo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


149 A.D.2d 255; 545 N.Y.S.2d 211; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11230



August 28, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order is reversed, without costs or disbursements, the motion is granted and the matter is remitted to the Supreme Court, Suffolk County, for issuance of a subpoena duces tecum in accordance herewith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed order from the Supreme Court for Suffolk County (New York) which denied defendant's motion pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 2307(a) to issue a subpoena requiring police department to produce at a hearing before the traffic violations bureau, a radar or other speed detection device and all written materials concerning said radar or device. Defendant also alleged that issuance of subpoena was proper under defendant's right to counsel.


OVERVIEW: The court remitted the matter for issuance of a subpoena duces tecum that ordered production at a hearing of records and materials only to the extent that they enabled defendant to conduct a meaningful cross examination.
