The issuing court denied defendant's motion for subpoena, relying on N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 15, § 123.1, which provided that the New York Civil Practice Laws and Rules generally were not binding on the traffic violations bureau (bureau). Defendant also argued that the U.S. Const. amend. VI right to assistance of counsel required issuance of a subpoena. The reviewing court found no possibility of imprisonment and no right to counsel, and also ruled that the bureau could not negate the authority of courts to issue a subpoena. The court held that no essential element of a fair trial could be dispensed with unless waived, even in administrative or quasi-judicial proceedings, and defendant should have been fully apprised of the claims against him and the evidence considered, and should have been given the opportunity to cross examine witnesses, inspect documents, and offer evidence in explanation or rebuttal.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order denying defendant's motion for subpoena and remitted the matter, because the traffic violations bureau could not negate the court's authority to issue a subpoena. Defendant's right to inspect evidence against him was an essential element of a fair trial and was not waived by defendant, however there was no possibility of imprisonment and defendant had no right to counsel.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Speeding -- Production of Radar Device at Hearing -- Statutory Right

1. A defendant charged with speeding (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1180 [b]) is entitled to the issuance of a properly worded judicial subpoena duces tecum under CPLR 2307 requiring a police department to produce at defendant's hearing on the speeding charge the radar device which allegedly detected his speeding and all documents pertaining to the maintenance of the device, since CPLR 2307, which applies in criminal proceedings (see, CPL 610.20) provides that a subpoena duces tecum addressed to a "department or bureau of a municipal corporation" must be issued by a Supreme Court Justice in the district where the desired materials are located, and the CPLR is the governing procedure "in all courts * * * except where the procedure is regulated by inconsistent statute" (CPLR 101); there is nothing in either the Vehicle and Traffic Law or the regulations promulgated thereunder which prohibits the issuance of a properly worded subpoena. Although 15 NYCRR 123.1 states that "The [CPLR] and [CPL] are not binding on [the Traffic Violations] bureau", that regulation cannot be read to invalidate every provision of the CPLR when one considers that the subpoena power invoked herein does not in any way infringe upon the Traffic Violations Bureau, does not regulate or otherwise interfere with the proceedings of the Bureau, or direct the Bureau to act or refrain from acting in a particular way. Defendant is not seeking pretrial discovery, and is entitled to the production at the hearing itself, not beforehand, of the very item upon which the People rely in bringing the speeding charge; the materials in question should only be turned over immediately prior to the commencement of cross-examination.

Motor  Vehicles  -- Speeding -- Production of Radar Device at Hearing -- Constitutional Right

2. The Sixth Amendment right to the effective assistance of counsel does not require the issuance of a subpoena duces tecum requiring a police department to produce at defendant's hearing on a speeding charge the radar device which allegedly detected his speeding and all documents pertaining to the maintenance of the device, since there is no Sixth Amendment right to counsel in a case in which a defendant is charged with a traffic infraction; a traffic infraction is not a crime and the resultant penalty upon conviction cannot be deemed a penal punishment (see, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 155). Thus, the right to counsel does not attach in the instant proceedings since that right arises only in criminal prosecutions where a defendant's personal liberty is at stake.

 

457 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sheldon v. Highlands


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


153 A.D.2d 733; 545 N.Y.S.2d 199; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11190



August 28, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowners sought review of a decision of the court of appeals (New York), which reversed the opinion and order of the court and declared 1983 N.Y. Laws 755 constitutional, in an action brought by the landowners to prohibit respondent town from imposing an assessment on their property for a sewer improvement.


OVERVIEW: The town adopted a resolution establishing a sewer improvement area for the purpose of constructing a sewer system. Due to some problems, the boundaries of the improvement area were revised, which affected certain properties within the improvement area including property belonging to the landowners. The landowners unsuccessfully commenced a proceeding to invalidate the assessment, alleging that a portion of their property was illegally added to the assessment area, the town did not comply with applicable law in increasing the area, and they were assessed a disproportionate amount of the cost of the sewer improvement. On appeal, the court affirmed the dismissal of the landowners' action for failure to state a cause of action. The court rejected the landowners' argument that they should not have been assessed a portion of the benefit charge for the improvement area because their property had no access to the sewer line. The court found that the landowners failed to disprove that the value of the property was enhanced, because the town was entitled to take into account the general benefit received and whether the improvement in general enhanced the value of the property.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the action for failure to state a cause of action and awarded the town a bill of costs.

 

458 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Flowers v. Sullivan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


149 A.D.2d 287; 545 N.Y.S.2d 289; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11068



August 21, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgments are affirmed, without costs or disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmates sought to overturn regulations promulgated by respondent department of correctional services, which restricted the use, acquisition, or possession of certain electronic devices in state prisons. They contended that the restrictions violated their First Amendment rights to access the media. The Supreme Court, Westchester County (New York), rejected their claims and the inmates appealed.


OVERVIEW: A directive of the department of correctional services banned the use or possession of AC electrical adapters at state prisons and set a $ 75 limit on the value of radio or radio tape player devices possessed by state inmates. In a companion proceeding, a second directive prohibited FM-capacity radio or radio tape player combinations in 20 facilities. The inmates alleged that the restrictions were not reasonably related to the promotion of legitimate governmental objectives and that they violated their First Amendment rights to access the media. The lower court held in favor of the department of correctional services in both proceedings. On appeal, the court held that (1) the restrictions complained of served the legitimate penological interests they were designed to promote, (2) the FM-capacity restriction was clearly and logically connected to the objective of preventing inmates from monitoring, intercepting, or interfering with prison radio transmissions, and (3) the AC electrical adapter restriction was reasonably related to the objective of not overloading limited electrical output capabilities at certain facilities and the $ 75 limitation to the objective of deterring theft.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments of the trial court, which had held that the challenged directives restricting certain electronic equipment were reasonably related to legitimate penological concerns and therefore did not violate the inmates' constitutional rights.


HEADNOTES

Prisons and Prisoners -- Inmate Electronic Devices -- Prohibition on A/C Adaptors and Expensive or FM Radios

1. Administrative directives of the Department of Correctional Services banning the use or possession of A/C adaptors, setting a $ 75 limit on the value of radio or radio/tape players possessed by prison inmates, and prohibiting FM capacity radios in certain correctional institutions are valid and do not impermissibly infringe on petitioner inmates' First Amendment rights since the challenged directives are reasonably related to legitimate penological concerns. Inasmuch as some inmates are capable of adapting FM radios to monitor, intercept or otherwise interfere with prison radio transmissions, there is a clear and logical connection between their prohibition and the valid governmental interest of promoting prison management and security; banning the use of A/C adaptors is justified by the legitimate goal of minimizing the danger of fires, overloaded circuits, power failures, etc., and inasmuch as the ban is not unconditional, it accomplishes the stated goals in a reasonable and nonintrusive manner; the value limitation on radios is reasonably and inexorably related to the maintenance of prison security, order and discipline by deterring theft. Moreover, the directives are content-neutral, there is no reason to doubt the sincerity of the justifications advanced by respondents, and courts should not invade the province of correctional authorities in administering prisons.

Judgments -- Res Judicata -- Participation of Same Litigants

2. Two proceedings challenging administrative directives of the Department of Correctional Services banning the use or possession by inmates of certain electronic devices should not be dismissed on the ground of res judicata, notwithstanding the fact that a petitioner in both proceedings was unsuccessful in Federal court in attempting to have the directives annulled, since there are other petitioners in the instant proceedings who did not participate in the Federal action, and thus, have not had a chance to have their claims heard; moreover, there has been no showing that the additional petitioners were in privity with the unsuccessful Federal petitioner during the pendency of the Federal lawsuit.

Disclosure -- Freedom of Information Law -- Data Relating to Electrical and Security Transmissions of Prison Authorities

3. A Freedom of Information Law request made by prison inmates seeking the specifications and other data relating to the electrical and security transmission systems of a correctional facility is denied since their request falls within one of the law's exemptions, viz., Public Officers Law § 87 (2) (f), which permits an agency to deny access to records or portions thereof if disclosure would endanger the life or safety of any person; disclosure of details regarding the electrical, security and transmission systems of a prison might impair the effectiveness of those systems and compromise the safe and successful operation of the prison, with the safety risk being magnified in light of the fact that disclosure is sought by inmates.

 

459 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Assay Partners v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


149 A.D.2d 63; 544 N.Y.S.2d 1008; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10664



August 10, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Determination of respondent Commissioner dated October 29, 1987, unanimously confirmed, without cost and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer challenged a determination of defendant, the Commissioner of the Department of Finance of the City of New York (commissioner), denying the taxpayer a refund of a real estate transfer tax payment on a building the taxpayer purchased in Manhattan from the United States. Although normally the seller would have been liable for the tax, the United States was exempt, and thus the tax fell to the purchaser as a non-exempt grantee.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer paid the municipal real property transfer tax on a building bought from the United States to the city under protest, and then sought a refund, which the commissioner denied in an administrative hearing. The taxpayer contended that granting an exemption for grantees of the United Nations (UN) and educational, charitable, and other like institutions, while taxing grantees of the United States, constituted a violation of the Supremacy Clause. The court affirmed the commissioner's determination, finding no discriminatory treatment of the United States and its agencies because the tax treated the United States the same as state governmental units. In addition, the taxpayer's claim that the city administered the tax so as to give preferential treatment to those dealing with the city, as compared with those doing business with the United States, was rejected because it was not raised at the administrative hearing. Further, the single such instance cited by the taxpayer did not in any case establish the existence of a consistent city policy of favoring city grantees and discriminatorily taxing federal grantees.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the determination of the commissioner that the taxpayer was not entitled to a refund of the municipal real property transfer tax.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Tax -- Discrimination against Grantees of United States

1. Administrative Code of the City of New York § 11-2101 et seq. (formerly Administrative Code § II46-1.0 et seq.), which imposes a tax on all transfers of real property in New York City over $ 25,000 at a rate of 2% of the total sales price, does not unlawfully discriminate against the United States or violate the Supremacy Clause (US Const, art VI, cl 2) by providing that grantees of the United Nations, other world-wide international organizations of which the United States is a member, or eleemosynary institutions are exempt from the tax but not grantees from the United States Government, since the United States is treated the same as grantees of State governmental units; the claim of petitioner grantee, which purchased real property in New York City from the Federal Government, that a State or local tax may not treat anyone better than the United States or those dealing with the United States misapprehends the nature of "discrimination" required before a breach of the Supremacy Clause is deemed to have been committed, inasmuch as such "discrimination" against the United States and its agencies is found only when other governmental units are treated in a preferred manner. Moreover, the assertion that "discrimination" occurs when grantees of the UN or other similar organizations are exempted from the tax while grantees of the United States are not is without merit since it is reasonable for the city to place such organizations in the same category as eleemosynary institutions, and exempting such organizations furthers the public policy of the United States as host country.

Courts -- Federal Courts -- Controlling Precedent

2. Summary affirmance by the United States Supreme Court of a holding issued by a three-Judge United States District Court is a controlling precedent.

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Tax -- Discriminatory Enforcement 

3. In a proceeding to annul a determination upholding a real estate transfer tax payment and denying petitioner a refund, it has not been shown that the taxing authority unconstitutionally administered the tax (see, Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-2101 et seq.) by treating those who deal with the city in a preferential manner where petitioner received an exemption when it purchased air rights from the city since the purpose of the roundabout transaction in which petitioner purchased the rights from a municipal public development corporation, which is a tax-exempt organization, was not to avoid the tax, but rather to obviate the necessity for a public auction or a bid proceeding for the air rights. Moreover, the showing by petitioner of the single transaction does not establish the existence of a consistent policy by the city of using tax-exempt organizations to favor city grantees as opposed to discriminatory taxation of Federal grantees.

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Preservation of Issue for Review -- Failure to Assert Claim at Administrative Hearing

4. In a proceeding to annul a determination upholding a real estate transfer tax payment and denying petitioner a refund, petitioner's assertion that the statute imposing the tax and providing for various exemptions (see, Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-2101 et seq.) was administered in a discriminatory manner, was not raised in the administrative hearing by petitioner and, therefore, may not be raised for the first time in an article 78 proceeding.

 

460 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Niesig v. Team I


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


149 A.D.2d 94; 545 N.Y.S.2d 153; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10705



August 7, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order is modified, (1) by deleting the provisions thereof which (a) denied those branches of the plaintiff's motion which were to compel the defendant J.M. Construction of New York, Inc., to submit to a deposition conducted by the plaintiff's attorney, and to compel the third-party defendant to respond to the plaintiff's interrogatories,  [***2] and (b) granted that branch of the third-party defendant's motion which was to vacate the plaintiff's interrogatories, and substituting therefor provisions granting those branches of the plaintiff's motion, denying that branch of the third-party defendant's cross motion, and directing J.M. Contruction of New York, Inc. to produce Mauro Ricchiuti, or if he is no longer employed by it, another witness to be deposed by the plaintiff, and directing the third-party defendant to respond to the plaintiff's interrogatories, and (2) by deleting the provision thereof which denied that branch of the plaintiff's motion which was for authorization to the plaintiff's attorney to conduct ex parte interviews of the individuals named by the third-party defendant as possible witnesses, and substituting therefor a provision granting that branch of the motion only to the extent of authorizing the plaintiff's attorney to interview persons who are not currently employed by any adverse party represented by an attorney, and otherwise denying that branch of the motion; as so modified, the order is affirmed insofar as appealed from, without costs or disbursements; the third-party defendant shall answer the [***3] plaintiff's interrogatories within 20 days after service upon it of a copy of this decision and order, with notice of entry, and the defendant J.M. Frederick Construction of New York, Inc. shall produce a witness to be deposed by the plaintiff upon written notice of not less than 10 days, to be provided by the plaintiff.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff injured party challenged the decision of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which denied his motion to compel defendant general contractor to be deposed, denied the injured party's motion to compel third-party defendant employer to respond to his interrogatories, and denied the injured party's motion for authorization for his attorney to conduct ex parte interviews of nonmanagerial employees of the employer.


OVERVIEW: The court held that it was not proper for opposing counsel or its investigator to contact ex parte an employee of a corporation that was a party to an action knowing that the information sought from the employee related to a subject of controversy. Only by viewing all present employees of a corporation as "parties" might the terms of N.Y. Jud. App., Code Prof. Resp. DR 7-104(A)(1) effectively be enforced. Neither the federal constitution nor the state constitution secured a right to attorneys who were actively involved in litigation to conduct ex parte examinations of the employees of adverse parties.Thus, the injured party's attorney was not allowed to conduct ex parte interviews of the employer's nonmanagerial employees. The injured party's claim under N.Y. Lab. Law § 240 was not the equivalent of liability premised on proof of actual negligence. Thus, because the action was not predicated solely on negligence, interrogatories were authorized. The court found that the "leave of court" authorized by the terms of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3130 should have been granted because the courts should not be reluctant to authorize the use of interrogatories even where depositions had been held.


OUTCOME: The court deleted the provisions of the trial court's order that denied the injured party's motion to compel the general contractor to submit to a deposition and to compel the employer to respond to the injured party's interrogatories and that prohibited the injured party from conducting ex parte interviews of persons who were not currently employed by any adverse party represented by an attorney. The court affirmed the order as modified.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Communication with Adverse Party -- Ex Parte Communication with Employees of Adverse Corporation

1. An attorney for plaintiff in a personal injury action may not communicate on an ex parte basis with certain individuals who, as employees of a corporate third-party defendant, are presumptively within the scope of the representation afforded by the attorneys who appeared on behalf of that corporation, since Code of Professional Responsibility DR 7-104 (A) (1) prohibits a lawyer from communicating with an adverse party whom he knows to be represented by an attorney in connection with the subject matter of that representation. Plaintiff's contention that such ex parte communications should be permitted is premised on an invalid assumption, viz., that the attorneys who represent the corporate third-party defendant do not in fact represent its employees; however, unless there is proof that the scope of the representation is more limited, it must be presumed that such representation extends not only to the corporation but to every current agent or employee thereof who is connected in any way with the instant action. Plaintiff's argument that the ethical prohibition on ex parte communications extends only to members of the corporation's "control group" or "alter ego" is theoretically unsound and practically unworkable: there is no test by which to differentiate between those employees who could not be contacted ex parte and those who could, and attempts to make that differentiation would lead to a flood of pretrial litigation. Plaintiff's attorneys herein properly sought an advance ruling before attempting to communicate with the third-party defendant's employees.

Disclosure -- Interrogatories -- Use of Both Interrogatories and Depositions in Action Based on Negligence and Strict Liability

2. In an action based on negligence and the strict liability provisions of Labor Law § 240, plaintiff may seek pretrial disclosure from defendants both by conducting depositions and by serving interrogatories since CPLR 3130 (1) provides that use of both disclosure devices is precluded "solely on a cause * * * of action for negligence" and that statutory phrase should be given a literal construction; an action based on a claimed violation of section 240 is substantively different from an action based on negligence.

 

461 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kern


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


149 A.D.2d 187; 545 N.Y.S.2d 4; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10653



July 31, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgments are affirmed; and it is further,

Ordered that the matters with respect to Scott Kern and Jason Ladone are remitted to the Supreme Court, Queens County, for further proceedings pursuant to CPL 460.50 (5).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged the judgments of the Supreme Court of Queens County (New York) convicting them of manslaughter in the second degree, assault in the first degree, and conspiracy in the fifth degree, claiming that the evidence was insufficient to support the convictions, that their inculpatory statements should have been suppressed, and that it was error to require the defense to articulate race-neutral reasons for peremptory challenges.


OVERVIEW: Defendants challenged their convictions for manslaughter, assault, and conspiracy in a racial attack that led to the death of a black man who was chased onto a freeway and killed by a car. Defendants argued that the evidence was legally insufficient to support their convictions, that their inculpatory statements to police should have been suppressed, and that the trial court erred in ruling that the defense, in exercising its peremptory challenges, was required to articulate a race-neutral explanation for challenges to black jurors. The appellate court affirmed the convictions after finding that the evidence was legally sufficient, that the hearing court did not err in denying the suppression of their statements, and that appellants were not prejudiced by the trial court's "reverse-Batson" ruling since the only black juror seated as a result of the failure to provide a race-neutral reason was excused prior to jury deliberations. Nevertheless, the court held that the trial court's "reverse-Batson" ruling was proper because racial discrimination, whether by the prosecution or the defense, was not countenanced, either substantively or procedurally.


OUTCOME: Because the evidence adduced at trial established that appellants created a grave risk of death that they consciously disregarded, and by doing so grossly deviated from the standard of conduct reasonable persons would have observed, the court affirmed the convictions, holding that the trial court's rulings were proper in all respects.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Manslaughter -- Victim Killed by Car after Being Chased onto Highway -- Conscious Disregard of Risk

1. In a prosecution of three youths who were charged with causing the death of a man by chasing him with bats and clubs onto a six-lane highway where he was struck and killed by an automobile, the evidence was legally sufficient to establish defendants' guilt of manslaughter in the second degree (Penal Law § 125.15 [1]), since, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, a rational trier of fact could have concluded that defendants, who were thoroughly familiar with the area in which the crime occurred, were aware that their actions in continuing to chase and threaten the victim as he ran to the end of a street, leaped over a barricade, and ran onto the highway, created a grave risk of death to the victim, which risk defendants were aware of and consciously chose to disregard; the victim had been physically threatened in the dark morning hours in an area unfamiliar to him, and the evidence clearly established that defendants did not abandon their chase once they reached the end of the street. Rather, the evidence showed that defendants did not stop their pursuit until they saw the victim hit by the car, and the jury could readily conclude that defendants' continued hot pursuit of the victim as he fled onto the highway amounted to a gross deviation from the standard of conduct that a reasonable person would have observed under the circumstances (see, Penal Law § 15.05 [3]).

Crimes -- Manslaughter -- Victim Killed by Car after Being Chased onto Highway -- "Sufficiently Direct Cause" of Death

2. In a prosecution of three youths who were charged with causing the death of a man by chasing him with bats and clubs onto a six-lane highway where he was struck and killed by an automobile, defendants' actions were a "sufficiently direct cause" of the victim's death so as to warrant the imposition of criminal liability, since the only reasonable alternative left open to the victim was to seek safety by crossing the highway; it cannot be said that defendants' despicable conduct was not a sufficiently direct cause of death, and defendants will not be heard to complain that, in desperately fleeing their murderous assault, the victim chose the wrong escape route.

Crimes -- Manslaughter -- Victim Killed by Car after Being Chased onto Highway -- Intervening Cause

3. In a prosecution of three white youths who were charged with causing the death of a black man by chasing him with bats and clubs onto a six-lane highway where he was struck and killed by an automobile, the alleged negligent operation of the vehicle was not an intervening proximate cause of death where, given the fact that the crime occurred during the night and the victim was fleeing from a mob of approximately 12 white youths shouting racial epithets and demanding that he get out of "their" neighborhood, it cannot be said that an intervening wrongful act occurred to relieve defendants from the directly foreseeable consequences of their actions. Even assuming that the operator of the vehicle was less than cautious, the facts demonstrate that his actions were not the sole cause of death since it was defendants' wrongful conduct which forced the victim to seek refuge from his assailants by crossing the highway. Moreover, although there was some evidence that the victim may have been under the influence of cocaine when he died, there was more than sufficient evidence from which the jury could conclude that the victim was not under the influence of cocaine.

Crimes -- Assault -- Evidence of Serious Physical Injury

4. In a criminal prosecution arising out of an attack by a mob on an unarmed victim, the evidence was legally and factually sufficient to support the three defendants' convictions for assault in the first degree since the prosecution established that the victim sustained "serious physical injury" as a result of the beating he received (see, Penal Law § 120.10 [1]; § 10.00 [10]); the victim was struck repeatedly with bats and clubs, and sustained numerous contusions, a laceration requiring five stitches, and a hematoma. One month after the beating, the victim still showed signs of injury. Viewing the testimony of the victim and various physicians in the light most favorable to the People, it must be concluded that the evidence was legally sufficient to establish that the victim sustained serious physical injury which impaired his vision and produced back spasms, and that the victim suffered a protracted impairment of his health. Moreover, a review of the facts (see, CPL 470.15 [1]) leads to the conclusion that the jury's verdict of guilt was not against the weight of the credible evidence.

Crimes -- Confession -- Isolation of Youthful Defendant from Parents or Attorney

5. In a criminal prosecution in which the 16-year-old defendant contended that his custodial confession was extracted from him after the police effectively cut off all of his avenues of assistance by taking him to one precinct rather than to another, the hearing court properly determined that the facts do not support a finding that the police acted in such a way as to purposely isolate defendant from his parents or his attorney, where a change in the police officers' plans resulted in defendant not being taken to the precinct where his mother was told he would be, after defendant indicated a willingness to cooperate and view photographs; his statements were made prior to the time that the police were advised that he was represented by counsel.

Crimes -- Confession -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review -- Reopening of Suppression Hearing

6. In a criminal prosecution in which the 17-year-old defendant contended that his custodial statements to the police should be suppressed since the officers failed to scrupulously honor his right to remain silent, to the extent that defendant's claims asserted on appeal are premised upon arguments and testimony which were not presented to the suppression court, they are not preserved for appellate review; once certain evidence purportedly favorable to the defense came to light during the trial, it was incumbent on defendant to seek to reopen the suppression hearing for the purpose of inquiring into the circumstances of his interrogation and no such request was made.

Crimes -- Confession -- Waiver of Right to Remain Silent

7. In a criminal prosecution, the 17-year-old defendant's motion to suppress his custodial statements to the police was properly denied where the evidence showed that both defendant and his father freely and voluntarily accompanied police officers to the precinct, that the police did not consider defendant to be a suspect at that time, that once the police were made aware of the fact that defendant had been identified as a participant in the crime they were investigating, he was immediately advised of his Miranda rights in his father's presence, with both defendant and his father signing a written waiver of those rights, and that defendant thereafter provided the police with an oral and written statement.

Crimes -- Confession -- Provocation of Statement from Defendant by Police

8. In a criminal prosecution arising out of an incident which generated much publicity, certain statements made by defendant need not be suppressed on the ground that the act of a police officer in providing defendant with a newspaper containing front-page coverage of the incident was calculated to provoke a statement, thereby purportedly rendering defendant's statements involuntary, since the officer's conduct, made after defendant's repeated insistence to see the paper, cannot be construed as an attempt to elicit or provoke an incriminating statement, and the police are not obligated to prevent a talkative person in custody from making an incriminating statement; defendant's outburst upon viewing the newspaper was in no way connected to police interrogation.

Crimes -- Confession -- Spontaneous Declaration to Assistant District Attorney

9. In a criminal prosecution, the statements made by the 17-year-old defendant to an Assistant District Attorney (ADA) at a police station should not be suppressed on the ground that they closely followed a period of intense interrogation and were made after his attorney had contacted the station and requested that all questioning of his client cease, since defendant's unprovoked and unsolicited remarks to the ADA, who identified himself as such to defendant, were spontaneous and not subject to suppression; the ADA was not obligated to refuse to listen to defendant's remarks. Those remarks were not tainted by defendant's prior custodial statements elicited in a police car, since over four hours elapsed between defendant's initial statement and his outburst and defendant was not subjected to continuous police interrogation, thereby attenuating any taint resulting from the earlier remarks, which were suppressed.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Academic and Moot Questions -- Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges by Defense

10. In a prosecution arising out of an incident in which a mob of white youths attacked and beat three black men, causing one of the men to run across a highway and be killed by an oncoming car, the issue of whether it is permissible for the defense to exercise its peremptory jury challenges in such a way as to exclude potential black jurors is moot where the only black juror seated was ultimately discharged on consent of both sides after the juror's son became ill, and, thus, defendants were not aggrieved by the trial court's ruling that the defense must provide a racially neutral explanation for rejecting potential black jurors; however, inasmuch as the question of whether the defense may use race-based peremptory challenges is one of integral importance to the criminal justice system, recurs on a continual basis, and often evades appellate review, the court shall address the issue.

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges by Defense -- State Action

11. The rule of Batson v Kentucky (476 U.S. 79),which prohibits the prosecution from exercising its peremptory jury challenges in a racially discriminatory manner, may be applied to the defense in a criminal action since the threshold requirement of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment, viz., State action, is not absent when a defendant, rather than the State, exercises his peremptory challenges to strike a juror; the source of the authority for a defendant's exercise of racially discriminatory peremptory challenges is State law, since peremptory challenges are not constitutionally mandated, but exist solely by reason of State statute (see, CPL 270.25). Moreover, State action is intimately involved in the jury selection process since it cannot be said that when the defense exercises its peremptory challenges in a racially discriminatory manner, the State is merely an observer where the State, by means of the exercise of real and apparent judicial authority in excusing the challenged juror, directly effects defendant's discriminatory act. To permit the defense to peremptorily strike jurors solely on the basis of race would necessarily and inevitably lead to injury to the jury system, injury to the law as an institution, and injury to the democratic ideals reflected in the processes in the courts.

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges by Defense -- Third-Party Standing of State to Object

12. Under the principles of third-party standing, the State has standing to object to a defendant's use of race-based peremptory jury challenges in selecting a jury, notwithstanding the fact that the State, i.e., the prosecution, is not a member of the cognizable racial group sought to be excluded from the petit jury, since the State has a substantial relationship with the excluded jurors and the community at large, and has a direct interest in protecting the rights of its citizens, since the rights of those infringed upon will not be asserted by anyone other than the State given the fact that in almost every instance the excluded juror is unaware that he has been discriminated against when he is dismissed by the court, and since the dismissed juror is not a party to the litigation. In view of the unlikelihood of anyone other than the State asserting the rights of the excluded jurors and of the community, those rights would likely be severely diluted or adversely affected unless the State were permitted to seek vindication thereof in the context of a particular case.

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges by Defense -- State Equal Protection Clause

13. The racially discriminatory exercise of peremptory challenges by a criminal defendant in selecting a jury violates the State Equal Protection Clause (NY Const, art I, § 11); the second sentence of the section is a civil rights provision intended to protect rights which are "elsewhere declared", thereby guaranteeing to each individual in the State the rights and privileges of citizenship, which necessarily encompass the right to serve on a petit jury (see, Civil Rights Law § 13; Judiciary Law § 500).

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of  Jury -- Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges by Defense  -- Trial Court Procedure

14. The court in a criminal trial complied with the procedure set forth in Batson v Kentucky (476 U.S. 79), which prohibits the prosecution from using race-based peremptory challenges in selecting a jury, after ruling that Batson applied to the defense, where the Judge inquired of the defense whether it intended to offer any opposition to the prosecutor's motion which asserted that the defense was systematically excluding blacks from the jury solely on the basis of race and defense counsel stated that they had no intention of responding to that claim; accordingly, the court did not have to give the defense the opportunity to articulate race-neutral reasons for their previously exercised peremptory challenges against black jurors.

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges by Defense

15. In a criminal prosecution, the trial court's finding that the defense was systematically excluding black jurors from the jury panel solely on the basis of race by the use of peremptory challenges was supported by the record; the reasons for the exercise of peremptory challenges by the defense against black jurors were made known by the defense early in the voir dire and since many of the black jurors who were peremptorily struck by the defense had previously been unsuccessfully challenged for cause, the court had an appreciation of the underlying rationale for the defense's peremptory challenges. Moreover, the experienced Trial Judge observed the jury selection procedure, was able to assess counsel's questions and statements during voir dire, and was fully aware that the defense had been successful in excluding all of the black jurors from the venire through a combination of challenges for cause and the use of peremptory challenges. Accordingly, even in the absence of a declaration of intent by defense counsel, the court's finding was proper and supported by the record.

Crimes -- Jurors -- Selection of Jury -- Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges by Defense

16. In a criminal prosecution arising out of an incident in which a mob of white youths attacked and beat three black men, causing the death of one of them, the fact that the crimes committed by defendants were racially motivated does not permit defense counsel to exercise their peremptory challenges against any black juror solely on the basis of race, since the ruling in Batson v Kentucky (476 U.S. 79), which prohibited the use of race-based peremptory challenges by the prosecution, clearly reflects an intention to prohibit all racially based peremptory challenges, including those which are related to the issues of a particular case.

Crimes -- Evidence -- Hearsay -- Present Sense Impression -- Harmless Error

17. In a criminal prosecution, although defendants' contention that it was error to have permitted the prosecution to introduce into evidence a redacted tape recording of a telephone call to an emergency police operator under the present sense impression exception to the hearsay rule may have merit, the error, if any, was harmless in view of the overwhelming proof of defendants' guilt.

Crimes -- Consolidation and Severance -- Multiplicity of Defendants

18. In a criminal prosecution arising out of an incident in which a mob of white youths attacked and beat three black men, causing the death of one of them, the motions of three defendants for severance were properly denied; each of defendants' inculpatory statements was redacted to avoid any references to the others and, thus, the statements as received into evidence were neither facially nor inferentially incriminating. Given the involvement of approximately a dozen youths in the attack, the redaction of the specific references to the defendants and the inserted references to the "others" or "another" clearly did not prejudice defendants. Moreover, the court gave a proper limiting instruction to the jury concerning the use of each of the defendants' statements against the remaining codefendants; thus, defendants' right of confrontation was not violated.

Crimes -- Lesser Included Offense -- Assault

19. In a criminal prosecution arising out of an incident in which a mob of youths attacked and beat a man, the trial court did not err in refusing to charge assault in the third degree (Penal Law § 120.00 [1]) as a lesser included offense of assault in the first degree (Penal Law § 120.10 [1]) since no reasonable view of the evidence would support the conclusion that the victim's injuries were not inflicted by the use of dangerous instruments, to wit, bats and tree limbs (see, CPL 300.50 [1]); moreover, defendant's challenge to the denial of the jury charge is foreclosed by reason of the jury's verdict of guilt as to the assault in the first degree counts and its implicit rejection of the charged lesser included offense of assault in the second degree.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Harsh and Excessive Sentence

20. In a criminal proceeding arising out of an incident in which a mob of white youths attacked and beat three black men, causing the death of one of them, the sentences of imprisonment meted out to three defendants, viz., two consecutive terms of 5 to 15 years for one defendant, two consecutive sentences of 3 to 9 years for another defendant, and two consecutive sentences of 2 1/2 to 7 1/2 years to the third defendant, were neither harsh nor excessive in light of their vicious and racially motivated conduct; moreover, defendants showed absolutely no remorse for their crimes. Each defendant displayed inexplicable callousness towards the victims and must be held accountable.

 

462 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Smith v. Kunkel


[No number in original]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


152 A.D.2d 893; 544 N.Y.S.2d 240; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10286



July 20, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After respondent state employer refused to accept petitioner employee's withdrawal of his resignation, the employee filed suit under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78. The Supreme Court of Albany County (New York) dismissed the complaint as untimely. The employee appealed.


OVERVIEW: The employee submitted his resignation for personal reasons, and it was accepted. He then sought to withdraw the resignation but the state employer refused the withdrawal, citing N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 4, § 5.3(c). The employee filed suit over a year later under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, contending that the refusal was arbitrary and capricious and that the statute cited was unconstitutional in that it violated procedural due process by not affording him a hearing. The trial court dismissed the action as untimely. The employee appealed. On review, the court found that the action was barred by a four-month statute of limitations. Furthermore, the court found that procedural due process was not violated because the employee had not been terminated; he voluntarily resigned.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the action.

 

463 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Morley v. Oswegatchie


[No number in original]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


152 A.D.2d 862; 544 N.Y.S.2d 72; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10268



July 20, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mobile home park owners challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court, Lawrence County (New York), which, inter alia, denied their application in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law art. 7, seeking a reduction in the assessments imposed on their real property.


OVERVIEW: The park owners rented lots to the occupants and owners of mobile homes located at a mobile home park. The park owners challenged the local real property tax assessments on the mobile home park, based upon the aggregate values on the land and the mobile homes situated thereon. The park owners argued that the inclusion in the assessment of the value of the mobile homes, owned by others, violated N.Y. Const., art. XVI, § 2, which expressly provided that assessments should in no case exceed full value. The trial court denied the owners' application for a reduction in the assessments in a N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law art. 7 proceeding. The court affirmed. The statutory authority for classifying mobile homes such as those on the owners' property as real property to be included within the assessment "against the real property itself" was under N.Y. Real. Prop. Tax § 102(12)(g). That classification was upheld as constitutional. The classification was reasonable in that the house trailers were stationary and used as residences, their utilities were physically connected to the land, and the occupants used the same local governmental services as the owners of more conventional-type dwellings.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment which denied the park owner's application seeking a reduction in the assessments imposed on their real property.

 

464 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Catanise v. Fayette


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


148 A.D.2d 210; 543 N.Y.S.2d 825; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9814



July 12, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously modified, on the law, and as modified, affirmed, with costs, and petition granted in accordance with the opinion by Balio, J.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a town justice, filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 challenging respondent town board's decision to reduce his salary during his term of office. The town justice appealed the dismissal of his petition by the Supreme Court, Seneca County (New York).


OVERVIEW: The town justice sought punitive damages and attorney fees, claiming that a reduction in salary during his term of office amounted to an unconstitutional encroachment upon the independence of the judiciary. The town justice alleged that the town board purposefully reduced his salary because it was unhappy with some of his decisions and wanted to punish him for those decisions and, at the same time, influence future rulings. The town board contended that N.Y. Town Law § 27 (1932) authorized it to reduce a town justice's salary during the term of office. The court rejected the town board's contention and held that the legislature did not intend the power to fix salaries to include the power to reduce a town justice's salary during the term of office. The court concluded that the reduction of the town justice's salary during his term of office violated fundamental principles of separation of powers and constituted an impermissible encroachment upon the independence of the judiciary.


OUTCOME: The court granted the town justice's petition to the extent of directing the town board to reinstate the town justice's annual salary. The court affirmed the portion of the trial court's judgment dismissing the town justice's request for punitive damages and attorney fees.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- Town Justice -- Salary -- Reduction of Salary during Term of Office

Reduction of the salary of a Town Justice during the Justice's elective term constitutes an impermissible encroachment upon the independence of the judiciary and violates fundamental principles of separation of powers; accordingly, petitioner Town Justice is entitled to have his prior salary reinstated. Although Town Justices are not included in the list of Judges and Justices in the State Constitution whose salary may not be diminished during the term of office for which they were elected or appointed (see, NY Const, art VI, § 25), such omission does not evidence any specific intent to abolish the constitutional protections theretofore enjoyed by Justices of the Peace. Moreover, Town Law § 27, which permits a town board to "fix, from time to time, the salaries of all officers and employees of said town", does not authorize the reduction of a sitting Town Justice's salary since that statute was enacted when the State Constitution expressly prohibited any diminution in the compensation of a Justice of the Peace, and it should not be inferred that the Legislature intended that the power to fix salaries includes the power to reduce a Justice's salary during his term of office.

 

465 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Buffalo Mem. Chapels v. Axelrod


[No number in original]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


152 A.D.2d 969; 544 N.Y.S.2d 253; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9873



July 12, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a licensed funeral director and a licensed funeral establishment, filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding to challenge a determination of respondent, the Department of Health of the State of New York, which adopted a decision of an administrative law judge (ALJ), sustained 59 of 60 charges pending against petitioners, and revoked petitioners' corporate and individual licenses.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners claimed that their due process rights were violated and that the determination of the ALJ was arbitrary and capricious, based upon errors of law, and not supported by substantial evidence. The court rejected petitioners' due process argument because the laws controlling funeral directors and establishments were not unconstitutionally vague, and the written charges were sufficient for petitioners to prepare a defense. A charge for failure to retain a receipt for a vault was not proper because the proof showed that a vault was never provided to the customer, which supported the conviction on another charge. Other charges were not proper because the Department failed to prove that petitioners knew that their corporate status had been revoked. Proof of knowledge was essential to a finding of fraudulent intent. Nine other charges had to be dismissed because the ALJ made statements concerning the lack of proof, and it was arbitrary and capricious for the ALJ to later sustain those charges. The court held that the 45 remaining charges were supported by substantial evidence. The Department was required to impose an appropriate sanction in light of the court's modifications.


OUTCOME: The court modified the Department's determination by dismissing certain charges against petitioners. The court confirmed the determination as modified and remitted the matter for further proceedings.

 

466 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Zane


[No number in original]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


152 A.D.2d 976; 543 N.Y.S.2d 777; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9883



July 12, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Supreme Court, Erie County (New York), which denied defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted for depraved indifference murder and felony murder when a firefighter was killed in a fire set by defendant. Defendant sought to have to indictment dismissed, but the trial court denied his motion. Defendant appealed. The court held that the count of the indictment charging defendant with depraved indifference murder was not defective since it alleged the mental element in the words of the statute, and in any event, defendant waived any challenge to the sufficiency of the indictment's factual allegations. The court also held that the trial court properly denied defendant's motion to dismiss the count of the indictment that charged defendant with felony murder. The felony murder statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(3), insofar as it applied to the crime of arson, was not unconstitutionally vague merely because it did not define what was meant by "in the course of and in furtherance of such crime." The felony murder statute was sufficiently definite. It was illogical to interpret the felony murder statute as meaning that the death had to have occurred at the time of the commission of the crime. The death needed only to be caused by the commission of the crime.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

467 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Charles


[No number in original]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


152 A.D.2d 593; 543 N.Y.S.2d 961; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9658



July 3, 1989 

 

468 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


151 A.D.2d 792; 543 N.Y.S.2d 121; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9224



June 26, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed and the case is remitted to the County Court, Nassau County, for further proceedings pursuant to CPL 460.50 (5).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment from the County Court, Nassau County, (New York), which convicted him of attempted criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, upon his plea of guilty and imposed sentence.


OVERVIEW: Following his conviction for attempted criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, defendant contended that the trial court erred in denying portions of his omnibus motion to suppress certain statements made by him to law enforcement officials. The court affirmed the trial court's judgment of conviction. First, because the voluntariness of defendant's statements to the police officer was not at issue, the state was not required to comply with the strict 15-day notice requirement of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 710.30. Second, the statements that defendant made while in the patrol car, at a time when he was in custody without the benefit of Miranda warnings, were admissible because they were spontaneous. Finally, the mandatory minimum sentencing provisions of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 for second felony offenders were not unconstitutional as applied to defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment convicting defendant of attempted criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree.

 

469 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Green


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


151 A.D.2d 693; 542 N.Y.S.2d 748; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8154



June 19, 1989 

 

470 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kuttner v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


147 A.D.2d 215; 543 N.Y.S.2d 172; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7543



June 15, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law, without costs, and motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, Governor of the State of New York and State Ethics Commission, sought review of the order of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which granted plaintiff attorneys' motion for a preliminary injunction restraining defendants from enforcing the Ethics in Government Act and restraining enforcement of N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73(8) against state officers and employees who left state service prior to January 1, 1989.


OVERVIEW: After the attorneys entered private practice following employment as state officers or employees, the attorneys brought an action against defendants, seeking a declaration that N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73(8) was unconstitutional or, in the alternative, seeking an injunction prohibiting defendants from enforcing an advisory opinion to the Ethics in Government Act (Act). The trial court granted the preliminary injunction, and defendants sought review. On appeal, the court held that the attorneys' contentions that N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73(8) was violative of equal protection was not likely to succeed on the merits based on a prior ruling that held that § 73(8) did not violate equal protection. The court held that § 73(8) was prospective in nature and therefore did not constitute the type of enactment prohibited by the Ex Post Facto Clause, U.S. Const. art. I, § 10. The attorneys' claim of improper delegation of authority was not likely to succeed. The attorneys' were likely to prevail on the issue that the Act violated the doctrine of separation of powers, but the attorneys did not establish that they would suffer irreparable harm without the preliminary injunction.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order granting a preliminary injunction to the attorneys because the trial court abused its discretion in granting the preliminary injunction.


HEADNOTES

Injunctions -- Preliminary Injunction -- Ethics in Government Act -- "Revolving Door" Prohibitions

1. A preliminary injunction is a drastic remedy which should be issued sparingly and only when the moving party establishes the likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable injury absent granting the injunction, and a balancing of the equities in its favor, and in considering whether a preliminary injunction was properly issued, appellate review is limited to whether the Supreme Court abused its discretion. Accordingly, in an action to declare invalid and unconstitutional a provision of the Ethics in Government Act (L 1987, ch 813) which places restrictions on how a former State officer or employee may earn compensation after he has separated from State service (see, Public Officers Law § 73 [8]), Supreme Court abused its discretion in granting the motion of plaintiff attorneys, who left State employment prior to January 1, 1989, for a preliminary injunction restraining the State Ethics Commission from enforcing an advisory opinion holding that plaintiffs are prohibited from appearing before their former agencies for two years, since the merits of plaintiffs' main contentions were discussed and resolved against them in Forti v New York State Ethics Commn. (147 AD2d 269), wherein it was determined that the Act did apply to people in plaintiffs' position, and that equal protection is not offended by treating State officers and employees differently from legislators and legislative employees inasmuch as there is a rational basis for the disparate treatment.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Employment Prohibitions on Former State Officers and Employees -- Ex Post Facto

2. Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which, inter alia, prohibits former State officers and employees from appearing before their former agencies for two years, does not violate the Federal constitutional proscription against ex post facto laws, and, consequently, no preliminary injunction should issue restraining enforcement of a State Ethics Commission advisory opinion holding that the statute applies to attorneys who separate from State service prior to January 1, 1989, since plaintiff attorneys are not likely to succeed on the merits of their claim; the statute is prospective in nature, regulating conduct after January 1, 1989, and does not seem to constitute the type of enactment prohibited by the Ex Post Facto Clause. Moreover, the limited restrictions on plaintiffs' practicing of their profession are not the types of punishment proscribed by the Ex Post Facto Clause.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Employment Prohibitions on Former State Officers and Employees -- Improper Delegation of Authority

3. A preliminary injunction restraining the State Ethics Commission from enforcing an advisory opinion holding that State officers and employees who leave State service prior to January 1, 1989 are prohibited for two years from appearing before their former agencies should not issue; Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which codifies the two-year prohibition, does not include an improper delegation of the legislative function by allowing State agencies to adopt more restrictive "revolving door" standards regulating practice before them, and there is little chance of plaintiff attorneys, who separated from State service prior to January 1, 1989, being successful on the merits of their improper delegation claim. It seems probable that a court would conclude that the Legislature could delegate authority to State agencies to adopt more restrictive "revolving door" provisions in light of the Legislature's clear purposes and intentions in enacting the Ethics in Government Act (L 1987, ch 813), viz., to restore public confidence in government and promote ethical behavior.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Employment Prohibitions on Former State Officers and Employees -- Separation of Powers

4. Under Public Officers Law § 73 (14), the State Ethics Commission has authority either to impose civil penalties for knowing and intentional violations of the "revolving door" provisions of the Ethics in Government Act (L 1987, ch 813), which restrict the employment opportunities of former State officers and employees, or to refer a violation to the appropriate prosecutor for criminal sanctions; however, it is the executive who is constitutionally charged to ensure that the laws are faithfully executed and who, represented by the prosecutor, has primary discretion in deciding whether to bring criminal charges. Accordingly, by giving the Commission prosecutorial discretion, the Legislature has essentially and improperly infringed upon an executive branch function, and since plaintiff attorneys, who left State employment prior to January 1, 1989 and are prohibited from appearing before their former agencies for two years, would be subject to criminal exposure if they undertook any proscribed acts in their private practices, their contention is justiciable, especially in a declaratory judgment action.

Injunctions -- Preliminary Injunction -- Ethics in Government Act -- Irreparable Harm -- Balancing of Equities

5. Although plaintiff attorneys, who left State service prior to January 1, 1989 and are prohibited from appearing before their former agencies for two years, are likely to prevail on their claim that Public Officers Law § 73 (14), which gives the State Ethics Commission the authority to refer violations of the Ethics in Government Act (L 1987, ch 813) to prosecutors, is a violation of the doctrine of separation of powers, they are still not entitled to a preliminary injunction restraining enforcement of an advisory opinion of the State Ethics Commission holding that the two-year employment restrictions are applicable to plaintiffs, since plaintiffs have failed to show irreparable injury or that the equities are in their favor; the provisions of the Act which apparently violate the separation of powers doctrine can be severed from the rest of the Act, thereby leaving no reason to enjoin the applicability of the rest of the Act, and the equities do not favor issuing the preliminary injunction since it is likely that only the penalty provisions of Public Officers Law § 73 (14) will be affected by any ultimate success on the merits by plaintiffs, whereas the substantive provisions governing plaintiffs' conduct will likely remain intact.

 

471 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Forti v. New York State Ethics Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


147 A.D.2d 269; 542 N.Y.S.2d 992; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7879



June 15, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law, without costs, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment denied, summary judgment granted to defendant and it is declared (1) that Public Officers Law § 73 (8) applies to State officers and employees who left State service before January 1, 1989, and (2) that said statute has not been demonstrated to be unconstitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant commission appealed the order of the Supreme Court in Albany County (New York), which held that the Ethics in Government Act (Act), specifically N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73(8), violated the equal protection rights of plaintiff attorney under the New York and United States Constitutions.


OVERVIEW: The attorney was working for a state agency at the time that the Ethics in Government Act passed. The attorney left government employment before the Act became effective, but after its enactment. The Act specified that agency employees were subject to its revolving door prohibitions before legislative employees became subject to the revolving door prohibitions. The lower court held that the classification contained in § 73(8) violated the equal protection guarantee under the New York and United States Constitutions. The court reversed, holding that because the legislature faced the public in elections every two years there was a rational basis for the distinction between agency employees and legislative employees. The court also rejected the claim of the attorney that his due process right to employment, under the New York and United States Constitutions, was violated. The court ruled that in the exercise of its police power that the State had the power to reasonably condition the conduct of businesses and to prescribe qualifications on the practice of law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the lower court, which had held that the revolving door restrictions on the attorney had violated his equal protection rights under the New York and United States Constitutions.


HEADNOTES

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Applicability of Recent Ethics Legislation

1. Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which set revised ethics standards prohibiting former State officers and employees from, inter alia, appearing before their former agencies for two years, does apply to State officers and employees who left State service prior to January 1, 1989 where the statute specifically states that it applies only to legislative employees who left or leave State service on or after January 1, 1989, since the Legislature clearly considered which categories of public servants who left State service before January 1, 1989 are subject to the law, and by specifically not according State officers and employees the same treatment as legislative employees, the Legislature evidently intended the former category of public servants to be treated differently from the latter category. The statute expressly applies to any "person who has served as a state officer or employee"; however, the words "has served" are not dispositive, since they can reasonably apply to any individual who was but is no longer a State officer or employee regardless of whether his State service ended before, on, or after January 1, 1989. Moreover, inasmuch as section 73 (8) repealed by implication Public Officers Law § 73 former (7), if the new statute did not apply to State officers and employees who left State service prior to January 1, 1989, then no such ethics provision would govern their conduct, a result which could not have been intended.

Statutes -- Repeal by Implication -- Enactment of Comprehensive New Code -- Revival Provision 

2. Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which set revised ethics standards for State officers and employees who separate from State employment, repealed by implication Public Officers Law § 73 former (7). Although repeals by implication are not favored, an amendment which covers the entire subject is deemed to repeal the previous omitted parts by implication; as a sweeping reform imposing a comprehensive ethics code, the Ethics in Government Act (L 1987, ch 813), of which section 73 (8) is a part, was clearly intended to cover the field so that previous omitted provisions, such as section 73 former (7), were repealed. Moreover, the express intention for revival of the former subdivision in the event that the Act's amendments are declared invalid indicates that the former subdivision was repealed.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Retroactivity of Revised Statutory Ethics Standards

3. Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which set revised ethics standards for State officers and employees who separate from State service, is not retroactive or contrary to the fundamental principle that statutes should be applied prospectively, absent a clear indication otherwise; although the statute is intended to apply to State officers and employees who left State service before January 1, 1989, it only affects conduct occurring on or after that date, so it is not truly retroactive. The argument of plaintiff, an attorney who left State service prior to January 1, 1989 and who is prohibited from appearing before his former agency for two years notwithstanding the fact that the expertise he gained in his former position allegedly led to his hiring by his present law firm, that application of the statute's restrictions on postseparation employment creates a harsh result is rejected since the law does not prevent plaintiff from practicing his chosen profession or even his specialty; plaintiff may perform a variety of activities, including appearing in court against his former agency, so long as he does not appear or practice before the agency during the time periods specified in the statute.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Employment Prohibitions on Former State Officers and Employees -- Equal Protection

4. Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which set revised ethics standards for State officers and employees who separate from State service and which placed greater restrictions on former State officers and employees than on legislators or legislative employees, does not violate constitutional guarantees of equal protection since the Legislature could rationally determine that public servants' postemployment restrictions should be a function of the institutional checks endemic to a particular governmental process which encourage ethical conduct; arguments as to the wisdom and effectiveness of the statute are irrelevant to an equal protection analysis. The Legislature must answer to the voters every two years, and such public accountability, absent at even the highest levels of the administrative processes, can reasonably be considered as the ultimate institutional check on the conduct of legislators and legislative employees; the administrative process, by contrast, is characterized by relatively few decision makers, generally working in a single agency, so that the potential for improper conduct is more concentrated. Inasmuch as there is a rational basis to classify State officers and employees differently from legislative employees, the exclusion of only legislative employees who left State service before January 1, 1989 from coverage under the statute does not constitute an unconstitutional classification.

Public Officers -- Conflicts of Interest -- Employment Prohibitions on Former State Officers and Employees -- Due Process

5. Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which set revised ethics standards for State officers and employees who separate from State service by prohibiting former employees from, inter alia, appearing before their former agencies for two years, does not violate the due process rights of an attorney who used to work for the Department of Environmental Conservation and who was hired by his present firm allegedly because of his expertise in environmental matters, since due process rights do not allow unrestricted activity and, in the exercise of its police power, the State has authority to reasonably condition the conduct of business and prescribe qualifications on the practice of law; the restrictions in question do not deprive plaintiff of his right to practice law but merely impose reasonable, limited restrictions in order to promote a legitimate concern of the State at the expense of preventing plaintiff from pursuing his professional employment to the fullest extent possible.

Public Officers  -- Conflicts of  Interest -- Employment Prohibitions on Former State Officers and Employees -- Separation of Powers

6. Public Officers Law § 73 (8), which set revised ethics standards for State officers and employees who separate from State employment, resulting in plaintiff attorney being prohibited from appearing before his former agency for two years, does not violate the doctrine of separation of powers by intruding upon the judiciary's authority over the conduct of attorneys since the Legislature has traditionally regulated various aspects of attorneys' conduct; the Legislature also has the power to delegate authority to administrative agencies so long as there are adequate standards for administration, and in light of the comprehensiveness of the Ethics in Government Act (L 1987, ch 813), of which section 73 (8) is a part, there is no constitutional problem. Accordingly, in the absence of any successful constitutional challenge, summary judgment in favor of defendant State Ethics Commission is warranted even though it did not move for summary judgment below.

 

472 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Malone


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


151 A.D.2d 697; 543 N.Y.S.2d 939; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8244



June 12, 1989 

 

473 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Howard


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


147 A.D.2d 177; 542 N.Y.S.2d 536; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7382



June 8, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment, Supreme Court, New York County, rendered on February 13, 1986, reversed on the law, the defendant's motion to suppress the evidence granted, and the indictment dismissed. The matter is remitted to the trial court for the purpose of entering an order in favor of the accused pursuant to CPL 160.50, not less than 30 days after service of this order upon the respondent, with leave during this 30-day period to respondent to move and seek any further stay of the implementation of CPL 160.50 as in the interest of justice is required.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the judgment of the Supreme Court in New York County (New York), which convicted him of attempted criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: At approximately 10:00 p.m., two police officers were on duty seated in a marked patrol car on the lookout for traffic violators. They observed defendant, who was standing near a subway entrance. The officers watched defendant look up and down the street, look up and down the subway stairs, and, thereafter, return to a position near the wall. Two or three times during this period he placed his right hand inside his jacket as though he were adjusting something. The officers approached defendant, and they noticed a bulge in his jacket pocket. While the officers testified that the bulge was not identifiable as a gun, they frisked defendant and recovered the gun in issue. Defendant was subsequently convicted of attempted criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree. The court reversed the conviction, holding that the search was improper because the officers did not have a reasonable suspicion that defendant was about to commit a crime. His movements near the subway station were innocuous, and the observation of a bulge in his pocket was an insufficient basis for a search of a weapon.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment, which convicted defendant of attempted criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Unlawful Search and Seizure -- Stop and Frisk

A motion to suppress a gun found on the person of defendant should be granted and an indictment charging him with criminal possession of a weapon dismissed where the circumstances observed by the arresting police officers who searched defendant did not rise to the level of reasonable suspicion; defendant's behavior during the short time he was being observed by the officers was innocuous or, at best, equivocal where defendant was standing near a subway entrance at 10:00 p.m., looking down the subway stairs and up and down the streets, and then moving to stand near a wall. Defendant did not make any furtive or threatening gestures which might indicate that criminal activity was afoot, and his conduct was consistent with that of an innocent man. The only other fact observed by the officers was defendant twice reaching inside his jacket pocket as though he were adjusting something, and that innocuous movement was readily susceptible of an innocent interpretation. The fact that defendant walked away when he saw the officers approach did not provide a basis for any greater level of intrusion than the minimal level of approaching to request information, and by submitting to the officers' command to halt, defendant was seized within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment.
