Mere observation of an undefinable bulge in defendant's pocket is insufficient as a basis for a frisk, and the unsupported conclusory statements by the officers that they were in fear of their lives appears to be little more than a rote recital of the words deemed necessary to retroactively validate a patently improper search. Moreover, the fact that defendant was seized in a "high crime area" cannot alone justify excessive police behavior.

 

474 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ramos


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


150 A.D.2d 811; 543 N.Y.S.2d 288; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7270



May 30, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed.

 

475 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Islip v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


147 A.D.2d 56; 541 N.Y.S.2d 829; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7117



May 15, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order and judgment is modified, on the law, by deleting the second and third decretal paragraphs thereof, and substituting therefor provisions dismissing so much of the plaintiffs' fifth cause of action as is based on allegations (1) that ECL 27-0704 (2) is unconstitutional insofar as it authorizes the Commissioner of the DEC to adopt changes in the boundaries of the deep flow recharge area, and (2) that ECL 27-0704 (4) (a) is unconstitutional insofar as it authorizes the Commissioner of the DEC to determine whether proposed landfills outside the deep flow recharge area pose a threat to groundwater quality; as so modified, the order and judgment is affirmed insofar as appealed and cross-appealed from, without costs or disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant town and respondent state cross-appealed from the Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York), which declared that N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 (2) violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1, that N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 (4) (a) was not violative of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1, and that N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 was not violative of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16.


OVERVIEW: The trial court held that N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 incorporated a preexisting "law," and thus violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16. The court reversed because the major purpose of the constitutional requirement that a statute contain an explicit recitation of its terms, rather than an indirect expression of them through the incorporation of another law, was to assist all persons concerned -- such as the lawmakers themselves or those to be affected by the law -- to easily and readily comprehend what the law actually means. However, the court held that the statute in question not only referred to another document (not a "law"), but also expressly stated where that document could be found, so it violated neither the letter nor the spirit of the constitution. The court also concluded that any question involving the constitutionality of the legislature's delegation of certain authority on the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation presented no justiciable controversy because there was no indication that the Commissioner considered exercising the power which the trial court enjoined him from exercising.


OUTCOME: The court found that the trial court erred insofar as it declared that one environmental protection statute unconstitutionally incorporated another law. The court further found that the trial court's declaration that other portions of the environmental statutes were constitutional should be deleted because there was no justiciable controversy.


HEADNOTES

Environmental Conservation -- Solid Waste Management Facility --  Limitations on Siting Landfills -- Constitutionality of Statute

1. ECL 27-0704, which places limitations on the ability of local governments in Nassau and Suffolk Counties to build new landfills or expand existing landfills within any geographic area designated as "a deep flow recharge area", as defined in the Long Island Comprehensive Waste Treatment Management Plan of 1978, does not violate NY Constitution, article III, § 16, which prohibits one statute from incorporating by reference another statute, since the aforementioned Plan cannot be characterized properly as a "law"; rather, it is a scientific study which contains certain geological data. Accordingly, the terms of the Constitution, construed literally, do not apply, and even if the constitutional provision is liberally interpreted, there would be no violation since there is no realistic possibility that any party likely to be affected by the statute has been left ignorant of its scope, and since there is little chance that a revision of the Plan would have consequences unforeseen, much less overlooked, by the Legislature. Moreover, there is no evidence that the hydrogeologic zones, which may be changed by administrative action, have ever undergone revision; thus, whether the automatic incorporation of a revised Plan would violate the Constitution is an academic question.

Courts -- Justiciable Questions -- Environmental Conservation -- Landfills and Groundwater

2. In an action in which plaintiff town sought a declaration that ECL 27-0704 (2) is an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power to the extent that it permits the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation to alter the boundaries of "a deep flow recharge area", within which landfills may not be built or expanded, no justiciable controversy is presented since the Commissioner has never changed the boundaries of such area and there is no allegation of his having any intent to do so in the future; consequently, any question involving the constitutionality of the Legislature's delegation to the Commissioner of the power to make changes is essentially academic. Any declaration would be purely advisory and there is no indication that plaintiff plans to construct or operate a landfill in any area outside the boundaries of a deep flow recharge area as it is now defined. The harm which plaintiff anticipates, i.e., an enlargement of the area in question, may never occur; thus, there is no controversy ripe for judicial review.

Parties -- Standing -- Environmental Conservation -- Landfills and Groundwater

3. In an action in which plaintiff town sought a declaration that ECL 27-0704 (2) is an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power to the extent it permits the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation to alter the boundaries of "a deep flow recharge area", within which landfills may not be built or expanded, plaintiff lacks standing since there is nothing to indicate that such an alteration of the boundaries of the area is contemplated, and, thus, there is no indication of how plaintiff may be aggrieved by any such alteration; plaintiff has failed to show how its property rights or interests have been injured by the actual or threatened use of the power to alter boundaries of such recharge area.

Parties -- Standing -- Environmental Conservation -- Landfills and Groundwater

4. In a declaratory judgment action, the court erred in considering the assertion of plaintiff town that ECL 27-0704 (2) violates the constitutional prohibition against delegation of legislative powers to an administrative agency (see, NY Const, art III, § 1) insofar as it delegates to the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation the authority to prevent the construction of new landfills or the expansion of existing landfills in Nassau or Suffolk Counties outside "deep flow recharge areas", where there is only one basic factual controversy between the parties, viz., plaintiff's application for permission to construct a landfill on a site which is located entirely within a recharge area. The Commissioner is entrusted with the discretion to determine whether construction or expansion of a landfill would pose a threat to groundwater quality (see, ECL 27-0704 [4] [a]), and plaintiff has not shown itself to have been adversely affected since it has neither alleged nor proved that the Commissioner has exercised, or has threatened to exercise, the power to preclude the construction of landfills outside the boundaries of the current recharge area. Accordingly, there is no justiciable controversy.

Courts -- Justiciable Questions -- Lack of One Party to Address Question

5. In a declaratory judgment action in which it has been determined that there is no justiciable controversy, notwithstanding the fact that the lack of a justiciable controversy was argued solely by one party, the court should examine the issue, since lack of a justiciable controversy is a fundamental defect.

 

476 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


McGraw-Hill, Inc. v. State Tax Com.


No. 57346


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


146 A.D.2d 371; 541 N.Y.S.2d 252; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6197


March 20, 1989, Argued  
May 11, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Determination annulled, with costs, petition granted and matter remitted to respondent for further proceedings not inconsistent with this court's decision.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner corporation brought a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to review a determination of respondent, the state tax commission (commission), which sustained a corporate franchise tax assessment imposed under N.Y. Tax Law art. 9-A.


OVERVIEW: The commission concluded that because N.Y. Code R. & Regs. tit. 20, § 4-4.3(f)(2) applied only to receipts from radio and television advertising, it did not affect the prior practice of treating receipts from magazine advertisements under the origin formula. The commission sustained the audit division's notices of deficiency and presumed the constitutionality of its interpretation because it was uncontroverted that the advertising contracts originated in New York. The court granted the corporation's petition, finding that the regulation was unconstitutional under U.S. Const. amend. I. The court concluded that the regulation permitted the broadcasting of commercial messages by way of radio or television to be classified as a service, but such a classification during the audit period was not permitted for the corporation, whose advertising receipts arose from sales of advertising contained in its publications. The court determined that the difference in treatment between the print and broadcast media under the regulation violated amend. I guarantee of freedom of the press, and the commission did not show that the regulation was necessary to serve a compelling state interest.


OUTCOME: The court granted the corporation's petition, and annulled the commission's determination, finding that the regulation at issue was unconstitutional under the First Amendment. The court remitted the matter to the commission for further proceedings not inconsistent with its opinion.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Transfer to Appellate Division -- Retention of Proceeding Improperly Transferred

1. Inasmuch as a proceeding to review a determination of the State Tax Commission sustaining a corporate franchise tax assessment concerned only questions of law, it did not involve an issue of substantial evidence under CPLR 7803 (4) and was, therefore, improperly transferred to the Appellate Division; however, in the interest of judicial economy, the court shall address the merits of the case.

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Tax on Print Media Advertising Revenue -- Constitutionality of Differentiation between Print and Broadcast Media

2. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Tax Commission sustaining a corporate franchise tax assessment against a nationwide magazine publisher on the grounds that the entire amount of net receipts it derived from advertising should be used in calculating the tax (i.e., the origin formula), rather than only that percentage of the total net advertising income that its New York circulation bore to the total circulation (i.e., the destination formula), a regulation (20 NYCRR 4-4.3 [f] [2]), which provided that the destination formula should be applied only to receipts from broadcast media, violates the First Amendment guarantee of freedom of the press by permitting a difference in treatment between the print and broadcast media; a tax that singles out the press for differential treatment is presumptively unconstitutional, and a taxing scheme which taxes some members of the press but exempts others of the press does not escape First Amendment scrutiny even if businesses outside of the press are also not exempt. Given the disparate treatment between the print and broadcast media, it was incumbent upon the Commission to show that the regulation was necessary to serve a compelling State interest, and the Commission failed to do so; although the unique nature of electronic media makes it more susceptible to government regulation and there are many differences between the two media, those factors do not justify the different treatment.

 

477 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Eyedent v. Vickers Management


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


150 A.D.2d 202; 541 N.Y.S.2d 210; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6221



May 11, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner tenants sought review of the order of the Appellate Term, Supreme Court, First Department (New York), which reversed a lower court's grant of their motion to compel respondent landlords to correct deficiencies in certain apartment buildings and denied the tenants' motion without prejudice. Respondent, New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD), joined the action, but supported the tenants.


OVERVIEW: The city building department issued a vacate order to evacuate the tenants when the landlords failed to make certain repairs to the apartment buildings to make them fit for habitability. The tenants sought to compel the landlords to make the necessary repairs. The landlords argued that the vacate order terminated the tenancies and that forcing them to make the repairs was a taking of their property under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments. The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court and reinstated the order of the lower court. The court held that the vacate order did not terminate the tenancies because the vacate order were issued to protect public safety and required that the landlords correct the conditions that rendered the buildings unfit for habitability under New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 27-2140(c)(1). The court rejected the landlords' contention of economic hardship because the need to make the repairs should have been anticipated. The court rejected the landlords' contention of an unconstitutional taking because they failed to present any evidence of the economic value of the premises or of the cost of repairs.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and vacated the order of the appellate court, reinstated the order of the lower court in granting judgment in favor of the tenants to compel the landlords to make repairs to their apartment buildings, and remanded the matter to a housing court for appropriate relief.

 

478 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Duboy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


150 A.D.2d 882; 540 N.Y.S.2d 905; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6193



May 11, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from: 1) a judgment of the County Court of Albany County (New York), which convicted defendant upon his plea of guilty of the crimes of use of a child in a sexual performance and sodomy in the second degree, and 2) an order of the same court which denied defendant's motion pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10 to vacate the judgment of conviction, without a hearing.


OVERVIEW: Following allegations that defendant performed sexual acts with and photographed nude children, and the discovery at his apartment of various books, magazines and photographs of nude children performing sexual acts, defendant was charged with various sex crimes. Defendant pleaded guilty to single counts of use of a child in sexual performance and sodomy in the second degree. Defendant argued that acts performed in the privacy of his residence were protected. The Supreme Court held that the state's compelling interest in regulating child pornography was not dependent on whether the material was distributed commercially or possessed privately because the focus was on the harm to the child. Such logic was equally applicable to Penal Law § 263.05, that was not violative of the constitutional right of privacy or overbroad as prohibiting private acts as claimed by defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment and order.

 

479 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Simon


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


146 A.D.2d 393; 540 N.Y.S.2d 791; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 16859



May 9, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Respondent's name is stricken from the roll of attorneys and counselors-at-law in the State of New York effective May 9, 1989.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the Departmental Disciplinary Committee, sought an order striking respondent attorney's name from the roll of attorneys pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 90(4)(b), based on the attorney's federal felony conviction.


OVERVIEW: The attorney was convicted of aiding and conspiring to aide a racketeering enterprise, extortion, receiving a bribe, mail fraud, and perjury. The Committee argued that the attorney's conviction for giving a false declaration before a grand jury under 18 U.S.C.S. 1623 was essentially similar to a perjury violation under N.Y. Penal Law § 210.15, and that his name should be stricken from the roll of attorneys. Counsel for the attorney stated that the attorney was appealing his convictions, and that the application of § 90(4)(a) to provide for the automatic disbarment, prior to the resolution of his appeal, constituted deprivation of the attorney's property without due process of law. The court held that that argument had already been rejected. Under the statutory scheme, disbarment at the time of the attorney's conviction was required. If the conviction was subsequently reversed or the attorney was pardoned, he could then seek vacatur or modification of the disbarment under N.Y. Jud. Law § 90(5).


OUTCOME: The court denied the attorney's request that he be suspended pending determination of his appeal. The court granted the Committee's request and it ordered that the attorney's name be stricken from the roll of attorneys.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Disciplinary Proceedings

Respondent attorney, who was found guilty of the Federal crimes of aiding a racketeering enterprise, conspiring to aid a racketeering enterprise, extortion, receiving a bribe, mail fraud, perjury, and filing a false income tax return, is disbarred since he automatically ceased to be an attorney upon his conviction for perjury, which concededly is analogous to the New York felony of perjury in the first degree; respondent's contention that Judiciary Law § 90 (4) (a), which provides for automatic disbarment upon conviction of a felony, violates his constitutional right to due process is without merit since the constitutionality of the statute has specifically been upheld. The unequivocal language of the statute demonstrates the Legislature's intent to disbar convicted felons without waiting for the criminal appeal process to be exhausted; Judiciary Law § 90 (5), which provides for the vacatur or modification of the disbarment if the conviction is subsequently reversed or pardoned, evidences the Legislature's rejection of an alternative to automatic disbarment and establishes that an automatically disbarred attorney is not without recourse in the event of a successful appeal.

 

480 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Seaboard Contracting & Material, Inc. v. Smithtown


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


147 A.D.2d 4; 541 N.Y.S.2d 216; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6526



May 8, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order and judgment (one paper) is reversed, on the law, with costs, the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is denied, upon searching the record, the defendants are granted summary judgment, and it is declared that the the provisions of Town of Smithtown Code chapters 44A and 54 insofar as they are applicable to the mining industry are constitutional on their face, and that the Town of Smithtown is a proper lead agency under the New York State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL article 8), and the complaint is otherwise dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant town appealed from the Supreme Court in Suffolk County (New York), which granted a motion by plaintiff for summary judgment in an action for a judgment declaring that certain provisions of the town code were unconstitutional insofar as they were applicable to the mining industry, adjudged those provisions unconstitutional, and transferred lead agency status from defendant town to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff, the owner of mineral rights of a residentially zoned parcel of real property located in defendant town, sought to declare that the provisions of the town code, Smithtown, N.Y., Code §§ 54 and 44A, were unconstitutional insofar as they were applicable to the mining industry. The town had enacted amendments to the ordinance to allow sand mining only within districts specifically zoned for heavy industry. The amendment provided that any enterprise seeking to conduct a sand mining operation within a "heavy industry" district had to comply with certain requirements and had to establish that the proposed mining operation would not produce a significant adverse effect upon the environment. The court reversed the granting of summary judgment in favor of plaintiff. The court disagreed with the lower court that the New York State Mined Land Reclamation Law, ECL § 23-2701 et seq., preempted the challenged ordinances and found that the ordinances were constitutional on their face. Further, the court found the ordinance in question was enacted as a proper exercise of the town's legislative function for legitimate objectives in furtherance of the town's health and general welfare.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the granting of plaintiff owner's motion for summary judgment, in its suit against the town to declare certain town ordinances were unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Mining -- Constitutionality -- State Preemption

1. Two local ordinances, one which regulates the destruction and removal of trees and the other which allows sand mining only in certain districts and pursuant to various restrictions, are constitutional on their face and were not superseded by the State Mined Land Reclamation Law (see, ECL 23-2703 [2]), which provides that local laws are superseded with respect to mining but that localities may impose stricter land reclamation standards, since the mining ordinance deals with the location of the mining and not its operation, and the tree removal ordinance does not constitute an impermissible limitation upon the right to conduct sand mining operations; the tree removal ordinance was a reasonable response to concerns involving the welfare of the community and any impact upon mining operations appears to be incidental rather than as a result of a covert design to circumvent the comprehensive plan for mining set forth in the State statute. The tree removal ordinance is facially constitutional since it applies equally to all landowners in the community; a proceeding pursuant to CPLR article 78 is the appropriate forum to challenge the constitutionality of the ordinance as applied to a particular mining operation.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Lead Agency

2. In an action for a judgment declaring two local ordinances which affected petitioner's mining operation unconstitutional, Supreme Court erred when it transferred lead-agency status from the locality to the State Department of Environmental Conservation since the anticipated impact of the proposed mining operation is of local rather than State-wide significance; therefore, pursuant to 6 NYCRR 617.6 (e) (5) the town should retain its status as lead agency for purposes of the Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8).

 

481 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York State Ass'n of Counties v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


150 A.D.2d 845; 540 N.Y.S.2d 599; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5443



May 4, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Commissioner of the New York State Department of Health (department) appealed an order of the Supreme Court of Albany County (New York), which denied the department's motion to dismiss the complaint in an action by plaintiff New York State Association of Counties (county association) challenging defendant's implementation of a new Medicaid reimbursement methodology for nursing homes.


OVERVIEW: The department implemented a new Medicaid reimbursement methodology for nursing homes under N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, § 86-2. The county association brought an action on behalf of those counties that owned and operated nursing homes, challenging the regulations. The department brought a motion to dismiss the complaint on the ground that the claims were barred by the four-month limitations period applicable to proceedings under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78. The trial court denied the motion, and the department appealed. The court modified by reversing as to certain causes of action and otherwise affirmed. The court held that the Article 78 limitation period applied to bar the causes of action alleging that the department acted arbitrarily and capriciously and that the regulations violated federal and state law, because there had been another form of judicial proceeding, namely under Article 78, available to the county association for resolution of their claims. The causes of action challenging the methodology on constitutional grounds were not time-barred because constitutional challenges could not be brought through Article 78 proceedings.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's order by reversing so much thereof as denied the department's motion to dismiss the complaint as to three of the association's causes of action challenging the department's implementation of a new methodology for Medicaid reimbursement, granting the motion as to such causes of action, and dismissing them as time-barred. As so modified, the court affirmed the order.

 

482 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Migliore


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


150 A.D.2d 169; 540 N.Y.S.2d 442; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5421



May 2, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People challenged the decision of the Supreme Court, New York County, which convicted defendant of criminal possession of a controlled substance and sentenced her to an indeterminate term of imprisonment from four years to life.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance and sentenced to an indeterminate term of imprisonment from four years to life. The People appealed. On review, the court found that when the trial court sentenced defendant if found that the statute mandating a minimum sentence of 15 years to life would be unconstitutional. N.Y. Penal Law §§ 220.21, 60.05(2); § 70.00(2)(a)(i). However, the court found that the trial court erred. The court reasoned that defendant did not play a merely passive role as a courier for her husband, but instead was a willing and active participant in the sale of over a pound of heroin, more than four times the threshold weight required for conviction. Moreover, defendant perjured herself at trial by fabricating a story about a package containing pastry implements rather than heroin. Therefore, defendant's sentence was modified and defendant was resentenced to a term of imprisonment from 15 years to life.


OUTCOME: The trial court's decision that sentenced defendant to a minimum of four years imprisonment for criminal possession of a controlled substance was modified to a minimum of 15 years.

 

483 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


United University Professions v. Newman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


146 A.D.2d 273; 540 N.Y.S.2d 579; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5006



April 27, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Determination modified, without costs, by annulling so much thereof as ordered petitioner to make full refunds to all charging parties; matter remitted to the Public Employment Relations Board for further proceedings not inconsistent with this court's decision; and, as so modified, confirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Upon transfer by the Supreme Court, in Albany County (New York) for a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding, petitioner organization, a certified public employee organization, sought review of respondent Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) members' determination, which partially sustained improper practice charges filed against the organization because its agency shop fee refund procedures for certain years were inadequate.


OVERVIEW: The organization was authorized to collect agency shop fees from employees within a negotiating unit who were not members of the organization, but the organization had to provide a refund procedure. The organization objected to PERB's determination that its refund procedures for certain fiscal years were improper. The court ruled in favor of PERB, except as to the procedural issues raised by the organization, which were not addressed by PERB. The court found, inter alia, that (1) given the existence of acceptable alternatives, a union could not be allowed to commit dissenters' funds to improper uses even temporarily; (2) the potential objectors to how agency shop fees were spent were to be given sufficient information to gauge the propriety of the union's fee; (3) PERB erred in ordering refunds to all charging parties without first passing on the organization's procedural objections; and (4) if an improper practice charge was subject to dismissal for procedural deficiencies, the charging party clearly would not be entitled to relief, such that the matter should be remitted to PERB for a determination of organization's procedural objections contained in its exceptions on appeal.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed as modified, without costs, PERB's decision by annulling so much thereof as ordered the organization to make full refunds to all charging parties, and it remitted the matter to PERB for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law -- Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies -- Procedural Objections

1. In a proceeding transferred to the Appellate Division to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate, although PERB failed to address procedural issues raised by petitioner concerning the timeliness and sufficiency of the improper practice charges filed against it arising out of its refund procedures and such failure would ordinarily be cause for a remittal to PERB for its determination of the merits of petitioner's procedural objections prior to judicial review of PERB's substantive determination, enough of the various charges fall outside the scope of petitioner's procedural objections to permit PERB's substantive review of the validity of petitioner's refund procedures for the years in issue.

Civil Service -- Public Employee Organization -- Agency Shop Fees -- Refund Procedure

2. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate, there is no basis for disturbing PERB's determination that the procedures, which allowed an "advance reduction" payment to be made after the commencement of the fiscal year (i.e., after collection of the fees had begun) created a risk that an objector's funds would be improperly used, at least temporarily, to finance political or ideological activities; the union's argument that owing to the State's lag payroll the risk was minimal is unavailing since there existed an acceptable alternative which virtually eliminated the risk by requiring that the "advance reduction" payment be made at the beginning of the fiscal year, an alternative that petitioner adopted in its refund procedures for later years.

Civil Service -- Public Employee Organization -- Agency Shop Fees -- Refund Procedure

3. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate owing to the failure to provide financial information to the agency fee payers prior to the opportunity to object to the "advance reduction" refund, there is nothing irrational in PERB's conclusion that mere inclusion of the union's financial information in a union newspaper, without making any effort to alert potential objectors, was inadequate.

Civil Service -- Public Employee Organization -- Agency Shop Fees -- Refund Procedure -- Independent Audit

4. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate, PERB's determination that the refund procedures be accompanied by an independent audit did not require the independent auditor to make legal determinations as to the portions of the fees used for permissible and impermissible purposes, but only to verify the expenditures claimed by petitioner.

Civil Service -- Public Employee Organization -- Agency Shop Fees -- Refund Procedure -- Appeal

5. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate, there is no cause to disturb PERB's conclusion that petitioner's two-step appeal procedure at the completion of the fiscal year did not comply with the constitutional requirement of a reasonably prompt decision by an impartial decision maker.

Civil Service -- Public Employee Organization -- Agency Shop Fees -- Refund Procedure -- Escrow Account

6. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate, PERB properly required that petitioner maintain a 10% "cushion" in an escrow account for amounts reasonably in dispute while challenges to the amount of the fee are pending, since the amount of the "advance reduction" payment petitioner would make to objectors is an estimate based upon a prior year's expenditures, thereby creating the potential for an impermissible use of agency shop fee payers' moneys; inasmuch as the actual amount to be refunded cannot be determined until the actual expenditures are determined at the end of the fiscal year, PERB could conclude that 10% of the "advance reduction" payment would adequately reflect the amount reasonably in dispute.

Civil Service -- Public Employee Organization -- Agency Shop Fees -- Refund Procedure -- Filing Objections

7. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate, there is no merit in petitioner's contention that PERB's determination must be annulled insofar as it concluded that the 15-day filing period for objections and the union's requirement that objections be filed by certified mail were overly burdensome, unreasonable and coercive, since procedures must be carefully tailored to minimize the infringement on an objector's constitutional rights.

Civil Service -- Public Employee Organization -- Agency Shop Fees -- Refund Procedure

8. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate, PERB's requirement that the refund procedure must include an appeals procedure for an end-of-the-year adjustment based upon actual expenditures, in addition to the appeal provided by the refund procedures at the time of the advance payment based upon a prior fiscal year's expenditures, was not irrational since PERB imposed that requirement based upon its construction of the refund procedure provision of the aforecited statute.

Civil Service -- Public Employee Organization -- Agency Shop Fees -- Refund Procedure 

9. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) which found that petitioner public employee organization's agency shop fee refund procedures (see, Civil Service Law § 208 [3] [a]) were inadequate, PERB erred in ordering refunds to all charging parties without first passing on petitioner's procedural objections to the improper practice charges filed against it, since if an improper practice charge is subject to dismissal for procedural deficiencies, the charging party clearly would not be entitled to relief; accordingly, the matter should be remitted to PERB for a determination of petitioner's procedural objections contained in its exceptions on appeal and in the event that PERB sustains any of those objections, it should fashion an appropriate remedy.

 

484 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Asso. v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


146 A.D.2d 212; 540 N.Y.S.2d 888; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4902



April 20, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order modified, on the law, without costs, by deleting so much thereof as declared 13 NYCRR 300.17 (c) within the Attorney-General's rule-making authority; it is declared that 13 NYCRR 300.17 (c) is invalid; and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff trade associations brought an action against defendant state seeking to declare N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198-a(k) constitutionally invalid and to invalidate certain of the statute's implementing regulations. The Supreme Court (New York) declared both the statute's New Car Lemon Law arbitration mechanism and implementing regulations constitutionally valid. The trade associations appealed.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198-a(k) implemented the New Car Lemon Law alternative arbitration mechanism. The trade associations brought an action against the state seeking to declare the statute constitutionally invalid and to invalidate certain of the statute's implementing regulations. The trial court declared the arbitration mechanism and implementing regulations constitutionally valid. On appeal, the trade associations contended that the compulsory arbitration requirements of the statute deprived car manufacturers of their right to trial by jury. The court held (1) the remedy under the Lemon Law was equitable in nature and no right to trial by jury had been impaired by virtue of alternative arbitration mechanism, (2) there was no per se constitutional right of access to the civil courts, (3) although the attorney general had broad authority to implement the arbitration program, there was no authority to promulgate regulations that contravened the governing statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's finding that the statute passed constitutional muster. The court held that the implementation regulations, with the exception of one, were valid.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration -- Replacement Vehicle

1. The compulsory arbitration requirements of the New Car Lemon Law (see, General Business Law § 198-a [k]) do not deprive automobile manufacturers of their constitutional right to trial by jury since acceptance of a replacement vehicle of comparable quality, one of the remedies under the law, is purely equitable in nature, akin to a direction for specific performance, for which there is no right to a jury trial; under the Uniform Commercial Code, a buyer of goods may seek specific performance where "the goods are unique or in other proper circumstances" (UCC 2-716 [1]), and the Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a) was enacted to afford consumers a more effective avenue of redress and may readily be considered a "proper circumstance" for equitable relief.

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration -- Refund Claim

2. The compulsory arbitration requirements of the New Car Lemon Law (see, General Business Law § 198-a [k]) do not deprive automobile manufacturers of their constitutional right to trial by jury since a consumer's claim for a refund, one of the remedies under the law, is equitable in nature, for which there is no right to a jury trial. The Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a) does not anticipate an initial revocation of the product on the part of the buyer; the statute speaks to a manufacturer's acceptance of a vehicle from the consumer, but does not explicitly require an outright rejection of the contract by the consumer (see, General Business Law § 198-a [c] [1]). Thus, the Lemon Law provides an equitable alternative akin to the remedy of restitution, which serves to restore the status quo ante without mandating a literal rescission of the contract, and the fact that incidental costs are recoverable does not compel a contrary conclusion, since a party may receive full relief in an equity action. Moreover, while incidental items are recoverable, consequential damages are not, and the purpose of the Lemon Law was clearly designed as an alternative to the traditional methods of consumer recovery.

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration -- Right of Access to Supreme Court

3. The compulsory arbitration requirements of the New Car Lemon Law (see, General Business Law § 198-a [k]) do not violate automobile manufacturers' constitutional right of access to Supreme Court's jurisdiction (see, NY Const, art VI, § 7 [a]) since there is no per se constitutional right of access to the civil courts, and the arbitration provides a reasonable alternative to judicial resolution of Lemon Law claims. Although the selection of a forum rests with the consumer, not the manufacturer, given the obvious inequality in their bargaining positions, there is no impropriety. Therefore, the absence of a de novo judicial review provision does not invalidate section 198-a (k).

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration -- Delegation of Judicial Authority

4. The compulsory arbitration requirements of the New Car Lemon Law (see, General Business Law § 198-a [k]) do not constitute an unconstitutional delegation of judicial authority since automobile manufacturers do not have a fundamental right to a jury trial because the Lemon Law remedies (see, General Business Law § 198-a) are equitable in nature. Moreover, the statute does not work an abdication of judicial responsibility since the Legislature has specifically provided for arbitration by impartial arbitrators and for judicial review of any awards, which review is at the heightened standard attendant compulsory arbitration awards (see, CPLR 7511 [b] [1] [iii]). Given that judicial supervision, the fact that nonjudicial personnel adjudicate claims in the first instance does not render the mechanism constitutionally infirm; in essence, the arbitration process remains within the judicial domain.

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration -- Irrebuttable Standard of Liability

5. A regulation (13 NYCRR 300.17 [c]) implementing the compulsory arbitration requirements of the New Car Lemon Law (see, General Business Law § 198-a [k]) inhibits a viable defense by converting the presumption of reasonableness set forth in General Business Law § 198-a (d) into an irrebuttable standard of liability, since the statute presumes that reasonable effort to repair has been made where the vehicle has undergone four repair attempts or remains out of service for 30 days; although the statutory language does not establish a conclusive presumption, the regulation has precisely that effect by providing that arbitrators "shall not consider evidence that the nonconformity, defect or condition can be corrected through further repairs". There is no authority to promulgate regulations that contravene the governing statute, and while arbitrators may not direct further repairs, such evidence is clearly relevant to the ultimate issue of whether the consumer qualifies for a refund or a replacement.

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration -- Implementing Regulations

6. The alternate arbitration procedure established by the New Car Lemon Law (see, General Business Law § 198-a [k]) is not an "adjudicatory proceeding" within the meaning of the State Administrative Procedure Act, since the arbitration program is conducted by a professional arbitration firm or arbitrator, not an "agency" as defined in State Administrative Procedure Act § 102 (1); nor is there any "on the record" requirement for the new Lemon Law arbitration procedure. Consequently, the failure to implement the procedural safeguards set forth in State Administrative Procedure Act article 3 does not vitiate the compulsory arbitration mechanism.

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration -- Due Process

7. The mechanism for implementing the compulsory arbitration requirements of the New Car Lemon Law (see, General Business Law § 198-a [k]) accords the participating parties procedural due process, since manufacturers must be given timely notice of any claim; the arbitrator must be impartial; any relevant evidence may be introduced and any testimony given under oath; parties may retain counsel; and the awards are subject to judicial review pursuant to CPLR article 75.

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Compulsory Arbitration -- Judicial  Review 

8. Effective judicial review of awards rendered pursuant to the compulsory arbitration requirements of the New Car Lemon Law (see, General Business Law § 198-a [k]) is not precluded notwithstanding that a complete record as set forth in State Administrative Procedure Act § 302 (1) is not required and the arbitrator simply renders a decision "in writing" (see, CPLR 7507), since the arbitration decision form being utilized provides for the summary of the evidence and findings of fact (see, 13 NYCRR 300.17 [a]), and manufacturers are not precluded from requesting a stenographic transcript. In any event, the developed record must provide a rational basis for the arbitrator's decision, thereby assuring meaningful review.

 

485 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Udzinski


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


146 A.D.2d 245; 541 N.Y.S.2d 9; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5019



April 17, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Suffolk County Court (New York), which, upon a jury verdict, convicted him of sexual abuse in the first degree, assault in the second degree, and assault in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: In addition to two other crimes, which defendant was not appealing, a jury convicted defendant of sexual abuse in the first degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 130.65(1), which provided that a person was guilty of sexual abuse in the first degree when he subjected another person to sexual contact by "forcible compulsion." On appeal, defendant argued that although the indictment charged defendant with the use of actual force, the jury was allowed to convict him by finding a threat of force. The court affirmed his conviction. While it would be error for the trial judge to instruct the jury, over objection, that the crime could be committed through a threat when the indictment charges use of actual force, counsel for defendant failed to object to the jury charge. The error of the trial judge in giving the correct definition of the crime but not narrowing the definition to what was contained in the indictment was not such a fundamental irregularity that it should be reviewed, despite defendant's failure to preserve the point for appeal through an objection. Defendant's consecutive sentences were affirmed because the charged offenses involved distinct acts without common material elements.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review -- Right to be Tried Only on Theories Charged in Indictment

1. An error in a jury charge, which defendant claims constituted a violation of his constitutional right to be tried only upon theories charged in the indictment, is not reviewable as a matter of law in the absence of a timely objection. Accordingly, where the indictment specified that defendant committed sodomy through the use of actual force alone, it was error for the Trial Judge to have instructed the jury that the crime may also be committed by the use of the threat of force; however, that error was not jurisdictional or otherwise fundamental, and far from working a radical change, constituted, at worse, an instruction which conveyed to the jury the correct definition of the elements of the crime with which defendant was charged, where the indictment against defendant purportedly led him to believe that the People would limit their "theory" so as to, in effect, narrow the definition of the crime. The preservation doctrine, which requires that errors be objected to at trial when there still is time to cure any defects, applies to many errors affecting fundamental rights, encourages parties to be vigilant, serves as a means of avoiding errors in the first instance, and should only be circumvented where a question of jurisdiction or fundamental rights is involved and public injury would result.

Crimes -- Harmless and Prejudicial Error -- Right to be Tried Only on Theories Charged in Indictment

2. In a sex crimes prosecution in which the Trial Judge instructed the jury that the crime of sodomy may be committed by the use of the threat of force, whereas the indictment charged and the prosecutor attempted to prove that defendant used actual force to commit the crime, the error was harmless since defendant was not in any way prejudiced by the alleged error and there was no possibility that that error affected the jury's verdict; under no rational view of the evidence could the jury have convicted defendant based on a finding that he threatened but did not actually exert physical force, the evidence showing that defendant accomplished his crime by actual force as well as by the threats naturally implicit therein.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review -- Guilt of Offense Not Charged in Indictment

3. It is not always a nonwaivable jurisdictional error for a Trial Judge to instruct the jury in a criminal case that it may find defendant guilty of an offense not charged in the indictment; jurisdictional error does not occur even when a Trial Judge submits to the jury a crime which is neither itself contained in the indictment, nor one which is necessarily included within any charge contained in the indictment as a lesser included offense. A defendant may, by failing to make a timely objection, forfeit his right to appellate review of a claim that the Trial Judge erroneously allowed criminal liability to be imposed for a crime which not only was not charged in the indictment, but which also might never have been considered by the Grand Jury, since such error is not so fundamental as to be properly reviewable in the absence of an objection. Accordingly, assuming that sexual abuse in the first degree perpetrated by threats of force is a different crime from sexual abuse in the first degree perpetrated by the use of actual force, it was not jurisdictional error, thereby reviewable on appeal in the absence of a timely objection, to have instructed the jury that it may find defendant guilty if he used threats where the indictment mentioned only the actual use of force.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review -- Right to be Tried Only on Theories Charged in Indictment -- Fair Notice to Defendant

4. In a sex crimes prosecution in which the indictment stated that defendant committed the crime of sodomy by the use of actual force and the Trial Judge instructed the jury that it could find defendant guilty if he merely threatened the use of force, the alleged variance between the terms of the indictment and the charge was so slight as to render inconceivable the idea that defendant might have been deprived of fair notice of the theory that the prosecution would pursue as that theory was ultimately reflected in the jury charge. Had defendant registered a timely protest, the error would likely have been cured; however, inasmuch as there was no possibility that defendant was deprived of fair notice of the basis for the accusations against him, no question of law is presented for appellate review in the absence of a timely objection at trial.

 

486 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Green


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, FOURTH DEPARTMENT


146 A.D.2d 281; 540 N.Y.S.2d 95; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5992



April 14, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order of the Supreme Court, Erie County (New York), which convicted and sentenced him upon his plea of guilty to the crime of attempted rape in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pleaded guilty by way of an Alford plea to avoid conviction on more serious charges after the trial court denied his motion for a mistrial based on the prosecution's allegedly discriminatory use of peremptory challenges to exclude all black venire persons from the jury. The trial court also denied a subsequent motion by defendant to withdraw his plea. The court affirmed the order of the trial court. The court held that (1) defendant's Batson claim was subsumed within the waiver of his right to a trial that resulted from his guilty plea and did not survive the guilty plea; (2) a Batson motion would not be treated like the denial of a suppression motion because the right to appeal a suppression ruling after a guilty plea was provided by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 710.70(2) and the statutory exception should not be judicially expanded; and (3) precedent cited by defendant was distinguishable because in that case the defendant had waived a jury trial, not pleaded guilty.


OUTCOME: On appeal, the court affirmed the conviction and sentence.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Plea of Guilty -- Forfeiture of Right to Raise Issues on Appeal -- Discriminatory Use of Peremptory Challenges

A defendant who timely objects to the allegedly discriminatory use of peremptory challenges by the prosecutor (see, Batson v Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79) foregoes his right to raise that issue on appeal after he enters a plea of guilty, since defendant, by pleading guilty, specifically waives his right to any trial, either jury or nonjury, and his plea renders irrelevant his contention that the criminal proceedings preliminary to trial were infected with impropriety and error. Defendant's Batson rights are no greater than his right to a jury trial itself which is waived by a guilty plea. Moreover, defendant's contention that his Batson motion should be treated in the same manner as the denial of a suppression motion, which survives the plea, is without merit since defendant's right to challenge a suppression ruling after pleading guilty is a specific exception created by statute ( CPL 710.70 [2]) that should not be judicially expanded.

 

487 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bredero Vast Goed, N. v. v. Tax Com. of State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


146 A.D.2d 155; 539 N.Y.S.2d 823; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4388



April 6, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, corporations and real estate company, challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court in Albany County (New York) which dismissed their petition to review the determination of appellee state tax commission, which assessed a real property transfer gains tax pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law art. 31-B.


OVERVIEW: A real estate company that was jointly owned by three corporations entered into a partnership agreement whereby it assigned its rights in a piece of real estate to the limited partnership. The real estate company and its individual partner orally agreed that the individual's designee would acquire the realty company's stock for a sum that was commensurate with 85 percent of the appraised property value of the real estate. The state tax commission assessed a 10 percent gains tax on the transfer pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law art. 31-B after it was characterized as a transfer of real property in excess of $ 1,000,000. The lower court upheld that assessment. The court held that the tax commission rationally determined that the transaction was a transfer of real property because: (1) N. Y. Tax law § 1440(7) employed an expansive, rather than a literal, definition of real property to maximize revenue, and (2) the statute included transfers of any interest in real property. The court deferred to the state tax commission's rational decision to look beyond the two-tiered nature of the conveyance in order to determine that the parties effectively transferred an interest in the real estate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment without costs.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Gains Tax -- Two-Tiered Conveyance

1. The State Tax Commission rationally determined that a transaction was subject to the real property transfer gains tax imposed by Tax Law article 31-B, where one corporation acquired stock from another corporation which had an 85% interest in a partnership which, in turn, held title to certain real property, since the definition of "transfer of real property" (Tax Law § 1440 [7]) includes transfers of "any interest in real property by any method, including but not limited to" certain described formats, and that broad, expansive definition was designed to maximize revenues. The statutory definition evinces a legislative deferral to the Commission's construction of the transfer concept; the Commission looked beyond the two-tiered nature of the conveyance and determined that petitioner corporations effectively transferred an interest in the property and that determination keys into the economic reality that the partnership's sole asset consisted of the subject property and that the new 85% general partner acquired a controlling interest in the real estate.

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Gains Tax -- Federal Preemption

2. The State Tax Commission rationally determined that a transaction was subject to the real property transfer gains tax imposed by Tax Law article 31-B, and the argument of petitioners, three public Netherlands corporations, that Internal Revenue Code § 897 (26 USC § 897), enacted as part of the Foreign Investors in Real Property Tax Act of 1980, precludes application of article 31-B to the instant conveyance is unavailing since the Federal act, which prevented the imposition of a tax on gains from foreign investments until 1985, did not preempt New York's taxing authority.

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Gains Tax -- Exemption -- Transfer Made Prior to Effective Date

3. The State Tax Commission rationally determined that a transaction was subject to the real property transfer gains tax imposed by Tax Law article 31-B and that petitioner corporations are not entitled to the exemption contained in Tax Law § 1443 (6) where petitioners failed to enter into a "written contract" to consummate the transaction prior to the effective date of article 31-B; the Commission is accorded considerable discretion in assessing whether the "written contract" exemption has been satisfied, and there was evidence that the written board resolutions authorizing the transaction were not unqualified prior to the effective date of the statute, but were conditioned on the approval of remaining terms of sale. That contingency speaks against a binding option agreement, and the record does not show that payment and certain written notice provisions of a buy-sell agreement were implemented, a fact which indicates that the ultimate conveyance was not simply a direct exercise of a pretax option agreement, but the result of negotiations independent of any option rights.

Taxation -- Real Estate Transfer Gains Tax -- Retroactive Taxation

4. Assessment of the real estate transfer gains tax (Tax Law art 31-B) against petitioner corporations did not constitute retroactive taxation in violation of due process where petitioners were contractually obligated to sell certain stock containing an interest in real property three days prior to the effective date of the transfer tax, since the retroactive extension of a taxing statute does not, per se, violate the Due Process Clause of the 5th Amendment; significantly, petitioners were cognizant of the pending gains tax legislation one week before it became effective, were advised to execute a written agreement to insure an exemption, and then orally committed themselves to the transaction several days later, and given that scenario, it is difficult to perceive any justifiable reliance on a pregains tax status. Moreover, petitioners executed their written stock sale agreement one day after the gains tax went into effect; there was no excessive retroactive period and the legislation constituted a legitimate revenue generating measure.

 

488 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


King Service, Inc. v. Town Bd., Malta


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


149 A.D.2d 806; 539 N.Y.S.2d 594; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4386



April 6, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner business challenged a judgment from the Supreme Court, Saratoga County (New York), which dismissed the business's application, in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, to remove a condition imposed by respondent town board in granting a planned development district. The business sought to expand from a service station to include a convenience store, but it would have to remove its nonconforming sign.


OVERVIEW: The business use of the property, which was a service station, predated the zoning ordinance, so the business could continue its operation, including the sign, as a prior nonconforming use. The business wanted to add a convenience store, so it sought a zoning ordinance amendment to create a planned development district. The trial court dismissed the business's application to remove the condition created by the ordinance. The court affirmed. The court held that the condition for approving the development district, removing the nonconforming sign, not only promoted the aesthetic purpose underlying the sign provisions but advanced a more fundamental zoning goal. The court observed that a strong policy favored the eventual elimination of nonconforming uses, and the amendment promoted that policy by rezoning the business so that the commercial use was no longer nonconforming. The business argued that the condition requiring removal was an unconstitutional taking of its property, but the court noted that the condition substantially advanced legitimate state interests, and the business failed to establish that the condition denied it an economically viable property use.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment, holding that a condition imposed by the town board in order to grant a planned development district was a legitimate government interest, did not deny the business economically viable use of its property, and could not be removed.

 

489 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Multi-State Developers, Inc. v. Great Neck


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


149 A.D.2d 414; 539 N.Y.S.2d 764; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4400



April 3, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed, without costs or disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner contested a judgment of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which dismissed the proceeding and declared that a zoning ordinance was not unconstitutional as applied to the property owner's property, in a hybrid action for a judgment declaring sections of the zoning ordinance unconstitutional, and a proceeding to review respondent appeals board's denial of the property owner's application for a use variance.


OVERVIEW: Part of the property owner's land was zoned "Business A," and the rest was denominated "Residence C." The property owner wished to erect a two-story medical building and parking lot on the property. Under Village of Great Neck, N.Y., Code § 210-84(D)(2), a medical building was considered a conditional permitted use of property zoned Business A, provided there was adequate parking, but the property owner was required to obtain a use variance in order to develop the remainder of property as a parking lot and thereby satisfy the conditions necessary to erect a medical building. The board refused to grant a variance, and the supreme court upheld that determination. On the property owner's appeal, the court affirmed the supreme court's decision, holding that because compliance with the zoning ordinance's parking standards was necessary before a conditional use permit could be issued, and because the board had no power to waive or modify the conditions specified in the ordinance, the property owner was not entitled to a conditional use permit, and also failed to demonstrate the need for a variance. Moreover, the zoning ordinance was constitutional as applied to the property.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the supreme court's judgment upholding the board's denial of the property owner's request for a use variance in order to procure a conditional use permit for the construction of a medical building on the property owner's land.

 

490 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


King v. Chmielewski


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


146 A.D.2d 102; 539 N.Y.S.2d 546; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4167



March 30, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant petitioners sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which granted petitioner's motion for reargument, affirmed its original decision dismissing their petition under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to review a determination of respondents, the town of Coeymans Planning Board and the town clerk, that denied a request by petitioners for subdivision approval, and dismissed the petition as time barred.


OVERVIEW: The petitioners commenced a proceeding against respondents under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to compel the clerk to issue a certificate of approval of their subdivision plan or, alternatively, to annul the board's decision denying their application. The trial court dismissed the petition as time-barred. On appeal, the court affirmed the dismissal and held that the proceeding against the board was time-barred pursuant to N.Y Town Law § 282 because it was not commenced within 30-days after the filing of the board's decision. The court found that the proceeding against the clerk was timely filed because the petitioners' challenge to the clerk's refusal to issue a default certificate was governed by the four-month limitation of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 217. The court determined that the clerk was not obligated to issue a default certification because the 45-day period within which the board had to act on the petitioners' proposal was tolled during the time the county reviewed the petitioners' application. The court found that, by virtue of this tolling, the board's denial of the application was within the required 45 days and the petitioners' demand for a default certification was properly rejected.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the determination dismissing the petitioners' application for subdivision approval in favor of the board.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- When Cause of Action Accrues -- Proceeding against Town Planning Board

1. A proceeding to review a determination of a town planning board was time barred where the minutes of a November 4 board meeting were delivered to the board's office the next day and the proceeding was not commenced until December 16, since Town Law § 282 provides that a proceeding seeking review of a town planning board decision must be commenced within 30 days after the decision is filed in the planning board office, and delivery of the minutes is equivalent to the "filing of the decision" so as to trigger the 30-day provision; moreover, the statute does not speak in terms of when the applicant is notified, but focuses on the filing with the board.

Limitation of Actions -- Four-Month Statute of Limitations -- Proceeding against Town Clerk

2. Town Law § 282, which provides that a proceeding seeking review of a town planning board decision must be commenced within 30 days after the decision is filed in the planning board office, is not applicable with respect to a petition against the town clerk seeking issuance of the requested subdivision approval on the grounds that 45 days have passed since the request was submitted and, hence, the request was approved by default (see, Town Law § 276 [4]), since section 282 applies only to determinations of a planning board and the reference in the statute to "any officer, department, board or bureau of the town" merely confers standing on the enumerated persons or entities to challenge to the town clerk's refusal to issue a default certificate is not governed by the time constraints delineated in section 282, but by CPLR 217, which imposes a four-month limitation period; by that standard, the proceeding against the town clerk was timely commenced.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Subdivision Approval --  Default Approval

3. A town clerk is not obligated to issue a default certificate of subdivision approval pursuant to Town Law § 276 (4), which, in effect, requires a town planning board to rule on a subdivision application within 45 days after a public hearing, notwithstanding the fact that more than 45 days have elapsed between the hearing and petitioners' demand for the issuance of the certificate, since the statute speaks to a plat submitted in final form and the application in question was not finalized until the town planning board actually received the written recommendation of the county planning board; not until receipt of that recommendation was the town board authorized to proceed on the application. Moreover, by the town's own regulations, a "final plat" anticipates a subdivision proposal containing all information or detail required by law which if approved may be duly filed. Accordingly, the 45-day period was tolled pending review by the county, and by virtue of that tolling, the town board's denial was well within the required 45 days.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Subdivision Approval -- Unconstitutional Denial

4. In a proceeding to review a determination of a town planning board denying petitioners' application for approval of a subdivision, petitioners' constitutional claim is unfounded since the record is devoid of any evidence indicating that racial discrimination was a motivating factor in the board's decision.

 

491 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Besser v. E. R. Squibb & Sons, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


146 A.D.2d 107; 539 N.Y.S.2d 734; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4175; CCH Prod. Liab. Rep. P12,089



March 30, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on July 10, 1987, affirmed, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff individual filed a personal injury action based upon her alleged exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during gestation. Defendant manufacturer asserted affirmative defenses, and the individual filed a motion to dismiss those defenses. The manufacturer, joined by other manufacturers, then filed a cross-motion for summary judgment. The supreme court (New York) granted the manufacturers' cross-motion. The individual appealed.


OVERVIEW: In 1975, the individual was diagnosed with a condition allegedly caused by her exposure to DES during her gestation some 20 years earlier. Following the passage of a revival statute (1986 N.Y. 682, § 4), she filed suit against a manufacturer of the DES. In addition to a general denial, the manufacturer's answer asserted the action was time-barred as an affirmative defense. When the individual filed a motion to dismiss the defenses, the manufacturer cross-moved for summary judgment. While the motion was pending, the individual commenced similar actions against other manufacturers. At the supreme court's direction, the parties stipulated to consolidation and deeming the summary judgment motion on behalf of all the a manufacturers. Summary judgment was granted, and the individual appealed. On appeal, she argued that, inasmuch as § 4 began with the words "notwithstanding any other provision of law," N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 202 should have been disregarded. The court held the provisions of the revival statute (1986 N.Y. 682, § 4) did not override the provisions of the borrowing statute (N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 202).


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed, without costs and without disbursements.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- Revival Statute -- Toxic Torts -- Borrowing Statute

1. Plaintiff, who was allegedly injured as a result of in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES), may not bring an action against defendant pharmaceutical companies in New York pursuant to the Toxic Tort Revival Statute (L 1986, ch 682 ), which provided a new Statute of Limitations in personal injury cases arising out of the latent effects of exposure to certain substances, including DES, based on the date of discovery of those effects (see, CPLR 214-c), and also provided a one-year "window period" for persons to sue whose claims were barred by operation of the preexisting "last exposure" rule, where plaintiff has had no contacts with New York save for establishing residence here prior to instituting suit, since the "borrowing statute" (CPLR 202) requires that where a cause of action accrues outside New York in favor of a nonresident, the foreign Statute of Limitations applies if it is shorter than the applicable New York limitation period, and that statute is applicable to the instant plaintiff who lacks any nexus with New York save a recently acquired residence; the fact that plaintiff is now a New York resident is irrelevant since plaintiff can avoid operation of CPLR 202 only if she was a New York resident at the time her cause of action accrued, and such statutory distinction in treatment has been constitutionally upheld.

Limitation of Actions -- Borrowing Statute -- Where Cause of Action Accrues

2. For the purposes of applying the "borrowing statute" (CPLR 202), which requires that where a cause of action accrues outside New York in favor of a nonresident, the foreign Statute of Limitations applies if it is shorter than the applicable New York limitation period, a cause of action sounding in negligence or strict products liability accrues where the injury occurs; in cases involving exposure to a chemical substance, the injury, if any, occurs at the time, and thus the place, of exposure.

Limitation  of Actions -- Revival Statue -- Toxic Torts -- Borrowing Statute

3. Plaintiff, who was allegedly injured as a result of in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES), may not bring an action against defendant pharmaceutical companies in New York pursuant to the Toxic Tort Revival Statute (L 1986, ch 682), which provided a new Statute of Limitations in personal injury cases arising out of the latent effects of exposure to certain substances, including DES, based on the date of discovery of those effects (see, CPLR 214-c) and also provided a one-year "window period" for persons to sue whose claims were barred by operation of the preexisting "last exposure" rule, where plaintiff had no contacts with New York until she established residence here and brought her action, since the "borrowing statute" (CPLR 202) requires that where a cause of action accrues outside New York in favor of a nonresident, the foreign Statute of Limitations applies if it is shorter than the applicable New York limitation period, and that statute is applicable notwithstanding the language of the revival statute that "Notwithstanding any other provision of law" it shall apply to toxic torts, since that law was enacted to remedy the unfair consequences suffered by injured New Yorkers under the "last exposure" rule which foreclosed many actions before damages became apparent. The revival statute is conce rned solely with the harshness of a time bar that focused on a victim's exposure to a toxic substance, and not with the salutary purposes underlying the borrowing statute. Thus, barring plaintiff's claim will prevent the forum shopping CPLR 202 was enacted to prohibit and further the Legislature's interest in reviving the claims of New Yorkers.

Limitation of Actions -- Revival Statute -- Toxic Torts -- Borrowing Statute

4. A plaintiff, who was allegedly injured as a result of in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) and who lacks all contacts with New York save her establishing residency here prior to bringing suit, may not avail herself of the benefits of the Toxic Tort Revival Statute (L 1986, ch 682), which revived the claims of those persons injured by exposure to toxic substances who were denied a remedy by the effect of New York's preexisting "last exposure" rule, since the "borrowing statute" (CPLR 202), which requires that where a cause of action accrues outside New York in favor of a nonresident, the foreign Statute of Limitations applies if it is shorter than the applicable New York limitation period, applies; in passing the revival statute, the Legislature had no interest in reviving the claims of nonresident plaintiffs who were adequately protected under their own States' Statutes of Limitations, and it is noted that the instant plaintiff was exposed to DES in Pennsylvania and was diagnosed as suffering from such exposure in New Jersey, States whose limitations period begin to run upon discovery of the injury.
