Thus, plaintiff did have a viable cause of action in another jurisdiction at some point in time. The introductory phrase of the revival statute, "Notwithstanding any other provision of law", can only mean that the CPLR's three-year limitations period on personal injury actions shall not apply to claims brought within the one-year "window period" in which to bring a revived action.

Limitation of Actions -- Revival Statute -- Toxic Torts -- Borrowing Statute

5. The "borrowing statute" (CPLR 202), which requires that where a cause of action accrues outside New York in favor of a nonresident, the foreign Statute of Limitations applies if it is shorter than the applicable New York limitation period, applies to causes of action brought pursuant to the Toxic Tort Revival Statute (L 1986, ch 682), which revived the claims of those persons injured by exposure to toxic substances who were denied a remedy by the effect of New York's preexisting "last exposure" rule and created a one-year "window period" in which to bring suit; the language of the revival statute that "Notwithstanding any other provision of law" the revival statute shall be applicable to toxic tort causes of action, does not bar application of CPLR 202. Although the revival statute makes reference to other specific statutes as being inapplicable to toxic torts, their inclusion is consistent with the Legislature's intention to eliminate all vestiges of the "last exposure" rule judicially grafted onto CPLR 214 and should not be read as a purposeful omission of the "borrowing statute", a statute of a wholly different nature which was designed to prevent forum shopping. Moreover, the failure to apply the "borrowing statute" would divest defendants of those vested rights created by the laws of sister States where the action would otherwise be barred.

 

492 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rivera v. Rozzi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


148 A.D.2d 726; 539 N.Y.S.2d 465; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4178



March 27, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner police officer, in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, sought to review a determination of respondent Commissioner of the Nassau County Police Department that the police officer had violated department rules and regulations and fined him 24 days' pay.


OVERVIEW: The police officer was charged with violating department rules prohibiting conduct unbecoming a member of the department, the submission of a false official statement, and the appearance of a police officer as a witness for a defendant in a criminal trial without first informing his commanding officer of his intention to do so. The police officer argued that the determination should be annulled on the ground that the regulations were unconstitutionally overbroad and vague as applied to him. The court held that the Commissioner properly determined that the police officer had violated each of the regulations. Although the regulation prohibiting conduct unbecoming a member of the department could conceivably be unconstitutionally overbroad and vague when applied to certain conduct, under the facts and circumstances of the case, the regulation was not unconstitutionally overbroad and vague as applied to the offending conduct engaged in by the officer. The claim that the other two rules were overbroad and vague lacked merit. Both rules used specific language and the record indicated that the officer's actions did, in fact, violate the rules.


OUTCOME: The court confirmed the Commissioner's determination and dismissed the proceeding on the merits, without costs or disbursements.

 

493 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


148 A.D.2d 929; 539 N.Y.S.2d 167; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2559



March 10, 1989 

 

494 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Landquest, Inc. v. Planning Bd. of Hoosick


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


148 A.D.2d 831; 538 N.Y.S.2d 666; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 2354



March 9, 1989 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant developer challenged a judgment of the Supreme Court in Rensselaer County (New York), which dismissed the developer's application, in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, to prohibit appellee Planning Board of the Town of Hoosick from exercising jurisdiction over the developer's subdivision.


OVERVIEW: The developer had presented the Board with a proposed 15-lot subdivision of a 19.25-acre parcel. At the time the Board functioned only in an advisory capacity. Despite objections, the developer got approval of the project from the appropriate county and state departments. The developer filed the subdivision map and was granted building permits by the town clerk. Construction on a single family home on one lot was started and the road accessing three lots was graded. In the interim, the town adopted a resolution empowering the Board to approve or disapprove various land use changes within the town, including authority to pass upon already filed plats of subdivisions entirely or partially undeveloped, pursuant to N.Y. Town Law § 276. A proceeding commenced by the developer to prevent the Board from disproving its project resulted in the trial court's finding that 20 percent of the lots or more were unimproved within the meaning of § 276(1), giving the Board jurisdiction. All other arguments were rejected. On review, the court concluded that the Board was not deprived of jurisdiction since 80 percent of the subdivision had not been developed by way of a substantial character.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

 

495 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Carella v. Collins


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


144 A.D.2d 78; 536 N.Y.S.2d 1020; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 479



January 26, 1989 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Related proceeding at Collins v. Carella, 1991 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2463 (N.D.N.Y, Feb. 26, 1991)
Later proceeding at Carella v. Collins, 80 N.Y.2d 1020, 607 N.E.2d 813, 1992 N.Y. LEXIS 3924, 592 N.Y.S.2d 666 (1992)
Related proceeding at Carella v. King, 198 A.D.2d 567, 603 N.Y.S.2d 219, 1993 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10294 (N.Y. App. Div. 3d Dep't, 1993)
Subsequent appeal at, Dismissed by Carella v. Collins, 204 A.D.2d 831, 614 N.Y.S.2d 329, 1994 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5164 (N.Y. App. Div. 3d Dep't, 1994)



DISPOSITION: Appeal from order entered April 15, 1987 dismissed, without costs.

Order entered January 25, 1988 reversed, on the law, without costs, and matter remitted to the Family Court of Saratoga County for a new trial on the issue of respondent's support obligations.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant father challenged the orders from the Saratoga County Family Court (New York), which granted a petition directing him to pay support obligations and arrears, and which directed that he be committed to jail for failure to comply with the support order.


OVERVIEW: The father claimed that: (1) the delegation of power to administrative law judges was improper; (2) administrative law judges lacked jurisdiction, and (3) because he was unable to financially comply with the support order, incarceration was improper under N.Y. Fam. C. Act § 439 (e), and it was unconstitutional. The court disagreed with the first two allegations as it had the authority to delegate hearing powers to administrative entities, so long as judicial review remained. However, the court found persuasive the father's assertion that incarceration was improper. The court said the father proved he was financially unable to comply with terms of the support order and should have been relieved of the commitment order. The court found the father made partial payments, worked most of the time, and that he made several attempts to have the support order modified. Because of those factors the order of commitment was in error. The court concluded that to deprive him of liberty by commitment to prison, it was necessary to show the willful violation of a prior court order, by clear and convincing evidence. No such evidence was adduced, and incarceration was improperly ordered.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of incarceration, it dismissed without costs the order requiring arrears, and it remitted the matter to the Family Court for a new trial on the issue of respondent's support obligations. The court held that no clear and convincing evidence was shown that the father could have paid his support obligations, and just didn't do it, so incarceration was improperly ordered.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Timeliness -- Notice of Appeal

1. In a support proceeding, respondent's argument that the order directing payments should be modified to a point where he will be financially able to comply must be rejected as untimely where more than 30 days passed since the entry of the order; an appeal from such order must be taken no later than 30 days from the entry and service thereof (Family Ct Act § 1113).

Appeal -- Matters Reviewable -- Ability to Comply with Support Order

2. In a support proceeding, although respondent's appeal from an order directing him to pay support is untimely, his appeal from a subsequent order sentencing him to 15 weekends in jail for failure to comply with the support order is timely and that appeal may be pursued on the ground that he is financially unable to comply with his support obligations (Family Ct Act § 455).

Husband and Wife -- Support -- Waiver of Right to Challenge Support Order

3. In a support proceeding, the assertion that respondent husband has waived his right to challenge the support order of a Hearing Examiner by failing to comply with the requirements of Family Court Act § 439 (e), in that respondent did not submit written objections to such order to Family Court within 30 days, is unpersuasive; respondent is not precluded from appealing the propriety of such order by failing to submit such objections since the content of the Hearing Examiner's order is not in issue. The issue is whether the Hearing Examiner lacked jurisdiction to hear the case and inasmuch as respondent timely appealed from an order of the Family Court dismissing that issue, the constitutionality of the Hearing Examiner's order is properly before the Appellate Division.

Courts -- Family Court  --  Hearing Examiners -- Constitutionality

4. Family Court Act § 439 is not unconstitutional insofar as it authorized the transfer of Family Court's powers from constitutionally elected Judges to nonjudicial, unelected employees of the Unified Court System, since NY Constitution, article VI, § 30 vests broad power in the Legislature to make procedural rules for the courts, and the Legislature, in enacting section 439, has recognized the need to expand the powers of Hearing Examiners to expedite child support determinations. Moreover, even if the authority vested in Hearing Examiners could be shown to infringe in some way upon the province of Family Court Judges, any such infringement would not be an unconstitutional grant of authority since the final authority to review determinations made by Hearing Examiners is reserved for Family Court Judges

Courts -- Family Court -- Hearing Examiners -- Referral to Examiner in Another County

5. In a support proceeding, there is no merit to respondent's argument that a Hearing Examiner in one county improperly and without authorization determined issues pending in the Family Court in another county, where the Hearing Examiner in the latter county had been disqualified owing to the fact that he had been respondent's attorney in other Family Court proceedings; Family Court Act § 439 (f) provides that counties may agree to share the services of Hearing Examiners, and, thus, the Family Court in one county had the authority to refer the matter to the Hearing Examiner in the other county, who then had jurisdiction to determine the support issues raised in the proceeding.

Husband and Wife -- Support -- Willful Failure to Pay

6. In a support proceeding, there is merit to respondent's contention that he has shown his financial inability to comply with the terms of a support order and, thus, should be relieved of the order committing him to 15 weekends in jail, where Family Court's conclusions appear to be based on few facts in the record, which did disclose numerous attempts to successfully comply with the support order, including borrowing money or, in the alternative, to have the order modified so as to render compliance practicable. Family Court's emphasis on respondent's alleged access to funds is not well founded. The record does not demonstrate a failure to make payments accompanied by an absence of any attempt to modify the order of support, nor does it demonstrate the failure to use any part of respondent's wages to make payments; to deprive a person of liberty, the willful violation of a prior court order must be established by clear and convincing evidence, and such evidence was not presented.

 

496 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Van Dyke v. New York State Dep't of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


144 A.D.2d 85; 537 N.Y.S.2d 332; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 480



January 26, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, on the law, without costs, and petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: With respect to petitioner employee's proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, seeking reinstatement to his position as assistant in occupational education civil rights with respondent Department of Education, the department appealed the ruling of the supreme court (New York), which concluded that the employee was a non-probationary, permanent employee who could not have been terminated absent a hearing pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law §75.


OVERVIEW: The employee was provisionally appointed to his position with the department. He subsequently passed a competitive examination for the assistant position, and an eligible list was established, upon which he ranked sixth. He was granted a permanent appointment to the assistant position subject to a flexible probationary period, which was extended. Then the department notified the employee of his summary termination. The employee sought reinstatement of his position. The supreme court ordered the employee's reinstatement with associated benefits. The court reversed the judgment and held that the petition should have been dismissed as untimely because any challenge to the probation requirements had to have been made within four months of the extension of the probationary term. Also, because the probationary term continued through the employee's termination, he was not entitled to a hearing prior to discharge. The employee did not become entirely eligible for a permanent appointment until the other candidates on the eligible list opted for other positions. Thus, the relevant probationary term began on that date.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's ruling that the employee was to have been reinstated to his position with the department.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- Four-Month Statute of Limitations -- Civil Service Probationary Period

1. A proceeding to review a determination of the Commissioner of Education terminating petitioner summarily from his position is untimely where it was commenced more than four months after petitioner was notified that his probationary period was to be extended (see, CPLR 217), since the case focuses upon the imposition of a term of probation to petitioner's permanent appointment, petitioner not having challenged the substantive basis for his dismissal. By petitioner's own account, he had acquired tenure by the time of the probation extension, and inasmuch as that was a discretionary extension, it had an impact on petitioner's employment status. Consequently, any challenge to the probation requirements had to be made, at least, within four months of the extension, rather than within four months of petitioner's dismissal.

Civil Service -- Appointment and Promotion -- Probationary Term -- Full Qualification

2. In a proceeding to review a determination of the Commissioner of Education terminating petitioner summarily from his position, the petition should be dismissed since there was no impropriety in petitioner's summary termination. Where a provisional employee, such as petitioner, is subsequently given a permanent appointment, the probationary term is properly measured from the point when the employee fully qualifies for the permanent position, thereby satisfying the constitutional mandate compelling appointments on the basis of "merit and fitness" (NY Const, art V, § 6), and in light of the fact that petitioner was ranked sixth on the eligible list resulting from the competitive examination, he did not become entirely eligible for a permanent appointment until the higher ranking candidates on the eligible list opted for other positions. Petitioner's permanent appointment coincided with the date the last candidate ahead of him so opted, and since petitioner's dismissal occurred within two years of that date, both sides concurring that two years was the maximum probationary period, petitioner was not entitled to a hearing prior to discharge.

 

497 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Festa v. Leshen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


145 A.D.2d 49; 537 N.Y.S.2d 147; 1989 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 231



January 17, 1989 



DISPOSITION: Order, Appellate Term, First Department, entered on March 14, 1988, which modified judgment of the Civil Court, New York County, entered on August 6, 1986, unanimously reversed on the law, without costs and without disbursements, and the judgment of the Civil Court reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, apartment dweller and New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), sought review of a decision of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which granted respondent landlord a final judgment of possession against the apartment dweller and held that the DHCR's amendments to the Rent Stabilization Code, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 2523.5(b)(1), (2), were invalid.


OVERVIEW: The landlord brought a holdover proceeding against the apartment dweller in a trial court. As an affirmative defense, the apartment dweller asserted that the landlord had conferred tenant status on him by accepting his rent checks. The trial court dismissed the petition and awarded the apartment dweller possession of an apartment. The lower court granted possession to the landlord and held that the DHCR's amendments to the Rent Stabilization Code (Code), N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 2523.5(b)(1), (2), were invalid. The court reversed the lower court's judgment and reinstated the trial court's judgment. The court held that the enactment of § 2523.5(b)(1), (2), was the product of a proper exercise of the DHCR's statutory authority to promulgate amendments to the Code; and that the apartment dweller, as the brother of a named tenant, was entitled to protection of § 2523.5(b)(1).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower court's grant of possession of an apartment to the landlord and the trial court's determination that the DHCR's amendments to the Rent Stabilization Code (Code) were invalid. The court held in part that the enactment of the amendments was the product of a proper exercise of the DHCR's statutory authority to promulgate amendments to the Code.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Authority of Division of Housing and Community Renewal to Issue Succession Regulations

The provisions of the Rent Stabilization Code which provide that relatives who reside with a named tenant may succeed to the tenant's lease rights upon the tenant's death or abandonment of the dwelling (9 NYCRR 2523.5 [b] [1], [2]) are a proper exercise of the statutory authority of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) to promulgate amendments to the Code; accordingly, a holdover proceeding against the brother of a sole tenant of record, who moved into the subject apartment at the commencement of the tenancy, is dismissed where the tenant of record subsequently vacated the premises and the brother began paying rent in his own behalf. In amending the Code to confer succession rights on various family members, DHCR acted rationally and within the scope of its lawfully delegated authority, and in furtherance of its duty to alleviate the continuing critical shortage of housing in New York City. If DHCR may, without the benefit of a statutory definition, define "tenant" in its rent stabilization regulations, and if, without an express statutory mandate to do so, succession provisions may be included in the State and city rent control regulations, DHCR may include either or both of those same provisions in the Code; having been delegated the authority for amending the Code, DHCR properly sought to promulgate regulations which would provide for succession rights to the family of a tenant residing in a rent-stabilized apartment in New York City.

 

498 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dyla


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


142 A.D.2d 423; 536 N.Y.S.2d 799; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13884



December 30, 1988 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Appeal denied by People v. Dyla, 74 N.Y.2d 808, 545 N.E.2d 880, 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 3457, 546 N.Y.S.2d 566 (1989)
Post-conviction relief denied at People v. Dyla, 39 A.D.3d 662, 831 N.Y.S.2d 912, 2007 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4525 (N.Y. App. Div. 2d Dep't, 2007)
Post-conviction relief denied at People v. Dyla, 2008 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5630 (N.Y. App. Div. 2d Dep't, June 17, 2008)



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of the judgment of the Nassau County Court (New York) which found appellant guilty of murder and burglary.


OVERVIEW: Appellant committed a murder while released from prison on parole. Appellant's failure to inform his parole officer that police had contacted him constituted a violation of appellant's parol conditions. Parole officer arrested appellant when they met because appellant again refused to state that he had been contacted. The police arrived and appellant willingly went to the station for questioning. Appellant was told and understood he was not under arrest for homicide. After being given his Miranda rights, appellant confessed. The court held the arrest of appellant by the parole officer was based upon probable cause that appellant had violated the conditions of parole, and that even if the arrest was considered illegal because no parole violation warrant had been issued, it did not amount to an unreasonable seizure and did not violate any constitutional rights. The court further found that any taint possibly caused by the arrest had dissipated prior to the confession at the police station.


OUTCOME: Appellant's conviction was affirmed because appellant's confession had been properly admitted at trial; no constitutional rights of appellant had been violated and any taint possibly caused by a parol officer's arrest without a warrant had dissipated prior to appellant's confession to police.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Arrest -- Probable Cause -- Arrest of Parolee by Parole Officer

1. The arrest of a parolee by his parole officer was based upon probable cause to believe that the parolee had violated certain conditions of his parole where one of those conditions was that the parolee disclose any contact he may have with the police, and where it became apparent to the parole officer during an interview with the parolee that the latter was persisting in his failure to admit that he had had contact with the police, a contact which the parole officer was sure had occurred, having previously spoken with the police. Accordingly, the arrest of the parolee by his parole officer was not an unreasonable seizure in contravention of constitutional standards (US Const 4th Amend, 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 12).

Crimes -- Arrest -- Warrantless Arrest of Parolee by Parole Officer -- Suppression of Confession

2. In a prosecution for murder  [***2] and burglary, even if the arrest of defendant parolee is considered illegal because no parole violation warrant had been issued (see, Executive Law § 259-i [3] [a] [i]; 9 NYCRR 8004.2), the arrest did not amount to an unreasonable seizure and did not violate any of defendant's constitutional rights; accordingly, exclusion of defendant's subsequent confession to the police is not an appropriate remedy. Exclusion from evidence of a voluntary confession is warranted only when it is shown that the confession was obtained in violation of a constitutionally protected right of the accused, and no such violation occurred because parolees have no constitutional right to be arrested only pursuant to a warrant. Violation of the aforementioned statute requiring the issuance of a parole violation warrant does not require suppression of the confession since that statute is not jurisdictional, is not meant to protect the privacy of the public, affects no substantial right, and is purely a technical requirement. The Constitution does not require the suppression of evidence gathered as a result of a seizure which is not unreasonable and, hence, not unconstitutional, solely on the grounds that  [***3] the seizure may be considered violative of some State statute, ordinance or regulation, where no bad faith is shown on the part of the police and where the statute in question is not designed to implement Fourth Amendment rights.

Crimes -- Confession -- Dissipation of Possible Illegal Taint

3. In a prosecution for murder and burglary, even assuming that the warrantless arrest of defendant parolee by his parole officer was so illegal as to warrant the application of the exclusionary rule, any taint caused by the arrest had dissipated prior to defendant's subsequent confession to the police, where the parole officer was not acting as an agent for the police, where the confession was preceded by a knowing and intelligent waiver of defendant's Miranda rights, and where there was a significant intervening event which occurred between the time of defendant's initial arrest and the time of his confession, i.e., defendant had been released after his initial arrest and was, thus, essentially free to choose between going with the police or not. A reasonable person in defendant's position at the time of his transfer from the parole office to police headquarters would have thought  [***4] himself free to leave, so that at that point defendant was not in custody. Moreover, whatever misconduct may have been committed by the parole officer in arresting defendant without a warrant cannot be attributed to the homicide detectives who scrupulously respected defendant's rights at every turn; the parole officer was not acting as a conduit for the police and the arrest for a parole violation was not a pretext for the arrest of defendant on a charge of homicide.

Crimes -- Arrest -- Custodial or Noncustodial Status of Defendant

4. In a prosecution for murder and burglary in which defendant parolee was arrested by his parole officer without a warrant and then turned over to the custody of homicide detectives, the fact that defendant learned that he failed a polygraph test administered pursuant to the homicide investigation did not transform his noncustodial status into a custodial one, since defendant had been specifically advised by the polygraph examiner that he was free to leave police headquarters at any time and that in the eyes of the law the results of the polygraph test were worthless; the fact that defendant failed the polygraph merely elevated defendant's status  [***5] as a suspect "a little bit more", and it cannot be inferred that the police considered defendant to be in custody at that point since a reasonably intelligent and innocent man, under the circumstances, would not have concluded that, because of the polygraph test results alone, he would be physically restrained if he sought to leave. Therefore, defendant was not under arrest at that point.

Parole -- Parole Violation Warrant -- Requirement for Arrest by Parole Officer

5. There is no rule of constitutional law which requires that a warrant must be issued prior to the arrest of a parolee known to have committed a parole violation, and it would be anomalous to hold that parolees have a constitutional right to be arrested only upon a warrant, while probationers, whose status is comparable, do not have a similar right, particularly since as a general matter parolees are guilty of more serious crimes than those who receive probation. The requirement that the arrest of a parole violator be preceded by the issuance of a warrant (Executive Law § 259-i [3] [a] [i]) is more in the nature of a procedural or "housekeeping" rule than a requirement designed to protect individual liberty, and  [***6] the type of warrant in question is not one issued by a neutral Magistrate, but is issued by an administrative officer who is basically a colleague of the officer who is seeking the warrant (see, 9 NYCRR 8004.2 [b]). Moreover, the failure to obtain a parole violation warrant is particularly excusable where no decision had been made by the parole officer as to whether to revoke parole until the parolee was actually in the presence of the officer.

Crimes -- Right to Remain Silent -- Subjective Belief of Defendant

6. In a prosecution for murder and burglary, there is no merit to defendant's argument that his statements to police were extracted in violation of his privilege against self-incrimination on the grounds that he subjectively believed that if he did not tell the truth, his parole would be revoked; even assuming that the defendant had such a perception, it would not have been a reasonable one, because the State may not punish a parolee for invoking his Fifth Amendment privilege by revoking his parole.

Crimes -- Confession -- Interrogation Technique -- Use of Polygraph

7. In a prosecution for murder and burglary, the interrogation techniques employed by the police  [***7] were not violative of due process; there was no abuse of a polygraph test since there is no evidence that the polygraph examiner deceived defendant with respect to the accuracy of the procedure or with respect to his own conclusions as to defendant's veracity.

 

499 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Cerniglia v. Ambach


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


145 A.D.2d 893; 536 N.Y.S.2d 227; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13782



December 29, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, the Supreme Court (New York) dismissed as moot the action of petitioners, school district, school board, and individual taxpayers, for a determination that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 8 § 175.34(a)(6) requiring use of a five-year average full value statistics to determine formula aid eligibility under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3602(31), was illegal. The petitioners appealed.


OVERVIEW: To be eligible for "full difference funding" under N.Y. Educ. Law § 3602(31), a school district was required to levy taxes at a "real property tax equivalent rate" (RPTER) that exceeded the previous year's rate by a certain percentage. The school district interpreted N.Y. Educ. Law § 3602(31)(a)(3) as dictating the use of one-year full value statistics rather than the five-year average full value called for by respondent Commissioner of Education's Regulations, 8 N.Y. Comp. Codes. R. & Regs. tit. 8 § 175.34(a)(6). As a result, respondent State Education Department deemed the district ineligible for full difference funding and reduced the amount of aid the district would receive by approximately $ 2.25 million. After the petitioners filed their court action, the state legislature enacted legislation that adopted a new formula for calculating school district aid. The court held that the subsequent legislation rendered the petitioners' action as moot. The issue was not likely to recur.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court dismissing as moot the action of petitioners to declare an administrative ruling relative to school funding illegal.

 

500 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Empire State Ass'n of Adult Homes, Inc. v. Perales


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


142 A.D.2d 322; 535 N.Y.S.2d 841; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13437



December 22, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law, without costs, motion granted and it is declared that 18 NYCRR 487.11 (l) (14) (viii) and (ix) has not been shown to be unconstitutional or invalid.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff trade association sought review of an order from the Supreme Court in Albany County (New York), which denied a motion by defendants, the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services and others, for summary judgment, and declared that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 487.11(l)(14)(viii), (ix), were unconstitutional on their face and as applied.


OVERVIEW: The trade association was comprised of owners and operators of adult care facilities that provided residential care to adults who were unable or substantially unable to live independently. N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 2(21). The individual plaintiffs each owned and operated an adult care facility. The trade association brought an action for a declaration that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 487.11(l)(14)(viii) and (ix), a regulation of defendant Department of Social Services, was unconstitutional on its face and as applied to them. The regulation, fixing spatial requirements for single and double bedrooms in adult care facilities licensed and certified by the department by its operation provided for three classes of facility. The court held that the trade association failed to establish that the regulation was so lacking in reason for its promulgation that it was essentially arbitrary. The determination to permit preexisting single rooms of at least 85 square feet and double rooms of at least 70 square feet per resident but to phase out smaller rooms would have caused financial burden only to those whose facilities were substantially substandard.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order and held that the statute regarding fixing of spatial requirements for certain adult care residence facilities was not shown to have been unconstitutional or invalid.


HEADNOTES

Social Services -- Adult Care Facilities -- Minimum Spatial Requirements for Bedrooms

1. Regulations of the Department of Social Services (18 NYCRR 487.11 [l] [14] [viii], [ix]) which fix minimum spatial requirements for single and double bedrooms in adult care facilities licensed and certified by the Department are not unconstitutional since no suspect class or fundamental right is involved and the regulations have a rational relation to a legitimate State objective, viz., to promote the health and welfare of residents in adult homes by increasing the minimum size of their rooms; the fact that the regulations create three classes of facilities, depending on when they were approved, does not render them [***2] unconstitutional since the classification system results in a phasing out of substandard rooms with the least possible hardship to the operators of adult homes, and in an effective and orderly, yet minimally disruptive, upgrading to the higher standard. The fact that some facilities will not have to be upgraded until a change of operator does not produce an unconstitutional result, notwithstanding the likely diminution in present value of the affected facilities, since the financial burden will inure only to those whose facilities are substantially substandard, and equal protection does not prevent a State from drawing lines that treat one class differently from others, given the absence of arbitrary or invidious discrimination.

Courts -- Justiciable Questions -- Advisory Opinion -- Diminution of Value of Adult Care Facilities

2. In an action challenging the constitutionality of regulations of the Department of Social Services (18 NYCRR 487.11 [l] [14] [viii], [ix]) which fix minimum spatial requirements for single and double bedrooms in adult care facilities licensed and certified by the Department, defendant's contention that plaintiffs are seeking an advisory [***3] opinion is rejected in light of the likelihood of present diminution of value of those facilities which will not have to be upgraded to the higher standard until a change of ownership of such facilities; therefore, plaintiffs' claim presents a justiciable issue.

 

501 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Eaton Assocs. v. Egan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


142 A.D.2d 330; 535 N.Y.S.2d 998; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13250



December 15, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Petition, insofar as it alleges that the guidelines promulgated by the Office of General Services pursuant to Executive Order No. 21 are invalid or have been invalidly applied, converted to an action for declaratory judgment; it is declared that the guidelines for certification of minority and women-owned business enterprises have not been shown to be invalid; determination confirmed, and remainder of petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Office of General Services (OGS) (New York) denied the certification of petitioner corporation as a minority-owned business. The corporation brought this proceeding against respondent, Commissioner of the New York State OGS (commissioner), challenging the OGS determination. The corporation sought an order annulling the determination and requiring OGS to certify the corporation as a minority and women-owned business enterprise (M/WBE).


OVERVIEW: The grounds for the corporation's challenge were that Executive Order No. 21 (Order), N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 4.21, and the OGS guidelines were unconstitutional; that the guidelines were not duly promulgated as a rule or regulation; that Order and the guidelines were invalidly adopted without statutory authority; that the corporation's procedural due process rights were violated due to the vagueness of the guidelines and the inadequacy of the procedures on the review of its application for certification; and that if the guidelines were valid, the denial of the corporation's application was irrational and inconsistent with the Order and the guidelines themselves. The court held that the corporation lacked standing because it had not suffered any personal injury fairly traceable to the Order that was likely to be redressed by the requested relief. Also, the corporation failed to avail itself of its right to a final administrative appeal, and had not brought itself within any of the exceptions to the doctrine that foreclosed judicial review to one who has not exhausted his administrative remedies. The guidelines were not unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court declared that the guidelines for certification of M/WBE have not been shown to be invalid and the court thereby confirmed the OGS determination, and dismissed the remainder of the petition.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Standing -- Challenge to Validity of Affirmative Action Program

1. A construction firm which is claiming status as a minority-owned business in order to take advantage of a State affirmative action program lacks standing to challenge the validity of an Executive Order which created a certification program and procedures to implement the affirmative action program, since petitioner is not aggrieved as it  [***2] might be were it not a nonminority business enterprise not eligible for favored treatment; petitioner has not suffered any personal injury fairly traceable to the Executive Order and may not complain of any injury which might be inflicted on others. Inasmuch as standing goes to the jurisdictional basis of a court's authority to adjudicate a dispute, petitioner's challenge is subject to sua sponte dismissal in spite of respondent's failure to raise the objection as to lack of standing.

Administrative Law -- Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies -- Affirmative Action Certification Procedure

2. The claim of a construction firm which asserted that it is a minority-owned business eligible to take advantage of a State affirmative action program and that the decision to deny its certification as a bona fide minority business enterprise lacks a rational basis is dismissed since petitioner failed to avail itself of its right to a final administrative appeal and has not brought itself within any of the exceptions to the doctrine that forecloses judicial review to one who has not exhausted his administrative remedies; a party does not avoid the exhaustion requirement merely by  [***3] asserting the deprivation of a constitutional right, and there is nothing to demonstrate that the alleged defects in procedures would not have been considered and cured at the final stage of the administrative appeal process.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Challenge to Affirmative Action Procedures

3. In a proceeding challenging both the validity of an Executive Order, which created a certification program and procedures to implement an affirmative action program, and a determination denying petitioner certification as a minority-owned business enterprise, although petitioner was precluded from alleging that the determination lacked a rational basis owing to its failure to exhaust its administrative remedies, petitioner is not precluded on his remaining challenges, directed to the invalidity of certain guidelines (9 NYCRR part 340) promulgated to implement the Order, on the grounds of vagueness, lack of statutory authority, improper promulgation as a rule or regulation, and inconsistency of said guidelines with the Order, since each of those claims may be the proper subject of a declaratory judgment action, and the pertinent portions of the petition may  [***4] be converted accordingly.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Guidelines -- Legislative Authorization

4. In a proceeding, converted to a declaratory judgment action, challenging the validity of certain guidelines which implement an Executive Order establishing an affirmative action program for minority and women-owned business enterprises, judicial notice may be taken that the guidelines were duly filed with the Secretary of State as 9 NYCRR part 340, and, thus, petitioner's objection with respect to their improper promulgation is foreclosed. Likewise, the guidelines are not subject to attack for lack of legislative authorization since the guidelines are expressly intended merely to create the procedures and criteria for certification for the affirmative action program authorized under the Prison Construction Act (L 1983, ch 56), and for similar programs "as authorized by such other laws, rules, regulations and orders as they apply" (9 NYCRR 340.1), and to implement the aforementioned Executive Order. Insofar as the guidelines are used for certification purposes in connection with the affirmative action program under the Prison Construction Act, they have  [***5] statutory authority, and as to any other affirmative action program of the executive branch wherein the guidelines may be applied, petitioner has not shown that any of such programs are anything but voluntary; accordingly, lack of statutory authority for the use of the guidelines in connection with such voluntary affirmative action programs is not fatal to their validity.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Guidelines -- Consistency with Enabling Executive Order

5. Guidelines (9 NYCRR part 340) which implement an Executive Order establishing an affirmative action program for minority and women-owned business enterprises are not invalid by reason of any inconsistency with said Order, which is aimed expressly to insure that only bona fide minority business enterprises benefit from the program, since the definitional criteria for a minority business enterprise contained in the Order require that the ownership interest of minority persons in a business enterprise be "real, substantial and continuing", and the guidelines are clearly designed to implement that policy. Determining the actual independent control by the minority interest necessarily entails investigation  [***6] into the internal business practices of the enterprise.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Guidelines -- Vagueness Challenge

6. Guidelines (9 NYCRR part 340) which implement an Executive Order establishing an affirmative action program for minority and women-owned business enterprises are not invalid by reason of vagueness since each of the standards and criteria to which petitioner construction firm objects is clearly designed and appropriate to insure that minority persons claiming to own the business enterprises are in fact exercising actual, autonomous managerial control; persons of ordinary intelligence could readily understand what pattern of conduct of the affairs of the enterprise is necessary to avoid being disqualified from participation in the program, and given the obvious need for flexibility in providing standards to be applied in a myriad of business configurations, any more specificity in the guidelines would unduly weaken and inhibit the ability of the State to insure that only bona fide minority business enterprises receive the benefits of the Governor's program.

 

502 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Brookhaven v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


142 A.D.2d 338; 535 N.Y.S.2d 773; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13235



December 15, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, towns, officials, and taxpayers, appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which granted defendant state's motion for summary judgment in their action for a declaration that 1981 N.Y. Laws 53, 1982 N.Y. Laws 53, 1983 N.Y. Laws 53, and 1984 N.Y. Laws 53 (chapter laws) were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The towns and their officials and taxpayers filed an action for a judgment declaring unconstitutional the chapter laws, which required the use of 1970 census and 1969 assessment rolls, rather than the 1979 and 1980 figures, in apportioning state aid to localities for the fiscal years of 1981-1985. The trial court granted the state's motion for summary judgment. The towns, officials, and taxpayers appealed. The court affirmed, with costs. The court found that the state, by the affidavit of the director of its budget division, demonstrated that the revenue sharing methodology rationally furthered a legitimate state objective and did not violate equal protection. The court found that the legislature envisioned the use of the older figures as a means of supplementing per capita state aid to cities experiencing serious economic adversity, as manifested by population loss, at the expense of localities that were prospering with their population.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed, with costs, summary judgment for the state in the action of the towns, officials, and taxpayers for a judgment declaring the chapter laws unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

State -- Budget -- State Aid to Localities -- Use of Old Census Data and Assessment Rolls -- Equal Protection

1. In an action seeking to have chapter 53 of the Laws of 1981, 1982, 1983 and 1984 declared unconstitutional insofar as they require the use of 1970 census figures and 1969 assessment rolls in apportioning State aid to localities for the respective fiscal years, judgment which granted defendants' motion for summary judgment and declared the statutes constitutional is affirmed; since neither a suspect classification nor a fundamental right is called into issue by plaintiff towns' equal protection claim, the statutes in question will pass constitutional muster if they can be said to rationally further a legitimate State purpose, and in light of the affidavit submitted by the Director of the State Division of the Budget, which stated that one of the primary  [***2] goals of revenue sharing is the stabilization or reduction of local property taxes, that distribution of State aid is based upon several factors other than population, that localities with shrinking populations were in greater need of State aid than localities with expanding populations given that the former experienced no reduction in the demand for public services, and that use of more recent data could have precipitated severe local budget difficulties, hastened out-migration of businesses and residents, and impaired economic development, the rationales offered by defendants furnished reasonable justification for the enactments in question. Equal protection does not require that all towns be treated alike and plaintiffs may not be heard to complain that the Legislature could have accomplished the same goals in a better or different way. Defendants' comparison of towns with cities in analyzing property tax burdens was not unreasonable.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Challenge to Constitutionality of Legislative Enactments -- Statute of Limitations

2. In an action challenging the constitutionality of legislative enactments, rather than particular administrative  [***3] conduct taken pursuant thereto, a declaratory judgment action is the proper procedural vehicle to accomplish that challenge and, therefore, the four-month Statute of Limitations period contained in CPLR 217 is inapplicable.

Courts -- Justiciable Questions -- Challenge to Constitutionality of Legislative Enactments

3. In an action challenging the constitutionality of chapter 53 of the Laws of 1981, 1982, 1983 and 1984 insofar as they require the use of 1970 census figures and 1969 assessment rolls in apportioning State aid to localities for the respective fiscal years, defendants' assertion that the question is non-justiciable is without merit since the dispute centers on whether the Legislature exceeded its authority as limited by the Equal Protection Clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions.

 

503 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hawkins v. Preble


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


145 A.D.2d 775; 535 N.Y.S.2d 501; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12995



December 8, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Town of Preble appealed from an order and judgment of the Supreme Court of Cortland County (New York), which granted plaintiff landowner's motion for summary judgment and declared that Preble, N.Y., Zoning Ordinance § 27 was void because the provisions of the New York State Mined Land Reclamation Law, N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law art. 23, tit. 27, superseded it.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the Town contended that Preble, N.Y., Zoning Ordinance § 27 did not regulate the extractive mining industry in contravention of N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 23-2703(2) but merely established a specific geographic area in which mining was prohibited. The court disagreed and upheld the supreme court's ruling declaring the ordinance void. The ordinance did not designate with any specificity the boundaries of the prohibited mining zones. Rather, the ordinance prohibited mining below the water table on all lands in the town, except in connection with construction of a building on the same lot. The ordinance's effect was not a general prohibition of mining in the town, or any specific area, but an express limitation of the mining process. The Town's characterization of the zoning ordinance as a permissible general land use regulation was inaccurate, as the ordinance was indistinguishable from another town's ordinance, governing the removal of earth and earth products, that the court deemed preempted by § 23-2703(2).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the supreme court's order and judgment granting the landowner's motion for summary judgment and declaring a section of the Town's zoning ordinance to be void, without costs.

 

504 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kasper v. Brookhaven


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


142 A.D.2d 213; 535 N.Y.S.2d 621; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12966



December 5, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment of the Supreme Court, Suffolk County, dated February 6, 1987, is affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff non-resident owner sought review of the judgment of the Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York), which granted a motion for summary judgment by defendants, and declared constitutional Town of Brookhaven, N.Y., Code § 85-411, which provided for issuance of permits to a restricted number of single-family homeowners for the purpose of creating and maintaining accessory rental apartments within their owner-occupied homes.


OVERVIEW: Section 85-411 allowed accessory apartments within homes situated in single-family residence zoning districts, limited the number of apartments within any given area, and provided for certain permit requirements, including owner occupancy. The non-resident owner sought a declaration that § 85-411 was void and unconstitutional insofar as it required owner occupancy. On appeal, the court affirmed the summary judgment, finding that the town did not exceed its legislative authority under N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10. The court noted that a zoning measure was insulated from attack if it fell within the embrace of the town's authority to regulate property as a means of promoting the general welfare of the community, and that mere disparate treatment was not a sufficient basis for voiding a zoning provision. The court concluded that the distinction between homeowners who occupied their homes and those who did not was rationally related to the legitimate zoning goal of aiding occupying homeowners in retaining and maintaining their properties, while answering the need for affordable rental accommodations without disturbing the single-family-residence character of the affected districts.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed with costs the order of the supreme court granting defendants' motion for summary judgment and declaring the local code at issue constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Rental Apartments in Owner-Occupied Homes -- Validity of Ordinance

1. A town may validly enact a local law which, while providing for the issuance of permits to a restricted number of single-family homeowners for the purpose of creating and maintaining accessory rental apartments within their homes, limits the availability of those accessory apartment permits, and consequently the financial benefits which flow therefrom, to only those homeowners who also occupy their homes. The ordinance did not exceed the legislative powers granted to the town in Town Law § 261; the town possessed broad zoning authority pursuant to Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 and, therefore, could enact laws which supersede the Town Law.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Rental Apartments in Owner-Occupied Homes -- Constitutionality  [***2] of Ordinance

2. A town may constitutionally enact a local law which, while providing for the issuance of permits to a restricted number of single-family homeowners for the purpose of creating and maintaining accessory rental apartments within their homes, limits the availability of those accessory apartment permits, and consequently the financial benefits which flow therefrom, to only those homeowners who also occupy their homes; the law did not draw an irrational distinction between owners who occupy their homes and those who do not, since a strong presumption of constitutionality attaches to zoning legislation and the classification in question is rationally related to the permissible goals of the legislation, viz., alleviating the growing shortage of affordable housing within the town while at the same time providing financial relief to those homeowners who may be of modest means and who will be better able to retain ownership of their residences and to maintain them in aesthetically acceptable condition by leasing the available, unused living space in their homes. Given the limited number of permits available, permitting nonoccupying homeowners to create and maintain accessory  [***3] apartments would deny others of lesser financial means the opportunity to augment their income. Mere disparate treatment is insufficient to invalidate the legislation in question, which has no exclusionary purpose or effect, and which does not diminish the property of nonoccupying owners so as to constitute a confiscation.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Rental Apartments in Owner-Occupied Homes -- Permissible Regulation of Property User

3. A town may lawfully enact a local law which, while providing for the issuance of permits to a restricted number of single-family homeowners for the purpose of creating and maintaining accessory rental apartments within their homes, limits the availability of those accessory apartment permits, and consequently the financial benefits which flow therefrom, to only those homeowners who also occupy their homes, and such law does not impermissibly regulate the user of the property rather than the use of the property, since the law does not attach a personal condition to any individual landowner, nor is it unrelated to the use of the property within the town. The law constitutes a permissible accessory-use zoning provision and an accessory  [***4] use (i.e., a use incidental to and occasioned by the principal use of the premises) by its very nature ordinarily attaches to the occupancy of the premises rather than to the mere ownership thereof, so that the owner of a residence typically must occupy the premises in order to take advantage of the benefits offered by accessory-use legislation.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Rental Apartments in Owner-Occupied Homes -- Propriety of Summary Judgment

4. In an action testing the constitutionality of a zoning ordinance which provides for the issuance of permits to a restricted number of single-family homeowners for the purpose of creating and maintaining accessory rental apartments within their homes and limits the availability of such permits to only those homeowners who also occupy their homes, inasmuch as it has been established as a matter of law that the owner-occupancy requirement serves the permissible legislative purpose of providing occupying homeowners of modest means with additional income, the only factual issue open to debate concerns whether the requirement in question is the wisest and most efficient legislative vehicle for accomplishing the desired end, and  [***5] that is an inquiry from which the courts are excluded; accordingly, summary judgment was properly granted declaring the subject ordinance constitutional.

 

505 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Seawall Associates v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


142 A.D.2d 72; 534 N.Y.S.2d 958; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12381



December 1, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Orders and judgments (two papers), Supreme Court, New York County, both entered on March 16, 1988 (actions Nos. 1 and 3), unanimously reversed, on the law and on the facts, the injunction is vacated, and Local Law No. 9 in its entirety is declared constitutional, without costs and without disbursements.

Order and judgment (one paper), Supreme Court, New York County, entered on March 16, 1988 (action No. 2), unanimously affirmed, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners filed multiple actions challenging New York, N.Y., Local Law 9. The supreme court (New York) entered orders and judgments which declared invalid various provisions of Local Law 9 and enjoined defendant city from implementing or enforcing said provisions. In addition, defendant officials' cross motion to dismiss was granted. The city appealed, and the property owners cross appealed.


OVERVIEW: In response to a shortage of single-room occupancy (SRO) housing, the city enacted New York, N.Y., Local Law 9. Subsequently, the supreme court consolidated the property owners' motions; converted their motions for injunctive relief to motions for summary judgment; granted the city's cross motion for summary judgment in the action, which sought invalidation of Local Law No. 9 upon the basis that it violated the environmental laws; and granted summary judgment for the property owners in the other actions upon the ground that the anti-warehousing, buy-out, replacement, and hardship provisions of Local Law No. 9 violated the property owners' due process rights and constituted a taking of their property for public use without just compensation. On appeal, the court found Local Law No. 9 was constitutional in all respects because it did not either constitute an unconstitutional taking of property or violate due process, in view of the fact that the provisions of that law were intended to accomplish the legitimate governmental goal of preventing homelessness and did not deny the property owners the opportunity to earn a reasonable rate of return on their property.


OUTCOME: The orders and judgments were reversed, the injunction was vacated, and the local legislation was declared constitutional, without costs and without disbursements. The order granting the motion to dismiss of the officials was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Preservation of Single-Room Occupancy Buildings -- Unconstitutional  [***2] "Taking" without Due Process of Law

1. Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 of the City of New York (see, Administrative Code of City of New York § 27-198.2), which provides for a five-year moratorium on the demolition or conversion of single-room occupancy (SRO) housing and, requires SRO owners to maintain their units in a habitable condition and to make a good-faith effort to rent such units, subjecting violators to civil penalties, is constitutional in all respects. Local Law No. 9, following years of study and public hearings, was enacted to cope with a serious public emergency, i.e., the rise in the number of homeless persons, and while the law may temporarily diminish the value of an SRO property, it does not reduce the value of that property to the level where it would be an unconstitutional taking, since the law permits SRO owners to earn a return of 8.5% of the assessed value of the property and that figure was derived from the hardship provisions of the rent control laws, which have been held constitutional. Moreover, the replacement and buy-out options of the law, which require SRO owners who wish to alter their buildings to either relocate affected tenants or contribute $ 45,000  [***3] to a housing development fund for each demolished unit, are neither exorbitant nor a disguised tax, since the $ 45,000 figure is the estimated cost of acquiring and rehabilitating an SRO unit, plaintiffs have offered no persuasive evidence that said sum is arbitrary or capricious, and said moneys will go directly into a special fund to develop low- and moderate-income housing; the requirement that property owners contribute to such special funds has been held not to constitute an unconstitutional "taking".

Municipal Corporations -- Preservation of Single-Room Occupancy Buildings -- Unconstitutional "Taking" without Due Process of Law

2. Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 of the City of New York (see, Administrative Code of City of New York § 27-198.2), which provides for a five-year moratorium on the demolition or conversion of single-room occupancy (SRO) housing, and requires SRO owners to maintain their units in a habitable condition and to make a good-faith effort to rent such units, subjecting violators to civil penalties, is constitutional in all respects since it does not either constitute an unconstitutional taking of property or violate due process in view of the fact that  [***4] the provisions of the law are intended to accomplish the legitimate governmental goal of preventing homelessness, and do not deny SRO owners the opportunity to earn a reasonable rate of return on their property. There can be no unconstitutional taking of property where the law provides for an economically viable use, which may not necessarily be the highest economic use. Furthermore, the law contains a hardship provision which permits an SRO owner to seek exemption from the law, upon application to the Commissioner of the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, who is given the power to grant such relief. Although one owner or class of owners may bear a heavier economic burden than another, that fact alone does not automatically mean that a property owner is being singled out for an unconstitutional taking.

Municipal Corporations -- Preservation of Single-Room Occupancy Buildings -- Environmental Impact

3. Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 of the City of New York (see, Administrative Code of City of New York § 27-198.2), which provides for a five-year moratorium on the demolition or conversion of single-room occupancy (SRO) housing, and requires SRO owners to maintain  [***5] their units in a habitable condition and to make a good-faith effort to rent such units, subjecting violators to civil penalties, does not violate State and city environmental laws, since the law in question merely seeks the maintenance and/or repair of existing structures without substantially altering them; accordingly, inasmuch as the State and city environmental laws only require an environmental review when an action is undertaken which involves substantial changes in existing structures, the action to be undertaken pursuant to Local Law No. 9 is exempt from such review (see, ECL 8-0105 [5] [iii]).

 

506 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bri-Mar Corp. v. Town Bd. of Knox


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


145 A.D.2d 704; 534 N.Y.S.2d 831; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 12389



December 1, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner operators filed an application, in a combined proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 and for declaratory judgment, to review a determination of respondent town board, which denied the operators' request for expansion of their trailer park. The Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), entered judgment dismissing the operators' application. The operators appealed.


OVERVIEW: The operators owned a 25-unit mobile home park. They applied to the town board for approval to expand the mobile home park by 48 units. The town board denied the application for expansion because the existing sewage disposal method used by the operators was contrary to Town of Knox, N.Y., Sanitary Code § 10 (Town Code). In their subsequent combined proceeding, the operators argued that the Town Code was invalid as preempted by state law, unconstitutional, and inconsistent with state and county laws. In dismissing the proceeding, the trial court held that the town board's determination was rational and the Town Code was not inconsistent with the state and county codes because the Town Code set a higher standard for sewage disposal based on legitimate factors. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court, annulled the town board's determination, declared the Town Code invalid, and remitted because the Town Code's blanket proscription against the operator's method of sewage disposal removed the possibility of sewage disposal as allowed by the state and, therefore, was inconsistent with the state standards.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that dismissed the operators' application, without costs, annulled the determination, declared the relevant section of the town's sanitary code invalid, and remitted the matter to the town board for further proceedings.

 

507 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Reisner v. Board of Regents


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


142 A.D.2d 22; 535 N.Y.S.2d 197; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11876



November 23, 1988 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended March 31, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Determination confirmed, and petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, petitioner physician sought review of a decision from respondent Board of Regents of the State of New York, which suspended the physician's license to practice medicine for three years.


OVERVIEW: The physician, a psychiatrist who evaluated patients for sexual reassignment surgery, was found by the board to be grossly negligent, and the board ordered a three-year suspension of the physician's license. The physician sought review, raising multiple arguments. The court confirmed the board's determination and dismissed the physician's petition. It found that the board did not exceed its statutory authority when it used the preponderance of the evidence standard instead of the substantial evidence standard. Even though N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 230.10 was amended after the physician was served and the amendment required use of the substantial evidence standard, the physician was not harmed by the board's application of the wrong standard because the standard afforded the physician greater protection. The board did not exceed its authority when it revised factual findings based on the preponderance standard because the report did not consist of new factual findings but was a summary statement of how the evidence supported the physician's guilt. Finally, the court found that the board's decision was supported by substantial evidence and was not arbitrary, capricious, or unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the board's determination to suspend the physician's license to practice medicine.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law -- Hearing -- Evidentiary Standard

1. In an administrative proceeding examining charges of professional misconduct against a psychiatrist, respondent State Board of Regents did not exceed its statutory authority in applying the preponderance of the evidence standard to the findings of State Board for Professional Medical Conduct (the hearing committee) rather than the substantial evidence standard, as was done by the hearing committee; although the Board of Regents should have applied the substantial evidence standard because the psychiatrist was charged by the Office of Professional Medical Conduct in September 1981, Public Health Law § 230 (10) (f) having been amended to provide that the preponderance  [***2] of the evidence standard should be used in hearings initiated after January 1985, respondent did not exceed its authority since the fact that it applied the "preponderance" standard in no way harmed petitioner. Petitioner was, in fact, afforded even more protection. Moreover, respondent's interpretation of the statutory provisions delineating its duties and powers (see, Education Law § 6510-a [2]) should be given deference and accepted since its actions were not unreasonable or irrational.

Administrative Law -- Hearing -- Evidentiary Standard

2. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Board of Regents adopting the findings of a hearing committee that petitioner psychiatrist was guilty of professional misconduct and imposing a penalty, petitioner's contention that respondent exceeded its authority by revising factual findings of the hearing committee by finding guilt by a preponderance of the evidence is without merit, since respondent is specifically charged by statute with deciding guilt by considering the transcript, exhibits, and other evidence (see, Education Law § 6510-a [2] [a], [b]); accordingly, respondent is empowered to examine the testimony  [***3] in order to determine whether the person charged is guilty, and the determination of guilt herein by a preponderance of the evidence did not require respondent to make new factual findings. Rather, it was a statement of how the evidence supported guilt. Inasmuch as the determination was not irrational, it should not be disturbed by the court.

Administrative Law -- Hearing -- Evidentiary Standard -- Due Process

3. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Board of Regents adopting the findings of a hearing committee that petitioner psychiatrist was guilty of professional misconduct and imposing a penalty, petitioner's contention that any consideration of the substantial evidence standard is unconstitutional in that it violates the Due Process Clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions is without merit.

Administrative Law -- Hearing -- Evidentiary Standard -- Equal Protection

4. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Board of Regents adopting the findings of a hearing committee that petitioner psychiatrist was guilty of professional misconduct and imposing a penalty, petitioner's claim that his equal protection rights have been violated  [***4] because prospective application of an amendment to Public Health Law § 230 (10) (f), which sets out the evidentiary standard to be applied at hearings into charges of professional misconduct against physicians, creates unequal treatment of two classes of persons, one class to be adjudicated by a substantial evidence standard and the other to be adjudicated according to a preponderance of the evidence standard, is without merit; petitioner was not denied equal protection and is not aggrieved since respondent Board of Regents found guilt by a preponderance of the evidence, affording petitioner the benefit of the higher standard of proof.

Administrative Law -- Hearing -- Substantial Evidence

5. In a proceeding to review a determination of respondent State Board of Regents adopting the findings of a hearing committee that petitioner psychiatrist was guilty of professional misconduct and imposing a penalty, petitioner's argument that the findings of guilt were not supported by substantial evidence is without merit where the State's experts testified that petitioner's psychiatric evaluations of patients were inadequate, and respondent's determination was based upon its evaluation  [***5] of the massive amount of testimony adduced at the hearing; it was noted that the evaluation reports of petitioner with respect to the patients in issue did not conform to acceptable medical standards and petitioner's claim that that finding was not supported by the evidence owing to the conflicting testimony of his expert witnesses is equally without merit, since petitioner's challenge raises questions of credibility which are determined solely by respondent. The record demonstrates substantial evidence to support respondent's determination, which is not arbitrary, capricious or unreasonable.

Administrative Law -- Hearing -- Bias of Hearing Committee

6. In a proceeding to review a determination of respondent State Board of Regents adopting the findings of a hearing committee that petitioner psychiatrist was guilty of professional misconduct and imposing a penalty, petitioner's contention that the hearing committee was biased because its chairperson, a psychiatrist, had known an expert witness for the State for 25 years is without merit where, upon objection by petitioner, the other members of the committee met separately and discussed the situation, determining that the chairperson  [***6] should remain; there was no error in that procedure. The mere fact that the chairperson and a witness knew and associated with one another professionally does not in and of itself demonstrate bias; in any type of medical proceedings, members of the same medical specialty may by necessity often be members of the same organizations; moreover, the chairperson was also acquainted with two psychiatrists who testified for petitioner. Petitioner has failed to demonstrate bias in the hearing committee.

Administrative Law -- Hearing -- Joinder

7. In a proceeding to review a determination by respondent State Board of Regents adopting the findings of a hearing committee that petitioner psychiatrist was guilty of professional misconduct and imposing a penalty, petitioner's contention that he was prejudiced by the joinder of the hearing into the charges against him with the hearing into charges against a surgeon who performed gender reassignment surgery on five patients whom petitioner had approved for such procedure, is unavailing where the relationship between petitioner and the surgeon involved common patients. In light of the fact that petitioner evaluated the patients and gave his  [***7] recommendation to the surgeon that they were appropriate candidates for the surgery, any investigation as to the adequacy of their treatment involved common factual issues, making joinder appropriate. Moreover, separate hearings would have required duplication of much of the evidence that was submitted at the lengthy hearing; thus, consolidation preserved time and resources. Petitioner was not prejudiced by the joinder since the hearing committee gave separate and independent consideration to the evidence with respect to him and the surgeon; petitioner's claim that joinder was prejudicial in that it held him to a standard of care of a primary treating physician is not persuasive.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Disciplinary Proceedings -- Penalty

8. In a proceeding to review a determination of respondent State Board of Regents adopting the findings of a hearing committee that petitioner psychiatrist was guilty of professional misconduct and imposing a penalty of a three-year suspension, the last two years to be stayed, and a three-year probation, petitioner's assertion that the penalty was excessive is not persuasive; a court is restricted in its review of the propriety of sanctions  [***8] imposed against physicians and in light of the fact that respondent found serious deficiencies in petitioner's approval of patients for irreversible sex-change surgery without having adequately evaluated them, the punishment imposed is not shocking to one's sense of fairness, and, hence, not excessive.

 

508 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Esther C. v. Ambach


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


142 A.D.2d 94; 535 N.Y.S.2d 462; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11887



November 23, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Order modified, on the law, with costs to plaintiffs, by reversing so much thereof as made an award of $ 750 for counsel fees for the motion for counsel fees; matter remitted to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with this court's decision; and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff handicapped children and defendant Commissioner of Education of the State of New York sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court of Albany County (New York), which determined that the handicapped children had prevailed in the parties' underlying action, awarded the handicapped children $ 11,687 in counsel fees and $ 177 in disbursements, and awarded the handicapped children $ 750 in counsel fees on the fee application.


OVERVIEW: After the commissioner determined that the cost of the handicapped children's educational services was not reimbursable, the handicapped children commenced a proceeding in the trial court challenging the commissioner's determination.
