The trial court awarded judgment in favor of the handicapped children. The handicapped children then filed a motion for an award of counsel fees under a provision of the Handicapped Children's Protection Act, codified at 20 U.S.C.S. § 1415(e)(4)(B). The trial court determined that the handicapped children had prevailed in the underlying action, awarded the handicapped children $ 11,687 in counsel fees and $ 177 in disbursements, and awarded the handicapped children $ 750 in counsel fees on the fee application. Both parties sought review of the trial court's judgment. The court reversed the trial court's award of $ 750 for counsel fees on the fee application, but otherwise affirmed the trial court's judgment. The court found that the handicapped children's action was brought under § 1415(e)(4)(B) because the handicapped children were allowed to bypass the administrative process where exhaustion was futile or inadequate.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's award of counsel fees to the handicapped children on the fee application and remanded the matter to the trial court for further proceedings. As modified, the court affirmed the trial court's award of attorney fees and disbursements to the handicapped children.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children -- Counsel Fees -- Retroactivity of Statute

1. Section 5 of the Handicapped Children's Protection Act (Pub L 99-372; 100 US Stat 798), which provides for retroactivity with regard to the awarding of counsel fees to the parents or guardian of a handicapped child who is the prevailing party in an action pursuant to the Education of the Handicapped Act (EHA; 20 USC § 1400 et seq.), is not an unconstitutional exercise of Congress' spending power, and the contention that EHA, as enacted in 1975, did not give notice to the States that they would be required to pay counsel fees as a condition of receiving  [***2] Federal funds is without merit, since there is no question that the legislation at issue is clear and unambiguous. Moreover, the retrospective grant of counsel fees does not constitute a legislative encroachment upon a judicial function, since EHA is not a simple funding statute; a motion for counsel fees requires an inquiry separate from the merits and such a motion does not imply a change in the judgment but merely seeks what is due because of the judgment.

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children -- Counsel Fees -- Exhaustion of Administrative Remedies

2. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Commissioner of Education that the cost of educational services to plaintiffs, four handicapped children, at a religious school for the deaf would not be reimbursed for a certain school year, the Commissioner's argument that counsel fees were improperly awarded to the prevailing plaintiffs (see, 20 USC § 1415 [e] [4] [B]) since the proceeding was not an "action or proceeding brought under [20 USC § 1415 (e)]" because of petitioners' failure to pursue the administrative remedies specified in 20 USC § 1415 (b) (2) and (c), and that, therefore, there is no authority  [***3] for an award of such fees, is without merit; inasmuch as it was the Commissioner, the tribunal of last resort in the required administrative proceedings (see, Education Law § 4404), who made the disputed legal determination, the charade of asking him to overturn his own decision would have been senseless. Accordingly, parents may bypass the administrative process where exhaustion would be futile or inadequate, or when a question of statutory analysis is involved.

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children -- Counsel Fees

3. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Commissioner of Education that the cost of educational services to plaintiffs, four handicapped children, at a religious school for the deaf would not be reimbursed for a certain school year, the Commissioner's argument that counsel fees should have been imposed against the local school board and not the Commissioner pursuant to the provisions of the Education of the Handicapped Act (see, USC § 1415 [e] [4] [B]) is without merit since the Commissioner did not appeal the judgment in the underlying proceeding and will not now be heard to complain that the fault was not his; further, the decision  [***4] to terminate the subject placements, turning on a question of statutory interpretation, was that of the Commissioner and not the local Board of Education.

Schools -- Education of Handicapped Children -- Counsel Fees -- Prevailing Rate

4. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Commissioner of Education that the cost of educational services to plaintiffs, four handicapped children, at a religious school for the deaf would not be reimbursed for a certain school year pursuant to the Education of the Handicapped Act (20 USC § 1400 et seq.), Supreme Court did not abuse its discretion in awarding counsel fees to the prevailing plaintiffs (see, 20 USC § 1415 [e] [4] [B]) at a rate of $ 90 per hour since that was the rate determined to prevail in the State capital area at the time of the underlying proceeding, and 20 USC § 1415 (e) (4) (C) provides that fees awarded shall be based on rates prevailing in the community in which the proceeding arose; the fact that the Commissioner has his office in the State capital and plaintiffs were seeking relief against a State officer supports a finding that the proceeding arose there, although injury to plaintiffs occurred  [***5] elsewhere. However, it was error to have awarded the same rate for a partner's time as for an associate's.

 

509 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Albany Area Builders Ass'n v. Guilderland


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


141 A.D.2d 293; 534 N.Y.S.2d 791; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10961



November 10, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Judgment rendered in favor of plaintiffs, and it is declared that the Town of Guilderland Transportation Impact Fee Law is invalid, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff builders commenced a proceeding to challenge defendant town's authority under N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law §§ 10, 11 to enact a Transportation Impact Fee Law (TIFL), which required all applicants for building permits who sought to make an improvement to land or change use of land that would generate additional traffic to pay a transportation impact fee at the time the permit was issued.


OVERVIEW: The court held that N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law §10(1)(i), which permitted local governments to adopt laws relating generally to their own property, affairs or government, did not authorize TIFL because TIFL had effects that went beyond the town's boundaries. The court noted that the imposition of a transportation impact fee would inhibit new construction within the town's boundaries and would shift new development to surrounding localities. The court further ruled that the town was not authorized under N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(1)(ii)(a)(6) to adopt TIFL because it did not relate to the acquisition, care, management and use of the town's highways, roads, streets, avenues and property, or under N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law §10(1)(ii) (a)(7), which permitted laws relating to the acquisition of transit facilities and the ownership and operation thereof. N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law §10(1)(ii)(a)(12) did not authorize the adoption of TIFL because it did not directly further the objective of public safety, but, rather, was aimed at raising revenues. The court also ruled that TIFL was inconsistent with and preempted by general laws regulating highway funding and municipal finance.


OUTCOME: The court rendered judgment in favor of the builders, holding that the town did not have statutory or constitutional authority to adopt TIFL and that the law was invalid for lack of such authority.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- Authority to Enact Transportation Impact Fee Law

1. A town does not have the authority to enact a transportation impact fee law, which provides that all applicants for building permits must pay a fee, determined by a schedule, reflecting the additional traffic generated by the proposed construction, and which establishes a transportation impact fee trust fund wherein the fees will be placed to be subsequently used for capital improvements to the road network; Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 (1) (i), which permits local governments to adopt laws relating generally to their own "property, affairs or government", does not authorize the local law in question because of that law's far-reaching implications. It can hardly be disputed that the law in question has effects which go beyond the town's boundaries, and that the imposition of the fee in question will inhibit new construction within the town's boundaries and  [***2] thereby shift new development to surrounding localities; inasmuch as increased development is an issue affecting localities throughout the State and is, therefore, a matter of State concern, the law in question does not relate solely to the town's "property, affairs or government".

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- Authority to Enact Transportation Impact Fee Law

2. A town does not have the authority to enact a transportation impact fee law, which provides that all applicants for building permits must pay a fee, determined by a schedule, reflecting the additional traffic generated by the proposed construction, and which establishes a transportation impact fee trust fund wherein the fees will be placed to be subsequently used for capital improvements to the road network. Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 (1) (ii) (a) (6), which permits municipalities to regulate the use of their roadways, does not authorize the law in question, since that provision has never been interpreted to permit a municipality to create new taxes to fund highway improvements and is not to be so construed now. Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 (1) (ii) (a) (7), which permits laws relating to the acquisition  [***3] of transit facilities and the ownership and operation thereof, merely grants localities the authority to acquire tangible means of moving people and things from place to place and does not explicitly or implicitly grant municipalities the authority to create new forms of taxation to support transit facilities.

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- Authority to Enact Transportation Impact Fee Law

3. A town does not have the authority to enact a transportation impact fee law, which provides that all applicants for building permits must pay a fee, determined by a schedule, reflecting the additional traffic generated by the proposed construction, and which establishes a transportation impact fee trust fund wherein the fees will be placed to be subsequently used for capital improvements to the road network. Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 (1) (ii) (a) (12), which authorizes local governments to adopt laws relating to the government, protection, order, conduct, safety, health and well-being of persons or property therein, does not authorize the local law in question, since local laws must bear a reasonable relationship to the objective sought to be promoted, i.e., public safety,  [***4] health or welfare, in order to come within the police power of a municipality, and while the objective presumably sought to be promoted by the local law in question is public safety, that goal is not directly furthered; rather, the law in question is aimed at raising revenues.

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- Authority to Enact Transportation Impact Fee Law

4. A town does not have the authority to enact a transportation impact fee law, which provides that all applicants for building permits must pay a fee, determined by a schedule, reflecting the additional traffic generated by the proposed construction, and which establishes a transportation impact fee trust fund wherein the fees will be placed to be subsequently used for capital improvements to the road network; to the extent that the fee imposes the expense of highway improvements upon a small group of home buyers even though the benefit of such improvements is enjoyed by the public generally, the fee resembles a tax (see, Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [ii] [a] [9-a]).

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- Authority to Enact Transportation Impact Fee Law -- State Preemption

5. A town does  [***5] not have the authority to enact a transportation impact fee law, which provides that all applicants for building permits must pay a fee, determined by a schedule, reflecting the additional traffic generated by the proposed construction, and which establishes a transportation impact fee trust fund wherein the fees will be placed to be subsequently used for capital improvements to the road network, since such local law is inconsistent with and preempted by the general laws regulating highway funding and municipal finance; the means by which revenues are raised and expended for the purpose of improving transportation facilities are the subject of comprehensive regulation by the Legislature, primarily codified in Town Law article 8, and permitting towns to raise revenues with impact fees would allow towns to circumvent the statutory restrictions on how money is raised and, further, would permit towns to create a fund of money subject to limited accountability, not subject to the statutory requirements governing how funds for highway improvements are spent (see, Highway Law §§ 141, 271, 284, 285, 285-a). Accordingly, the town had neither the statutory nor the constitutional (see,  [***6] NY Const, art IX, § 2 [c]) authority to enact its transportation impact fee law.

 

510 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Keyes


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


141 A.D.2d 227; 535 N.Y.S.2d 162; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10932



November 3, 1988 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Leave to Appeal Granted March 22, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law, motion denied, indictment reinstated and matter remitted to the County Court of Albany County for further proceedings not inconsistent with this court's decision.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state appealed from an order of the Albany County Court (New York), which granted a motion by defendant to dismiss the indictment charging him with violating N.Y. Penal Law § 263.15, entitled "Promoting a sexual performance by a child."


OVERVIEW: The county court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that it failed to state a crime pursuant to the statute, and the state appealed. The court reversed the order, denied defendant's motion, and reinstated the indictment, holding that it specifically charged defendant with violations of § 263.15 in that he knowing the character and content thereof did procure the proscribed material from either an undercover police officer of the United States Postal Service. The form and content of the indictment complied with statutory requirements under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 200.50 and charged the perpetration of criminal conduct intended to be proscribed. The court held that the word "procure" in the context of § 263.15 should be assigned its most natural and obvious meaning, that is, an intent to acquire, obtain, or to get possession of, and that the addition of the word "procure" as proscribed conduct in N.Y. Penal Law § 263.00(5) was indicative of the legislature's determination to attack the anathema of exploitation of children through sexual performances.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the county court, which granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment, denied defendant's motion, reinstated the indictment charging him with promoting a sexual performance by a child, and remitted the matter to the county court.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Indictment -- Promoting Sexual Performance by Child

An indictment charging defendant with violating Penal Law § 263.15, i.e., promoting a sexual performance by a child, is legally sufficient where the conduct defendant is accused of committing is the receipt and possession at his home of magazines and videotapes of children under the age of 16 engaging in various sex acts, since the statute proscribes the "[promoting]" of any sexual performance by a child, and "promote" is defined by Penal Law § 263.00 (5) as meaning "to procure", which in the context of the statutory framework should be assigned its most natural and obvious meaning: an intent to acquire or get possession of. The addition of the word "procure" as proscribed conduct is indicative  [***2] of the Legislature's determination to combat child pornography, which produces physical or psychological harm to the children involved, thereby rendering irrelevant the issue of whether the proscribed material is distributed commercially or possessed privately. A State has wider leeway in regulating child pornography in light of a State's compelling interest in safeguarding the well-being of minors, and the insertion of the word "procure" into section 263.00 (5) some years after the enactment of Penal Law article 235 dealing with obscenity, indicates a specific intent to expand and enlarge the meaning of the word "promote".

 

511 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. James


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


144 A.D.2d 717; 535 N.Y.S.2d 452; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10922



November 3, 1988 

 

512 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Krugman v. Board of Assessors


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


141 A.D.2d 175; 533 N.Y.S.2d 495; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10321



October 24, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order is reversed, with costs, the proceeding is converted into one pursuant to CPLR article 78 to review a determination of the respondents reassessing the value of the petitioner's property for the 1987/1988 tax year, the petition is granted to the extent of vacating the reassessment, and the matter is remitted to the respondents for a new assessment in accordance herewith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner property owner appealed the judgment of the Supreme Court in Nassau County (New York), which denied his motion for summary judgment in his action against respondent municipality challenging respondent's assessment of his property.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner property owner brought an action against respondent municipality seeking, among other things, a review of the tax assessment of his property and a declaratory judgment invalidating the respondent's method of reassessing the value of real property only upon resale. The trial court denied petitioner's motion for summary judgment despite respondent's failure to serve an answer in a timely fashion. On appeal, the court concluded that respondent's practice involving the selective reassessment of real property upon a transfer thereof violated the equal protection clauses of the federal and state constitutions because it permitted similarly situated properties to be taxed unequally with no demonstration that the unequal treatment was rationally related to the achievement of a legitimate governmental purpose. The assessment of petitioner's property was vacated and the matter remitted to respondent for a new determination.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the trial court denying petitioner property owner's motion for summary judgment and vacated the assessment of petitioner's property because respondents' method of tax reassessment was constitutionally invalid.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Assessment of Property upon Transfer

1. The practice of a local taxing unit involving the selective reassessment of real property upon a transfer thereof violates the Equal Protection Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 11) because it permits similarly situated properties to be taxed unequally with no demonstration that the unequal treatment is rationally related to the achievement of a legitimate governmental purpose; accordingly, petitioner property owner's assessment based upon the invalid method of reassessment must be vacated and the matter remitted  [***2] for a new assessment. The taxing unit's disparate treatment of new property owners on the one hand and long-standing property owners on the other has the effect of permitting property owners who have been long-standing recipients of public amenities to bear the least amount of their cost. It appears that the sole purpose of the different classes is to serve administrative convenience by relieving the locality of the burden of conducting a total review of the tax roll, and that method lacks any rational basis in law and results in invidious discrimination between owners of similarly situated property.

Taxation -- Assessment -- Challenge to Assessment Method

2. In a proceeding in which petitioner property owner is challenging the constitutionality of the practice of the local taxing authority whereby real property is reassessed only when there has been a transfer of title, petitioner's challenge is clearly based upon an allegation that respondents' method of reassessing property values is erroneous and, thus, the activity challenged should properly be reviewed by way of a collateral proceeding; pursuant to CPLR 103 (c), the court may remedy procedural infirmities by converting  [***3] the instant RPTL article 7 proceeding into a CPLR article 78 proceeding. Although taxpayer challenges to a real property assessment are generally restricted to a proceeding under RPTL article 7 and petitioner's first cause of action may be deemed within the purview of that law, petitioner's second cause of action challenges the method of reassessment and seeks a declaration of its invalidity, and article 7 does not contemplate that type of challenge.

Pleading -- Notice to Admit -- Failure to Respond

3. In a proceeding in which petitioner property owner challenged the constitutionality of the practice of the local taxing authority whereby real property is reassessed only when there has been a transfer of title, respondents' failure to respond to petitioner's service of a notice to admit was at their peril, since petitioner sought to obtain admissions by means of that procedural device and not by way of RPTL 712 (1).

Taxation -- Assessment -- Existence of Triable Issues of Fact

4. In a proceeding in which petitioner property owner challenged the constitutionality of the practice of the local taxing authority whereby real property is reassessed only when there has been a  [***4] transfer of title, relevant factual allegations must be deemed admitted for purposes of the action where petitioner served a notice to admit upon respondents who failed to respond, since the fact sought to be elicited, i.e., whether respondents only reassess property upon its transfer, could be readily admitted or denied, and an admission pertaining to the method of assessing the value of petitioner's property is of the type contemplated by CPLR 3123 (a). Moreover, respondents' opposition to petitioner's motion for summary judgment leaves no room for doubt that the methodology applied by respondents did involve only reassessing recently transferred properties, since respondents did not deny that practice.

 

513 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Shields v. Katz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


143 A.D.2d 743; 533 N.Y.S.2d 451; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 10152; Unemployment Ins. Rep. (CCH) P15,436A



October 11, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, putative class of mental patients (mental patients), sought review of the decision of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York.) granting a motion to dismiss their complaint for failure to join a necessary party and lack of subject matter jurisdiction in favor of defendants, state mental hospital and its officials, in the mental patients' action seeking a declaration that N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 29.23 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The state mental hospital (hospital) was appointed as representative payee to receive the mental patients' social security benefits after certifying that the mental patients were incapable of handling their own funds and without affording them prior notice or an opportunity to dispute the certification. Portions of the benefits were applied to the cost of their care and maintenance at the hospital. The mental patients brought an action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and also sought the return of money representing payments to the hospital on their behalf. The trial court granted the hospital's motion to dismiss. On review, the court reversed the decision. The court held that the trial court erred in dismissing the complaint for failure to join the federal secretary of human services because the complaint was narrowly drawn to challenge only the state law governing the procedure whereby a state mental facility certified patients as incompetent to manage their own funds and then controlled those funds. The trial court did not lack subject matter jurisdiction because it was the proper forum for a claim seeking a declaration regarding the constitutionality of a statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decision dismissing the mental patients' complaint and held that the trial court should have exercised jurisdiction over the mental patients' claims for declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief.

 

514 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Islip v. Caviglia


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


141 A.D.2d 148; 532 N.Y.S.2d 783; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9319



September 26, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order and judgment (one paper) is modified, on the law and the facts, by deleting so much of the judgment as declared the provision of section 68-341.1 of the Code of the Town of Islip requiring a special exception, constitutionally valid and substituting therefor a declaration that the special exception requirement is unconstitutional; as so modified, the judgment is affirmed, with costs to the respondent.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed from an order and judgment of the Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York), which permanently enjoined them from operating an adult bookstore at certain premises in accordance with a town ordinance, Islip, New York Town Code § 68-341.1(B). The trial court granted a stay of the order and judgment pending the outcome of the appeal.


OVERVIEW: The issue was the constitutionality of an ordinance that relegated defendants' adult bookstore to the town's industrial district. The court held that the ordinance was not aimed at the content of the books sold but was in the nature of a time, place and manner restriction, and that the ordinance was constitutionally permissible. However, the court reversed the part of the judgment that declared the provision of Town of Islip Code 68-341.1 requiring a special exception, constitutionally valid and substituted a declaration that the special exception requirement was unconstitutional. The town could not impose an additional barrier to the relocation of the bookstore in an Industrial I zone by vesting unfettered discretion in the zoning board to grant or deny a special exception permit. The ordinance relocated but did not ban adult establishments and, therefore, did not impermissibly abridge the liberty of speech under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8. The ordinance imposed a time, place and manner restriction upon the operation of adult business in a reasonable attempt to preserve the quality of community life.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the order and judgment be modified, on the law and the facts, by deleting so much of the judgment as declared the provision of the section of the Code of the Town of Islip requiring a special exception, constitutionally valid and substituting therefor a declaration that the special exception requirement was unconstitutional; as so modified, the judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Time, Place and Manner Restriction on Adult Bookstore

1. A town ordinance which relegated the location of an adult bookstore, defined as an establishment which sells books, films, etc., and excludes any minor by reason of age, to the town's industrial zoning district does not offend the United States Constitution since the ordinance is not aimed at the content of the books sold but is in the nature of a constitutionally permissible time, place and manner restriction;  [***2] the ordinance, which was enacted after extensive studies, is not aimed at the content of the books but, rather, at the effect of the bookstore upon the community and its quality of life. The ordinance is designed to serve a substantial governmental interest, viz., to prevent the type of "skid-row" environment caused by proliferation of sex-oriented businesses, and it provides reasonable alternative locations within the town for adult-use establishments, there being sufficient industrial zoned property dispersed throughout the town so that the spatial limitations (i.e., no such establishment to be situated near schools, residences, etc., or near another such establishment) do not operate to foreclose all adult bookstores.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- State Constitution

2. A town ordinance which relegates the location of adult bookstores to the town's industrial zoning district and provides that no such store may be situated near schools, residences, etc., or near another such store does not offend NY Constitution, article I, § 8, which declares that no law shall be passed to restrain the liberty of speech, since the rationale upholding the time, place and manner  [***3] restrictions on adult bookstores set forth by the United States Supreme Court is sound and withstands scrutiny under the State Constitution; the ordinance in question does not ban adult establishments and, therefore, does not impermissibly abridge the liberty of speech, and there is no prior restraint upon the bookstore's owners' constitutionally protected right to disseminate adult books and other materials. The time, place and manner restrictions are a reasonable attempt to preserve the quality of community life, and the State's interest in ensuring a balance between the right of an adult bookstore to remain in business and the right of a town to protect its business districts from the spectre of "skid-row" deterioration is well served.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Regulation of Adult Bookstores -- Vagueness and Overbreadth

3. A town ordinance which relegates the location of adult bookstores to the town's industrial zoning district and provides that no such store may be situated near schools, residences, etc., or near another such store is not unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, since a person of ordinary intelligence is given fair notice of what conduct  [***4] is forbidden and explicit standards are set forth to preclude arbitrary and discriminatory application. The ordinance relocates, but does not proscribe, constitutionally protected speech or conduct, is limited to establishments which exclude minors by reason of age, and reasonably confines its application to those establishments found to have a secondary detrimental effect on the community.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Regulation of Adult Bookstores -- Amortizing Legal Nonconforming Use

4. A town ordinance which relegates the location of adult bookstores to the town's industrial zoning district, provides that no such store may be situated near schools, residences, etc., or near another such store, and provides that "By amortization, the right to maintain a legal non-conforming adult use shall terminate in accordance with [a] schedule" that varies from approximately 15 months to over 5 years, depending on the amount of capital investment in the business as of the date of the enactment of the ordinance, does not impair the bookstore's rights under either the Federal or State Constitution, since shorter amortization periods have been upheld as constitutional.

Municipal  [***5] Corporations -- Zoning -- Regulation of Adult Bookstores -- Special Exception Permit -- Severability

5. A town ordinance which relegates the location of adult bookstores to the town's industrial zoning district and provides that no such store may be situated near schools, residences, etc., or near another such store impermissibly vests town officials with the power to discriminate on the basis of the content of books or other forms of expression by permitting such uses only as a special exception after public hearing, where the ordinance contains no express provisions setting standards for the Zoning Board to follow in deciding whether to grant or deny special exception permits; the unfettered discretion granted the Zoning Board may serve to disguise content censorship. However, the special exception provision is superfluous and does not affect the constitutionality of the remainder of the ordinance, and in light of the severability clause in the ordinance, which is an express statement by a legislative body that the valid provisions of the ordinance should be enforced, the constitutionally offensive special exception provision is severed and declared unconstitutional, and the  [***6] rest of the ordinance permitted to stand.

 

515 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cortez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


143 A.D.2d 464; 532 N.Y.S.2d 585; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9229



September 22, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the County Court of Washington County (New York) that convicted him of assault.


OVERVIEW: The court affirmed defendant prison inmate's conviction for assaulting a correction officer. The assault statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 120.05(3), which allowed conviction for causing physical injury, was not unconstitutionally vague, given a statutory definition of "physical injury." The victim's status as a peace officer performing his duties was properly regarded as an aggravating circumstance, and this did not violate equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

516 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bobka v. Huntington


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


143 A.D.2d 381; 532 N.Y.S.2d 561; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9240



September 19, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff peddlers brought suit against defendant town seeking a declaration that chapter 149 of the town code, which regulated solicitors and peddlers, was unconstitutional. The Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York) held that the prohibited streets provision in the ordinance was constitutional, and the peddlers appealed.


OVERVIEW: Peddlers who sold flowers along the town's streets sought a declaration that the ordinance which excluded them from certain prohibited streets was unconstitutional because its real purpose was to protect retail florists from competition. The ordinance's stated purposes were protecting the peace of citizens in their homes, protecting consumers from fraud, and the prevention of congestion and unsafe conditions in the streets. The parties stipulated that the streets on the prohibited list had heavy traffic. The court held that the peddlers had failed to overcome the presumption of constitutionality that applied to local ordinances. The regulation of street use to prevent traffic congestion was a legitimate exercise of the town's police power and the peddlers had not shown beyond a reasonable doubt that the ordinance was enacted for any impermissible reason. If any state of facts, whether known or assumed, justified the ordinance, its constitutionality would be upheld. The evidence before the trial court indicated that the ordinance was rationally related to its stated purposes of preventing interference with the movement of traffic and unsafe conditions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's judgment upholding the ordinance's constitutionality.

 

517 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Vanterpool


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


143 A.D.2d 282; 532 N.Y.S.2d 279; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8932



August 29, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York), which convicted him of assault in the first degree and criminal possession of a weapon in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: After a nonjury trial, the trial court convicted defendant of assault in the first degree and criminal possession of a weapon in the second degree. Defendant sought review of the trial court's ruling. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court's decision, holding that the evidence was legally sufficient to support the defendant's conviction and that the verdict was not against the weight of the evidence under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 470.15(5). The court also found that defendant was not denied effective representation of counsel upon review of the counsel's performance in its entirety in conjunction with the evidence, law, and circumstances of the case notwithstanding defendant's dissatisfaction with the quality of his counsel's summation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment convicting defendant of assault in the first degree and criminal possession of a weapon in the second degree.

 

518 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Beard


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


143 A.D.2d 101; 531 N.Y.S.2d 351; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8141



August 1, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged his sentences imposed by the County Court, Suffolk County (New York), which imposed sentences upon defendant as a second felony offender pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06, based on a his previous conviction on felony charges 13 years earlier. In the current action defendant was convicted on charges by the State for burglary and drug offenses.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was adjudicated by the trial court as a second felony offender based on his prior conviction for attempted robbery in the third degree. The invocation of the tolling provision under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06(1)(b)(v) resulted from defendant's imprisonment on the robbery charge and brought the conviction within the 10-year limitations period of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 and resulted in longer sentences for his current convictions. On appeal, the court vacated the sentences imposed by the trial court, determined that defendant was a first felony offender, and reduced his sentences. Although the 10-year limitations period under § 70.06 limited the determination of second felony offense status to convictions for felonies within the 10 previous years, subject to tolling if defendant was imprisoned, that tolling provision contemplated that defendant had not been imprisoned without reason or unconstitutionally. Defendant's conviction on the attempted robbery charge was reversed on appeal, the indictments were dismissed, and therefore could not serve as a basis for his classification as a second felony offender.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's sentences imposed on defendant to treat him as a first felony offender.

 

519 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Cohen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


139 A.D.2d 221; 530 N.Y.S.2d 830; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 8041



July 28, 1988 



DISPOSITION: The petition is granted; the Hearing Panel findings of fact and conclusions of law are confirmed; the punishment of public censure is imposed; and the cross motion is granted only to the extent of confirming said findings of fact and conclusions of law, and otherwise denied, all as indicated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The matter was before the court on disciplinary proceedings instituted by petitioner, the Departmental Disciplinary Committee for the First Judicial Department (Committee) (New York), which recommended that respondent attorney be publicly censured for his conduct in avoiding subpoenas and court orders to show cause.


OVERVIEW: The Committee brought charges against the attorney alleging that he willfully and intentionally disobeyed and resisted an order of the supreme court that he appear and testify in an ongoing trial; that he knowingly and intentionally evaded service of a so-ordered subpoena requiring his testimony in the trial; and that he willfully and intentionally attempted to evade service of an order to show cause; all in violation of N.Y. Code Prof. Resp. DR 1-102(A)(4), (5), (6). After a hearing, a Committee panel sustained the charges and recommended that the matter be referred to the court with a recommended sanction of public censure. The court sustained the hearing panel's findings of fact and conclusions of law, and imposed public censure, concluding that the attorney's conduct in evading the service of subpoenas and an order to show cause constituted conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice and conduct which adversely reflected on his fitness to practice law. The court denied the portion of the attorney's cross motion to confirm the panel's report, concluding that the disciplinary rules were not unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court granted the Committee's petition recommending public censure, confirmed the hearing panel's findings of fact and conclusions of law, and imposed the punishment of public censure. The court granted the attorney's cross motion only to the extent of confirming the findings of fact and conclusions of law, and otherwise denied the motion.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Disciplinary Proceedings

1. The conduct of an attorney in evading the service of two subpoenas directing him to testify in a Medicaid fraud case involving a former client, and in evading service of an order to show cause why he should not be held in contempt for ignoring the second subpoena constituted conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice (see, Code of Professional Responsibility DR 1-102 [A] [5]) and conduct adversely reflecting on the attorney's fitness to practice law (see, Code of Professional Responsibility DR 1-102 [A] [6]), since the failure to testify impeded the proper administration  [***2] of justice in the fraud case; the evasion and circumvention of the service of the court papers reflects a disdain for the legal process which cannot be condoned, and, thus, the punishment of public censure should be imposed.

Attorney and Client -- Disciplinary Proceedings

2. In an attorney disciplinary proceeding, respondent attorney's contention that Code of Professional Responsibility DR 1-102 (A) (6) is unconstitutionally vague and multiplicious is unavailing, since a statute is void for vagueness if it fails to give a person of ordinary intelligence reasonable notice that the contemplated conduct is forbidden by statute, and DR 1-102 (A) (6), which prohibits an attorney from engaging "in any other conduct that adversely reflects on his fitness to practice law", does not exist in a vacuum, but must be read in conjunction with the other ethical strictures in the Code; accordingly, respondent, an experienced attorney, must certainly be on notice that his conduct in disobeying subpoenas and an order to show cause adversely reflected on his fitness to practice law. Moreover, a finding of guilt with respect to violating DR 1-102 (A) (5), which prohibits conduct prejudicial to  [***3] the administration of justice, and DR 1-102 (A) (6) is not multiplicious where the finding arises out of the same conduct, since the willful and intentional failure to comply with the subpoenas and order to show cause constituted a violation of each rule.

 

520 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Empire State Asso. of Adult Homes, Inc. v. Perales


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


139 A.D.2d 41; 530 N.Y.S.2d 682; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7424



July 7, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a health care providers association and individual facilities, challenged the judgment of the Supreme Court in Albany County (New York), which granted a motion by defendants, social services department and intervenor, for summary judgment declaring that N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law §§ 131, 131-o and 18 N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, §§ 485.12, 487.6 were constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The statutes and regulations in question established personal allowance accounts for adult care facility residents that received public assistance. The court affirmed the finding of constitutionality, determining that the trial court properly found that the statutes and regulations in question did not violate equal protection or due process guarantees. Plaintiffs contended that the federal government was permitted to recoup Federal Supplemental Security Income (SSI) overpayments made due to its miscalculation and permitted residents to use personal allowance grants by buying any items they wish from other merchants. Plaintiffs further argued that the provisions penalized only adult care facility operators, who were denied access to personal allowance accounts to pay for any shortfalls in agreed-upon payments resulting from SSI benefit reductions. The court found that the challenged provisions were a proper exercise of the state's police power to protect elderly citizens. The state had an affirmative duty to aid the needy and there was a rational basis for the guarantee of a monthly allowance of a given amount to adult care facility residents to purchase personal necessities.


OUTCOME: The judgment of constitutionality was affirmed, without costs, in plaintiffs' challenge to statutes and regulations that established personal allowance accounts for adult care facility residents that received public assistance.


HEADNOTES

Social Services -- Adult Care Facilities -- Personal Allowance Accounts

1. Social Services Law §§ 131 and 131-o and 18 NYCRR 485.12 and 487.6, which establish personal allowance accounts for adult care facility residents who receive public assistance, do not violate equal protection or due process guarantees of the operators of adult care facilities; the challenged provisions, which provide that the accounts are for the exclusive use of the residents of adult care facilities in purchasing basic personal items and that adult home operators are prohibited from using any portion of those accounts to compensate them for services provided, are a proper exercise of the State's police power to protect elderly citizens. The State has an affirmative duty to aid the needy and there is a rational basis for the guarantee of a set sum of money per month to adult care facility residents  [***2] to purchase personal necessities. Merchants from whom residents choose to make purchases do not occupy a position very different from facility operators in regard to the use of personal allowance funds since residents may buy needed personal items from the facility operators, as well as from other vendors, if they so choose. Moreover, it appears that an adult care facility resident's Supplemental Security Income benefits would not be reduced to recoup prior overpayments if such reduction would result in termination of an admission agreement, thereby rendering unavailing the operators' argument that they need to invade such funds of "overpaid" residents or terminate their admission agreements for failure to make timely payments for charges they agreed to pay.

Parties -- Intervention -- Resident of Adult Care Facility

2. In an action challenging the constitutionality of certain statutes and regulations affecting the operation of adult care facilities, Supreme Court did not abuse its discretion in allowing a resident of such a facility who receives Federal Supplemental Security Income benefits to intervene in the litigation, since the resident is a person who would be directly  [***3] affected by the outcome of the action, which seeks a ruling on the use of such benefits, and there was no showing of undue delay or prejudice to plaintiff operators.

 

521 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


James N. v. D'Amico


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


139 A.D.2d 302; 530 N.Y.S.2d 916; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 14779



July 7, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Application denied and petition dismissed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an original N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding in the nature of prohibition, petitioner suspect challenged a determination of respondent judge that granted the application of respondent district attorney for an order directing the suspect to provide a dental cast impression to aid authorities in the investigation of a homicide.


OVERVIEW: The judge granted the application of the district attorney for an order directing the suspect to provide a dental cast impression to aid authorities in the investigation of a homicide. In an original N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding in the nature of prohibition, the suspect challenged the judge's order. The suspect conceded that the court below had jurisdiction to hear the application but argued that the court below exceeded its jurisdiction because the district attorney failed to establish probable cause that the suspect committed the crime. On appeal, the court found that it did not have to address the probable cause issue because it determined that prohibition did not lie to obtain collateral review of an order directing a suspect to supply corporeal evidence. Accordingly, the suspect's petition was dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the suspect's petition challenging the determination of the judge, which granted the application of the district attorney for an order directing the suspect to provide a dental cast impression to aid authorities in the investigation of a homicide.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition -- Collateral Review of Order Directing Suspect in Criminal Matter to Supply Corporeal Evidence

Prohibition does not lie to obtain collateral review of an order directing a suspect in a homicide investigation to supply corporeal evidence, i.e., a dental cast impression; inasmuch as the order challenged is equivalent to the issuance of a search warrant, use of the writ of prohibition would violate the well-established rules governing use of the writ and defeat the underlying policies of limiting proliferation of litigation in criminal cases and avoiding consequent delays in investigation and prosecution. The order was issued by a Judge who had jurisdiction to entertain the District Attorney's application and petitioner's challenge to the  [***2] order, that it was issued on less than probable cause, merely asserts a substantive error of law and does not demonstrate that the court exceeded its power. Moreover, the harm sought to be prevented, that petitioner submit to a dental cast impression, does not justify issuance of the extraordinary writ inasmuch as the procedure is safe and the intrusion minimal; permitting collateral review of a discovery order is totally at odds with standard criminal procedure and the order, like any probable cause determination, may be challenged by a suppression motion and reviewed on direct appeal if petitioner is convicted.

 

522 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. North Street Book Shoppe, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


139 A.D.2d 118; 530 N.Y.S.2d 869; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7834



July 7, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, on the law, by combining the two counts upon which defendant was convicted into one count, and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant book store appealed its conviction from the Broome County Court (New York) for two counts of obscenity in the third degree alleging that the definition of obscenity was vague to the point of denying defendant due process and that the state's obscenity law violated free speech rights under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted on two counts of obscenity as the result of its sale of two sexually explicit magazines in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 235.00(1) and 235.05. The court modified the judgment by combining the two counts into one explaining that the single sale of two magazines, though separately wrapped and priced, constituted but one count of promoting obscene material. The court affirmed the judgment as modified rejecting defendant's constitutional claims that its due process rights were violated because the definition of obscenity under § 235.00(1) was vague and that its free speech rights were broader under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8 than its rights under the parallel provision of the U.S. Constitution. The court explained that obscenity as defined under the statute was not impermissibly vague and was easily interpreted as pertaining to hard core pornography by providing a reference point and incorporating the terms used by the United States Supreme Court to define obscenity. Further, defendant provided no compelling historical basis for extending the First Amendment protection under the state constitution beyond the protection provided under its Federal counterpart.


OUTCOME: The court modified defendant's conviction from two counts to one count explaining that the single sale of two magazines constituted but one count of promoting obscene material. The court affirmed the conviction as modified explaining that the state's definition of obscenity was not impermissibly vague and defendant's free speech rights were no broader under the state constitution than under the parallel provision of the Federal constitution.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Obscenity -- Constitutionality of Statute Defining Obscenity

1. Penal Law § 235.00, which defines obscene material, is not unconstitutionally vague since it is easily interpreted as pertaining to hard core pornography and is a codification of the criteria set forth by the United States Supreme Court in Miller v California (413 U.S. 15); by incorporating the yardstick of "contemporary community standards", the statute provides a reference point, and by reinterpreting "utterly without socially redeeming value", it employs terms whose breadth work in a defendant's favor. The very use of those terms by the United States Supreme Court in defining obscenity has been deemed authority for the proposition that they are not impermissibly vague. Moreover, defendant, which was convicted of  [***2] obscenity, has not demonstrated that the free speech provision of the State Constitution (NY Const, art I, § 8) is broader than the First Amendment; not only has the State Court of Appeals declined on at least two occasions to fashion a free speech/obscenity demarcation different from the Federal standard, but the fact that selling and promoting obscenity has been a crime in New York for some 120 years lends additional force to the presumption that the statute is constitutional.

Crimes -- Instructions -- Obscenity

2. In an obscenity prosecution, the trial court did not err in instructing the jury to determine obscenity based upon the community's "acceptance" of the particular materials in question; although the word "tolerance" would have been a better choice, "acceptance" has been condoned and a fair reading of the jury charge conveys the properly broad meaning of acceptance. In any event, inasmuch as defendant had not appealed the jury's finding that its magazines were substantively obscene, the court must assume they are and, thus, if there was error, it was harmless.

Crimes -- Obscenity -- Single Sale of Two Magazines

3. In a prosecution for obscenity, the single  [***3] sale of two magazines, though separately wrapped and priced, constituted but one count, not two, of promoting obscene material (see, CPL 40.20 [2]); however, inasmuch as defendant was sentenced concurrently on each count, the error in failing to combine the counts was harmless.

Crimes -- Obscenity -- Evidence -- Foundation

4. In a prosecution in which defendant was convicted of obscenity in the third degree, defendant's contention that in an effort to demonstrate prevailing community standards it should have been permitted to introduce comparable magazines received in evidence at an earlier trial in the same county wherein the jury acquitted a local bookstore of obscenity in the second degree, is without merit since defendant had to establish a foundation demonstrating both similarity of the material and reasonable community acceptance; however, the earlier not guilty verdict does not equate to acceptability, but merely says that the People did not prove every element of their case beyond a reasonable doubt.

 

523 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rex Paving Corp. v. White


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


139 A.D.2d 176; 531 N.Y.S.2d 831; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 14868



July 7, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, on the law, without costs, by reversing so much thereof as declared defendants' programs invalid; matter remitted to Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with this court's decision; and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The parties filed cross-appeals from a judgment of the Supreme Court in Albany County (New York), which partially granted plaintiff contractor's motion for summary judgment and upheld in part the constitutionality of defendant commissioners' affirmative action programs in favor of disadvantaged business enterprises.


OVERVIEW: Commissioners implemented affirmative action programs that favored disadvantaged business enterprises, following a congressional finding that minorities were denied effective participation in public contracts. A contractor filed an action against the commissioners, seeking a declaration that the commissioners' programs were illegal and unlawful because the commissioners acted without legislative authority, because they violated the administrative procedure act, and because the programs denied the contractor equal protection. The trial court partially granted the contractor's motion for summary judgment, but upheld the constitutionality of the programs, and the parties filed cross-appeals. The court initially noted that the potential effect on the contractor's ability to participate in government contracts warranted a recognition of standing to challenge the commissioners' programs. As to the merits, the court held that a two-prong analysis established that the programs were narrowly tailored to achieve their goals. However, the trial court had not properly explored whether the programs were justified by a compelling governmental interest, such as remedying past discrimination.


OUTCOME: The trial court's judgment was modified by reversing that portion of the judgment that declared the commissioners' programs invalid, and was affirmed as modified.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Standing of Contractor to Challenge Affirmative Action Program for Awarding State Construction Contracts

1. A domestic corporation which supplies materials and services as both a general contractor and subcontractor for public improvement projects has standing to challenge affirmative action programs implemented by the State to give minority and women-owned businesses a greater share of State construction contracts, since plaintiff seeks to preserve its right to compete for public contracts on the same terms as others, an interest the Equal Protection Clause may protect (see, NY Const, art I, § 11), since plaintiff has sufficiently alleged that the  [***2] affirmative action programs may have a harmful effect upon its ability to obtain contracts because of the preference to be given to minority and women-owned firms, and since there is no perceptible legislative intent to bar review of the State programs. While the allegations of injury are concededly vague, standing need not be justified by injury-in-fact in every instance. Accordingly, the potential effect on plaintiff's ability to participate in government contracts warrants a recognition of standing to challenge the State programs.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Programs -- Legislative Authorization

2. There is sufficient legislative authorization for the State Department of Transportation to implement an affirmative action program designed to award a greater share of construction contracts to minority and women-owned businesses with respect to Federally funded highway projects, since the Legislature, in Highway Law § 85, expressly authorized the Department to pursue all measures necessary to comply with the Federal aid highway acts and accompanying regulations, which require that affirmative action programs be implemented. Moreover, Transportation  [***3] Law § 428 (1) requires the Department to comply with "federal laws relative to participation of minority and women-owned business enterprises" where Federal financial assistance is received on transportation infrastructure projects. Accordingly, those statutory provisions provide clear legislative authorization regarding Federally funded projects.

Evidence -- Judicial Notice -- Matters of Public Record

3. In an action challenging the State's implementation of affirmative action programs for exclusively State-funded construction contracts on the grounds that the Governor has failed to act pursuant to the authority granted by Transportation Law § 428 (2), the court shall take judicial notice of the Governor's letter and the regulations promulgated and filed at the Governor's direction where those regulations and letter were not before the Supreme Court and are dehors the certified record on appeal, since judicial notice may be taken of matters of public record, including regulations filed by a State agency ( CPLR 4511 [a]) and official Executive memoranda. Inasmuch as an appellate court is required to apply the law as it exists at the time of appeal, it is appropriate to take  [***4] judicial notice of the Governor's letter and the filed regulations, particularly since the latter are remedial and prospective in nature.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Programs -- Authorization by Governor

4. An affirmative action program applicable to exclusively State-funded contracts and implemented by the State Department of Transportation has been legislatively authorized in light of the action taken by the Governor pursuant to Transportation Law § 428 (2) in transmitting a letter empowering and directing the Department to implement such a program in accord with attached procedures and guidelines; in light of the Governor's further authorization of the Department to adopt procedures and guidelines necessary to administer the program, the only barrier to the program has been cleared, and the Department subsequently filed the appropriate regulations with the Secretary of State.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Program -- Prison Construction

5. Affirmative action programs implemented by the State Office of General Services (OGS) with respect to prison construction contracts have been legislatively authorized since the Prison  [***5] Construction Act (L 1983, ch 56, § 12) expressly requires each contracting agency to implement an affirmative action program for contracts it finances; to effectuate its provisions, the Act specifically charges OGS with monitoring such programs. Thus, the OGS program enjoys clear legislative authorization with respect to contracts funded by the Act. With respect to other OGS construction contracts, OGS adopted regulations which confirm that its affirmative action program is entirely voluntary (see, 9 NYCRR part 342).

Statutes -- Incorporation by Reference -- Incorporation of Federal Statutes

6. In an action challenging the implementation by the State of affirmative action programs designed to give minority and women-owned businesses a greater share of State construction contracts, plaintiff's contention that the State statutes in question (Highway Law § 85; Transportation Law § 428) incorporate by reference various Federal acts in violation of NY Constitution, article III, § 16 is without merit, since the State acts merely authorize State officials to comply with the relevant Federal guidelines; moreover, the State officials are not acting under a Federal delegation of  [***6] authority but under direction from the Legislature.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Programs -- Federally Funded Contracts -- Equal Protection

7. Affirmative action programs implemented by the Department of Transportation and designed to award minority and women-owned businesses a greater share of State construction contracts do not deprive plaintiff contractor of equal protection of the laws under NY Constitution, article I, § 11 insofar as those programs relate to Federally funded contracts, since the regulations implementing those programs are statutorily authorized and necessary to ensure the continued receipt of Federal highway funds.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Programs -- State-Funded Contracts -- Equal Protection

8. In an action challenging the implementation by the State of affirmative action programs designed to give minority and women-owned businesses a greater share of State contracts, the State, in addressing the contention of plaintiff contractor that such programs deny it equal protection, is obligated to establish a firm basis for the remedial action taken since there must be some showing of prior discrimination  [***7] by the government unit involved before allowing limited use of racial classifications in order to remedy such discrimination. Consequently, inasmuch as findings have yet to be made as to whether the State engaged in any past discriminatory practices in the construction industry, the lower court not having reached plaintiff's equal protection challenge, the matter should be remitted to Supreme Court for a factual determination of whether the challenged programs have a legitimate remedial purpose. It is noted that while racial classifications must be "narrowly tailored" to achieve the stated goal, a lesser standard of judicial review pertains to women-owned business enterprises, which focuses on whether the means employed are "substantially related" to the goal of alleviating past discrimination. Moreover, although the State is not required to show actual instances of prior unlawful discrimination, there must be convincing evidence that the program in question is appropriate to remedy apparent discrimination, and statistical evidence of an abrupt disparity between actual participation of minority business concerns in public contracts and the percentage of qualified minority businesses  [***8] in the relevant labor pool should suffice.

State -- Construction Contracts -- Affirmative Action Programs -- Constitutionality of Good-Faith Efforts to Fulfill Minority Participation Requirements

9. An affirmative action program implemented by the State Department of Transportation and designed to give minority and women-owned businesses a greater share of construction contracts passes constitutional muster where the program does not impose a fixed, mandatory set-aside, but simply requires contractors to utilize "good faith" efforts in fulfilling participation requirements; the inherent flexibility of the program limits the detrimental impact on nonminority contractors, and because the program is subjected to annual review, the lack of a specific durational limit is not fatal.

 

524 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Med. Malpractice Ins. Ass'n v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


138 A.D.2d 177; 531 N.Y.S.2d 231; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7242



June 30, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on February 4, 1987, affirmed, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff excess insurer filed an action for a preliminary injunction against defendant Governor of New York, seeking to enjoin the implementation and enforcement of an amendment to the Medical Malpractice Reform Act of 1986, which would have required excess insurer to refund stabilization reserve charges. The Supreme Court (New York) granted excess insurer's motion for an injunction. Governor sought review.


OVERVIEW: Excess insurer was statutorily required to provide malpractice insurance to all physician applicants in the State. Excess insurer was also required to maintain a stabilization reserve fund, which it could use to offset deficits, pursuant to N.Y. Ins. Law § 5509(a). At the end of 1985, excess insurer transferred the stabilization reserve fund to its premium account to offset its deficit. Then, the State legislature passed the amendment to the Act, requiring excess insurer to return the stabilization funds. All parties agreed that excess insurer was operating at a deficit. The court held that the trial court did not err in granting the motion for a preliminary injunction, as excess insurer was ultimately likely to succeed on the merits. Specifically, an appropriation of the stabilization fund, in which excess insurer had a vested property right, would have constituted an unconstitutional deprivation of property in violation of due process. Moreover, the court held that enforcement of the amendment would have caused irreparable harm to excess insurer, as without an injunction, excess insurer would have been unable to recoup the distributed funds.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Preliminary Injunction Enjoining Implementation of Statute Requiring Refund of Certain Reserve Fund Charges by Medical Malpractice Insurance Association

1. In an action challenging the constitutionality of Laws of 1986 (ch 266, § 11), which required the Medical Malpractice Insurance Association, an entity created by the Legislature to deal with the malpractice insurance crisis in New York, to refund to hospitals stabilization reserve fund charges which it had collected on excess insurance policies and applied as authorized to offset operating deficits, a preliminary injunction enjoining the implementation and enforcement of said law was properly granted since the Association is ultimately likely to succeed on the merits of its challenge, the Association would be irreparably harmed if such [***2] relief were not granted, and, on balance, the equities favor it.

Injunctions -- Preliminary Injunction -- When Remedy Appropriate

2. It is appropriate, when the constitutionality of a statute is challenged, to issue an injunction prohibiting the implementation of the statute pending litigation, since to withhold relief and allow illegal enforcement of an unconstitutional statute would strip a litigant of a constitutionally protected right and defeat the purpose of the declaratory action.

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- State Regulation -- Insurer's Property Interest in Reserve Fund

3. Although the Legislature has the prerogative to regulate the insurance industry, the right to regulate by exercise of the State's police power is not absolute, and where a statute would have retroactive effect, courts shall scrutinize the legislation more closely to examine whether the law is reasonably calculated to serve a compelling public interest, and the extent to which retrospective application creates unfairness. Moreover, a regulated entity cannot be compelled to carry on its business at a loss, and retroactive legislation may not impair or destroy vested rights. Accordingly,  [***3] the interest of the Medical Malpractice Insurance Association, a nonprofit unincorporated association created by the Legislature to deal with the malpractice insurance crisis in New York, in a stabilization reserve fund is not a mere unilateral expectation but rather a legitimate claim of entitlement to those funds already collected from its insureds, deposited in said fund, and intended and used to offset its deficit; the Association's interest in the fund is a property interest upon which the Association has and continues to rely, a reliance that must not be arbitrarily undermined.

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Stabilization Reserve Fund of Medical Malpractice Insurance Association

4. The right of the Medical Malpractice Insurance Association, a nonprofit unincorporated association created by the Legislature to deal with the medical malpractice insurance crisis in New York, to maintain and use the amounts collected for its stabilization reserve fund, i.e., a fund representing collections on excess insurance policies and applied as authorized by statute to offset operating deficits, is founded upon Insurance Law § 5509 (a), which explicitly stated that "[the] fund  [***4] shall be used for payment to the association of any deficit", and, thus, the statute expressly manifests the Association's property right in amounts collected for the stabilization reserve fund. The Association is not a State agency and its assets are not the property of the State: the reserve fund is administered solely by the Association and not by any governmental entity; the Association is the exclusive custodian of the fund, and the State does not assume liability for inadequacies in the fund. Thus, Laws of 1986 (ch 266, § 11), which requires the association to refund to hospitals stabilization reserve fund charges, constitutes an unconstitutional deprivation of property in violation of due process, and amounts to forcing the association, a regulated entity operating, as is conceded by all parties, at a loss, to carry on its business at a loss, a concept repugnant to constitutional protections of due process.

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Preliminary Injunction -- Statute Regulating Medical Malpractice Insurance Association -- Irreparable Harm

5. In an action challenging the constitutionality of Laws of 1986 (ch 266, § 11), which requires the Medical Malpractice [***5] Insurance Association, an entity created by the Legislature to deal with the medical malpractice insurance crisis in New York, to refund to hospitals stabilization reserve fund charges collected on excess insurance policies and applied as authorized by statute to offset operating deficits, petitioner Association has shown that failure to grant a preliminary injunction enjoining implementation of section 11 would result in irreparable harm where it has demonstrated that it would be forced to refund immediately more than $ 10 million in stabilization reserve fund charges from operating income that is necessary to meet obligations incurred with respect to excess policies, and in the absence of such injunction, the Association, which is concededly operating at a deficit, would, despite a favorable outcome in the instant action, be unable to recoup the distributed funds; the amounts refunded could not economically be recovered in plenary actions because the amounts due on the policies are small, and, in addition, the administrative costs entailed in pursuing recovery of the refunds could not be recovered from either the Insurance Department or the individual hospital policyholders.

 [***6] Insurance  -- Malpractice Insurance -- Preliminary Injunction -- Statute Regulating Medical Malpractice Insurance Association -- Balancing of Equities

6. In an action challenging the constitutionality of Laws of 1986 (ch 266, § 11), which requires the Medical Malpractice Insurance Association, an entity created by the Legislature to deal with the medical malpractice insurance crisis in New York, to refund to hospitals stabilization reserve fund charges collected on excess insurance policies and applied as authorized by statute to offset operating deficits, petitioner Association has shown that a balancing of the equities commands issuance of a preliminary injunction restraining the implementation of section 11, since a refund and subsequent recovery of the amounts refunded would seemingly compound the adverse impact respondent State officials have propounded on an unspecified but complicated fee reimbursement schedule; inasmuch as the Association has already demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits, the preservation of the status quo pending a final determination strikes an appropriate balance of the interests of all parties.

 

525 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Salvatore v. Schenectady


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


139 A.D.2d 87; 530 N.Y.S.2d 863; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 7236



June 30, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, on the law, without costs, by reversing so much thereof as dismissed petitioners' CPLR article 78 application; determination annulled, petition granted and the Building Inspector of the City of Schenectady directed to process petitioners' application for a building permit without regard to a certificate of approval from the city's Historic District Commission; and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners sought review of a judgment from the Supreme Court, Schenectady County (New York), which upheld the constitutionality of respondent city's historic preservation zoning ordinance and which affirmed the Historic District Commission's (Commission) conditioned approval of the property owners' permit application for the construction of a pool and deck on property designated "historic residential district."


OVERVIEW: After the property owners began building a pool and deck in an area designated "historical residential district," construction was halted because a permit was required under the city's zoning ordinance. Upon disapproving the property owners' application for a permit, the Commission recommended that the property owners submit a design compatible with the area. When the design was submitted, the Commission conditioned its approval of the application upon certain changes. As a result, the property owners brought a declaratory judgment action against the city, claiming the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague. Following a verdict for the city, review was sought, and the court affirmed and reversed. In affirming, the court held the ordinance was constitutional because its standards were sufficiently precise and objectively verifiable to give fair notice and provide minimal guidelines to safeguard against arbitrary enforcement and were clearly consistent with the legitimate legislative purposes of historic district regulation. In reversing, the court held the Commission's decision had been untimely under the ordinance, which constituted an approval as provided by the ordinance.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the constitutionality of the city's historic preservation zoning ordinance, but in reversing the Commission's conditioned approval of the property owners' permit application for the construction of a pool and deck on property designated "historic residential district," the court held the Commission's untimeliness in deciding the application was to be given effect and deemed an approval, as provided in the ordinance.
