In a civil action arising out of a criminal prosecution involving Medicaid fraud, defendants' contention that their due process rights  [***4] were violated because no hearing was conducted with respect to the imposition of the provisional remedies available pursuant to the forfeiture provisions of CPLR article 13-A is without merit where the court heard extensive argument and defendants were given an opportunity to submit affidavits and memoranda of law; although no evidentiary hearing was held, the procedure was not ex parte, and the submissions of counsel did not raise factual issues with regard to the substantive elements of the charged crimes.

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Proceeds of Crime -- Dissipation of Assets

4. In a civil action arising out of a criminal prosecution involving Medicaid fraud in which provisional remedies were sought pursuant to the forfeiture provisions of CPLR article 13-A, the failure to grant an attachment order "may result" in the dissipation of assets ( CPLR 1312 [3]) and the State sufficiently demonstrated that defendants, with intent to defraud, were about to dispose of certain assets ( CPLR 6201 [3]) where it was revealed that defendants were attempting to sell the facility that generated the allegedly fraudulent billings, where most of defendants' assets were located outside New York  [***5] State, where the conceded substantial living expenses of defendants presented a real danger of dissipation of assets prior to a final disposition of the action, and where one of the defendants was a predicate felon facing mandatory imprisonment and had substantial contacts with a foreign country; the facts not only supported the claiming authority's request for an attachment, but also buttressed its claims for a receivership and injunctive relief (see, CPLR 6301).

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Proceeds of Crime -- Provisional Remedies -- Hardship to Defendant

5. In a civil action arising out of a criminal prosecution involving Medicaid fraud in which provisional remedies were sought pursuant to the forfeiture provisions of CPLR article 13-A, affidavits submitted by one defendant, which contained a meaningful disclosure of his financial status, were sufficient to trigger the procedure whereby a balancing of the hardship to him resulting from the imposition of the provisional remedies, including possible infringement of his right to paid counsel of his choice, and the need to preserve the availability of property should have been made.

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Proceeds  [***6] of Crime -- Provisional Remedies -- Infringement on Right to Counsel

6. In a civil action arising out of a criminal prosecution involving Medicaid fraud in which provisional remedies were sought pursuant to the forfeiture provisions of CPLR article 13-A, given the refusal of defendants to provide the court with a meaningful disclosure of their financial status, it is not possible to determine either their financial net worth or their actual ability to hire counsel of their choice, and, thus, it cannot be said that the imposition of such remedies (e.g., attachment) infringed on defendants' right to paid counsel of their choice, a right which is qualified and can be outweighed by countervailing governmental interests.

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Proceeds of Crime -- Requiring Defendants to Disclose Financial Information -- Self-Incrimination

7. In a civil action arising out of a criminal prosecution involving Medicaid fraud in which provisional remedies were sought pursuant to the forfeiture provisions of CPLR article 13-A, an order requiring defendants to disclose certain financial information does not impose an unconstitutional sanction by forcing them to face self-incrimination  [***7] in order to obtain a release of their assets, since information concerning the full extent of defendants' assets and financial condition is an integral part of the statutory forfeiture plan, and it is pure speculation to conclude that by complying with the disclosure order, defendants will necessarily incriminate themselves; moreover, the order expressly permits "the invocation of the self-incrimination privilege". The order is not an invalid attempt by the State to compel testimony without granting immunity or to penalize the exercise of the privilege since a party's invocation of the privilege against self-incrimination in a civil case, which is what a forfeiture proceeding is in New York, may be considered by the finder of facts, and there is no automatic forfeiture of defendants' property resulting from their failure to disclose information inasmuch as the provisional remedies imposed result in a "freezing" of defendants' assets via attachment and not a forfeiture; accordingly, the disclosure order directed in conjunction with the provisional remedy phase of the forfeiture action does not violate the Fifth Amendment.

 

546 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wittenberg v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


135 A.D.2d 132; 523 N.Y.S.2d 1003; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 772



February 2, 1988 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment (one paper) of the Supreme Court, New York County, entered on April 7, 1987, unanimously reversed, on the law, without costs and without disbursements, defendants' cross motion for summary judgment granted, and Local Law No. 66 declared constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, city and others, appealed from an order of the Supreme Court of New York County (New York) that granted plaintiff rent-stabilized apartment owners' motion for summary judgment, denied defendants' cross-motion for summary judgment, and declared that New York City, N.Y., Local Laws No. 66 (1986), N.Y. Admin. Code § 26-517.1(c), was unconstitutional and void. The apartment owners' complaint sought declaratory and injunctive relief.


OVERVIEW: Defendants challenged the trial court order that declared N.Y. Admin. Code § 26-517.1(c) (Local Law No. 66) unconstitutional, granted the apartment owners' motion for summary judgment, and denied defendants' cross-motion for summary judgment. The city council enacted Local Law No. 66 to help defray the costs of state's administration of the New York City Rent Stabilization Law and made the $ 10 fee imposed upon the owners retroactive to fiscal year 1984/1985. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's order, granted defendants' cross-motion for summary judgment, and declared that the Local Law No. 66 was constitutional. The court held that the retroactive fee imposition under the Local Law No. 66 was constitutional because it was not in conflict with the enabling statute, N.Y. Unconsol. Law § 8628. The court found that although framed in prospective terms, the 1983 amendments to § 8628 took effect on April 1, 1984, and thus permitted the city to collect fees from that date at a rate of $ 10 per unit per year. Further, since Local Law No. 66 levied the $ 10 fee for only one fiscal year, it did not violate the annual ceiling provided in N.Y. Unconsol. Laws § 8628(c).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court order that granted the apartment owners' motion for summary judgment in their action seeking to enjoin the city form collecting a retroactive fee to defray administration costs associated with the New York City Rent Stabilization Law. The court held that the city law imposing the fee was constitutional and granted defendants' cross-motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Retroactive Annual Fee from Owners of Rent-Stabilized Buildings

1. Local Laws, 1986, No. 66 of the City of New York, which imposed a one-year retroactive fee upon owners of rent-stabilized multiple dwellings in order to recoup an equivalent amount already paid by the city to the State in reimbursement of the costs of administering the Rent Stabilization Law, is not in conflict with the enabling statute (McKinney's Uncons Laws of NY § 8628), which permitted the city to impose  [***2] such fee; although the enabling statute was framed in prospective terms, 1983 amendments to it took effect on April 1, 1984 and permitted the city to collect fees from that date. Further, since the local law levied the fee for only one year, it did not violate the annual ceiling provided in the enabling statute.

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Retroactive Annual Fee from Owners of Rent-Stabilized Buildings

2. Local Laws, 1986, No. 66 of the City of New York, which imposed a one-year fee retroactive to April 1, 1984 upon owners of rent-stabilized multiple dwellings in order to recoup an equivalent amount already paid by the city to the State in reimbursement of the costs of administering the Rent Stabilization Law, does not unconstitutionally discriminate against those property owners who acquired title after October 1, 1984 where the the City of New York stated that it did not intend to impose the fee on those owners who purchased their property after October 1, 1984 but would attempt to locate the prior owners to charge them for fiscal year 1984 -1985; it was entirely reasonable for the city to interpret the statutory term "owners" as meaning owners in title before  [***3] October 1, 1984, an interpretation which obviates any constitutional infirmity.

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Retroactive Annual Fee from Owners of Rent-Stabilized Buildings -- Delay in Enacting Fee Levy

3. Local Laws, 1986, No. 66 of the City of New York, which imposed a one-year fee retroactive to April 1, 1984 upon owners of rent-stabilized multiple dwellings in order to recoup an equivalent amount already paid by the city to the State in reimbursement of the costs of administering the Rent Stabilization Law, is not void because of the two-year delay attending its passage since owners of rent-stabilized multiple dwellings had actual notice of the fee imposition by virtue of the 1983 enabling statute (McKinney's Uncons Laws of NY § 8628), which explicitly provided for the payment of the fee; the delay in enacting the fee levy for the 1984-1985 fiscal year could not have created an expectation that the city would forego the levy and cover the administrative costs out of general revenues. Moreover, due process is not violated since the property owners cannot claim that they would have behaved differently had they known that the city would, at some point, collect  [***4] the fee for the 1984-1985 fiscal year. There is a compelling public interest served by the local law, which, in fact, does not impose a retroactive tax, but merely seeks to recoup a benefit received by the owners, who owed the fee for the 1984-1985 fiscal year but were not required to pay it at that time.

 

547 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Oliver v. County of Broome


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


136 A.D.2d 793; 523 N.Y.S.2d 253; 1988 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3



January 7, 1988 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which dismissed his application to review a determination of respondent comptroller denying his request for a redetermination of his retirement status and the effective date of his retirement.


OVERVIEW: The employee sought review of the comptroller's determination denying his request for a redetermination of his retirement status and the effective date of his retirement. The lower court dismissed the employee's application, and he appealed. The judgment was affirmed. The court held that the prior judgment directing the county to restore the employee to the payroll did not take immediate effect, and the employee was thus not entitled to full pay from the date of early retirement, due to the automatic stay of enforcement provision. The court held that the comptroller's approval of retirement benefits retroactive to the date when the previous retirement had been approved was not arbitrary. The court held that the prior judgment, which ordered the comptroller to process the employee's application as a Tier II member, precluded the employee from subsequently relitigating his tier status.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment dismissing the employee's application to review the comptroller's denial of his request for a redetermination of his retirement status and the effective date of his retirement.

 

548 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hawkins v. Coughlin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


132 A.D.2d 381; 523 N.Y.S.2d 542; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 50336



December 28, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed, without costs or disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner filed a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 seeking an order compelling respondents, Commissioner of Correctional Services and others, to give him credit for certain prison time served. The Supreme Court in Queens County (New York) dismissed the proceeding. Petitioner appealed.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner was convicted for armed robbery. He served part of his sentence and then was released on parole. He appealed that conviction, which was later vacated. While on parole, he was charged and taken into custody on a sodomy charge to which he plead guilty. He sought credit for time served on the robbery conviction to be applied against the sodomy conviction. The trial court denied his petition. On appeal, the court held that in order to be entitled to credit for jail time, petitioner was required to be "in custody" when charged with the subsequent offense against which he sought to apply the jail time for the vacated conviction. The court affirmed the trial court's order dismissing the petition, holding that for purposes of determining jail time credit, being on parole was not considered to be "in custody."


OUTCOME: The trial court's order dismissing petitioner's request for jail time credit was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Prisons and Prisoners -- Jail Time Credit

Penal Law § 70.30 (3), which provides that where a person has been in custody due to a charge that culminated in a dismissal or an acquittal, the amount of time that would have been credited against a sentence for such charge, had one been imposed, shall be credited against any sentence that is based on a charge for which a warrant or commitment was lodged during the pendency of such custody, is applicable only when a defendant is in actual custody; a defendant who is on bail or released on his own recognizance or a parolee is not in custody so as to trigger application of the statute. Accordingly, since petitioner was on parole and not in actual custody at the time he was arrested for sodomy in the first degree, he is [***2] not entitled to any jail time credit for time spent in confinement prior to the date of his arrest on that charge.

 

549 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Winkler v. Spinnato


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


134 A.D.2d 66; 523 N.Y.S.2d 530; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 50868



December 28, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is modified, on the law, by adding a provision declaring that Public Officers Law § 3 (19) and § 30 (5-a) are constitutional as applied to the plaintiffs; as so modified, the judgment is affirmed, with one bill of costs payable to the defendants and the intervenor appearing separately and filing separate briefs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant firefighters sought review of the judgment of the Supreme Court, Queens County (New York), which denied firefighters' motions for summary judgment and a preliminary injunction, denied respondent city fire commissioner and state's motion to dismiss, and granted summary judgment to respondents in firefighters' action challenging a governmental policy of enforcing local residency requirements.


OVERVIEW: The state traditionally enforced a policy requiring employees of local governments, including firefighters, to reside within or near the political unit in which they serve. City fire commissioner and state enforced the residency requirement more strictly against firefighters living outside the state than against those living inside the state, and in particular, notified firefighters that if their spouse and family lived outside the designated areas, even if firefighter maintained a separate residence within the designated area, they would be fired. Firefighters challenged this action, alleging these public officers laws unconstitutional, arguing they violated the due process clause, the equal protection clause, and the privileges and immunities clause. The trial court granted city fire commissioner and state's summary judgment motion, and firefighters appealed. The court held that the public officer laws, including the new residency requirements imposed upon firefighters, were constitutional, and that state could enforce its residency rule against out-of-state firefighters, even while choosing not to similarly enforce its rule against in-state firefighters.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment of the trial court by declaring that the statutes in question were constitutional, and affirmed the judgment of the trial court as modified.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Firefighters -- Residency Requirement -- Equal Protection

1. The State, in enforcing its traditional policy of requiring certain employees of local governments to reside within or near the political unit in which they serve, may draw a distinction between those public employees who have violated local residency requirements by living outside the State, and those public employees who have violated such laws by residing in unsanctioned locations within the State, and although the imposition of more stringent measures [***2] of enforcement upon the former class of public servants may be perceived as a form of discrimination against a group of persons based solely upon State residence, that discrimination is founded upon a valid exercise of the State's authority to require its own employees, or the employees of any of its political subdivisions, to reside within the State. Accordingly, New York City firefighters may be required to reside within the State (see, Public Officers Law § 3 [19]; § 30 [5-a]) since there is no fundamental right to government employment for purposes of the Equal Protection Clause and the State need only show a rational basis for establishing such requirement; given that State residents are more likely to pay property taxes in New York, spend their money in New York, and pay resident income taxes, the State's economic self-interest is a legitimate interest which serves as a rational basis justifying the distinction between State residency and out-of-State residency.

Civil Service -- Firefighters -- Privileges and Immunities -- In-State Residency Requirement for Public Employees

2. A State law (see, Public Officers Law § 3 [19]; § 30 [5-a]) which requires that any [***3] or all of its own officers or employees, or any officers or employees of its political subdivisions (e.g., firefighters), must reside within the State, does not violate the Privileges and Immunities Clause of the United States Constitution since State or local public employment is not a "privilege" which bears upon the vitality of the Nation as a single entity; a State's ability to require that its employees, or the employees of its political subdivisions, reside within the State is a matter which directly implicates its sovereignty and is a valid form of discrimination inasmuch as it is designed to further the State's rightful goal of limiting to its own citizens the prerogative of public employment.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Firefighters -- Residency Requirement

3. In litigation challenging a residency requirement for firefighters, who sought a declaration that a firefighter may be a lawful inhabitant and domiciliary of a permitted county irrespective of the domicile or residency of his family and irrespective of the fact that he may have more than one residence, in order to warrant the granting of such declaratory relief, it must appear that the municipal [***4] authorities have taken the position that a firefighter may not be in compliance with the requirement unless he resides with his family or unless he maintains only one residence, and since the authorities have not taken such a position no actual controversy exists and the court is, hence, precluded from issuing a declaratory judgment.

 

550 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Jackson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


135 A.D.2d 831; 522 N.Y.S.2d 675; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 52764



December 28, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendant appealed from a judgment of the County Court, Dutchess County (New York) convicting him of two counts of sodomy in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: Criminal defendant contended that the trial court abused its discretion when it compelled his presence at trial after he waived his right to be present. The court held that although defendant was entitled to waive his presence, the People had a right to require defendant's presence for the purpose of identification by its witnesses. Thus, the refusal of the trial court to grant the defendant's motion to remain outside the courtroom did not constitute an abuse of discretion or a denial of his statutory or constitutional rights. Defendant's contention that the court improperly denied his request to submit to the jury the charge of consensual sodomy as a lesser included offense of sodomy in the first degree was without merit. The consensual sodomy statute had been declared unconstitutional prior to trial; thus, consensual sodomy was no longer a crime at the time of trial. As no abuse of discretion occurred, the judgment and sentence were affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

551 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lewis v. Chesworth


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


135 A.D.2d 995; 522 N.Y.S.2d 717; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 52883



December 23, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner state trooper sought review of the decision by respondent superintendent of state police that dismissed the state trooper from his employment.


OVERVIEW: The state trooper was served with several charges of misconduct during his employment. Following a hearing, the state trooper was found guilty of 19 charges and dismissal from employment was recommended. The superintendent adopted these findings and the recommended penalty, and issued an order of dismissal. The state trooper argued that the evidence did not support his dismissal. The court disagreed and confirmed the superintendent's determination and dismissed the state trooper's petition for review. The testimony of many witnesses, together with the state trooper's own admissions provided substantial evidence to support each of the charges upon which he was found guilty. The court found that the state trooper neither sought to compel the testimony of the unavailable witness by court order nor raised constitutional objections at that time. Furthermore, the regulations upon which the charges were based were not unconstitutionally vague and overbroad. The superintendent was vested with broad discretion to establish rules and regulations to govern discipline and control the state police force.


OUTCOME: The superintendent's determination that the state trooper be dismissed from his employment was confirmed and the state trooper's petition for review was dismissed.

 

552 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Jefferds v. Ellis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


132 A.D.2d 321; 522 N.Y.S.2d 398; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 51565; 5 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. 2d (Callaghan) 826



December 18, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Order unanimously reversed, on the law, with costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, Cattaraugus County, for further proceedings, in accordance with opinion by Lawton, J.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff buyer brought an action against defendant seller seeking the return of a repossessed vehicle. The Supreme Court of Cattaraugus County (New York) held that the repossession rights afforded to a secured party upon default under N.Y. U.C.C. §§ 9-503, 9-504 were in violation of the buyer's constitutional right to due process. The seller appealed.


OVERVIEW: The buyer and seller entered into an agreement for the lease and purchase of a truck. Six months later, the seller repossessed the vehicle without the knowledge or permission of the buyer. This repossession was done without breach of the peace and without judicial process. The buyer acknowledged that he owed taxes on the truck but contended that the seller had no right to repossess the vehicle based on that nonpayment. The buyer claimed that N.Y. U.C.C. § 9-503, which authorized a secured party to retake possession of collateral without prior notice and hearing, was unconstitutional. The seller asserted that he had the right to repossess this vehicle because of the buyer's breach of the lease agreement. On appeal, the court held that § 9-503 was constitutional because peaceable self-help remedies by secured creditors did not involve "state action" but rather constituted private action not governed by the Fourteenth Amendment. In order for the trial court to have ordered the truck's return to the buyer, it had to first determine that it was probable that the buyer would have succeeded on the merits.


OUTCOME: The court unanimously reversed the judgment for the buyer in his action for the return of a repossessed vehicle and remitted the matter to the trial court for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Secured Transactions -- Repossession and Sale of Collateral -- Right of Secured Party to Act without Judicial Process

Uniform Commercial Code §§ 9-503 and 9-504, which grant a secured party the right to retake possession of collateral without breaching the peace and without prior judicial notice, are constitutional whether or not the conditional sale agreement between the parties contains an express provision authorizing repossession on default of the agreement; peaceable self-help remedies by secured creditors do not involve "State action" but, rather, constitute private [***2] action not governed by the Fourteenth Amendment. The lease and purchase agreement governing the instant transaction was equivalent to a conditional sales contract and repossession under such a contract was authorized at common law; moreover, acknowledging the right of a secured party to peaceably repossess collateral preserves one of the objectives of the Uniform Commercial Code, viz., to streamline transactions and de-emphasize form.

 

553 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bagarozy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


132 A.D.2d 225; 522 N.Y.S.2d 848; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 51551



December 15, 1987 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended April 11, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Judgment, Supreme Court, Bronx County, rendered on July 15, 1986, unanimously reversed, on the law, and the matter remanded for a new trial. Motion by defendant-appellant for leave to file a pro se supplemental brief granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court, Bronx County (New York) entered upon a jury verdict convicting him of two counts of sodomy in the second-degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 130.45, claiming that the court erroneously denied his motion for a mistrial based on prosecutorial misconduct.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's conviction of two counts of sodomy in the second-degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 130.45 was reversed on appeal where the court found that prejudicial information relating to defendant's homosexual life-style, associations, and prior crimes was admitted into evidence on the mistaken ground that it proved defendant's intent to commit the acts. The court found that the evidence was actually used for the improper purpose of demonstrating defendant's propensity to commit the crimes charged, noting that intent was not an issue in the case because defendant denied any physical contact with the alleged victims and never offered an innocent explanation of those acts. The court also pointed out that the prosecutor was allowed to cross-examine a defense witness about a wide range of prejudicial matters that were only remotely and tangentially related to direct testimony. Finally, the prosecutor's closing argument was held to be an incitement to convict, invoking extralegal norms that transcended the evidence and the law. The court balanced the gravity and pervasiveness of the errors against the weight of admissible evidence and found that defendant was denied a fair trial.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed and the case remanded for a new trial where prejudicial information concerning defendant's life-style and associations, including evidence of other crimes, was admitted into evidence to demonstrate a propensity to commit the crimes charged, and the prosecution's closing argument incited to convict on grounds that transcended evidence and law.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Proof of Other Crimes -- Sodomy

1. In a sodomy prosecution in which the 37-year-old defendant was convicted of engaging in oral sex with two boys under the age of 14, it was reversible error to have permitted the introduction of evidence that defendant was affiliated with the newsletter of the North American Man-Boy Love Association, an organization that advocates sexual activity between adults and boys, as proof of defendant's "intent" to commit sodomy, and that defendant had been previously known to the police as a pedophile, since the true purpose behind the introduction of that evidence was to expose defendant's sexual preferences in order to demonstrate a propensity to commit the crimes charged, which was [***2] a clear violation of well-settled legal principles. In the trial of sex offenses, extrinsic evidence of intent is admissible only where there is no challenge to the occurrence of the physical contact and intent of the actor is at issue because the nature of the contact is subject to varying interpretations. In the instant case, the acts charged are not equivocal and defendant has consistently denied any sexual contact; thus, defendant's intent was never at issue. Moreover, by eliciting that defendant was a "known pedophile" to police, the prosecutor indirectly flouted the court's repeated ruling excluding defendant's police record for similar conduct.

Crimes -- Sodomy -- Disclosure of Defendant's Legal Challenge to Penal Statute

2. In a sodomy prosecution in which the 37-year-old defendant was accused of engaging in oral sex with two boys under the age of 14, neither law nor logic permitted the disclosure of defendant's Federal court legal challenge to the law under which he was being prosecuted where a prosecution witness, who recanted his allegation in court, asserted on cross-examination that the police had harassed him into originally accusing defendant, and that [***3] that harassment was the predicate for a Federal damage suit, and where the constitutional challenge was a separate cause of action to which the witness was not a party, since merely by introducing a new issue, a party does not run the risk that any evidence relating to it, no matter how remote or tangential, will be brought out. The prosecutor used the witness' resort to the courts as a pretext to reveal defendant's effort to legalize sexual conduct with youths; that testimony had no impeachment value as to the witness and its only purpose was to demonstrate defendant's sexual tendencies. Moreover, it was improper to have asked the witness if his coplaintiffs in the Federal action were "other boys who refused to testify in the Grand Jury", and to have revealed the existence of salacious pictures taken from defendant's apartment; nor did the jury, after the prosecutor broadcasted the title in its presence, need to view a pornographic videotape to know what was portrayed in it.

Crimes -- Argument and Conduct of Counsel -- Invocation of Divine Authority in Prosecutor's Summation

3. In a sodomy prosecution in which the 37-year-old defendant was accused of engaging in oral [***4] sex with two boys under the age of 14, the prosecutor's invocation of Divine Authority, coupled with an appeal to "the citizens of this county" to thwart the corruption of their youth by the North American Man-Boy Love Association, an organization advocating sex between adults and boys with which defendant was affiliated, took the summation beyond the pale of routine oratorical excess and was an incitement to convict on grounds that transcend the evidence and the law.

Crimes -- Corroboration as to Sex Offenses -- Date of Occurrence

4. In a sodomy prosecution in which the 37-year-old defendant was accused of engaging in oral sex with two boys under the age of 14, the date of one incident should have been presented to the jury as a question of fact where the complainant demonstrated an inability to fix that date with any precision (e.g., placing Thanksgiving in February), since that incident related to a time when corroboration was no longer required to establish the legal sufficiency of complainant's testimony.

 

554 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Epstein v. New York State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


132 A.D.2d 52; 521 N.Y.S.2d 880; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49541



December 3, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Determination modified, without costs, by annulling so much thereof as assessed sales and use tax on petitioners' admission charges collected prior to March 1, 1981, and, as so modified, confirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayers appealed a decision by respondent New York State Tax Commission (commission), which sustained the New York Department of Taxation and Finance's (department) determination, which issued notices of determination and demand for payment of sales and use tax on admission charges and food and beverages sold for periods running from mid-1977 through late-1981.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers' business presented live entertainment. The taxpayers did not collect sales and use tax on the sales of admission tickets, nor did they keep adequate records on food and beverage sales. The department determined that the admission charges were taxable under N.Y. Tax Law § 1105(f)(3) and demanded payment of sales and use tax for periods running from mid-1977 through late-1981. The commission sustained the department's determination. The court modified the determination of the department by annulling it to the extent that it assessed sales and use tax on the taxpayers' admission charges collected prior to March 1, 1981. The court confirmed the determination to the extent that it assessed sales and use tax on the taxpayers' admission charges collected on and after March 1, 1981 and to the extent that it assessed food and beverages sold. The court found that there was doubt as to whether the taxpayers' activities made it a cabaret, and thus subject to tax under § 1105(f)(3). The court held that that uncertainty precluded the department from assessing the tax on the taxpayers' admission charges prior to March 1, 1981, the date § 1105(f)(3) was made retroactive to.


OUTCOME: The court modified the determination of the department by annulling it to the extent that it assessed sales and use tax on the taxpayers' admission charges collected prior to March 1, 1981, and, as so modified, confirmed the determination to the extent that it assessed sales and use tax on the taxpayers' admission charges collected on and after March 1, 1981 and to the extent that it assessed food and beverages sold.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes -- Cabaret Tax

1. In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Tax Commission which imposed sales and use taxes on the admission charges to petitioners' business establishment, which presented live music, comedians, dancers and plays in a converted bowling alley where patrons could also purchase food and drink, since there is a legitimate doubt as to whether petitioners' activities come within Tax Law § 1105 (f) (3), the "cabaret tax", the statute must be construed in petitioners' favor; thus, the lack of certainty as to the applicability of the "cabaret tax" precludes the Commission from assessing the [***2] tax on petitioners' admission charges prior to the adoption of an amendment clarifying the statute to clearly require such tax. The need for the clarifying amendment, which was supported by the Commission, is a clear admission of ambiguity in the scope of the "cabaret tax".

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes -- Retroactive Application

2. In a proceeding to review the determination of the State Tax Commission imposing the "cabaret tax" (Tax Law § 1105 [f] [3]) on petitioners' establishment, petitioners failed to show that the Legislature acted arbitrarily in amending Tax Law § 1101 (d) (12), which defines "cabaret", to provide for a retroactive application of the tax; the amendment reflected a sound and lawful legislative purpose, i.e., to clarify the scope of and expand the tax, and it was made retroactive presumably because the Legislature assumed that enterprises like petitioners' were already within the scope of the law prior to its amendment. A retroactive tax does not violate due process unless its operation is harsh and oppressive, and given petitioners' failure to show arbitrariness on the part of the Legislature, the Commission is entitled to assess the tax [***3] for the period covered by the amendment.

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes -- Mark-Up Tests

3. In a proceeding to review the imposition of sales and use taxes on petitioners' sales of food and beverage, use of mark-up percentages by the State Tax Commission as an audit method was not unreasonable in light of the lack of adequate records kept by petitioners (see, Tax Law § 1138 [a] [1]); the Commission is entitled to employ an audit method reasonably calculated to estimate the tax liability, and petitioners failed to demonstrate by convincing evidence that the method used and assessments reached were erroneous.

 

555 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Collins


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


134 A.D.2d 607; 521 N.Y.S.2d 529; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 50815



November 30, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment of the County Court of Suffolk County (New York), which convicted her of two counts of kidnapping in the first degree and imposed sentence accordingly.


OVERVIEW: A jury convicted defendant of kidnapping. On appeal, she argued that her guilt was not proven beyond a reasonable doubt, that the trial court erred by denying her motion to suppress certain statements made by her to an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) when personnel of that agency rescued the complainant, and that the mandatory minimum sentence required by N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 was unconstitutional as applied to her. Upon review, the court affirmed, holding that: (1) defendant's guilt was proven beyond a reasonable doubt; (2) defendant's motion to suppress was properly denied because the FBI had reasonable grounds to believe that there was an immediate need for their assistance to protect the complainant's well-being; and (3) the minimum sentence statute was not unconstitutional as applied to defendant. Defendant's remaining contentions were either unpreserved for appellate review or were without merit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's kidnapping conviction and her sentence.

 

556 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Property Clerk, New York City Police Dep't v. Seroda


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


131 A.D.2d 289; 521 N.Y.S.2d 233; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 48921



November 19, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on March 23, 1987, unanimously reversed, on the law, the petition reinstated and the matter remanded for a disposition on the merits, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, property clerk for the New York City Police Department, sought review of a judgment by the Supreme Court in New York County (New York), which dismissed the property clerk's petition. The petition requested a declaration that certain property in the clerk's possession be deemed forfeited, pursuant to § 14-140 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York. The property was an auto leased by the respondent owners.


OVERVIEW: The owners' auto was seized by the police during a drug bust and turned over to the property clerk. The property clerk filed suit to proceed with forfeiture, which was opposed by the owners arguing, in part, that the proceeding was untimely because it had not been commenced within 10 calendar days of receipt of the owners' written demand for the auto's return. The trial court granted judgment in favor of the owners, which was appealed by the property clerk. The court reversed and held that: (1) the McClendon order provided that a property clerk must, within 10 days of a timely demand for the return of property or money, and within 90 days after the issuance of a district attorney's release or the termination of criminal proceedings, either return the property or money or commence a forfeiture proceeding; (2) the property clerk had the burden of proving by a preponderance of the evidence that he was entitled to detain the property or money; (3) the 10 days referred to working days, not calendar days, and began to run from the date of receipt of a demand; and (4) analogies to N.Y. Gen. Constr. Law § 20 and N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 3388(4) were inapplicable.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's dismissal of the property clerk's petition. The court reinstated the petition and remanded the matter for a disposition on the merits, without costs or disbursements.


HEADNOTES

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime -- Limitations Period

In light of a controlling 1974 Federal court order concerning forfeiture proceedings involving property held by the Property Clerk of the New York City Police Department, the applicable time period for instituting a forfeiture proceeding pursuant to Administrative Code of the City of New York § 14-140, which deals with property representing the proceeds of criminal activity or serving as the instrumentality of criminal conduct, is 10 "working" days after a demand for the return of the property has been made, and "working" days must be construed as excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays; General Construction [***2] Law § 20, which generally provides that all calendar days are to be included in computing time periods, is inapplicable since that statute is a guideline for statutory and contractual interpretation and has no application to a judicial order which specifically provides otherwise. Moreover, the 10-day period begins on the date the demand is received, not the date of its mailing, since the goal of according the police property clerk the broadest 10-day period possible would be frustrated by a date of mailing rule, given the uncertainty of mail delivery.

 

557 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Prusky v. Webb


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


134 A.D.2d 718; 520 N.Y.S.2d 975; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 50909



November 12, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, a family care provider, sought review of a determination of respondent, the Commissioner of the Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities of the State of New York, which revoked petitioner's family care home operating certificate.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner's operating certificate was revoked, a hearing officer sustained a charge of physical abuse against him, and a six-month suspension of his operating certificate was recommended. The Commissioner concurred with the finding of physical abuse and mandated the revocation of petitioner's certificate. Petitioner sought review pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78. In annulling the Commissioner's order to the extent it revoked petitioner's certificate, the court found that petitioner's actions of pushing and shoving his client violated N.Y. Mental. Hyg. Law § 16.19 and provided substantial evidence to support the Commissioner's determination that physical abuse occurred. The court found petitioner's argument that the regulations regarding abuse were vague without merit. The court determined that there was no difficulty in concluding that petitioner understood what conduct was prohibited and the evidence was clear he received specific training in the area. The court stated that petitioner failed to show the § 16.19 was void for vagueness. The court found the penalty imposed was unduly excessive given the circumstances surrounding the incident and remitted the matter for reconsideration.


OUTCOME: The court annulled the Commissioner's order to the extent it revoked petitioner's operating certificate. The court remitted the matter to the Commissioner for further proceedings.

 

558 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Menefee v. Floyd & Beasley Transp. Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


134 A.D.2d 331; 520 N.Y.S.2d 807; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 50512



November 9, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a transportation company and others, sought review of an order of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which granted a motion to set aside a jury verdict filed by respondents, an estate administratrix and decedents of the estate, and directed a new trial against the transportation company.


OVERVIEW: After a hearing, the trial court entered a verdict that found the transportation company negligent in a damages action filed by respondents, but determined that its negligence was not the proximate cause of the accident. Respondents filed a motion to set aside the verdict, which the trial court granted. In reversing the trial court's order on appeal, reinstating the verdict, and dismissing respondent's action against the transportation company, the court found that the trial court erred in reinstating the claims against the transportation company because they were previously dismissed and the dismissal had been affirmed by the court. The court found that respondents never obtained valid personal jurisdiction over the transportation company and found that the transportation company had properly preserved the issue of lack of personal jurisdiction in its previous preanswer motion. The court determined that the transportation company was not required to make a specific reference to any service defect in their motion. The court concluded that it was sufficient that the transportation company asserted no personal jurisdiction because they were not personally served.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's order and reinstated the verdict. The court dismissed the complaint against the transportation company.

 

559 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Fudger v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


131 A.D.2d 136; 520 N.Y.S.2d 950; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49507



October 29, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant prisoner sought review of a judgment from the Court of Claims (New York) which granted respondent state's motion to dismiss the prisoner's wrongful conviction claims made pursuant to the Unjust Conviction and Imprisonment Act, N.Y. Ct. Cl. Act § 8(b).


OVERVIEW: The prisoner was acquitted of a charge of arson but the jury was unable to agree as to a lesser included offense. The prisoner was retried on the same indictment and convicted of the lesser included offense. The court reversed the conviction on double jeopardy grounds. The prisoner filed an action to recover damages for wrongful conviction. The trial court granted the state's motion to dismiss the action. The court affirmed the trial court's judgment. First, the prisoner failed to prove that his conviction was reversed on one of the grounds stated in § 8(b). The double jeopardy claim related to the court's jurisdiction. However, it was also a constitutional violation and § 8(b) excluded dismissals that were based on constitutional violations. The court held that because reversals based on double jeopardy grounds did not have anything to do with the prisoner's innocence, a § 8(b) recovery could not be premised on double jeopardy grounds. Second, the prisoner failed to show the likelihood of success at trial in proving his innocence. Finally, the prisoner could not prove that he suffered damages from the arson conviction because he was incarcerated on an unrelated conviction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the claims court's judgment which granted the state's motion to dismiss the prisoner's wrongful conviction claims.


HEADNOTES

State -- Claim against State -- Documentation

1. In an action against the State, defendant's objection that claimant failed to properly document his claim was not asserted in its motion to dismiss and, thus, the challenge was waived.

State -- Unjust Conviction and Imprisonment Act

2. In a claim against the State based on claimant's alleged unjust imprisonment, claimant's apparent reliance on Court of Claims Act § 8-b (3) (b) (ii) (D) is misplaced since that statute requires that the law under which a claimant was prosecuted be unconstitutional, yet nowhere is it asserted that the arson statutes under which claimant was indicted and convicted (Penal Law §§ 150.05, 150.10) are unconstitutional.

State -- Unjust Conviction and Imprisonment Act -- Double Jeopardy

3. In a claim against the State based on claimant's alleged unjust imprisonment, claimant failed to establish a basis for his claim within the limited scope of Court of Claims Act § 8-b (3) (b) (ii), where the criminal action against [***2] him was dismissed on double jeopardy grounds, since although section 8-b provides relief to those deprived of their constitutional rights, the reversal of a conviction based on double jeopardy grounds has nothing to do with the innocence of an accused; inasmuch as the very essence of a claim under section 8-b is the innocence of claimant, it would prove inconsistent to allow recovery where a reversal was predicated on double jeopardy grounds.

State -- Unjust Conviction and Imprisonment Act -- Proof of Innocence

4. In a claim against the State based on claimant's alleged unjust imprisonment, claimant failed to factually demonstrate a likelihood of success at trial in proving his innocence, an essential component of his cause of action, since Court of Claims Act § 8-b, pursuant to which claimant's cause of action is maintained, mandates a showing of innocence and the presumption of innocence does not apply since the Legislature, in civil proceedings under section 8-b, specifically imposed the burden on claimant to prove his innocence by clear and convincing evidence, and claimant has merely presented a rehash of the trial evidence which led to his conviction.

State  [***3] -- Unjust Conviction and Imprisonment Act -- Injury

5. A necessary element of a claim against the State for unjust imprisonment is the establishment of injury as a result of imprisonment; mere damage to reputation does not suffice. Therefore, inasmuch as claimant remained imprisoned on other criminal charges after the arson charges against him were dismissed on double jeopardy grounds, he is not entitled to redress under Court of Claims Act § 8-b, which, because it creates a new cause of action, must be strictly construed.

 

560 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rathe v. Adirondack Concepts, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


131 A.D.2d 81; 520 N.Y.S.2d 82; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 48598



October 15, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant purchasers sought review of a decision of Supreme Court, Franklin County (New York), which found in favor of plaintiff sellers in plaintiffs' breach of contract action seeking damages and specific performance.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff sellers had bought a dairy farm from a third party but decided to sell the property when they were unable to afford the monthly payments. Defendant purchasers agreed to purchase the property under a combination lease and purchase agreement. The parties were then informed of a prior contract vendee's claim to the property, which resulted in defendants being unable to obtain the requisite financing for its proposed operation of the farm. Consequently, defendants stopped all payments of rents and taxes on the farm, contending that a cloud on the title excused its performance. In plaintiffs' action for damages and specific performance for breach of contract, the trial court found in plaintiffs' favor. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that defendants could not rely on plaintiffs' failure to record the contract and pay a recording fee to claim its unenforceability where defendants had introduced the contract into evidence, and defendants were not justified in repudiating the contract or claiming anticipatory breach of contract.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court for plaintiff sellers for damages and specific performance because defendant purchasers clearly breached their lease and purchase agreement with plaintiffs by their failure to pay a monthly contract amount. Defendants had no legitimate legal defense to excuse or avoid their required performance.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Mortgage Recording Tax -- Land Contract

1. In an action for money damages and specific performance of a contract to purchase land, the contract is an instrument constituting a mortgage within the meaning of Tax Law § 250 since it is an executory contract for the sale of real property under which the vendee has or is entitled to possession; therefore, the contract could have been recorded as a mortgage upon payment of the requisite recording tax had the vendee sought the protection of the recording act. However, the contract was not recorded and the failure to record was not raised until after the close of evidence and both sides had rested; thus, defendant's argument that plaintiffs' failure to comply with the provisions of Tax Law § 258, which provides that no mortgage shall be received in evidence unless the recording tax has been paid, renders the contract unenforceable is without merit since the tax imposed by the statute is a recording tax and not a tax [***2] on the mortgage, and payment of the tax is referable not to the mere existence of the mortgage but to a mortgage which has been recorded. Furthermore, upon repudiation and breach of the contract by defendants, there was no "executory" contract of sale in existence and, consequently, the instrument introduced into evidence is without the proscription set forth in the statute.

Contracts -- Breach or Performance of Contract -- Anticipatory Breach

2. In an action for money damages and specific performance of a contract to purchase land, the vendee's anticipatory breach of contract was without legal justification, where the vendee suspended its performance contending that the actions of prior contract vendees, now in bankruptcy, clouded the title, since the prior contract vendees' action against plaintiffs had been dismissed by Law Day and the dismissal of their contempt proceeding against plaintiffs' grantor had also been affirmed by that date; the contempt proceeding, in any event, would not affect plaintiffs' title since a prior judgment in Bankruptcy Court, holding that the prior contract vendees had no equitable interest in the property on the day they filed their bankruptcy [***3] petition, was res judicata as to the marketability of title until reversed on appeal. Moreover, even if the prior contract vendees had a further appeal pending on Law Day, a right to appeal is not sufficient to relieve a purchaser of the obligation to accept title.

 

561 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Swartz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


130 A.D.2d 288; 520 N.Y.S.2d 224; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 47459



October 8, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged an order from the Supreme Court in Tompkins County (New York) that convicted him of manslaughter in the first degree upon entry of a guilty plea.


OVERVIEW: After defendant's young stepdaughter was severely beaten, he was indicted for second degree murder under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(2). The trial court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment on the ground that the statute was unconstitutionally vague, and defendant entered a guilty plea to first degree manslaughter. On appeal, the court affirmed, holding first that defendant's guilty plea to manslaughter did not constitute a waiver of his challenge to the "depraved indifference" murder section of the New York Penal Law because his objection went to the jurisdiction of the trial court to hold criminal proceedings against him and was therefore nonwaivable. However, the court concluded that the definition of depraved mind murder in § 125.25(2) was a more than sufficiently definite standard in providing an objective assessment of the degree of risk presented by defendant's reckless conduct. Thus, the statute provided both fair notice and meaningful guidelines for law enforcement officials.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order that convicted defendant of first degree manslaughter and concluded that New York's depraved mind murder statute was not so vague and indefinite as to violate due process.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Plea of Guilty -- "Depraved Indifference" Murder

1. Defendant's guilty plea to manslaughter did not constitute a waiver of his constitutional challenge to the validity of the "depraved indifference" murder provision of Penal Law § 125.25 (2) where defendant preserved his objection by duly and timely raising the issue before the trial court. Defendant's challenge to the validity of the original accusation in the indictment was a jurisdictional one and a guilty plea to the crime for which he was indicted would not have precluded his attack on the constitutionality of section 125.25 (2). Since the objection goes to the jurisdiction of the court and was, thus, nonwaivable, defendant may maintain his challenge on his plea to the reduced charge.

Crimes -- Murder -- "Depraved Indifference" Murder -- Constitutionality

2. In a criminal prosecution involving the fatal beating of defendant's two-year-old stepdaughter, defendant's contention [***2] that the phrase "[under] circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human life", which elevates a reckless homicide from manslaughter to murder, is so vague and indefinite as to violate constitutional due process protections, is without merit since depraved mind murder has been a part of State law for over 150 years and its meaning is well settled. The more important aspect of the "void for vagueness" doctrine is not the provision of actual notice of prohibited conduct but the mandatory inclusion of minimal guidelines for law enforcement agencies; the doctrine recognizes that some forms of conduct which a State may validly make subject to penal sanctions cannot, and need not, be defined with precision. There is no doubt that the conduct defendant was accused of committing falls well within the statute's known boundaries; therefore, defendant lacks standing to challenge the vagueness of the statute as it might be hypothetically applied to the conduct of others.

 

562 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Schanback v. Schanback


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


130 A.D.2d 332; 519 N.Y.S.2d 819; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 53398



October 5, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is reversed insofar as appealed from, on the law, without costs or disbursements, and the matter is remitted to the Supreme Court, Nassau County, for a de novo determination of the economic issues involved in the parties' equitable distribution action.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant husband sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court-Nassau County (New York), which directed a certain equitable distribution of the marital property and distributive award in favor of appellee wife as a result of divorce proceedings. Both the husband and the wife objected to the trial court's referral of the divorce's economic issues to a judicial hearing officer as an "examination of a long account" under N.Y.C.P.L.R. 4317(b).


OVERVIEW: The trial court ruled that the economic issues involved in the divorce constituted an "examination on a long account," which allowed compulsory reference of the matter to a judicial hearing officer over the parties' objections, pursuant to Rule 4317. An equitable distribution and distributive award was made, which was appealed by the husband. The court reversed the trial court's referral decision and held that: (1) a judicial hearing officer had the authority and power to hear equitable distribution matters but not without the parties' consent unless the referral was limited to making non-binding findings of fact; (2) fundamental differences existed between an "examination of a long account," which was an accounting for goods sold, work performed, or money advances that was traditionally limited to matters concerning basic mathematical calculations, and an equitable distribution, which required an exercise of judgment and discretion regarding many issues; (3) there was no statutory authority for such a compulsory referral; and (4) the judicial hearing officer's decision satisfied the statutory requirement of a referee's report and was deemed as a referral to hear and report.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's compulsory referral of the divorce's economic issues to a judicial hearing officer and remitted the matter for a de novo determination of the economic issues.


HEADNOTES

References -- Matters Subject to Reference -- Compulsory Reference in Equitable Distribution

1. An equitable distribution matter may not be referred to a Judicial Hearing Officer to hear and determine the economic issues to be resolved between the parties in the absence of their consent since such matter does not constitute an "examination of a long account" within the meaning of CPLR 4317 (b), which provides for the submission of matters to Referees in the absence of the consent of the parties; although the instant matter involves long and complicated financial questions, courts have demonstrated [***2] reluctance in ruling that a matter constitutes a "long account" subject to compulsory reference merely on the basis that lengthy financial calculations are involved. Fundamental differences exist between the type of issues to be resolved in an equitable distribution matter and those traditionally involved in "[examinations] of a long account", since unlike a mercantile account, the distributive award to which a spouse is entitled cannot be determined by reference to a contractual or mathematical formula, but requires the exercise of the court's discretion; moreover, the issue of spousal maintenance involves a number of intangible factors and is qualitatively different from questions concerning a "long account". The fact that the parties herein are not entitled to a jury trial does not warrant a different result since they do have a right to have a Supreme Court Justice resolve their dispute; in addition, no specific statutory authority exists to permit compulsory reference of equitable distribution matters.

References -- Matters Subject to Reference -- Equitable Distribution

2. Although it was improper for the court to have ordered the parties to an equitable distribution [***3] action to have their financial matters heard and determined by a Judicial Hearing Officer in the absence of their consent to such procedure, a new trial into the matters examined by the Hearing Officer is not required since "exceptional" conditions exist which would have justified the reference to a Hearing Officer to hear and report, as opposed to hear and determine, with or without the parties' consent. Thus, in the absence of authorization to determine, the reference will be deemed as one to hear and report; inasmuch as the Hearing Officer's detailed decision clearly satisfied the statutory requirement that a Referee's report set forth findings of fact and conclusions of law (see, CPLR 4320), upon remittitur, Supreme Court shall make a determination of the issues involved, following submission to it of the Hearing Officer's report and such motions by the parties to confirm or disaffirm as they deem appropriate.

 

563 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Diamond v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, APPELLATE DIVISION, SECOND DEPARTMENT


130 A.D.2d 292; 519 N.Y.S.2d 691; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 47712; 45 Fair Empl. Prac. Cas. (BNA) 1554



October 1, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order and judgment is reversed insofar as appealed from by the appellants Cuomo, Regan, the New York State Employees' Retirement System and the Policemen's and Firemen's Retirement System, on the law, without costs or disbursements, and the cross motion of those appellants to dismiss the complaint is granted to the extent that [***2] it is declared that NY Constitution, article VI, § 25 (b) and Judiciary Law § 23, do not violate the plaintiffs' rights under the US Constitution to due process of law and equal protection of the laws; and it is further

Ordered that the appeal by the Westchester County Board of Elections is dismissed as academic, without costs or disbursements, in light of our determination on the appeal by the appellants Cuomo, Regan, the New York State Employees' Retirement System and the Policemen's and Firemen's Retirement System.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff elected state court judges filed a complaint in the Supreme Court, Kings County (New York), that sought, inter alia, a declaratory judgment that N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 25(b) and N.Y. Jud. Law § 23 violated plaintiffs' due process and equal protection rights under the U.S. Constitution, and an injunction barring defendants, certain New York officials and boards, from requiring plaintiffs' mandatory retirement by reason of age.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff elected state court judges commenced an action seeking, inter alia, a declaratory judgment that N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 25(b) and N.Y. Jud. Law § 23 were violative of plaintiffs' due process and equal protection rights under the U.S. Constitution, and a permanent injunction enjoining defendants, certain New York officials and boards, from causing plaintiffs' involuntary retirement by reason of age. Defendants filed cross-motions to dismiss the complaint and for a declaration that the challenged provisions were constitutional. The trial court held that the challenged provisions had no rational basis and were violative of plaintiffs' constitutional rights. The trial court granted plaintiffs' request for declaratory relief and denied defendants' cross-motion. The court reversed. The court concluded that New York's involuntary retirement rules were fully consistent with constitutional principles of equal protection. The court held that New York need not set aside its mandatory retirement rule solely because, under the purported command of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, a small percentage of such judges (18 percent) had been exempted from that rule.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the holding of the lower court and found the involuntary retirement statutes did not discriminate on the basis of age. The court decided the classification of state and local officers into elective and nonelective categories was founded upon a reasonable basis as the distinction was not between appointed and elected judges; it was a distinction between elected state officers generally, as opposed to nonelected state officers.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- Mandatory Retirement -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Federal Legislation

1. The amendment of the Federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (29 USC § 621 et seq.) to extend its protections to "employees" over 70 years old, as opposed to elected officials, did not effect a change of circumstances which would affect the continued vitality of Maresca v Cuomo (64 NY2d 242), which upheld the State's traditional policy of requiring certain Judges to retire at the age of 70 as being fully consistent with constitutional principles of equal protection, since the State constitutional and statutory provisions which plaintiffs seek to invalidate [***3] (NY Const, art VI, § 25 [b]; Judiciary Law § 23) contain no distinction between appointed Judges over the age of 70 and elected Judges over the age of 70; the only relevant statute which does draw any distinction based on the criterion of whether a particular State official holds his office by election or appointment is 29 USC § 630 (f); however, that statute is not challenged by plaintiffs and, thus, is beyond the scope of the court's review.

Judges -- Disqualification -- "Rule of Necessity"

2. Although the members of the Appellate Division may be affected by the outcome of the present appeal involving a challenge to State laws providing for the mandatory retirement of certain members of the judiciary at the age of 70 (NY Const, art VI, § 25 [b]; Judiciary Law § 23), that fact does not call for recusal since the case involves not only the constitutionality of a statute, but also an interpretation of the State Constitution, and thus no direct appeal lies to the Court of Appeals (see, CPLR 5601 [b]). Inasmuch as the Appellate Division has exclusive jurisdiction at this stage of the proceedings to review the questions involved, under the "rule of necessity"  [***4] it is required to hear the instant appeal.

 

564 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. McNeill


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


133 A.D.2d 506; 519 N.Y.S.2d 576; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49966



September 24, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the County Court of Albany County (New York), which convicted defendant upon his plea of guilty of the crime of attempted criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged in an indictment with criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree based on his sale of cocaine to an undercover police officer. Defendant entered a plea of guilty to a reduced charge of attempted criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree. At sentencing, defendant requested leave to withdraw his plea, alleging that he was deprived him of the effective assistance of counsel and his plea was coerced. The court denied defendant's request and defendant appealed. The court found that since defendant had an opportunity to hear the tape in its entirety prior to pleading guilty, no prejudice was demonstrated. The court further found no abuse of discretion in lower court's refusal to vacate the plea. The court found that a review of the plea allocution confirmed that defendant was thoroughly apprised of the consequence of his plea, that he acknowledged that he had been given a full opportunity to discuss the matter with his attorney, that the plea was of his own free will and that he was pleading guilty to avoid a potential persistent felony offender sentence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court which convicted defendant of attempted criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree.

 

565 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Municipal Housing Authority v. New York State Emergency Financial Control Bd.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


133 A.D.2d 340; 519 N.Y.S.2d 240; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49850



September 8, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner Municipal Housing Authority for the City of Yonkers (Authority) filed for judicial review of an order issued by respondent New York State Emergency Financial Control Board for the City of Yonkers (Board), which directed the Authority to produce certain financial information. The Supreme Court of Westchester County (New York) enjoined the Board from asserting jurisdiction over the Authority. The Board appealed.


OVERVIEW: The New York State Financial Emergency Act of 1984 for the City of Yonkers (Act), 1984 N.Y. Laws ch. 103, § 2, was enacted to establish a plan for restoring the city to financial solvency. It empowered the Board to oversee the finances of the city and covered organizations. After the Board determined that the Authority was a covered organization, it ordered it to produce copies of all of its contracts. The lower court found that the Authority was not a covered organization because it did not receive funds from the Board; the federal government funded it. The court modified the lower court's order. The court held that the Authority was a covered organization under the Act notwithstanding that it did not receive funds from the Board. The court found that the construction given to the statutory language by the lower court was contrary to the plain meaning of the words contained therein. The Act stated that the definition of a covered organization in any event included, without limitation, the Board of Education of the City of Yonkers and the Yonkers City Housing Authority. The court noted that the effective July 19, 1985, the Authority ceased to be a covered organization per se.


OUTCOME: The court modified the lower court's order. The modification mandated that all of the Board's orders that were directed at the Authority prior to July 19, 1985 were valid and enforceable, but all orders issued on and after July 19, 1985 were void.

 

566 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dumain v. Carey


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


133 A.D.2d 206; 519 N.Y.S.2d 17; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49715



August 24, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed that part of an order from the Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York), which denied its motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint and granted plaintiff's motion for summary judgment in an action for declaratory and injunctive relief.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs claimed that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3602 was unconstitutional to the extent that it provided for formulas in the calculation of state aid to school districts predicated upon inaccurate date not subject to verification. The supreme court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment to the extent of declaring that defendants' use of the data-gathering mechanism pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 20, § 2000.2 was arbitrary and capricious, as applied, to administer the distribution of state aid funds to plaintiffs under § 3602. Further, the supreme court ordered defendants to make the necessary adjustments of disbursements paid to plaintiffs for the school years 1980-1981 through 1984-1985 by use of the procedures afforded under 1984 N.Y. Laws 889. On appeal, the court reversed. The court did not find that the district income data was grossly inaccurate as alleged by plaintiffs. The selected verification program instituted pursuant to 889 found significant income overstatement in less than 3 percent of the school district and the amount of income so overstated was slightly over 1 percent of the total income reported on all long-form tax returns for the year of 1983.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order insofar as it was appealed from, on the law, with costs. The court denied in its entirety plaintiffs' cross-motion for summary judgment and granted defendants' motion for summary judgment to the extent that it was declared that the statutory law was constitutional insofar as it allocated state aid to education on a formula based on income tax data.

 

567 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


McGee v. Korman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


133 A.D.2d 38; 518 N.Y.S.2d 940; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49576



August 20, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Both appellant candidate and respondent objector sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court, Bronx County (New York), which dismissed a petition seeking a judgment declaring valid a designating petition by which the candidate sought to be a candidate for an office of Judge of the Surrogate's Court, Bronx County, in a primary election, and which dismissed as moot the proceeding brought by the objector to invalidate the said petition.


OVERVIEW: The candidate filed a petition seeking a place on a ballot for the primary election. The petition contained 11,690 signatures and the Board of Elections found over 7,000 of them invalid, leaving approximately 414 short of the 5,000 required. Proceedings were commenced by both the candidate and the objector for validation and invalidation. The candidate thereafter sought a continuance, which was granted, when the candidate conceded that he would be unable to establish the 5,000 signatures, but made a constitutional challenge to N.Y. Elec. Law § 6-136(2)(b), which required 5,000 signatures. The trial court dismissed both petitions and the constitutional challenge was thereafter rejected by the New York Supreme Court. Both parties appealed the dismissal of their petitions and the court reversed. The court found that because the proceeding in the trial court was dismissed prior to a determination of whether the petition filed on behalf of the candidate contained the requisite valid signatures, the matter was remanded to the trial court for such a determination.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the trial court dismissing the candidate's petition seeking a judgment declaring his designating petition valid and dismissing the objector's proceeding brought to invalidate the said petition and reinstated the matters to determine whether the said petition contained the appropriate number of valid signatures.

 

568 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Korman v. Sachs


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


133 A.D.2d 41; 518 N.Y.S.2d 976; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49579



August 20, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a candidate for judge, challenged judgments of the Supreme Court, Bronx County (New York), one of which confirmed a referee's report and denied the candidate's application to invalidate the designating petition of a second candidate. The second judgment granted respondents' application to invalidate the first candidate's designating petition. The second judgment was at issue before the court.
