OVERVIEW: The designating petition that the first candidate filed with the Board of Elections was invalidated by the supreme court because the petition was found to contain less than the minimum number of valid signatures required under N.Y. Elec. Law § 6-136(2)(b) for an office to be filled by all the voters of a county within the City of New York. The court reversed because § 6-136(2)(b) provided for a geographically based disparity of treatment of candidates for the same office in counties of substantially equivalent population, which violated the "one-person-one-vote" equal protection standards. The legislature had determined that in counties outside the City of New York, even though the population of any such county might have been equal to or greater than a county within the city, fewer signatures were required. Respondents had not shown that they could produce any evidence that would justify the requirement for a greater number of signatures within the City of New York, in order to demonstrate community support, than in counties of equivalent population outside the city. Accordingly, under constitutional standards the candidate was entitled to a place on the ballot.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the supreme court's judgment that denied the candidate's application to invalidate a second candidate's designating petition. The court reversed the supreme court's judgment that granted respondents' application to invalidate the first candidate's designating petition. The court ordered that the first candidate be placed on the ballot.

 

569 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


McGowan v. Burstein


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


130 A.D.2d 123; 518 N.Y.S.2d 247; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 45073



July 30, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Order modified, on the law, without costs, by reversing so much thereof as denied plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted their alternative request for a preliminary injunction; summary judgment awarded to plaintiffs and it is declared that defendants' use of the zone scoring technique on competitive civil service examinations is violative of NY Constitution, article V, § 6 and 4 NYCRR 67.1 (b) and (c), and that defendants are prohibited from using said technique unless authorized to do so by prior court order; and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant Civil Service Commission of the State of New York (commission) sought review of an order of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which denied the parties' cross motions for summary judgment and preliminarily enjoined the commission from using zone scoring on civil service examinations in plaintiff civil servants union's (union) declaratory judgment action to determine the constitutionality of zone scoring and to enjoin its use.


OVERVIEW: The commission employed a method of scoring civil service examinations known as zone scoring whereby raw score results from the examinations were grouped into zones and job applicants with raw scores coming within the same zone were assigned the same score. The union commenced an action for declaratory judgment regarding the constitutionality of zone scoring and to enjoin its use, claiming that the method violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6. The trial court ruled that the commission's use of zone scoring appeared to be unconstitutional and preliminarily enjoined the commission from using the method, and denied the parties' cross motions for summary judgment. The commission sought review of the trial court's ruling. On appeal, the court modified the trial court's order by reversing the decision denying the union's motion for summary judgment and awarded summary judgment to the union, and prohibited the commission from using the zone scoring method. The court ruled that the commission's use of the method on civil service examinations violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6 and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 4, §§ 67.1(b), (c). The court affirmed the trial court's order as modified.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's order by reversing it to the extent that it denied the union's motion for summary judgment and granted a preliminary injunction, and awarded summary judgment to the union, declared that the commission's use of zone scoring was unconstitutional, and prohibited the commission from using the method unless authorized by prior court order. The court affirmed the trial court's order as modified.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Examinations -- Zone Scoring

Inasmuch as zone scoring, i.e., a test-grading technique employed by the Civil Service Commission whereby raw score results from civil service examinations are grouped into zones or ranges and job applicants with raw scores coming within the same zone or range are assigned the same score, is presumptively unconstitutional,  [***2] being violative of the State Constitution's mandate that "merit and fitness" be determined by "competitive" examination (NY Const, art V, § 6), in that the competitive advantage inuring to the benefit of higher scoring applicants is effectively neutralized, the Civil Service Commission was properly enjoined from prospectively using that technique in establishing eligibility lists from competitive civil service examinations; moreover, relegating applicants to zones, the breadth of which are determined after the examination, can work mischief since those with demonstrably higher raw scores can be passed over by nominating officials for those with lower scores within the same zone, rendering the one in three rule (Civil Service Law § 61 [1]) ineffective. While zone scoring may be appropriate in certain cases where the need therefor has been shown (e.g., affirmative action), no such showing has been made; nor is authority for zone scoring to be found in regulations providing for the "statistical adjustment" of test scores ( 4 NYCRR 67.1 [b], [c]), since any such adjustment must preserve the "relative order of scores".

 

570 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Swan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


130 A.D.2d 6; 519 N.Y.S.2d 581; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 45059



July 21, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously reversed, on the law, and new trial granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the decision of the Cattaraugus County Court (New York), which convicted him of murder in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant shot and killed an officer who responded to information that there was a domestic disturbance at defendant's home. Defendant executed a written waiver of jury trial. The trial court disapproved defendant's waiver, but failed to state upon the record its reasons for such disapproval. The court reversed defendant's conviction. The court held that under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 2, defendant had a constitutional right to waive trial by jury in all criminal cases, except those in which the crime charged could be punishable by death. Defendant could not have been subjected to the death penalty on conviction of any of the crimes that he was charged with. Under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 320.10, the trial court had to approve the execution and submission of a jury trial waiver unless it determined that it was tendered as a stratagem to procure an otherwise impermissible procedural advantage or that defendant was not fully aware of the consequences of his choice. The trial court's discretion to reject a waiver was carefully circumscribed and had to be explained on the record. The trial court failed to state its reasons.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decision convicting defendant of murder in the first degree.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Right to Jury Trial -- Waiver

1. In a murder prosecution in which defendant interposed an insanity defense and during jury selection executed in the presence of the Trial Judge a written waiver of jury trial, which was thereafter submitted in open court, it was reversible error for the court to have disapproved the waiver without stating on the record its reasons for such disapproval, since defendant had an absolute right to a trial without a jury. CPL 320.10 (2) circumscribes the court's discretion in rejecting waivers of the right to a jury trial, requiring the court to state on the record its reasons for disapproving the waiver; if there was justification for the court's refusal to permit defendant to be tried by a Judge without a jury, it is not apparent in the record, and absent any statement by the court as to the basis for its action, it must be concluded that defendant was denied a [***2] right guaranteed to him under the State Constitution.

Crimes -- Fair Trial -- Court's Failure to Question Jury after Prolonged Delay of Trial -- Mistrial

2. In a homicide prosecution arising out of the shooting of a police officer, the court's failure to question the jury as to the potential for prejudice occasioned by the delay of the trial for approximately 100 days worked to deny defendant a fair trial where the District Attorney joined in the defense motion to voir dire the jury, since it was essential to an intelligent resolution of defendant's mistrial motion that a voir dire be conducted. Although the decision whether to declare a mistrial rests in the sound discretion of the trial court, the question of whether the jury remained capable of rendering a fair and objective verdict according to the evidence is unanswerable on this record because, in the absence of any inquiry by the court, it is impossible to determine that the jurors were not prejudiced.

Crimes -- Murder -- First Degree Murder

3. An indictment charging defendant with first degree murder arising out of the fatal shooting of a police officer need not be dismissed notwithstanding the fact [***3] that the death sentence, i.e., the statutory penalty therefor, has been held unconstitutional, since it is well established that murder in the first degree under Penal Law § 125.27 remains a viable substantive crime.

 

571 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Civil Serv. Emples. Ass'n v. Regan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


129 A.D.2d 378; 517 N.Y.S.2d 812; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 44917



July 16, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, on the law, without costs, and defendants' cross motion for summary judgment granted to the extent of declaring that the classification of plaintiffs Bernard E. Nogas and William C. Waterhouse as Tier III members was not in violation of NY Constitution, article V, § 7.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, Comptroller of the State of New York and others, appealed from an order of the Supreme Court in Albany County (New York), which granted a motion by appellee employees for summary judgment and declared that certain public employees were eligible for benefits under N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 11 in the declaratory judgment action commenced by the employees who had entered the Retirement System between July 1 and December 31, 1976.


OVERVIEW: By the terms of 1976 N.Y. Laws 890, which had been passed on July 27, 1976, a new Tier III retirement program was made applicable to public employees joining the Retirement System on or after July 1, 1976; however, Tier III was not made operative until January 1, 1977. Employees joining the system between July 1 and December 31, 1976, were temporarily eligible for Tier II benefits until Tier III became operative. Appellees joined the Retirement System in late December 1976 and were temporarily placed in Tier II until they were made members of the Tier III plan the following January. The court found that employees commencing public employment and joining the Retirement System between July 1 and December 31, 1976, were not entitled to permanent Tier II coverage because all of the contractual terms providing for temporary coverage under Tier II until January 1977 were on the books on the date appellees joined the Retirement System. The court found that the change in status was not the result of a subsequent legislative enactment and that there had been no attempt to diminish their benefits after the expiration of the statute that was in effect when they entered the Retirement System.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court and granted appellant's motion for summary judgment to the extent of declaring that the classification of appellees as Tier III members was not in violation of the state constitution.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Retirement and Pension Benefits

Persons commencing public employment and joining the New York State Employees Retirement System between July 27, 1976 and December 31, 1976 are not entitled to permanent coverage by the provisions of Retirement and Social Security Law article 11 (Tier II), and are instead to be classified in Tier III, a less advantageous plan. On July 27, 1976, Laws of 1976 (ch 890) as enacted, providing that the new Tier III retirement program was made applicable to public employees joining the Retirement System on or after July 1, 1976 but that Tier III would not be [***2] operative until January 1, 1977. As to those employees who joined the Retirement System on or after July 27, 1976, the terms of Laws of 1976 (ch 890) are applicable, and although the statute provided them with temporary Tier II status, it also provided that temporary status would end on December 31, 1976 and that the provisions of Tier III, which already applied to them, would become operative as to them commencing on January 1, 1977. All of these contractual terms had been enacted into law on the date these individuals joined the Retirement System, and there was no attempt to diminish the benefits of members after the expiration of a statute which was in effect when they entered the Retirement System. Laws of 1976 (ch 890) did not violate the rights of persons entering the Retirement System between July 27, 1976 and December 31, 1976 under NY Constitution, article V, § 7, which established membership in a public retirement system as a contractual relationship and provided that the Legislature could not diminish or impair the terms of the contract once it was entered into.

 

572 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Byrnes v. County of Monroe


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


129 A.D.2d 229; 517 N.Y.S.2d 637; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 44896



July 10, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent county sought review of an order of the Supreme Court in Monroe County (New York), which declared N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 1022.12, invalid and granted summary judgment in favor of petitioner attorney.


OVERVIEW: An attorney assigned to represent an indigent defendant on two misdemeanors sought payment of counsel fees in excess of the statutory maximum because of extraordinary circumstances. The attorney's application was approved by a city court judge pursuant to N.Y. County Law § 722-b, but the county refused to pay the voucher until the attorney received the further approval of the supervising judge, pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 1022.12(b), which the supervising judge denied. The attorney sought summary judgment in lieu of complaint. The trial court granted the attorney summary judgment in lieu of complaint. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that the statute and the rule were in direct and irreconcilable conflict. The court held that the attorney was therefore entitled to the money that he requested under the statute and not under the rule. Because the rule was inconsistent with the general state-wide procedure provided by the New York County Law, the rule had to yield to the statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that granted the attorney summary judgment in lieu of complaint and the county was directed to pay the attorney a sum with interest plus costs and disbursements.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Compensation -- Assigned Counsel for Criminal Defendants

Petitioner attorney is entitled to be paid by the County for assigned counsel fees in excess of the statutory maximum because of extraordinary circumstances, his application having been approved by the Trial Judge pursuant to County Law § 722-b but the County having refused to pay the voucher until petitioner received the approval of the Supervising Judge of Criminal Courts as required by a rule of the Appellate Division, Fourth Department (22 NYCRR 1022.12 [b]). Special Term properly determined that the rule and statute were in direct and irreconcilable conflict, declared the rule invalid, and granted petitioner's motion for summary judgment in lieu of complaint. Since the rule is inconsistent with the general State-wide procedure provided by the County Law, in that it provides for an additional step [***2] of review, the rule must yield to the statute.

 

573 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Love


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department


129 A.D.2d 258; 517 N.Y.S.2d 649; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 44904



July 10, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment unanimously affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State appealed the judgment of the Monroe County Court (New York), which resentenced defendant as a first felony offender after it granted defendant's N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.20 motion and vacated his prior sentence as a second felony offender. The State was before the court pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §450.30(2), which permitted the State to appeal whether a sentence is invalid as a matter of law.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's sentence as a second time felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law §70.06(1)(a) was vacated when the prior felony conviction was set aside as unconstitutional. The State argued that under N.Y Penal Law §70.06(1)(b)(iv), any time spent in prison on any prior offense extended the 10 year time period in which if the second felony conviction occurred the second sentence had to be enhanced. Defendant argued that the prior felony conviction, overturned on constitutional grounds, was a nullity that could not be used to enhance the sentence on the subsequent conviction. The court held that §70.06(1)(b)(iv) had to be read in light of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.21(7)(b), which prohibited the use of an unconstitutionally obtained conviction as a predicate felony conviction for imposition of an enhanced sentence. The court held that reading § 400.21(7)(b) in harmony with N.Y. Penal Law §70.06(1)(b)(v) required that any period during which defendant was incarcerated by virtue of an unconstitutionally obtained conviction could not be used to toll the 10-year period of the second felony offender sentencing statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court unanimously.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second Felony Offender

Under Penal Law § 70.06 (1) (b) (v), the period of time during which a defendant was incarcerated by reason of an unconstitutionally obtained conviction may not be used to extend the statutory 10-year period for determining whether defendant was subject to a predicate felony conviction thus warranting the enhanced punishment authorized for a second felony offender under that statute. Accordingly, defendant, convicted of robbery in the first degree in 1983, was properly resentenced as a first offender since a 1972 conviction for assault in the second degree which was unconstitutionally obtained could not serve as a predicate felony, nor could a 1968 conviction for grand larceny in the third degree; defendant was sentenced on the 1968 conviction more than 10 years prior to the commission of the felony for which he was being sentenced, and the 10-year statutory period was not tolled by the period during which defendant had been incarcerated on the 1972 conviction. Although the [***2] statute does not make any exception for time served by reason of an unconstitutionally obtained conviction, CPL 400.21 (7) (b) prohibits the use of an unconstitutionally obtained conviction in determining whether a defendant has been subjected to a predicate felony conviction, and the two must be read together; a conviction obtained in violation of one's constitutional rights may not be used to enhance punishment for another offense.

 

574 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Green v. WLS Promotions, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


132 A.D.2d 521; 517 N.Y.S.2d 537; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49051



July 6, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant corporations sought review of a decision from the Supreme Court, Orange County (New York) that denied their motion for summary judgment and dismissing their complaint and granting plaintiff victim's motion to strike an affirmative defense. The matter involved a negligence action to recover damages for personal injuries.


OVERVIEW: The victim brought an action to recover damages for personal injuries against two corporations. The matter arose when the victim was injured at a racetrack. The supreme court denied the corporations' motion for summary judgment as well as a motion to dismiss the complaint. Further, the court granted a motion by the victim to strike an affirmative defense by the corporations. Upon review, the court held that the victim had paid a fee for the use of a place of amusement. As such, the facility, an automobile racetrack, was an establishment within the contemplation of the N.Y. Gen. Oblig. Law § 5-326, which voided any release signed by a user of a place of amusement where the owner or operator of the facility received a fee or other compensation for its use and where the release exempted the owner from liability due to negligence. The corporation asserted that the statute did not apply to the facility because it involved an inherently dangerous activity. However, in affirming the decision of the lower court, the court held that the claim was not for injuries caused by conditions inherent in the activity, but for the negligence of the owners.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the supreme court in denying the corporations' motions for summary judgment.

 

575 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Mindel v. Gross


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


132 A.D.2d 535; 517 N.Y.S.2d 541; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 49063



July 6, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant village challenged the order of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which denied its motion to dismiss plaintiff citizen's action to declare a zoning ordinance invalid for improperly excluding hotels and low income people from the community and for violating the Donnelly Antitrust Act, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 340 et seq., and the Sherman Antitrust Act, 15 U.S.C.S. § 1 et seq.


OVERVIEW: The citizen contended, inter alia, that the zoning ordinance was discriminatory because it totally excluded hotels from any of the zoning districts and that it did not promote the health and welfare of the community because it excluded low income people from the community by its exclusion of hotels. The court held that the trial court properly denied the motion to dismiss the citizen's claim that the exclusion of hotels was discriminatory because hotels were permitted uses within the business zoning district prior to the amendment of the zoning ordinance. The trial court erred in denying the village's motion to dismiss the claim relating to the exclusion of low income people because the citizen failed to set forth sufficient facts upon which his claim was based. The antitrust claims should have been dismissed because the citizen failed to allege a competitive injury as required under the Donnelly Antitrust Act and the Sherman Antitrust Act.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order of the trial court by deleting the provisions denying the village's motion to dismiss the citizen's claims relating to the exclusion of low income people and violation of antitrust statutes and by substitution provisions granting the motion on those claims. The court then affirmed the order as modified.

 

576 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Weissman v. Bellacosa


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


129 A.D.2d 189; 517 N.Y.S.2d 734; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 44889



June 29, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the appeal from the order is dismissed, without costs or disbursements; and it is further,

Ordered that the judgment is reversed, on the law, without costs or disbursements; the order is vacated, the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment is granted, and it is declared that Judiciary Law § 221-d is unconstitutional insofar as it provides for a salary disparity between the Judges of the County Court in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and the matter is remitted to the Supreme Court, Westchester County, for further proceedings on the plaintiffs' claims for attorneys' fees and for entry of judgment.

The appeal from the intermediate order must be dismissed because the right of direct appeal therefrom terminated with the entry of judgment in the action (see, Matter of Aho, 39 NY2d 241, 248). The issues raised on appeal from the order are brought up for review and have been considered on [***2] the appeal from the judgment ( CPLR 5501 [a] [1]).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs judges appealed the decision from the Supreme Court, Westchester County (New York), which denied a motion by plaintiff to renew a prior motion for summary judgment, and a judgment dismissing the complaint seeking to have N.Y. Jud. Law § 221-d, which established a discriminatory salary schedule for judges, unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs judges filed a complaint seeking to have N.Y. Jud. Law § 221-d, which established a discriminatory salary schedule for judges, declared unconstitutional because it resulted in disparate financial treatment depriving plaintiffs of their rights to equal protection. Upon losing at summary judgment, the plaintiffs appealed arguing that they were entitled to parity with their counterparts. Salaries were previously determined and financed by the particular locality in which they served, thus reflecting differing fiscal philosophies and limitations. The court found that the disparate financial treatment perpetuated by the legislation challenged at bar deprived the plaintiffs of their rights to equal protection under the N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11, and the U.S. Const. amend XIV, § 1, and, accordingly, reversed the judgment, vacated the salary order, and granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment.


OUTCOME: Court dismissed the appeal of the order, vacated the order, and reversed the judgment denying plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment thereby granting the motion.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- Disparity in Judicial Salaries -- County Court Judges

Judiciary Law § 221-d, which established the operative salary schedule pursuant to which County Court Judges were compensated between the years 1979 and 1984, is an unconstitutional denial of equal protection insofar as it provided for a salary disparity between the Judges of the County Court in Nassau and Suffolk Counties since there exists no rational basis for the salary classifications created by the statute. A comparison of the statute's discriminatory salary schedule and the materials submitted in support of the geographical distinctions fails to establish that the classifications drawn rest upon grounds rationally related to the advancement of a legitimate State interest where the data clearly demonstrate that the functions, duties and responsibilities of County Court Judges serving in the two counties are identical, that for all practical purposes their case loads are the same, that there is no meaningful difference in county-wide population, and that there are absent significant economic distinctions between the two contiguous counties upon which [***3] to rationally ground the salary disparity.

 

577 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Ackley v. Goodman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


131 A.D.2d 360; 516 N.Y.S.2d 667; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 47845



June 23, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff prospective juror appealed the order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), which denied his request for an injunction and declared the law that required the prospective juror to fill out a questionnaire constitutional. The prospective juror claimed the questionnaire was not related to his qualifications as a juror and violated his rights to liberty and privacy.


OVERVIEW: The prospective juror objected to various questions asked on the juror qualification form pursuant to N.Y. Jud. Law § 513. The prospective juror claimed that some of the questions were unrelated to his qualifications as a juror and violated his rights of liberty and privacy under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. The trial court denied the prospective juror's request for injunctive relief and found that N.Y. Jud. Law § 513 was constitutional. The court held that the prospective juror had no constitutionally protected privacy right to nondisclosure of the information requested on the juror qualification questionnaire. The court ruled that state legislation that had some effect on individual liberty or privacy could not be held unconstitutional simply because a court found it unnecessary, in whole or in part. The court found that § 513 required information in the juror questionnaire that was rationally related to the purpose of the statute. The court affirmed the trial court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the trial court that denied the prospective juror's request for injunctive relief and declared the law that required prospective jurors to complete the juror qualification questionnaire constitutional.

 

578 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Garner v. Gunn


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


131 A.D.2d 632; 516 N.Y.S.2d 718; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 48098



June 15, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner noncompetitive employee challenged an order from the Supreme Court of Kings County (New York), which dismissed the employee's N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding to compel respondent transit authority to conduct a N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 75 hearing.


OVERVIEW: A noncompetitive employee for the New York City Transit Authority, a division engineer, was discharged from his position after an informal hearing conducted pursuant to the New York City Transit Authority's manual entitled Managerial Disciplinary Practice and Procedure. Instead of proceeding pursuant to the manual, the employee brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding to compel respondent transit authority to conduct a N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 75 hearing. The trial court dismissed the proceeding. The court affirmed. The court held that a noncompetitive employee was not entitled to the protections of N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 75. The court reasoned that the must proceed to the post-determination hearing per the manual, and then, if he was not reinstated, he could bring an action in the courts. The court concluded that his assertion that he was discharged because he was a so-called whistle-blower did not entitle him to a hearing under N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 75 where he otherwise did not have the right. N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 75-b(3)(c).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the noncompetitive employee's proceeding to compel the transit authority to conduct a New York Civil Service Law hearing.

 

579 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Arnot-Ogden Memorial Hospital v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


129 A.D.2d 103; 516 N.Y.S.2d 972; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 43667



June 11, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment reversed, on the law, without costs, defendant's cross motion for summary judgment granted and it is declared that Public Health Law § 2807 (former [9]) (as added by L 1985, ch 807 § 4) is valid and has not been shown to be unconstitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Supreme Court at Special Term in Chemung County, New York, granted plaintiff hospital's motion for summary judgment and declared that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-a(9) was unconstitutional. Defendant commissioner of health appealed.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-a(9) provided for the imposition of an assessment of 4.5 percent on revenues for in-patient services to Medicare patients received by the hospital. The hospital contended that § 2807-a(9) discriminated against the federal government and those with whom it did business, in violation of the Supremacy clause, U.S. Const. art. VI, cl. 2, was preempted by federal Medicare legislation, and denied the hospital equal protection, U.S. Const. amend. XIV; N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11. The court concluded that §2807-a(9) withstood the hospital's constitutional challenge. The court held that the cross-subsidization prohibited by 42 U.S.C.S. § 1395x(v)(1)(A) referred to the allowance or disallowance of recoverable costs in the reimbursement rate-setting methodology of the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The court held that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-a(9) did not violate equal protection and did not run afoul of the Supremacy Clause because it did not fall directly upon the Federal Medicare program and did not affect the hospital's Medicare rates.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Academic and Moot Questions

1. In an action to declare invalid Public Health Law former § 2807-a (9), which provided for the imposition of an assessment of 4.5% on revenues for in-patient services to Medicare patients received by voluntary nonprofit hospitals such as plaintiff and by private proprietary hospitals in order to provide a pool of funding for reimbursement of hospitals who suffer inordinate losses in serving indigent and uninsured patients, known as "bad debt and charity care" (BDCC), an appeal from an order and judgment granting plaintiff's motion for summary [***2] judgment was not rendered moot by the repeal of the challenged section and the substitution of a new method of assessment to fund BDCC pools, since the award of counsel fees to plaintiff as the prevailing party remains contingent on the outcome of the appeal.

Health -- Medicare Reimbursement Rates -- Reallocation of Medicare Revenues for Bad Debt and Charity Care Purposes

2. Special Term's award of counsel fees to plaintiff and its declaration of the invalidity of Public Health Law former § 2807-a (9), which provided for the imposition of an assessment of 4.5% on revenues for in-patient services to Medicare patients received by voluntary nonprofit hospitals such as plaintiff and by private proprietary hospitals in order to provide a pool of funding for reimbursement of hospitals who suffer inordinate losses in serving indigent and uninsured patients, known as "bad debt and charity care" (BDCC), are reversed, and summary judgment is granted dismissing the complaint. Federal Medicare law (42 USC § 1395 et seq.) does not expressly preempt former section 2807-a (9); there is no preemption by implication of a congressional intent totally to take over the field of regulation [***3] of hospital in-patient costs and revenues to the exclusion of State regulation; plaintiff has failed to demonstrate that its payment of the assessment either rendered compliance with Medicare a physical impossibility or obstructed a congressional purpose to enhance Medicare rates for hospitals disproportionately treating low-income patients; and the Federal statutory prohibition against cross-subsidization of recoverable costs was not intended to limit what a hospital may do with its revenues from any source, or to prevent a State from taxing or regulating a hospital's use of such revenues. The assessment did not violate equal protection; the legislative history and valid State objective in funding BDCC losses afford a rational basis for the distinctions in the assessment of hospital revenues to which plaintiff's objection is addressed. The statute does not run afoul of the Supremacy Clause (US Const, art VI, cl 2) as a discriminatory tax against the United States or those with whom it does business nor does it discriminate against persons with whom the United States does business in its Medicare program. Finally, the assessment is rationally related to the legitimate State objective [***4] of encouraging and enabling hospitals to serve the State's medically indigent population and thus, does not offend the Due Process Clause.

 

580 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hart


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


131 A.D.2d 927; 516 N.Y.S.2d 522; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 48354



June 11, 1987 

 

581 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Yonkers Racing Corp. v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


131 A.D.2d 565; 516 N.Y.S.2d 283; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 48020



June 8, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, the State of New York and the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court, Westchester County (New York), which, upon granting the motion for summary judgment of plaintiff racetrack, declared unconstitutional the imposition of a certain tax imposed upon the racetrack by the Board, and which permanently enjoined further imposition of the tax upon the racetrack by the Board.


OVERVIEW: The racetrack, which was licensed to conduct harness racing with pari-mutuel betting, entered into a contract with the State of Connecticut for the live simulcast of races to Connecticut off-track betting facilities in exchange for a fee. As required by N.Y. Rac. Pari-Mut. Wag. & Breed. Law § 528(3), the racetrack submitted the contract to the Board for approval, which was granted on the condition that the racetrack pay a tax on the fee. The racetrack paid the tax under protest and filed the instant action. The trial court found for the racetrack, and the court affirmed, concluding that the Board lacked the power to impose the tax and had unconstitutionally usurped a legislative function by setting the tax rate. Under N.Y. Const. art III, § 1, the power to tax was vested exclusively in the legislature. Only after the legislature had levied a tax and set the rate could it delegate the power to assess and collect the tax to an administrative agency. Although N.Y. Rac. Pari-Mut. Wag. & Breed. Law § 318(4) authorized the tax, it gave no rate for it, and the Board was without authority to analogize to the tax rate in N.Y. Rac. Pari-Mut. Wag. & Breed. Law § 527 to set the rate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's grant of summary judgment to the racetrack and its imposition of a permanent injunction prohibiting the Board from imposing the tax on the racetrack.

 

582 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Knack


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


128 A.D.2d 307; 516 N.Y.S.2d 465; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 43558



June 1, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is affirmed, and the matter is remitted to the County Court, Nassau County, for further proceedings pursuant to CPL 460.50 (5).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of the Nassau County Court (New York), which denied his motion to suppress evidence of a prior misdemeanor conviction of driving while intoxicated in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2). Defendant was charged a second time under that section and, because the prior conviction enhanced the subsequent charge, the trial court had convicted him, upon his plea of guilty, of driving while intoxicated as a felony.


OVERVIEW: Because defendant had previously been convicted of a misdemeanor for driving while intoxicated under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(5), a second conviction would constitute a felony. To avoid a felony conviction, defendant moved to suppress evidence of his first conviction on the grounds that his guilty plea was constitutionally invalid. The trial court denied defendant's motion to suppress. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court noted that, in N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 400.20, 400.21, the legislature had provided a mechanism to challenge predicate felonies which might lead to enhanced sentences but that no similar mechanism had been provided for predicate misdemeanors. The court held, however, that due process did not require the courts to fashion such a remedy. The court also emphasized that defendant had a full panoply of remedies available to challenge his conviction on the misdemeanor charge, including the right to attack the constitutionality of his prior plea. The court held, however, that defendant was not denied due process simply because his arsenal did not include the additional remedy of a motion to suppress.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the county court and remitted the matter for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Driving while Intoxicated as Felony -- Motion to Suppress Evidence of Prior Misdemeanor Conviction

There is no authority to permit a court to suppress, on motion, evidence of a prior misdemeanor conviction for driving while intoxicated where that prior conviction enhances a subsequent charge to felony status. Where defendant chooses to plead guilty to the new offense, the People are absolved from having to prove any of the elements of the offense, including the element of the prior conviction, which defendant asserts suffered from an invalid allocution and ineffective assistance of counsel. Although the Legislature has provided a procedural mechanism by which to challenge predicate felonies which may lead to enhanced sentences, it has not seen fit to enact similar legislation in cases where a defendant is prosecuted [***2] for a felony because the degree of criminal conduct is enhanced by virtue of a prior misdemeanor conviction, even though the result may be a greater sentence. Having been given a full range of opportunities to attack the propriety of his prior conviction, including withdrawal of his plea, direct appeal, and motion to vacate the judgment, and having exercised some of them, defendant is not denied due process simply because his arsenal does not include the additional remedy of a motion to suppress, and there is no justification for fashioning a new remedy in that form.

 

583 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lake v. Binghamton Hous. Auth.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


130 A.D.2d 913; 516 N.Y.S.2d 324; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 46900



May 28, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner executive director brought an action against respondents, housing authority and its board of directors, to annul the resolution of the board that declared the executive director's five-year employment contract unconstitutional. The Supreme Court (New York) held the five-year employment term void. The executive director appealed.


OVERVIEW: After the supreme court held the five-year provision void, the board terminated the executive director's employment and failed to honor severance pay and other termination provisions in the employment contract. The executive director sought to resettle the prior order and the supreme court found the severance and termination provisions valid and ordered payment. The board appealed. The court affirmed both orders of the supreme court. The court found that although the executive director was not a public officer and no constitutional infirmity existed, the contractual provision for a minimum five-year tenure in office was void as against public policy because such provision could bind the board's successors with respect to the executive director's employment. The court found that because the first order only invalidated the term of the executive director's employment, the second order granting the severance and termination benefits was not inconsistent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order declaring the extended term of the executive director's employment void. The court affirmed the order declaring the severance and termination benefits valid and ordering payment thereunder.

 

584 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Cheeseman v. Bellacosa


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


130 A.D.2d 920; 516 N.Y.S.2d 513; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 46903



May 28, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, an Albany County family court judge, appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which granted summary judgment for defendants, the Comptroller and State of New York, and declared that N.Y. Jud. Law § 221-e did not unconstitutionally deprive Albany County family court judges of equal protection because they were paid less than county judges earned.


OVERVIEW: The Albany County family court judge asserted that there was no rational basis for salary disparity between a family court judge and a county judge in Albany County. The trial court declared that the statutory salary scheme was constitutionally valid. On appeal, the court found the two courts differed drastically in subject matter jurisdiction, procedures, and functions. Thus, judges of the two courts were not members of the same class for purposes of equal protection analysis. The Albany County family judge further argued that of all of the other counties state-wide where different persons held the positions of family court judge and county judge equated their salaries within the same county, except Albany County and one other county. The court held that family court judges in such counties were not a discrete class and there was no evidence of invidious discrimination against the Albany County judge. The Albany County judge's salary was the same as that of the judges in 18 of those other counties. The court concluded that the Equal Protection Clause was not offended and the classification was not wholly arbitrary or capricious.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that granted defendants' cross motion for summary judgment and dismissed the Albany County family judge's claim that his salary was unconstitutional.

 

585 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Edgehill


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


130 A.D.2d 761; 516 N.Y.S.2d 55; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 46780



May 26, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court of Kings County (New York) convicting him of murder in the first and second degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of murder in the first and second degree. The court ruled that defendant's contention that the trial court should not have accepted his plea of guilty without further inquiry into possible defenses was not preserved for appellate review and was, in any event, without merit. Further, the court held that although the state's death penalty statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 60.06, had been declared unconstitutional, the crime of murder in the first degree had not. Also, the court found that although N.Y. C.P.L. 220.10 (5)(e) prohibited a defendant from entering a plea of guilty to murder in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27, that provision was enacted as part of the legislative scheme to enact a mandatory death penalty, and since the death penalty had been declared unconstitutional, the rationale behind 220.10 (5)(e) was not applicable when the judgment against defendant was rendered.


OUTCOME: Judgment was affirmed where defendant's contention that the trial court should not have accepted his plea of guilty without further inquiry into possible defenses was not preserved for appellate review, and the crime of murder in the first degree was not rendered unconstitutional by the determination that the state death penalty statute was unconstitutional.

 

586 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Foley v. Nelson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


128 A.D.2d 92; 515 N.Y.S.2d 644; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 43528



May 14, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 363-c, petitioner employees appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Schenectady County (New York) for respondent employers, dismissing their petitions. The employees contended that their employers were required to pay their full salaries.


OVERVIEW:  N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 363-c permitted the employers to pay the employees a performance duty disability benefit. Previously, the employees were denied accidental disability retirement benefits and the employers were required to continue paying the employees their full compensation under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 207-c. Under the new law, the employees were retired, their salaries were terminated, and they received a benefit of about one-half of their salary. The employees contended that N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 363-c was unconstitutional. The court affirmed the judgment dismissing the petitions. The court held that the employers were not required to provide the difference between the duty disability retirement benefit and full compensation because benefits under the General Municipal Law were not contractual rights protected by the United States Constitution, and benefits provided under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law §207-c were part of the terms and conditions of employment that the Legislature could alter without infringing on the right guaranteed by N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7 not to diminish pension or retirement benefits.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment dismissing the employees' petition to require their employers to pay their full salaries.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Retirement and Pension Benefits -- Duty Disability Retirement

In petitioners' proceedings alleging that Retirement and Social Security Law § 363-c was unconstitutional as applied to them, the petitions were properly dismissed. Following the enactment of Retirement and Social Security Law § 363-c, which added a new performance duty disability retirement benefit providing a benefit of approximately one-half pay to police officers such as petitioners who had become disabled while on the job but who had not qualified for accidental disability retirement benefits, and the amendment of General Municipal Law § 207-c to provide that [***2] employers would be permitted to terminate salary payments to an employee who was granted duty disability retirement benefits, petitioners' employers successfully submitted applications on behalf of petitioners for duty disability retirement benefits and the employers were permitted to terminate their General Municipal Law § 207-c full salary payments. Benefits under the General Municipal Law are not contractual rights protected by the US Constitution, but are part of the terms and conditions of employment which can be altered by the Legislature without infringing on the right guaranteed by the NY Constitution (art V, § 7) not to diminish pension or retirement benefits; accordingly, the decision not to require municipalities to provide the difference between the duty disability retirement benefit and full compensation was not in violation of the NY or US Constitutions. Petitioners have failed to submit evidence that Retirement and Social Security Law § 363-c diminished or impaired any of their retirement benefits.

 

587 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Murphy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


128 A.D.2d 177; 515 N.Y.S.2d 895; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 43535



May 14, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Clinton County Court (New York) entered upon a verdict convicting him of murder in the second degree and sentencing him to an indeterminate term of nine years to life imprisonment. Defendant was 13 years old but tried as an adult pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.43, for the stabbing death of a neighbor child.


OVERVIEW: Defendant challenged his conviction, claiming the evidence was insufficient to support his conviction. Defendant had asked if the child could accompany him while he exercised his dogs and the child was later found dead from 33 stab wounds. Defendant's family members saw defendant return to the house with blood soaked clothing, and a knife found near the scene had defendant's father's initials on it. On appeal, the court found that the evidence that his clothing was "drenched" with blood and other evidence, when viewed in the light most favorable to the prosecution, was sufficient to permit a jury to infer defendant's guilt. The court noted, however, that it did not believe that the jury's inference of defendant's consciousness of guilt from the prosecution's failure to produce his clothing was correct because there was no showing that defendant participated in the loss or destruction of his clothing. The court also assigned error to the introduction of hearsay testimony. Despite these errors, the court found that reversal of defendant's conviction was not mandated since the errors were considered harmless. The evidence established defendant's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court judgment convicting defendant of second-degree murder because the evidence did not warrant a reversal of the conviction and defendant was not deprived of a fair trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Murder -- Circumstantial Evidence

1. In a circumstantial evidence case, the inference which may be drawn from the proven facts must exclude to a moral certainty every reasonable hypothesis except guilt; if that burden is met, however, a verdict is supportable even though the defense posits a version of the facts consistent with defendant's innocence, and the guilty verdict thus rendered indicates that the jury accepted the prosecution's competing version of the facts, requiring the evidence to be viewed on appeal in a light most favorable to the prosecution. Accordingly, the evidence in the instant case was legally sufficient to support defendant's conviction of murder of a 10-year-old boy where there was evidence that defendant was the last person to be seen with the victim alive, that defendant had blood on his clothing when seen after returning from a walk in the woods with the victim, that the victim's death was caused by stabbing, that a knife to which defendant had [***2] access was found less than 50 feet from the body, that the knife in question was capable of producing the wounds in the victim's body, that fibers from the victim's shirt were found on the knife, and that defendant's explanation regarding the victim's absence was contradicted by the victim's mother and sister who denied having called the boy home.

Crimes -- Murder -- Reasonable Doubt

2. In a homicide prosecution, defendant's explanation of the presence of blood on his clothes shortly after being seen with the stabbing victim did not raise a reasonable doubt as to his guilt as a matter of law where defendant contended that the blood came from a cut on his thumb which he received when he fell on broken glass in a hole in the woods and stated that the hole contained no water, but the State Police said the hole contained approximately one foot of water and no broken glass, since the jury could have reasonably rejected defendant's story.

Crimes -- Evidence -- Defendant's Blood-Stained Clothing

3. In a homicide prosecution in which it was conceded that defendant and the stabbing victim were seen walking into the woods and that defendant returned with blood on his [***3] clothing, it was not error to have permitted the prosecution to introduce the fact that the defendant's clothing had disappeared while in the exclusive possession of defendant and his family, since the failure to produce the clothing or to account for its nonproduction would have allowed the jury to draw a negative inference against the prosecution as a result of the missing evidence, and it would be unfair to permit such an inference when the clothing was at all times in the exclusive control of defendant or his family, and could not be found even when the family's premises were searched pursuant to a warrant.

Crimes -- Harmless and Prejudicial Error -- Hearsay

4. In a homicide prosecution, although it was error to have given a charge permitting the jury to draw an inference of defendant's consciousness of guilt from the failure to produce defendant's blood-stained clothing, since there was no proof of defendant's knowledge, authorization or participation in the loss or destruction of the clothing, and although it was also error to have permitted the hearsay testimony of a witness who contradicted the testimony of defendant's parents, since the witness's statements were [***4] an impermissible attempt by the prosecution to impeach its own witnesses, being neither contradictory statements signed by defendant's parents nor contradictory oral statements made by them under oath (see, CPL 60.35), reversal of defendant's murder conviction is not mandated since the errors were harmless in light of the overwhelming evidence of defendant's guilt. Moreover, although hearsay testimony of a State Trooper was also improperly admitted, the court specifically limited all the hearsay to the issue of credibility, and, therefore, the testimony was not so prejudicial as to constitute reversible error.

Crimes -- Instructions -- Waiver

5. In a homicide prosecution, where the court gave a charge that was intended to convey to the jury the general principles requested by defendant but contained a few obviously incorrect words, defendant was required to alert the court to the error to afford an opportunity to correct it, and defendant's failure to do so resulted in a waiver of the objection; accordingly, a question of law was not preserved for appellate review, and the court does not find the error such that reversal is required in the interest of justice.

 [***5] Crimes -- Disclosure -- Failure to Disclose Exculpatory Material

6. In a homicide prosecution, the failure to preserve the stomach contents of the victim more than 30 days after the police report was not the destruction of Brady material where defendant was unable to establish when the victim had last eaten or what he had to eat; lacking appropriate foundation, the destruction of the evidence cannot be considered the destruction of Brady material. Moreover, the fact that a spot of blood on the victim's shoe was neither the type of the victim nor defendant, but was that of the victim's mother, was not so critical as to create a reasonable doubt of defendant's guilt, as a matter of law, and the apparent rejection of its significance by the jury is accepted.

Crimes -- Trial -- Trial of Juvenile in Family or County Court

7. CPL 210.43 (1) (b) is not an unconstitutional vesting of unreviewable power in the District Attorney to decide whether a particular case should be tried in Family Court or in County Court, since the statute does not create a right to have a particular case removed to Family Court. The only right a defendant has in this regard is to be protected [***6] from arbitrariness and none has been shown.

 

588 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gholston


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


130 A.D.2d 843; 515 N.Y.S.2d 628; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 46854



May 14, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from his conviction in the County Court of Chemung County (New York) for attempted promoting of prison contraband in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was in possession of a razor blade while an inmate and was convicted of violating N.Y. Penal Law § 205.00 (3) for attempted promoting of prison contraband. Defendant raised several procedural issues. The court held that defendant waived his claim that the commissioner of correctional services failed to file the "Standards of Inmate Behavior" rule book when defendant pleaded guilty. The court held that N.Y. Penal law §§ 205.00(3) & 205.25 did not violate N.Y. Const. art. III, § 16 because the statute authorized the department of correctional services to define what was contraband. The court held that defendant was not denied the right to appear before the grand jury because he did not request an opportunity to appear as required by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.50(5)(a) and did not timely object as required by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 190.50(5)(c).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for attempted promoting of prison contraband in the first degree.

 

589 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Librie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


130 A.D.2d 593; 515 N.Y.S.2d 302; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 46602



May 11, 1987 

 

590 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Novoa


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


130 A.D.2d 595; 514 N.Y.S.2d 1018; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 46606



May 11, 1987 

 

591 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Sullivan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


130 A.D.2d 604; 515 N.Y.S.2d 531; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 46618



May 11, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a junkyard owner, appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court, Queens County (New York), which convicted him, upon his guilty plea, of criminal possession of stolen property in the second degree. Defendant, a junkyard employee, appealed by from a judgment of the same court, which convicted him, upon his guilty plea, of obstructing governmental administration in the second degree and attempted tampering with physical evidence.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were arrested following a police inspection of the junkyard pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5) and New York City, N.Y. Charter § 436. The police found various car parts, which were discovered to have been stolen. Defendant owner was arrested following the inspection and defendant employee two days later. However, defendant employee was arrested for actions he took on the date of inspection. Both defendants argued that the trial court erred by denying their motions to suppress evidence. The court reversed defendants' convictions. Subsequent to the convictions, a decision of the New York Court of Appeals had declared N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5) and New York City, N.Y. Charter § 436 to be unconstitutional. The court held that defendant owner's conviction was required to be reversed in light of that decision. The court held that it did not need to reach the issue of defendant employee's standing to challenge the propriety of the search upon constitutional grounds since the statute and administrative code provision underlying his arrest and conviction were declared unconstitutional and he did have the requisite standing in that regard.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgments, on the law, dismissed the indictments, and remitted the matters to the trial court for the purpose of entering orders in its discretion.

 

592 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Asian Americans for Equality v. Koch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


128 A.D.2d 99; 514 N.Y.S.2d 939; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 43530



May 5, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Order, Supreme Court, New York County, entered on September 26, 1985, modified, on the law and on the facts, to the extent of granting city defendants' motion to dismiss the first and second causes of action, and except as thus modified, otherwise affirmed, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, city, mayor, and zoning officials (city), challenged the order of the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), denying their motion to dismiss two causes of action brought by plaintiff residents seeking to maintain a class action constitutional challenge to zoning amendments. The city argued that under N.Y.C.P.L.R. § 3211, the lower court improperly denied the motion on these remaining claims.


OVERVIEW: Under the authority of the city, a planning commission studied rezoning of a section of the city. It recommended the creation of a special district for low-income groups (district) and the rehabilitation of older housing accommodations, and it proposed regulations to accomplish these goals. The regulations were adopted, and the residents filed suit challenging the zoning amendments that created the district. On the city's motion to dismiss, the lower court dismissed only one of the residents' claims. The city appealed. Although the residents' action was time barred under N.Y.C.P.L.R. 217, the court ruled on the merits. The court reversed the denial of the city's motion to dismiss the residents' remaining claims. The court held that the city adopted the zoning amendments under a well-considered plan. The plan was comprehensive, and the district included the needs of both low-income and middle income residents of the area. The plan was properly adopted. The residents were seeking a change in the legislation, and the court would not substitute its judgment for that of the legislature in a zoning matter.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the denial by the lower court of the city's motion to dismiss the remainder of the residents' claims.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Failure to Provide for Low-Income Housing

In an action challenging a New York City zoning amendment, which created a special zoning district in the city's Chinatown area, on the grounds that the amendment was not the product of a "well-considered plan", that it failed to provide for the needs of low-income people and constituted exclusionary zoning, and that a special permit to construct a high-rise residential building and community facility in the district was illegally granted, Special Term erred in denying the city's motion to dismiss the first and [***2] second causes of action dealing with the creation of the district; the third cause of action concerning the grant of the special permit is moot in light of its invalidation by the Court of Appeals on environmental grounds. Not only were public hearings held at every stage of the process leading to the creation of the special district, but the zoning amendments were the product of a well-considered plan that took many factors into consideration including the needs of the area's low-income residents. Moreover, in denying the city's motion to dismiss, Special Term improperly relied on the holdings of the New Jersey Supreme Court in the Mount Laurel cases (see, 67 NJ 151, 336 A2d 713; 92 NJ 158, 456 A2d 390) which have been specifically rejected at the appellate level in New York; not only are the Mount Laurel holdings based solely upon the Constitution of New Jersey and are essentially legislative judgments, but not by the widest stretch of the imagination could the fact pattern in Mount Laurel, involving an area larger than four counties, be applicable to the district in question, which comprises between 14 and 20 city blocks.

 

593 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Corey B.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


129 A.D.2d 796; 514 N.Y.S.2d 788; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 45485



April 27, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a juvenile, challenged the disposition by the Family Court, Queens County (New York), finding defendant guilty of an act which, if committed by an adult, would have constituted the crime of jostling under N.Y. Penal Law § 165.25(1) and placing defendant with the youth division.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was observed by a police officer standing directly behind a woman on a rush hour train with his hand over the woman's open handbag. Defendant argued that § 165.25(1) was unconstitutionally overbroad and vague. On appeal, the court held that § 165.25(1) was not unconstitutionally vague as its constitutionality had been determined by a New York Court of Appeals. The court also held that § 165.25(1) was not unconstitutionally overbroad as applied to defendant. The court determined that the evidence was sufficient to establish defendant's guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. The court found that defendant lacked standing to challenge § 165.25(1) on the ground that it may have been unconstitutionally applied to others.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the family court's judgment.

 

594 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Argano v. Williston Park


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


129 A.D.2d 666; 514 N.Y.S.2d 425; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 45350



April 20, 1987 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff owner appealed a decision of the Supreme Court, Nassau County (New York), which declared that defendant village had the power to enact and enforce its zoning ordinances and that Laws of 1952, ch. 506, which authorized the village's board of trustee to enact ordinances, was valid and constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The owner constructed an extension to her residence and was informed by the village's attorney that the extension was built without the necessary permit. The Board of Zoning Appeals denied her permit for a variance, and she brought an action in the trial court for declaration that the village did not have the power to enact and enforce building zoning ordinances affecting property within its borders. The trial court declared that the village had the power to enact and enforce its zoning ordinances and that ch. 506 was valid and constitutional. The owner appealed, and the court concluded that the owner did not present sufficient proof to rebut the strong presumption of constitutionality of the statute beyond a reasonable doubt. The court concluded that ch. 506 was enacted long after the village was incorporated and did not concern or affect its existing charter. The court held that ch. 506 was a valid curative statute that restored the village's zoning power and superseded the County Government Law of Nassau County, L. ch. 879, § 1607 (1936).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

595 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Two Associates v. Brown


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, First Department


127 A.D.2d 173; 513 N.Y.S.2d 966; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 41498



April 9, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Order and judgment (one paper), Supreme Court, New York County, entered on May 27, 1986, unanimously reversed, on the law, defendant's cross motion for summary judgment denied in its entirety, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment for possession granted, and Emergency Operational Bulletin No. 85-1 of the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal declared invalid, without costs and without disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlord appealed a summary judgment entered by the Supreme Court, New York County, New York, in favor of defendant tenant in the landlord's action for first, a declaratory judgment that the tenant's right to occupy an apartment expired on the death of the tenant of record, and second, a judgment ejecting the tenant.


OVERVIEW: A landlord brought an action for a declaratory judgment that a tenant's right to occupy an apartment expired upon the death of his roommate, the tenant of record. The landlord's summary judgment motion was granted. The tenant then filed a motion for renewal of his summary judgment motion, asserting that a subsequent state agency emergency bulletin entitled him to a rent-stabilized renewal lease. The lower court recalled its prior decision and awarded the tenant the lease. On appeal, the court reversed. Administrative agencies could only promulgate rules to further the implementation of the law as it existed. The bulletin's "rules" were designed to extend the protection of the New York City Rent Stabilization Law to parties the legislature never intended to protect. Because the emergency bulletin was inoperative, the rule applied that no family member not named on a rent-stabilized lease was entitled to a renewal lease after the named tenant vacated the apartment. The tenant and similarly situated "gay life partners" could not claim that they were being denied equal protection of the law when the law failed to protect any family members who were not named in the lease as tenants.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the summary judgment in favor of a tenant in a landlord's action for a declaratory judgment and for a judgment ejecting the tenant. The landlord's motion for summary judgment for possession was granted, and an emergency operational bulletin issued by a state housing agency was declared invalid.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Entitlement to Renewal Lease -- Occupation of Apartment by Deceased Tenant's "Gay Life Partner"

Summary judgment is granted in favor of plaintiff landlord [***2] in his action seeking possession of the rent-stabilized apartment in which defendant resides, on the ground that he is not the tenant of record and that the lease of the tenant of record, who is deceased, has expired. Defendant, who had lived in the apartment together with the tenant of record, is not entitled to continued occupancy of the apartment with the right to a new lease in his name by virtue of his status as a surviving "gay life partner". Rights to a rent-stabilized apartment are governed solely by statute ( Sullivan v Brevard Assocs., 66 NY2d 489) and the Rent Stabilization Law makes no provision for a continued right of occupancy under such circumstances but provides that a renewal lease need be offered only to a "tenant". Emergency Operational Bulletin No. 85-1 of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), issued in response to the decision in Sullivan v Brevard Assocs., which requires a landlord to offer a renewal lease to a rent-stabilized tenant and his or her immediate family, requires that a landlord of rent-stabilized premises must offer the right to first refusal of a new lease to a nonimmediate family member, and provides that a new lease may [***3] be offered to an occupant of a rent-stabilized housing accommodation other than the tenant, immediate family, or nonimmediate family member if the "tenant" is no longer in occupancy, was not validly promulgated; under the Rent Stabilization Law only the named tenant as defined in the lease is entitled to a renewal lease, and no such right extends to a family member who has resided in the apartment together with the named tenant. The effect of the bulletin is to create a new law entitling a new broad class of people to a lease renewal and DHCR may not so act in the absence of a legislative amendment of the Rent Stabilization Law or without properly moving to amend the Rent Stabilization Code as specified in the law. The emergency bulletin cannot be deemed an effective amendment to the Rent Stabilization Code since the required procedures were not followed; moreover, the emergency bulletin was not promulgated in accordance with the procedures for rule making set forth in the State Administrative Procedure Act.

 

596 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Cherry v. Koch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


126 A.D.2d 346; 514 N.Y.S.2d 30; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 41241



April 6, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the defendant Holtzman's cross appeal is dismissed; and it is further,

Ordered that the order and judgment is modified, on the law, by deleting the provision thereof which addressed the merits of the constitutional challenge, and as so modified, the order and judgment is affirmed; and it is further,

Ordered that the defendant Holtzman is awarded one bill of costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appeal from an order of the Supreme Court of Kings County (New York) granting defendants' motions to dismiss plaintiffs' amended complaint, denying plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that plaintiffs had standing to sue, and declaring Penal Law §§ 230.00, and 230.03 constitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs sought a judgment declaring Penal Law §§ 230.00 and 230.03 unconstitutional as applied to them insofar as the laws declared private commercial sex between consenting adults to be illegal. The statutes prohibited prostitution and the patronizing of prostitutes, respectively. One of the plaintiffs claimed to be a prostitute, and the other claimed to be a patron of prostitutes. The supreme court held that plaintiffs had not presented a justiciable issue, and therefore, the court did not reach the issue of the statutes' constitutionality. At the very best, plaintiffs alleged a hypothetical future controversy that was not ripe for adjudication. Plaintiffs simply found the statutes personally offensive and were upset that the laws criminalized activities that they engaged in. Such was insufficient to confer standing upon plaintiffs to challenge the constitutionality of the laws.


OUTCOME: The case was not justiciable because plaintiffs lacked standing to seek a judgment declaring Penal Law §§ 230.00 and 230.03 unconstitutional as applied to them insofar as the laws declared private commercial sex between consenting adults to be illegal.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statutes Prohibiting Prostitution and Patronizing of Prostitutes -- Justiciable Controversy -- Standing

1. In an action for a judgment declaring Penal Law §§ 230.00 and 230.03 unconstitutional as applied to plaintiffs, a prostitute and a patron of prostitutes, insofar [***2] as the statutes declare illegal private commercial sex between consenting adults, plaintiffs have not presented a justiciable controversy, and so much of an order and judgment as granted defendants' motions to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action and denied plaintiffs' cross motion for summary judgment is affirmed. Plaintiffs have not alleged that they have been arrested or prosecuted or threatened with prosecution in connection with their prostitution activities, nor do they assert any facts from which it could rationally be inferred that they have a reasonable fear of being threatened with arrest or prosecution in the future, or that the criminalization of prostitution has inhibited or deterred them from engaging in acts of prostitution; the complaint does not set forth any real and substantial controversy between plaintiffs and defendants. The likelihood of prosecution is remote, and the only injury plaintiffs set forth is that they find the statutes personally offensive and are upset that these laws criminalize activities in which they allegedly engage, which is insufficient to confer standing upon them to challenge the constitutionality of the statutes.

 [***3] Appeal -- Parties Aggrieved -- Matter Reviewable

2.
