In an action for a judgment declaring Penal Law §§ 230.00 and 230.03 unconstitutional as applied to plaintiffs insofar as those sections declare illegal private commercial sex between consenting adults, a cross appeal by defendant District Attorney from so much of an order and judgment as held that plaintiffs, a prostitute and a patron of prostitutes, had standing to bring the action is dismissed because defendant is not aggrieved by Special Term's order, which granted her complete relief by dismissing the complaint. However, defendant may raise the question of plaintiffs' standing to sue in support of her argument in favor of affirmance of the order and judgment appealed from.

Appeal -- Law of the Case

3. The doctrine of the law of the case is applicable only between courts of coordinate jurisdiction and although the Supreme Court cannot reconsider a question if another Supreme Court Justice has previously decided the issue, the Appellate Division is not so barred. Accordingly, in an action for a judgment declaring Penal Law §§ 230.00 and 230.03 unconstitutional, wherein the Supreme Court dismissed the complaint [***4] for failure to state a cause of action, following which plaintiffs served an amended verified complaint and a different Supreme Court Justice granted defendants' motions to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action, stating that it was precluded from reconsidering the prior determination that plaintiffs had standing to bring the suit or that there was a justiciable controversy, so much of the order and judgment as declared the statutes constitutional is deleted. In view of the Appellate Division's determination that plaintiffs have failed to state a cause of action for declaratory relief since the case is not justiciable, the merits of plaintiffs' constitutional claims will not be addressed, and the Supreme Court, having once determined that plaintiffs have not presented the necessary requirements for a declaratory judgment action, should have similarly declined to have reached the merits.

 

597 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dreyfus Special Income Fund, Inc. v. New York State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department


126 A.D.2d 368; 514 N.Y.S.2d 130; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 41245



April 2, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent, New York State Tax Commission (commission), appealed a decision for petitioner corporate taxpayer by the Supreme Court in Albany County (New York) in an action for a refund of a franchise tax assessment.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer sought a refund of its franchise tax on the grounds that its income should have been calculated based on the taxable income reported to the internal revenue service. The commission claimed that the tax should have been computed on the basis of the taxpayer's entire net income as an investment company. The court affirmed the lower court's decision for the taxpayer, which had reversed the commission's decision, because "taxable income" in I.R.C. § 63 was presumptively to be applied to compute "entire net income" under N.Y. Tax Law § 208(9). Because I.R.C. § 852(b)(2) was used to calculate the federal taxable income and federal law controlled what was "entire net income," the commission's "net income" figure was to be the same as the federal amount. Thus, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 20, § 3.11 improperly defined federal "taxable income." The legislative silence and the regulation's years of existence did not imply that the legislature sanctioned the commission's interpretation. The legislative amendments only clarified N.Y. Tax Law § 208(9)(b)(1). Thus, the taxpayer was entitled to deduct dividends paid to its shareholders in the computation of its entire net income.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision for the taxpayer and against the commission in the action for a refund of a franchise tax assessment.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Computation of "Entire Net Income"

Supreme Court properly declared 20 NYCRR former 3.11 invalid as contrary to Tax Law § 208 (9) in that regulated investment companies were entitled to deduct dividends paid to their shareholders in computing their entire net income for taxable years beginning prior to January 1, 1980. Respondent State Tax Commission erred in applying the definition of "taxable income" contained in Internal Revenue Code § 63 (26 USC); Tax Law § 208 (9) provides that the figure to be used for computing "entire net income" shall be presumably the same as the "taxable income" that the taxpayer is required to report to the Federal Government, and since the [***2] Federal Government would arrive at petitioner investment company's taxable income by way of Internal Revenue Code § 852 (b) (2) and Federal law controls for the purpose of defining "entire net income" and is authorized by statute (Tax Law § 208 [9]), respondent's regulation is incorrect. The addition of Tax Law § 209 (7) in 1979 should not be perceived as a sanction of the agency's administrative interpretation. The franchise tax is not an income tax and thus, Tax Law § 208 (9) is not unconstitutional because enacted at a time when the Legislature was constitutionally prohibited from fixing taxes by references to any other law. Dividends were intended to be included in investment company net income. Petitioner's "taxable income" was properly determined in the first instance, since the deduction for dividends paid under Internal Revenue Code § 852 (b) (2) (D) is to be shown as an "other deduction" on the line of the appropriate form, which is deductible in arriving at "taxable income".

 

598 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lang v. Cohalan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


127 A.D.2d 17; 513 N.Y.S.2d 726; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 41329



March 30, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order is modified, on the law, by deleting the third decretal paragraph thereof, and substituting therefor a provision granting the defendants' applications for summary judgment in their entireties and declaring that Tax Law § 1210-A and Suffolk County Resolution No. 823 of 1984 are constitutional and represent a valid exercise of the State's taxing power. As so modified, the order is affirmed, with one bill of costs to the defendants appearing separately and filing separate briefs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, town and officials, filed suit against defendants, state and county, seeking a judgment declaring N.Y. Tax Law § 1210-A and Suffolk County, N.Y. Res. 823 (1984) unconstitutional. Subsequently, the Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York) entered an order denying plaintiffs' cross-motion for a preliminary injunction and summary judgment, dismissing the complaint in part and denying summary judgment motions by the state and county.


OVERVIEW: In their action, plaintiffs argued § 1210-A and Res. 823 impermissibly imposed a general, countywide tax for the benefit of a special district; constituted a denial of equal protection of the law; were impermissibly vague and uncertain; and were unlawfully enacted. In addressing the parties' various motions, the court dismissed the complaint insofar as it was asserted by the municipal plaintiffs due to their lack of standing, but refused to grant summary judgment to either party because it was not convinced there were no defenses to the causes of action, and the state and county's applications for summary judgment were nothing more than an afterthought. Plaintiffs appealed, and the county and state cross appealed. The court held summary judgment was appropriate, in addition to the dismissal ordered by the trial court, because N.Y. Tax Law § 1210-A did not constitute an unconstitutional delegation of the state's taxing power. In addition, the court held plaintiffs did not meet their burden of establishing the imposition of the additional sales and compensating-use tax was palpably arbitrary or amounted to invidious discrimination.


OUTCOME: The court ordered modification of the trial court's order by substituting a provision granting the motions for summary judgment by plaintiffs and declaring the tax statute and resolution were constitutional and represented a valid exercise of the state's taxing power. As so modified, the court affirmed the trial court's order.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute Increasing Sales Tax in Suffolk County

Tax Law § 1210-A, which authorized Suffolk County to adopt a local law or resolution imposing an additional one quarter of 1% countywide sales tax and compensating use tax for [***2] a five-year period in order to avert the financial difficulties suffered by the Southwest Sewer District, is constitutional, as is the resolution imposing the increased sales and compensating use tax, Suffolk County Resolution No. 823 of 1984. The legislative pronouncement that the financial difficulties of said sewer district and of other sewer districts are a countywide concern and that the stabilization of assessments and the continued operation of those districts would benefit the county as a whole is not palpably unjust, and there is thus no unconstitutional delegation of the State's taxing power. The burden of establishing that the imposition of this additional sales and compensating use tax upon only Suffolk County is palpably arbitrary or amounts to invidious discrimination has not been met; there is a rational basis for treating the residents of Suffolk County differently from the residents of Nassau County for the purposes of this statute. Any incidental benefit which may accrue to the owners of real property located in the subject sewer district does not invalidate the enactments. Furthermore, pursuant to Tax Law § 1210-A (b), any action taken by the County Executive [***3] with regard to the determination of the amounts necessary to stabilize assessments in a given sewer district must first be approved by the county legislature and thus the State Legislature has not improperly delegated its power to assess and collect taxes without setting proper guidelines. Finally, there is no violation of NY Constitution, article IX, § 1 (h) (1) and Municipal Home Rule Law § 33-a.

 

599 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Henry v. Alquist


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


127 A.D.2d 60; 513 N.Y.S.2d 730; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 41342



March 30, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the judgment is reversed, on the law, with costs, the petition is granted, and it is declared that the respondent's vehicle, a 1978 Camaro, New York license plate number 7215 AHR, is forfeited to the petitioner pursuant to Public Health Law § 3388, and title to that vehicle is vested in the petitioner.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner district attorney appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court, Suffolk County (New York), entered in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 3388 for forfeiture of a car used in drug trafficking. The trial court denied the petition and directed the vehicle returned to respondent owner, stating that a forfeiture would have been excessive in nature.


OVERVIEW: The owner pled guilty to attempted criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, a class C felony, N.Y. Penal Law §§ 110.00, 110.05, 220.16. At the trial, the district attorney presented evidence regarding three purchases of cocaine by an undercover police officer from the owner. Each time, she drove the car to a predetermined location. The owner contended, inter alia, that her boyfriend was the seller. At the conclusion of this testimony, the trial court granted the district attorney's motion for a directed verdict, and then reopened the matter, hearing testimony from the owner's probation officer, and arguments on whether a forfeiture would have constituted an unreasonable and excessive penalty for the crime to which the owner pled guilty. Reversing the decision, the court explained that the trial court did not have any statutory authority, pursuant to § 3388, to dismiss the petition and direct the return of the vehicle. The court added that, although a forfeiture might have been unconstitutional as excessive punishment, the facts of the case demonstrated that it was not in this instance.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision dismissing the district attorney's petition for forfeiture of the owner's car after she used it in drug trafficking, granted the petition, and declared that the vehicle was forfeited with title vested in the district attorney.


HEADNOTES

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Drug Sale

A judgment which, in a proceeding pursuant to Public Health Law § 3388 for forfeiture of an automobile used in drug trafficking, dismissed the petition and directed that the vehicle be returned to respondent, who was convicted of attempted criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, a class C felony, is reversed. The trial court does not have the right to decline a forfeiture of the respondent's vehicle pursuant to Public Health Law § 3388 and to direct [***2] the return of the vehicle despite the fact that the District Attorney had established that the vehicle had been used in violation of the statute, which section provides that it shall be unlawful to transport, carry or convey any controlled substance in, upon, or by means of any vehicle, and that any vehicle so used shall be seized and forfeited. The language of the statute is mandatory and does not provide for the court's exercise of its discretion except where a person who has an interest in the vehicle and who did not have knowledge of the forfeiture proceeding petitions for return of the forfeited property and establishes one of the statutory affirmative defenses. To the extent that the trial court's determination may be interpreted as a holding that the forfeiture sanction would violate the State and Federal constitutional proscriptions against cruel and unusual punishment (see, NY Const, art I, § 5; US Const 8th Amend), it is in error.

 

600 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


J.K.S.P. Restaurant, Inc. v. County of Nassau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department


127 A.D.2d 121; 513 N.Y.S.2d 716; 1987 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 41351; 3 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. 2d (Callaghan) 825



March 30, 1987 



DISPOSITION: Ordered that the order of the Supreme Court, Nassau County, dated June 3, 1985, is affirmed insofar as appealed from, without costs or disbursements.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff seller sued defendant county and corporation, seeking repossession of collateral, foreclosure, damages for conversion, and injunctive relief. The Supreme Court of New York at Special Term, Nassau County, denied a motion by the county for summary judgment, denied a motion by the corporation to cancel the notice of pendency filed against the property, and denied a motion by the seller for summary judgment. The parties filed cross-appeals.


OVERVIEW: The case involved a dispute over the validity of the seller's interest in a prefabricated diner, which was assembled onsite. The overriding issue raised on appeal was whether the diner on the property was to be treated as realty or personalty. The court held that the diner was a trade fixture and thus was personalty, because the diner was annexed to the leased realty by the seller and was intended to be used solely for the seller's business and trade and was built for a particular use. The court held, however, that a triable issue of fact existed as to whether removal would materially injure the property. Further, the court held that the county and the corporation did not acquire title to the diner by purchase of a tax deed at a tax sale. In addition, the court held that the seller's reliance on U.C.C. § 9-313, seeking to recover the diner as a fixture, was misplaced since the diner was a trade fixture and was not within the purport of the statute. The court held that before the seller could pursue its remedies as a secured creditor under U.C.C. art. 9, the trier of the facts must determine whether the diner was "movable" under U.C.C. 9-105(1)(h).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.


HEADNOTES

Fixtures -- Trade Fixtures

In plaintiff's action for repossession of a diner it had sold and related relief, brought after its successor defaulted in payments due under the security agreement it had entered into with plaintiff, a motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint by the county which had purchased a tax lien on the property upon which the diner was located was properly denied, as was plaintiff's motion for summary judgment seeking possession [***2] of the diner and foreclosure on its security interest in the diner. When the county took title to the property, plaintiff lost its right to remove the diner without regard to potential material damage to the freehold since the county was not bound by the terms of the lease between the former owner of the subject property and plaintiff, which provided that plaintiff had the right to remove the diner without regard to possible material injury to the freehold; nevertheless, since the diner remained the personalty of plaintiff due to its status as a trade fixture, notwithstanding termination of the lease, plaintiff had a right to remove the diner provided that removal would not materially damage the freehold, and there is a triable issue of fact as to whether removal would materially injure the property. Plaintiff may not recover the diner as a fixture pursuant to UCC 9-313, since the diner is a trade fixture and is not within the purport of the statute. Further, plaintiff may have a perfected security interest in the diner and may exercise its rights under the UCC if the trier of facts determines that the diner is "movable" under UCC 9-105 (1) (h). The facts that a building permit [***3] was obtained to construct the diner, that a certificate of occupancy was issued after completion of the construction, and that the diner was assessed by the county for real estate tax purposes does not mean that the diner constitutes realty. The county could not obtain ownership by foreclosing against the realty and could not, therefore, transfer title to the diner to purchasers of a tax deed from the county. Furthermore, since plaintiff's UCC-1 financing statement was duly recorded, the county's successor purchased the tax deed with full knowledge of plaintiff's prior lien on the diner. Finally, Special Term properly denied a motion by the current owner of the property, the county's successor, to cancel the notice of pendency filed by plaintiff; although the diner may be personalty and ultimately may be removed by plaintiff, at this stage of the litigation it cannot be stated that this action would not affect the possession, use or enjoyment of the real property ( CPLR 6501).
